Ἀαρών: Aaron, pr. name, indecl., the brother of Moses (Exod. 4:14), Lk. 1:15; Acts 7:40; Heb. 5:4; 7:11; 9:4*
Ἀβαδδών: Abaddon, pr. name, indecl., alternate spelling: Ἀββαδών, the angel who rules in hell, Rev. 9:11*
ἀβαρής: literally: weightless; figuratively: not burdensome, 2 Cor. 11:9*
Ἅβελ: Abel, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 23:35; Lk. 11:51; Heb. 11:4; 12:24
Ἀβιά: Abiajah, pr. name, indecl. Hebrew is Abijah. (1) the son of Rehoboam (1 Chr. 3:10) Mt. 1:7; (2) the division of priests to which Zechariah belonged (1 Chr. 24:10) Lk. 1:5*
Ἀβιληνή: Abilene, a district of the Syrian Decapolis; from Abila, the chief town, Lk. 3:1*
ἄβυσσος: bottomless; place of the dead, Lk. 8:31; Rom. 10:7
ἀγαθοεργέω: to do good, confer benefits, Acts 14:17; 1 Tim. 6:18*
ἀγαθοποιέω: to do good, do well; to do what is morally correct (1 Pet. 2:15, 20)
ἀγαθοποιός: doing good or right; subst., a well-doer, 1 Pet. 2:14*
ἀγαθωσύνη: goodness, virtue, beneficence, Rom. 5:14; Eph. 5:9; 2 Thess. 1:11; generosity, Gal. 5:22*
ἀγαλλιάω: to celebrate, praise; usually in the middle in the NT (ἀγαλλιάομαι) to exult, rejoice exceedingly; to desire ardently, Jn. 8:56
ἀγανακτέω: to be pained; to be angry, vexed, indignant; to manifest indignation, Mk. 14:4; Lk. 13:14
ἀγαπάω: to love, value, esteem, feel or manifest generous concern for, be faithful towards; to delight in, to set store upon, Rev. 12:11
ἀγάπη: love, generosity, kindly concern, devotedness; pl. love-feasts, Jude 12
ἀγγαρεύω: to press, or compel another to go somewhere, or carry some burden, Mt. 5:41; 27:32; Mk. 15:21*
ἀγγελία: a messsage, doctrine, or precept, delivered in the name of any one; command, 1 Jn. 1:5; 3:11*
ἀγενεαλόγητος: not included in a genealogy; independent of genealogy, Heb. 7:3*
ἀγενής: lit., without kin; fig., base, low, insignificant, 1 Cor. 1:28*
ἁγιάζω: to separate, consecrate; cleanse, purify, sanctify; regard or reverence as holy
ἅγιος: separate from common condition and use; dedicated. Lk. 2:23; hallowed; used of things, τὰ ἅγια, the sanctuary; and of persons, saints, e.g., members of the first Christian communities; pure, righteous, ceremonially or morally; holy
ἁγιωσύνη: sanctification, sanctity, holiness, Rom. 1:4; 2 Cor. 7:1; 1 Thess. 3:13*
ἁγνίζω: to purify; to purify morally, reform, to live like one under a vow of abstinence, as the Nazarites
ἀγνοέω: to be ignorant; not to understand; sin through ignorance
ἀγορά: a place of public concourse, forum, market-place; things said in the market, provision
ἀγοράζω: to buy; redeem, acquire by a ransom or price paid
ἀγοραῖος: one who visits the forum; a lounger, one who idles away his time in public places, a low fellow, Acts 17:5; pertaining to the forum, judicial; ἀγόραιοι, court days, Acts 19:38*
ἄγρα: a catching, thing taken, draught of fishes, Lk. 5:4, 9*
ἀγραυλέω: to remain in the open air, to live outside, especially by night, Lk. 2:8*
ἀγρεύω: to take in hunting, catch, Mk. 12:13*
ἄγριος: belonging to the field, wild; fierce, raging, Mt. 3:4; Mk. 1:6; Jude 13*
ἀγρός: a field, especially a cultivated field; pl. the country; lands, farms, villages
ἀγρυπνέω: to be awake, watch; to be watchful, vigilant
ἄγω: to lead. bring; lead away, drive off, as a booty of cattle; conduct, accompany; lead out, produce; conduct with force, drag, hurry away; guide, incite, entice; convey one’s self, go, go away; pass or spend as time; celebrate
ἀγωγή: guidance, mode of instruction, discipline, course of life, 2 Tim. 3:10*
ἀγών: place of contest, race-course, stadium; a contest, strife, contention; peril, toil
ἀγωνία: contest, violent struggle; agony, anguish, Lk. 22:44*
ἀγωνίζομαι: to be a combatant in the public games; to contend, fight, strive earnestly
ἀδελφή: a sister; near kinswoman, or female relative, a female member of the Christian community
ἀδελφός: a brother, near kinsman or relative; one of the same nation or nature; one of equal rank and dignity; an associate, a member of the Christian community
ἀδελφότης: brotherhood, the body of the Christian brotherhood, 1 Pet. 2:17; 5:9*
ἄδηλος: not apparent or obvious; uncertain, not distinct, Lk. 11:44; 1 Cor. 14:8*
ἀδημονέω: to be depressed or dejected, full of anguish or sorrow, Mt. 26:37; Mk. 14:33; Phil. 2:26*
ᾅδης: the invisible abode or mansion of the dead; the place of punishment, hell; the lowest place or condition, Mt. 11:23; Lk. 10:15
ἀδιαλείπτως: unceasingly, by an unvarying practice, Rom. 1:9; 1 Thess. 1:2; 2:13; 5:17*
ἀδικέω: to act unjustly; wrong; injure; violate a law
ἀδίκημα: an act of injustice, crime, Acts 18:14; 24:20; Rev. 18:5*
ἄδικος: unjust, unrighteous, iniquitous, vicious; deceitful, fallacious
ἀδόκιμος: unable to stand test, rejected, refuse, worthless
Ἀδραμυττηνός: of Adramyttium, a Greek city on the coast of Aeolia, in Asia Minor, Acts 27:2*
ἀδυνατέω: not to be able; to be impossible, Mt. 17:20; Lk. 1:37*
ἀετός: an eagle, Rev. 12:14; or vulture, Lk. 17:37
ἄζυμος: unleavened; τὰ ἄζυμα, the feast of unleavened bread; met. pure from foreign matter, unadulterated, genuine; τὸ ἄζυμον, genuineness, 1 Cor. 5:7, 8
Ἄζωτος: Azotus, Ashdod, a seaport in Palestine, Acts 8:40*. See PhotoGuide.
ἄθεος: an atheist; godless, estranged from the knowledge and worship of the true God, Eph. 2:12*
ἀθετέω: pr. to displace, set aside; to abrogate, annul, violate, swerve from; reject, condemn
Ἀθηναῖος: Athenian, inhabiting or belonging to Athens, Acts 17:21, 22*
ἀθλέω: to strive, contend, be a champion in the public games, 2 Tim. 2:5*
ἀθυμέω: to be discouraged, lose heart, Col. 3:21*
αἱμα: blood; of the color of blood; bloodshed; blood-guiltiness; natural descent
αἱματεκχυσία: an effusion or shedding of blood, Heb. 9:22*
αἱμορροέω: to have a flow of blood, Mt. 9:20*
αἴνιγμα: an enigma, riddle, any thing obscurely expressed or intimated, 1 Cor. 13:12*
Αἰνών: Enon, pr. name, indecl., where Jn. was baptizing, Jn. 3:23*. See PhotoGuide.
αἱρέω: some list as deponent αἱρέομαι, to take; mid. to choose
αἵρεσις: strictly, a choice or option; hence, a religious sect, faction; by implication, discord, contention
αἱρετίζω: to choose, choose with delight or love, Mt. 12:18*
αἱρετικός: one who creates or fosters factions, Tit. 3:10*
αἴρω: to take up, lift, raise; bear, carry; take away, remove; destroy, kill
αἰσθητήριον: an organ of perception; internal sense, Heb. 5:14*
αἰσχροκερδής: eager for dishonorable gain, greedy, 1 Tim. 3:8; Tit. 1:7*
αἰσχροκερδῶς: for the sake of base gain, greedily, 1 Pet. 5:2*
αἰσχρολογία: vile or obscene language, foul talk, Col. 3:8*
αἰσχρός: strictly, deformed, opposed to καλός; met. shameful, indecent, dishonorable, vile, 1 Cor. 11:6; 14:35; Eph. 5:12; Tit. 1:11*
αἰσχύνη: shame, disgrace; cause of shame, dishonorable conduct
αἰτέω: to ask, request; demand; desire, Acts 7:46
αἴτημα: a thing asked or sought for; petition, request, Lk. 23:24; Phil. 4:6; 1 Jn. 5:15*
αἰτία: cause, motive, incitement; accusation, crime, case
αἴτιος: causative; αἴτιος, an author or causer, Heb. 5:9; τὸ αἴτιον, equivalent to αἰτία
αἰχμαλωσία: captivity, state of captivity; captive multitude, Eph. 4:8; Rev. 13:10*
αἰχμαλωτεύω: to lead captive; met. to captivate, Eph. 4:8*
αἰχμαλωτίζω: to lead captive; by impl. to subject, Lk. 21:24; Rom. 7:23; 2 Cor. 10:5; 2 Tim. 3:6*
αἰών: pr. a period of time of significant character; life; an era; an age: hence, a state of things marking an age or era; the present order of nature; the natural condition of man, the world; ὁ αἰών, illimitable duration, eternity; as also, οἱ αἰῶνες, ὁ αἰῶν τῶν αἰώνων, οἱ αἰῶνες τῶν αἰώνων; by an Aramaism οἱ αἰῶνες, the material universe, Heb. 1:2
αἰώνιος: indeterminate as to duration, eternal, everlasting
ἀκαθαρσία: uncleanness; lewdness; impurity of motive, 1 Thess. 2:3
ἀκαιρέομαι: to be without opportunity or occasion, Phil. 4:10*
ἄκακος: free from evil, innocent, blameless; simple, Rom. 16:18; Heb. 7:26*
ἀκάνθινος: thorny, made of thorns, Mk. 15:17; Jn. 19:5*
ἄκαρπος: without fruit, unfruitful, barren; by impl. noxious
ἀκατάγνωστος: pr. not worthy of condemnation by a judge; hence, irreprehensible, Tit. 2:8*
ἀκατάκριτος: uncondemned in a public trial, Acts 16:37; 22:25*
ἀκατάλυτος: incapable of dissolution, indissoluble; hence, enduring, everlasting, Heb. 7:16*
ἀκατάπαυστος: also spelled ἀκατάπαστος, which cannot be restrained from a thing, unceasing, 2 Pet. 2:14*
ἀκαταστασία: pr. instability; hence, an unsettled state; disorder, commotion, tumult, sedition, Lk. 21:9; 1 Cor. 14:33; 2 Cor. 6:5; 12:20; Jas. 3:16*
ἀκέραιος: pr. unmixed: hence, without mixture of vice or deceit, sincere, blameless, Mt. 10:16; Rom. 16:19; Phil. 2:15*
ἀκμάζω: to flourish, ripen, be in one’s prime, Rev. 14:18*
ἀκμήν: pr. the point of a weapon; point of time: ἀκμήν, for κατἀκμήν, adv., yet, still, even now, Mt. 15:16*
ἀκοή: hearing; the act or sense of hearing, 1 Cor. 12:17; 2 Pet. 2:8; the instrument of hearing, the ear, Mk. 7:35; a thing heard; announcement, instruction, doctrine, Jn. 12:38; Rom. 10:16; report, Mt. 4:24, et al
ἀκολουθέω: to follow; follow as a disciple; imitate
ἀκούω: some list the future active as a middle deponent, ἀκούσομαι, to hear; to hearken, listen to, Mk. 4:3; Lk. 19:48; to heed, obey, Mt. 18:15; Acts 4:19; to understand, 1 Cor. 14:2; to take in or admit to mental acceptance, Mk. 4:33; Jn. 8:43, 47
ἀκρασία: intemperance, self-indulgence, Mt. 23:25; unruly appetite, lustfulness, 1 Cor. 7:5*
ἀκρίβεια: accuracy, exactness; preciseness, or rigor, severe discipline, Acts 22:3*
ἀκριβόω: to inquire accurately or diligently, Mt. 2:7, 16 (see v. 8)*
ἀκριβῶς: accurately, diligently, Mt. 2:8; Lk. 1:3; Acts 18:25; circumspectly, strictly, Eph. 5:15; precisely, distinctly, 1 Thess. 5:2
ἀκροβυστία: foreskin; uncircumcision, the state of being uncircumcised, Rom. 4:10; the abstract being put for the concrete, uncircumcised men, i.e., Gentiles, Rom. 4:9, et al
ἀκρογωνιαῖος: literally: lying at the extreme corner; with λίθος, corner or foundation stone, Eph. 2:20; 1 Pet. 2:6*
ἀκροθίνιον: the first-fruits of the produce of the ground, which were taken from the top of the heap and offered to the gods; the best and choicest of the spoils of war, usually collected in a heap, Heb. 7:4*
ἄκρον: the top, tip, end, extremity, Mk. 13:27; Lk. 16:24; Heb. 11:21
Ἀκύλας: Aquila, pr. name, Paul’s friend and Priscilla’s husband, Acts 18:2, 18, 26; Rom. 16:3; 1 Cor. 16:19; 2 Tim. 4:19*
ἀκυρόω: to deprive of authority, annul, cancel, Mt. 15:6; Mk. 7:13; Gal. 3:17*
ἀλάβαστρος: can be masculine, feminine (2x), or neuter (ἀλάβαστρον,   2x), an alabaster vase, Mk. 14:3 (2x); 26:7; Lk. 7:37*
ἀλαζονεία: arrogance; presumptuous speech, Jas. 4:16; haughtiness, 1 Jn. 2:16*
ἀλαλάζω: pr. to raise the war-cry, ἀλαλά: hence, to utter other loud sounds; to wail, Mk. 5:38; to tinkle, ring, 1 Cor. 13:1*
ἄλαλος: unable to speak or artilculate, Mk. 7:37; 9:17, 25*
ἅλας: variant spellings of ἅλα and ἁλός, salt, Mt. 5:13; Mk. 9:50; met. the salt of wisdom and prudence, Col. 4:6
ἀλείφω: to anoint with oil or ointment
ἀλεκτοροφωνία: the cock-crowing, the third watch of the night, intermediate to mid-night and daybreak, and termed cock-crow, Mk. 13:35*
ἀλέκτωρ: a cock, rooster, Mt. 26:34; Mk. 14:30; Lk. 22:34; Jn. 13:38
Ἀλεξανδρεύς: a native of Alexandria, an Alexandrine, Acts 6:9; 18:24
Ἀλέξανδρος: Alexander, pr. name. (1) The High Priest’s kinsman, Acts 4:6. (2) A Jew of Ephesus, Acts 19:33. (3) The coppersmith, 1 Tim. 1:20; 2 Tim. 4:14. (4) Son of Simon of Cyrene, Mk. 15:21*
ἀλήθεια: truth, Mk. 5:33; love of truth, sincerity, 1 Cor. 5:8; divine truth revealed to man, Jn. 1:17; practice in accordance with Gospel truth, Jn. 3:21; 2 Jn. 4
ἀληθεύω: to speak or maintain the truth; to act truly or sincerely, Gal. 4:16; Eph. 4:15*
ἀληθής: true, Jn. 4:18; worthy of credit, Jn. 5:31; truthful, Jn. 7:18
ἀληθινός: sterling, Lk. 16:11; real, Jn. 6:32; 1 Thess. 1:9; unfeigned, trustworthy, true, Jn. 19:35
ἀληθῶς: truly, really, Mt. 14:33; certainly, of a truth, Jn. 17:8; Acts 12:11: truly, actually, Jn. 4:18
ἁλίζω: to salt, season with salt, preserve by salting, Mt. 5:13; Mk. 9:49*
ἀλλά: but; however; but still more; ἀλλάγε, at all events; ἀλλή, unless, except. Ἀλλά also serves to introduce a sentence with keenness and emphasis, Jn. 16:2; Rom. 6:5; 7:7; Phil. 3:8
ἀλλάσσω: to change, alter, transform, Acts 6:14; Rom. 1:23; 1 Cor. 15:51, 52; Gal. 4:20; Heb. 1:12
ἀλλαχόθεν: from another place or elsewhere, Jn. 10:1*
ἀλληγορέω: to say what is either designed or fitted to convey a meaning other than the literal one, to allegorize; ἀλληγορούμενος, adapted to another meaning, otherwise significant, Gal. 4:24*
ἁλληλουϊά: (Hebrew) hallelujah, praise Yahweh or the Lord, Rev. 19:1, 3, 4, 6*
ἀλλογενής: of another race or nation, i.e., not a Jew; a stranger, foreigner, Lk. 17:18*
ἅλλομαι: to leap, jump, leap up, Acts 3:8; 14:10; to spring, as water, Jn. 4:14*
ἄλλος: another, some other; ὁ ἄλλος, the other; οἱ ἄλλοι, the others, the rest
ἀλλοτριεπίσκοπος: pr. one who meddles with the affairs of others, a busybody in other men’s matters; factious, 1 Pet. 4:15*
ἀλλότριος: belonging to another, Lk. 16:12; foreign, Acts 7:6; Heb. 11:9; a foreigner, alien, Mt. 17:25
ἀλλόφυλος: of another race or nation, i.e., not a Jew, a foreigner, Acts 10:28*
ἀλοάω: to thresh; to tread, 1 Cor. 9:9, 10; 1 Tim. 5:18*
ἄλογος: without speech or reason, irrational, brute, 2 Pet. 2:12; Jude 10; unreasonable, absurd, Acts 25:27*
ἀλόη: aloe, lign-aloe, a tree which grows in India and Cochin-China, the wood of which is soft and bitter, though highly aromatic. It is used by the Orientals as a perfume; and employed for the purposes of embalming, Jn. 19:39*
ἄλυπος: free from grief or sorrow, Phil. 2:28*
ἀλυσιτελής: pr. bringing in no revenue or profit; hence, unprofitable, useless; detrimental; ruinous, disastrous, Heb. 13:17*
ἄλφα: first letter of Greek alphabet, Alpha, Rev. 1:8.; 21:6; 22:13*
Ἁλφαῖος: Alphaeus, pr. name (1) Father of Jas. the less, Mt. 10:3; Mk. 3:18; Lk. 6:15; Acts 1:13. (2) Father of Levi, (or Matthew) Mk. 2:14*
ἅλων: a threshing-floor, a place where corn is trodden out; meton. the corn which is trodden out, Mt. 3:12; Lk. 3:17*
ἀλώπηξ: a fox, Mt. 8:20; Lk. 9:58; met. a fox-like, crafty man, Lk. 13:32*
ἅμα: also functions as an improper preposition with the genitive (2x), with, together with; at the same time
ἁμαρτάνω: pr. to miss a mark; to be in error, 1 Cor. 15:34; Tit. 3:11; to sin, Jn. 5:14; to be guilty of wrong, Mt. 18:15
ἁμάρτημα: an error; sin, offence, Mk. 3:28; 4:12; Rom. 3:25; 1 Cor. 6:18
ἁμαρτία: error; offence, sin, Mt. 1:21; a principle or cause of sin, Rom. 7:7; proneness to sin, sinful propensity, Rom. 7:17, 20; guilt or imputation of sin, Jn. 9:41; Heb. 9:26; a guilty subject, sin-offering, expiatory victim, 2 Cor. 5:21
ἀμάρτυρος: without testimony or witness, without evidence, Acts 14:17*
ἁμαρτωλός: one who deviates from the path of virtue, a sinner, Mk. 2:17; depraved, Mk. 8:38; sinful, detestable, Rom. 7:13
ἄμαχος: not disposed to fight; not quarrelsome or contentious, 1 Tim. 3:3; Tit. 3:2*
ἀμάω: to collect; to reap, mow or cut down, Jas. 5:4*
ἀμέθυστος: an amethyst, a gem of a deep purple or violet color, so called from its supposed efficacy in keeping off drunkenness, Rev. 21:20*
ἀμελέω: not to care for, to neglect, disregard, Mt. 22:5; 1 Tim. 4:14; Heb. 2:3; 8:9*
ἄμεμπτος: blameless, irreprehensible, without defect, Lk. 1:6; Phil. 2:15; 3:6; 1 Thess. 3:13; Heb. 8:7*
ἀμέριμνος: free from care or solicitude, Mt. 28:14; 1 Cor. 7:32*
ἀμεταμέλητος: not to be repented of; by impl. irrevocable, enduring, Rom. 11:29; 2 Cor. 7:10*
ἄμετρος: without or beyond measure, regardless of measure, 2 Cor. 10:13, 15*
ἀμήν: in truth, most certainly; so be it; ὁ ἀμήν, the faithful and true one, Rev. 3:14
ἀμήτωρ: pr. without mother; independent of maternal descent, Heb. 7:3*
ἀμίαντος: pr. unstained, unsoiled; met. undefiled, chaste, Heb. 7:26; 13:4; pure, sincere, Jas. 1:27; undefiled, unimpaired, 1 Pet. 1:4*
Ἀμιναδάβ: Aminadab, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:4; Lk. 3:33*
ἀμύνομαι: to ward off; to help, assist; to repel from oneself, resist, make a defence; to assume the office of protector and avenger, Acts 7:24*
ἀμφιβάλλω: to throw around; to cast a net, Mk. 1:16*
ἀμφίβληστρον: pr. what is thrown around, e.g., a garment; a large kind of fishnet, Mt. 4:18*
ἀμφιέννυμι: also spelled ἀμφιέζω and ἀμφιέννυμι, to clothe, invest, Mt. 6:30; 11:8; Lk. 7:25*
Ἀμφίπολις: Amphipolis, a city of Thrace, on the river Strymon, Acts 17:1*. See PhotoGuide.
ἄμφοδον: pr. a road leading round a town or village; the street of a village, Mk. 11:4*
ἀμφότεροι: both.  Only plural in the NT.
ἄμωμον: amomum, an odoriferous shrub, from which a precious ointment was prepared, Rev. 18:13*
Ἀμώς: Amos, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:10; Lk. 3:25*
ἄν: For the various constructions of this particle, and their significance, consult a grammar. At the beginning of a clause, it is another form of ἐάν, if, Jn. 20:23
ἀνά: prep. used in the NT only in certain forms. ἀνὰ μέρος, in turn; ἀνὰ μέσον, through the midst, between; ἀνὰ δηνάριον, at the rate of a denarius; with numerals, ἀνὰ ἑκατόν, in parties of a hundred.  In composition, step by step, up, back, again
ἀναβαθμός: the act of ascending; means of ascent, steps, stairs, Acts 21:35, 40*
ἀναβαίνω: to go up, ascend, Mt. 5:1; to climb, Lk. 19:4; to go on board, Mk. 6:51; to rise, mount upwards, as smoke, Rev. 8:4; to grow or spring up, as plants, Mt. 13:7; to spring up, arise, as thoughts, Lk. 24:38
ἀναβάλλω: to throw back; mid. to put off, defer, adjourn, Acts 24:22*
ἀναβιβάζω: to cause to come up or ascend, draw or bring up, Mt. 13:48*
ἀναβλέπω: to look upwards, Mt. 14:19; to see again, recover sight, Mt. 11:5
ἀναβοάω: to cry out or aloud, exclaim, Mt. 27:46*
ἀναγγέλλω: to bring back word, announce, report, Mk. 5:14; to declare, set forth, teach, Jn. 5:24
ἀναγεννάω: to beget or bring forth again; to regenerate, 1 Pet. 1:3, 23*
ἀναγινώσκω: to gather exact knowledge of, recognize, discern; especially, to read
ἀναγκάζω: to force, compel, Acts 28:19; to constrain, urge, Lk. 14:23
ἀναγκαῖος: necessary, indispensable, 1 Cor. 12:22; necessary, needful, right, proper, Acts 13:46; 2 Cor. 9:5; Phil. 1:24; 2:25; Heb. 8:3; near, intimate, closely connected, as friends, Acts 10:24
ἀναγκαστῶς: by constraint or compulsion, unwillingly, opposite to ἑκουσίως, 1 Pet. 5:2*
ἀνάγκη: necessity, Mt. 18:7; constraint, compulsion, 2 Cor. 9:7; obligation of duty, moral or spiritual necessity, Rom. 13:5; distress, trial, affliction, Lk. 21:23; 1 Cor. 7:26; 2 Cor. 6:4; 12:10; 1 Thess. 3:7
ἀναγνωρίζω: to recognize; pass. to be made known, or to cause one’s self to be recognized, Acts 7:13*
ἀνάγω: to conduct; to lead or convey up from a lower place to a higher, Lk. 4:5; to offer up, as a sacrifice, Acts 7:41; to lead out, produce, Acts 12:4; as a nautical term (in the middle or passive), to set sail, put to sea, Lk. 8:22
ἀναδείκνυμι: pr. to show anything by raising it aloft, as a torch; to display, manifest, show plainly or openly, Acts 1:24; to mark out, constitute, appoint by some outward sign, Lk. 10:1*
ἀνάδειξις: a showing forth, manifestation; public entrance upon the duty or office to which one is consecrated, Lk. 1:80*
ἀναδέχομαι: to receive, as opposed to shunning or refusing; to receive with hospitality, Acts 28:7; to embrace a proffer or promise, Heb. 11:17*
ἀναδίδωμι: to give forth, up, or back; to deliver, present, Acts 23:33*
ἀναζάω: to live again, recover life, revive, Rom. 7:9; met. to live a new and reformed life, Lk. 15:24, 32*
ἀναζητέω: to track; to seek diligently, inquire after, search for, Lk. 2:44, 45; Acts 11:25*
ἀναζώννυμι: to gird with a belt or girdle; to gird one’s self, 1 Pet. 1:13*
ἀναζωπυρέω: pr. to kindle up a dormant fire; met. to revive, excite; to stir up, quicken one’s powers, 2 Tim. 1:6*
ἀναθάλλω: to grow or bloom again; to renew, Phil. 4:10*
ἀνάθεμα: a devoted thing, ordinarily in a bad sense, a person or thing accursed, Rom. 9:3; 1 Cor. 12:3; 16:22; Gal. 1:8, 9; a curse, execration, anathema, Acts 23:14*
ἀναθεματίζω: to declare any one to be ἀνάθεμα; to curse, bind by a curse, Mk. 14:71; Acts 23:12, 14, 21*
ἀναθεωρέω: to view, behold attentively, contemplate, Acts 17:23; Heb. 13:7*
ἀνάθημα: a gift or offering consecrated to God, Lk. 21:5*
ἀναίδεια: pr. shamelessness; hence, persistence, without regard to time, place, or person, Lk. 11:8*
ἀναίρεσις: a taking up or away; a putting to death, murder, Acts 8:1*
ἀναιρέω: pr. to take up, lift, as from the ground; to take off, put to death, kill, murder, Mt. 2:16; to take away, abolish, abrogate, Heb. 10:9; mid. to take up infants in order to bring them up, Acts 7:21
ἀνακαθίζω: to set up; intrans. to sit up, Lk. 7:15; Acts 9:40*
ἀνακαλύπτω: to unveil, uncover; pass. to be unveiled, 2 Cor. 3:18; met. to be disclosed in true character and condition, 2 Cor. 3:14*
ἀνακάμπτω: pr. to reflect, bend back; hence, to bend back one’s course, return, Mt. 2:12; Lk. 10:6; Acts 18:21; Heb. 11:15*
ἀνάκειμαι: to be laid up, as offerings; later, to lie, recline at table, Mt. 9:10
ἀνακεφαλαιόω: to bring together several things under one, reduce under one head; to comprise, Rom. 13:9; Eph. 1:10*
ἀνακλίνω: to lay down, Lk. 2:7; to cause to recline at table, etc. Mk. 6:39; Lk. 9:15; 12:37; to recline at table, Mt. 8:11
ἀνακράζω: to cry aloud, exclaim, shout, Mk. 1:23; 6:49; Lk. 4:33; 8:28; 23:18*
ἀνακρίνω: to sift; to examine closely, Acts 17:11; to scrutinize, scan, 1 Cor. 2:14, 15; 9:3; to try judicially, Lk. 23:14; to judge, give judgment upon, 1 Cor. 4:3, 4; to put questions, be inquisitive, 1 Cor. 10:25, 27; Acts 11:12 v.l
ἀνάκρισις: investigation, judicial examination, hearing of a cause, Acts 25:26*
ἀνακύπτω: pr. to raise up one’s self, look up, Lk. 13:11; Jn. 8:7, 10; met. to look up cheerily, to be cheered, Lk. 21:28*
ἀναλαμβάνω: to take up, receive up, Mk. 16:19; to take up, carry, Acts 7:43; to take on board, Acts 20:13, 14; to take in company, Acts 23:31; 2 Tim. 4:11
ἀνάλημψις: a taking up, receiving up, Lk. 9:51*
ἄναλος: without saltness, without the taste and pungency of salt, insipid, Mk. 9:50
ἀνάλυσις: pr. dissolution; met. departure, death, 2 Tim. 4:6*
ἀναλύω: pr. to loose, dissolve; intrans. to loose in order to departure; to depart, Lk. 12:36; to depart from life, Phil. 1:23*
ἀναμένω: to await, wait for, expect, 1 Thess. 1:10*
ἀναμιμνῄσκω: to remind, cause to remember, 1 Cor. 4:17; to exhort, 2 Tim. 1:6; to call to mind, recollect, remember, Mk. 11:21; 14:72; 2 Cor. 7:15; Heb. 10:32*
ἀνάμνησις: remembrance; a commemoration, memorial, Lk. 22:19; 1 Cor. 11:24, 25; Heb. 10:3*
ἀνανεόω: also spelled ἀνανεόομαι, to renew; pass. to be renewed, be renovated, by inward reformation, Eph. 4:23*
ἀνανήφω: to become sober; met. to recover sobriety of mind, 2 Tim. 2:26*
Ἁνανίας: Ananias, pr. name I. A Christian of Jerusalem, Acts 5:1, etc. II. A Christian of Damascus, Acts 9:12, etc. III. High Priest, Acts 23:2; 24:1
ἀναντίρρητος: not to be contradicted, indisputable, Acts 19:36*
ἀναντιρρήτως: pr. without contradiction or gainsaying; without hesitation, promptly, Acts 10:29*
ἀναξίως: unworthily, in an improper manner, 1 Cor. 11:27*
ἀνάπαυσις: rest, intermission, Mt. 11:29; Rev. 4:8; 14:11; meton. place of rest, fixed habitation, Mt. 12:43; Lk. 11:24*
ἀναπαύω: to cause to rest, to soothe, refresh, Mt. 11:28; mid. to take rest, repose, refreshment, Mt. 26:45; to have a fixed place of rest, abide, dwell, 1 Pet. 4:14
ἀναπείθω: to persuade to a different opinion, to seduce, Acts 18:13*
ἀνάπειρος: also spelled ἀνάπηρος, maimed, deprived of some member of the body, or at least of its use, Lk. 14:13, 21
ἀναπέμπω: to send back, Phlm. 12; to send up, remit to a tribunal, Lk. 23:7, 11, 15; Acts 25:21*
ἀναπηδάω: to leap up, stand up, Mk. 10:50*
ἀναπίπτω: to fall or recline backwards; to recline at table, etc., Lk. 11:37; to throw one’s self back, Jn. 21:20
ἀναπληρόω: to fill up, complete, 1 Thess. 2:16; to fulfil, confirm, as a prophecy by the event, Mt. 13:14; to fill the place of any one, 1 Cor. 14:16; to supply, make good, 1 Cor. 16:17; Phil. 2:30; to observe fully, keep the law, Gal. 6:2*
ἀναπτύσσω: to roll back, unroll, unfold, Lk. 4:17*
ἀνάπτω: to light, kindle, set on fire, Lk. 12:49; Jas. 3:5*
ἀνασείω: pr. to shake up; met. to stir up, instigate, Mk. 15:11; Lk. 23:5*
ἀνασκευάζω: pr. to collect one’s effects or baggage (σκεύη) in order to remove; to lay waste by carrying off or destroying every thing; met. to unsettle, pervert, subvert, Acts 15:24*
ἀνασπάω: to draw up, to draw out, Lk. 14:5; Acts 11:10*
ἀνάστασις: a raising or rising up; resurrection, Mt. 22:23; meton. the author of resurrection, Jn. 11:25; met. an uprising into a state of higher advancement and blessedness, Lk. 2:34
ἀναστατόω: to lay waste, destroy; to disturb, throw into commotion, Acts 17:6; to excite to sedition and tumult, Acts 21:38; to disturb the mind of any one by doubts, etc.; to subvert, unsettle, Gal. 5:12*
ἀναστρέφω: to overturn, throw down, to turn back, return, Acts 5:22; 15:16; to live, to conduct one’s self, 2 Cor. 1:12; Eph. 2:3; 1 Tim. 3:15; Heb. 13:18; 1 Pet. 1:17; 2 Pet. 2:18; to gaze, Heb. 10:33*
ἀναστροφή: conversation, mode of life, conduct, deportment, Gal. 1:13
ἀνατάσσομαι: pr. to arrange; hence, to compose, Lk. 1:1*
ἀνατέλλω: to cause to rise, Mt. 5:45; intrans. to rise, as the sun, stars, etc., Mt. 4:16; to spring by birth, Heb. 7:14
ἀνατίθημι: in NT only mid., to submit to a person’s consideration, statement, or report of matters, Acts 25:14; Gal. 2:2*
ἀνατολή: pr. a rising of the sun, etc.; the place of rising, the east, as also pl. ἀνατολαί, Mt. 2:1, 2; met. the dawn or day-spring, Lk. 1:78
ἀνατρέπω: pr. to overturn, overthrow; met. to subvert, corrupt, 2 Tim. 2:18; Tit. 1:11; Jn. 2:15*
ἀνατρέφω: to nurse, as an infant, Acts 7:20; to bring up, educate, Acts 7:21; 22:3*
ἀναφαίνω: to bring to light, display; mid. and pass. to appear, Lk. 19:11; a nautical term, to come in sight of, Acts 21:3*
ἀναφέρω: to bear or carry upwards, lead up, Mt. 17:1; to offer sacrifices, Heb. 7:27; to bear aloft or sustain a burden, as sins, 1 Pet. 2:24; Heb. 9:28
ἀνάχυσις: a pouring out; met. excess, stream, flood, 1 Pet. 4:4*
ἀναχωρέω: to go backward; to depart, go away, Mt. 2:12; to withdraw, retire, Mt. 9:24; Acts 23:19; 26:31
ἀνάψυξις: pr. a refreshing coolness after heat; met. refreshing, recreation, rest, Acts 3:20*
ἀναψύχω: to recreate by fresh air; to refresh, cheer, 2 Tim. 1:16*
ἀνδρίζομαι: to render brave or manly; mid. to show or behave one’s self like a man, 1 Cor. 16:13*
ἀνέγκλητος: unblamable, irreproachable, 1 Cor. 1:8; Col. 1:22; 1 Tim. 3:10; Tit. 1:6, 7*
ἀνεκδιήγητος: which cannot be related, inexpressible, unutterable, indescribable, 2 Cor. 9:15*
ἀνεμίζω: to agitate with the wind; pass. to be agitated or driven by the wind, Jas. 1:6*
ἄνεμος: the wind; met. a wind of shifting doctrine, Eph. 4:14
ἀνεξεραύνητος: also spelled ἀνεξερεύνητος, unfathomable, incapable of human explanation, Rom. 11:33*
ἀνεξίκακος: enduring or patient under evils and injuries, 2 Tim. 2:24*
ἀνεξιχνίαστος: to track out, ἴξνος, a track which cannot be explored, inscrutable, incomprehensible, Rom. 11:33; Eph. 3:8*
ἀνεπαίσχυντος: without cause of shame, irreproachable, 2 Tim. 2:15*
ἀνεπίλημπτος: also spelled ἀνεπίληπρος. pr. not to be laid hold of; met. beyond reproach, unblamable, 1 Tim. 3:2; 5:7; 6:14*
ἀνέρχομαι: to ascend, go up, Jn. 6:3; Gal. 1:17, 18*
ἄνεσις: pr. the relaxing of a state of constraint; relaxation of rigor of confinement, Acts 24:23; met. ease, rest, peace, tranquility, 2 Cor. 2:13; 7:5; 8:13; 2 Thess. 1:7*
ἀνετάζω: to examine thoroughly; to examine by torture, Acts 22:24, 29*
ἄνευ: some classify as an improper preposition, without, Mt. 10:29; 1 Pet. 3:1; 4:9*
ἀνευρίσκω: to find by diligent search, Lk. 2:16; Acts 21:4*
ἀνέχομαι: also listed as ἀνέχω, but it is always in the middle in our literature, to endure patiently, 1 Cor. 4:12; 2 Cor. 11:20; 2 Thess. 1:4; to bear with, Matt 17:7; to suffer, admit, permit, Acts 18:14; 2 Cor. 11:4; 2 Tim. 4:3; Heb. 13:22
ἀνήκω: to come up to, to pertain to; ἀνήκει, impers. it is fit, proper, becoming, Col. 3:18; Eph. 5:4; Phlm. 8*
ἀνήρ: a male person of full age and stature, as opposed to a child or female, 1 Cor. 13:11; a husband, Mt. 1:16; a man, human being, individual, Lk. 11:31; used also pleonastically with other nouns and adjectives, Lk. 5:8; Acts 1:16
ἀνθίστημι: to oppose, resist, stand out against
ἀνθομολογέομαι: pr. to come to an agreement; hence, to confess openly what is due; to confess, give thanks, render praise, Lk. 2:38*
ἀνθρακιά: a mass or heap of live coals, Jn. 18:18; 21:9
ἀνθρωπάρεσκος: desirous of pleasing men, Eph. 6:6; Col. 3:22*
ἀνθρώπινος: human, belonging to man, 1 Cor. 2:4, 13; 4:3; 10:13; Jas. 3:7; 1 Pet. 2:13; suited to man, Rom. 6:19*
ἄνθρωπος: a human being, Jn. 16:21; Phil. 2:7; an individual, Rom. 3:28, et al. freq.; used also pleonastically with other words, Mt. 11:19; et al.; met. the spiritual frame of the inner man, Rom. 7:22; Eph. 3:16; 1 Pet. 3:4
ἀνίημι: (1) to loose, slacken, Acts 27:40; to unbind, unfasten, Acts 16:26; (2) to omit, dispense with, Eph. 6:9; (3) to leave or neglect, Heb. 13:5*
ἄνιπτος: literally: unwashed; figuratively: ceremonially unclean Mt. 15:20; Mk. 7:2*
ἀνίστημι: trans. to cause to stand up or rise, Acts 9:41; to raise up, as the dead, Jn. 6:39; to raise up into existence, Mt. 22:24; intrans. and mid., to rise up, Mt. 9:9; to rise up into existence, Acts 7:18; 20:30
Ἅννας: Annas, pr. name, short version of Ἅνανος, Lk. 3:2; Jn. 18:13, 24; Acts 4:6*
ἀνόητος: inconsiderate, unintelligent, unwise; Lk. 24:25; Rom. 1:14; Gal. 3:1, 3; Tit. 3:3; brutish, 1 Tim. 6:9
ἄνοια: want of understanding; folly, rashness, madness, Lk. 6:11; 2 Tim. 3:9*
ἀνοίγω: trans. to open, Mt. 2:11; intrans. to be opened, to be open, Mt. 3:16; Jn. 1:52
ἄνοιξις: an opening, act of opening, Eph. 6:19*
ἀνομία: lawlessness; violation of law, 1 Jn. 3:4; iniquity, sin, Mt. 7:23
ἄνομος: lawless, without law, not subject to law, 1 Cor. 9:21; lawless, violating law, wicked, impious, Acts 2:23; a transgressor, Mk. 15:28; Lk. 22:37
ἀνόμως: without the intervention of law, Rom. 2:12 (2x)
ἀνορθόω: to restore to straightness or erectness, Lk. 13:13; to re-invigorate, Heb. 12:12; to re-erect, Acts 15:16*
ἀντάλλαγμα: a price paid in exchange for a thing; compensation, equivalent ransom, Mt. 16:26; Mk. 8:37*
ἀνταναπληρόω: to fill up, complete, supply, Col. 1:24*
ἀνταποδίδωμι: to repay, give back, return, recompense, Lk. 14:14 (2x); Rom. 11:35; 12:19; 1 Thess. 3:9; 2 Thess. 1:6; Heb. 10:30
ἀνταποκρίνομαι: occurs in the NT only in the middle, to answer, speak in answer, Lk. 14:6; to reply against, contradict, dispute, Rom. 9:20*
ἀντέχω: to hold firmly, cling or adhere to; to be devoted to any one, Lk. 16:13; Tit. 1:9; to exercise a zealous care for any one, 1 Thess. 5:14; Mk. 6:24*
ἀντί: over against; hence, in correspondence to, answering to, Jn. 1:16; in place of, Mt. 2:22; in retribution or return for, Mt. 5:38; in consideration of, Heb. 12:2, 16; on account of, Mt. 17:27; ἀνθ’ ὡ, because, Lk. 1:20
ἀντιβάλλω: pr. to throw or toss from one to another; met. to agitate, to converse or discourse about, Lk. 24:17*
ἀντιδιατίθημι: to set opposite; mid. (only in the NT) to be of an opposite opinion, to be adverse; opponent, 2 Tim. 2:25*
ἀντίδικος: an opponent in a lawsuit, Mt. 5:25 (2x); Lk. 12:58; 18:3; an adversary, 1 Pet. 5:8*
ἀντίθεσις: pr. opposition; hence, a question proposed for dispute, disputation, 1 Tim. 6:20*
ἀντικαθίστημι: trans. to set in opposition; intrans. to withstand, resist, Heb. 12:4*
ἀντίκειμαι: pr. occupy an opposite position; met. to oppose, be adverse to, Gal. 5:17; 1 Tim. 1:10; opponent, hostile, Lk. 13:7
ἄντικρυς: can function as an improper preposition with the gen., also spelled ἀντικρύ, opposite to, over against, Acts 20:15*
ἀντιλαμβάνω: to aid, assist, help, Lk. 1:54; Acts 20:35; to be a recipient, 1 Tim. 6:2*
ἀντιλέγω: to speak against, contradict; to gainsay, deny, Lk. 20:27; to oppose, Jn. 19:12; Acts 13:45; 28:19; Rom. 10:21; Tit. 1:9; 2:9; pass. to be spoken against, decried, Lk. 2:34; Acts 28:22*
ἀντίλημψις: aid, assistance; meton, one who aids or assists, a help, 1 Cor. 12:28*
ἀντιλογία: contradiction, question, Heb. 6:16; 7:7; opposition, rebellion, Jude 11; hostility, Heb. 12:3*
ἀντιλοιδορέω: to reproach or revile again or in return, 1 Pet. 2:23*
Ἀντιόχεια: Antioch, pr. name I. Antioch, the metropolis of Syria, where the disciples first received the name of Christians II. Antioch, a city of Pisidia, Acts 13:14; 14:19; 2 Tim. 3:11. See PhotoGuide.
ἀντιπαρέρχομαι: to pass over against, to pass along without noticing, Lk. 10:31, 32*
Ἀντιπατρίς: Antipatris, pr. name, Acts 23:31*. See PhotoGuide.
ἀντιπέρα: can function as an improper preposition with the gen., opposite, Lk. 8:26*
ἀντιπίπτω: pr. to fall upon, rush upon any one; hence, to resist by force, oppose, strive against, Acts 7:51*
ἀντιστρατεύομαι: to war against; to contravene, oppose, Rom. 7:23*
ἀντιτάσσω: to post in adverse array, as an army; mid. to set oneself in opposition, resist, Acts 18:6; Rom. 13:2; Jas. 5:6; to be averse, Jas. 4:6; 1 Pet. 5:5*
ἀντίτυπος: of correspondent stamp or form; corresponding, in correspondent fashion, 1 Pet. 3:21; τὸ ἀντίτυπον, a copy, representation, Heb. 9:24*
ἀντίχριστος: antichrist, an opposer of Christ, 1 Jn. 2:18, 22; 4:3; 2 Jn. 7; plural in 1 Jn. 2:18*
ἀντλέω: to draw, e.g., wine, water, etc.; Jn. 2:8, 9; 4:7, 15*
ἄντλημα: pr. that which is drawn; a bucket, vessel for drawing water, Jn. 4:11*
ἀντοφθαλμέω: pr. to look in the face, met. a nautical term, to bear up against the wind, Acts 27:15*
ἄνυδρος: without water, dry, 2 Pet. 2:17; Jude 12; τόποι ἄνυδροι, dry places, and therefore, in the East, barren, desert, Mt. 12:43; Lk. 11:24*
ἀνυπότακτος: not subjected, not made subordinate, Heb. 2:8; insubordinate, refractory, disorderly, contumacious, lawless, 1 Tim. 1:9; Tit. 1:6, 10
ἄνω: above, Acts 2:19; Gal. 4:26; Col. 3:1; up, upwards, Jn. 11:41; ὁ, ἡ, τό, ἄνω, that which is above, Jn. 8:23; ἕως ἄνω, to the top
ἄνωθεν: from above, from a higher place, Jn. 3:31; of time, from the first or beginning, Acts 26:5; from the source, Lk. 1:33; again, anew, Jn. 3:3, 7; Gal. 4:9; with a prep., the top or upper part, Mt. 27:51
ἄξιος: pr. of equal value; worthy, estimable, Mt. 10:11, 13; worthy of, deserving, either good or evil, Mt. 10:10; correspondent to, Mt. 3:8; Lk. 3:8; Acts 26:20; comparable, countervailing, Rom. 8:18; suitable, due, Lk. 23:41
ἀξιόω: to judge or esteem worthy or deserving; to deem fitting, to require, Acts 15:38; 28:22
ἀξίως: worthily, Col. 1:10; suitably, in a manner becoming, Rom. 16:2
ἀπαγγέλλω: to announce that with which a person is charged, or which is called for by circumstances; to carry back word, Mt. 2:8; to report, Mt. 8:33; to declare plainly, Heb. 2:12; to announce formally, 1 Jn. 1:2, 3
ἀπάγχω: to strangle; mid. to choke or strangle one’s self, hang one’s self, Mt. 27:5*
ἀπάγω: to lead away, Mt. 26:57; to conduct, Mt. 7:13, 14; pass. to be led off to execution, Acts 12:19; met. to be led astray, seduced, 1 Cor. 12:1
ἀπαίρω: to take away; pass. to be taken away; to be withdrawn, Mt. 9:15; Mk. 2:20; Lk. 5:35*
ἀπαιτέω: to demand, require, Lk. 12:20; to demand back, Lk. 6:30*
ἀπαλγέω: pr. to desist from grief; hence, to become insensible or callous, Eph. 4:19*
ἀπαλλάσσω: to set free, deliver, set at liberty, Heb. 2:15; to rid judicially, Lk. 12:58; mid. to depart, remove, Acts 19:12*
ἀπαλλοτριόω: pass. to be alienated from, be a stranger to; alien, Eph. 2:12; 4:18; Col. 1:21*
ἀπάντησις: a meeting, encounter; εἰς ἀπάντησιν, to meet, Mt. 25:6; Acts 28:15; 1 Thess. 4:17*
ἅπαξ: once, 2 Cor. 11:25; once for all, Heb. 6:4; 9:26, 28; 10:2; 1 Pet. 3:18, 20; Jude 3; εἰδὼς ἅπαξ, knowing once for ever, unfailingly, constantly, Jude 5
ἀπαράβατος: not transient; not to be superseded, unchangeable, Heb. 7:24*
ἀπαρνέομαι: to deny, disown, Mt. 26:34; to renounce, disregard, Mt. 16:24
ἀπαρχή: pr. the first act of a sacrifice; hence, the firstfruits, first portion, firstling, Rom. 8:23
ἀπασπάζομαι: to take leave of, say farwell to, Acts 21:6*
ἀπατάω: to deceive, seduce into error, Eph. 5:6; 1 Tim. 2:14; Jas. 1:26*
ἀπάτωρ: pr. without a father, fatherless; hence, independent of paternal descent, Heb. 7:3*
ἀπείθεια: an uncompliant disposition; obstinacy, disobedience, unbelief, Rom. 11:30, 32; Eph. 2:2; 5:6; Heb. 4:6, 11; Col. 3:6*
ἀπειθέω: to be uncompliant; to refuse belief, disbelieve, Jn. 3:36; to refuse belief and obedience, Rom. 10:21; 1 Pet. 3:20; to refuse conformity, Rom. 2:8
ἀπειθής: who will not be persuaded, uncompliant; disobedient, Lk. 1:17; Acts 26:19; Rom. 1:30; 2 Tim. 3:2; Tit. 1:16; 3:3
ἀπειλέω: to threaten, menace, rebuke, Acts 4:17; 1 Pet. 2:23*
ἀπειλή: threat, commination, Acts 4:29; 9:1; harshness of language, Eph. 6:9*
ἄπειμι: to go away, depart, come Acts 17:10*
ἀπεῖπον: to refuse, forbid, to renounce, disclaim, 2 Cor. 4:2*
ἀπείραστος: inexperienced, untempted, incapable of being tempted, Jas. 1:13*
ἀπεκδέχομαι: to expect, wait or look for, Rom. 8:19, 23, 25; 1 Cor. 1:7; Gal. 5:5; Phil. 3:20; Heb. 9:28
ἀπεκδύομαι: to put off, renounce, Col. 3:9; to despoil a rival, Col. 2:15*
ἀπέκδυσις: a putting or stripping off, renunciation, Col. 2:11*
ἀπελεγμός: pr. refutation; by impl. disrepute. contempt, Acts 19:27*
ἀπελπίζω: to lay aside hope, despond, despair; also, to hope for something in return, Lk. 6:35*
ἀπέναντι: some classify as an improper preposition, opposite to, over against, Mt. 27:61; contrary to, in oppositition to, against, Acts 17:7; before, in the presence of, Mt. 27:24; Rom. 3:18; Acts 3:16*
ἀπερισπάστως: without distraction, without care or solicitude, 1 Cor. 7:35*
ἀπερίτμητος: pr. uncircumcised; met. uncircumcised in respect of untowardness and obduracy, Acts 7:51*
ἀπέρχομαι: to go away, depart, Mt. 8:18; to go forth, pervade, as a rumor, Mt. 4:24; to arrive at a destination, Lk. 23:33; to pass away, disappear, Rev. 21:4; ἀπέρχομαι ὀπίσω, to follow, Mk. 1:20
ἀπέχω: trans. to have in full what is due or is sought, Mt. 6:2, 5, 16; Lk. 6:24; Phil. 4:18; to have altogether, Phlm. 15; hence, it is enough, Mk. 14:41; intrans. to be distant, Lk. 7:6; to be estranged, Mt. 15:8; Mk. 7:6, mid. to abstain from, Acts 14:20
ἀπιστέω: to refuse belief, be incredulous, disbelieve, Mk. 16:11, 16; Lk. 24:11, 41; Acts 28:24; to prove false, violate one’s faith, be unfaithful, Rom. 3:3; 2 Tim. 2:13
ἀπιστία: unbelief, want of trust and confidence; a state of unbelief, 1 Tim. 1:13; violation of faith, faithlessness, Rom. 3:3; Heb. 3:12, 19
ἄπιστος: unbelieving, without confidence in any one, Mt. 17:17; violating one’s faith, unfaithful, false, treacherous, Lk. 12:46; an unbeliever, infidel, pagan, 1 Cor. 6:6; pass. incredible, Acts 26:8
ἁπλότης: simplicity, sincerity, purity of mind, Rom. 12:8; 11:3; Eph. 6:5; Col. 3:22; liberality, as arising from simplicity and frankness of character, 2 Cor. 8:2; 9:11, 13; 11:3*
ἁπλοῦς: pr. single; hence, simple, uncompounded; sound, perfect, Mt. 6:22; Lk. 11:34*
ἁπλῶς: in simplicity; sincerely, really, or, liberally, bountifully, Jas. 1:5*
ἀπό: pr. forth, from, away from; hence, it variously signifies departure; distance of time or place; avoidance; riddance; derivation from a quarter, source, or material; origination from agency or instrumentality
ἀποβαίνω: to step off; to disembark from a ship, Lk. 5:2; Jn. 21:9; to become, result, happen, Lk. 21:13; Phil. 1:19*
ἀποβάλλω: to cast or throw off, cast aside, Mk. 10:50; Heb. 10:35*
ἀποβλέπω: pr. to look off from all other objects and at a single one; hence, to turn a steady gaze, to look with fixed and earnest attention, Heb. 11:26*
ἀπόβλητος: pr. to be cast away; met. to be condemned, regarded as vile, 1 Tim. 4:4*
ἀποβολή: a casting off; rejection, reprobation, Rom. 11:15; loss, deprivation, of life, etc., Acts 27:22*
ἀπογίνομαι: to be away from, unconnected with; to die; met. to die to a thing by renouncing it, 1 Pet. 2:24*
ἀπογραφή: a register, inventory; registration, enrollment, Lk. 2:2; Acts 5:37*
ἀπογράφω: pr. to copy; hence, to register, enrol, Lk. 2:1; Heb. 12:23; mid. to procure the registration of one’s name, to give in one’s name for registration, Lk. 2:3, 5*
ἀποδείκνυμι: to point out, display; to prove, evince, demonstrate, Acts 25:7; to designate, proclaim, hold forth, 2 Thess. 2:4; to constitute, appoint, Acts 2:22; 1 Cor. 4:9*
ἀποδεκατόω: to pay or give tithes of, Mt. 23:23; Lk. 11:42; 18:12; to tithe, levy tithes upon, Heb. 7:5*
ἀποδέχομαι: to receive kindly or heartily, welcome, Lk. 8:40; 9:11; Acts 18:27; 28:30; to receive with hearty assent, embrace, Acts 2:41; to accept with satisfaction, Acts 24:3*
ἀποδημέω: to be absent from one’s home or country; to go on travel, Mt. 21:33; 25:14, 15; Mk. 12:1; Lk. 15:13; 20:9*
ἀποδίδωμι: to give in answer to a claim or expectation; to render a due, Mt. 12:36; 16:27; 21:41; 22:21; to recompense, Mt. 6:4, 6, 18; to discharge an obligation, Mt. 5:33; to pay a debt, Mt. 5:26; to render back, requite, Rom. 12:17; to give back, restore, Lk. 4:20; 9:42; to refund, Lk. 10:35; 19:8; mid., to sell, Acts 5:8; 7:9; Heb. 12:16; pass., to be sold, Mt. 18:25; to be given up at a request, Mt. 27:58
ἀποδιορίζω: pr. to separate by intervening boundaries; to separate or divide, Jude 19*
ἀποδοκιμάζω: to reject upon trial; to reject, Mt. 21:42; Mk. 12:10; Lk. 20:17; 1 Pet. 2:4, 7; pass., to be disallowed a claim, declared useless, Lk. 9:22; 17:25; Heb. 12:17
ἀποδοχή: pr. reception, welcome; met. reception of hearty assent, 1 Tim. 1:15; 4:9*
ἀπόθεσις: a putting off or away, laying aside, a euphemism for death, 1 Pet. 3:21; 2 Pet. 1:14*
ἀποθήκη: a place where anything is laid up for preservation, repository, granary, storehouse, barn, Mt. 3:12; 6:26; 13:30; Lk. 3:17; 12:18, 24
ἀποθησαυρίζω: pr. to lay up in store, hoard; met. to treasure up, secure, 1 Tim. 6:19*
ἀποθλίβω: pr. to press out; to press close, press upon, crowd, Lk. 8:45*
ἀποθνῄσκω: to die, Mt. 8:32; to decay, rot, as seeds, Jn. 12:24; 1 Cor. 15:36; to wither, become dry, as a tree, Jude 12; met. to die the death of final condemnation and misery, Jn. 6:50; 8:21, 24; to die to a thing by renunciation or utter separation, Rom. 6:2; 1 Cor. 15:31; Gal. 2;19; Col. 3:3
ἀποκαθίστημι: also spelled ἀποκαθιστάνω, to restore a thing to its former place or state, Mt. 12:13; 17:11; Mk. 3:5; 8:25
ἀποκαλύπτω: pr. uncover; to reveal, Mt. 11:25; pass. to be disclosed, Lk. 2:35; Eph. 3:5; to be plainly signified, distinctly declared, Rom. 1:17, 18; to be set forth, announced, Gal. 3:23; to be discovered in true character, 1 Cor. 3:13; to be manifested, appear, Jn. 12:38;Rom. 8:18; 2 Thess. 2:3, 6, 8; 1 Pet. 1:5; 5:1
ἀποκάλυψις: a disclosure, revelation, Rom. 2:5; manifestation, appearance, Rom. 8:19; 1 Cor. 1:7; 2 Thess. 1:7; 1 Pet. 1:7, 13; 4:13; met. spiritual enlightenment, Lk. 2:32
ἀποκαραδοκία: earnest expectation, eager hope, Rom. 8:19; Phil. 1:20*
ἀποκαταλλάσσω: to transfer from a certain state to another which is quite different; hence, to reconcile, restore to favor, Eph. 2:16; Col. 1:20, 22*
ἀποκατάστασις: pr. a restitution or restoration of a thing to its former state; hence, the renovation of a new and better era, Acts 3:21*
ἀπόκειμαι: to be laid up, preserved, Lk. 19:20; to be in store, be reserved, await any one, Col. 1:5; 2 Tim. 4:8; Heb. 9:27*
ἀποκόπτω: to cut off, Mk. 9:43, 45; Jn. 18:10, 26; Acts 27:32; to castrate, make a eunich, Gal. 5:12*
ἀποκρίνομαι: to answer, Mt. 3:15; in NT to respond to certain present circumstances, to avow, Mt. 11:25
ἀποκρύπτω: to hide away; to conceal, withhold from sight or knowledge, Lk. 10:21; 1 Cor. 2:7; Eph. 3:9; Col. 1:26*
ἀπόκρυφος: hidden away; concealed, Mk. 4:22; Lk. 8:17; stored up, Col. 2:3*
ἀποκτείνω: also spelled ἀποκτέννω or ἀποκτένω, to kill, Mt. 14:5; to destroy, annihilate, Mt. 10:28; to destroy a hostile principle, Eph. 2:16; met. to kill by spiritual condemnation, Rom. 7:11; 2 Cor. 3:6
ἀποκυέω: pr. to bring forth, as women; met. to generate, produce, Jas. 1:15; to generate by spiritual birth, Jas. 1:18*
ἀποκυλίω: to roll away, Mt. 28:2; Mk. 16:3, 4; Lk. 24:2*
ἀπολαμβάνω: to receive what is due, sought, or needed, Lk. 23:41; Rom. 1:27; Gal. 4:5; Col. 3:24; 2 Jn. 8; to receive in full, Lk. 16:25; to receive back, recover, Lk. 6:34; 15:27; 18:30; mid. to take aside, lead away, Mk. 7:33
ἀπόλαυσις: beneficial participation, 1 Tim. 6:17; enjoyment, pleasure, Heb. 11:25*
ἀπολείπω: to leave, leave behind; pass. to be left, remain, 2 Tim. 4:13, 20; Heb. 4:6, 9; 10:26; to relinquish, forsake, desert, Tit. 1:5; Jude 6*
ἀπόλλυμι: to destroy utterly; to kill, Mt. 2:13; to bring to nought, make void, 1 Cor. 1:19; to lose, be deprived of, Mt. 10:42; to be destroyed, perish, Mt. 9:17; to be put to death, to die, Mt. 26:52; to be lost, to stray, Mt. 10:6
Ἀπολλωνία: Apollonia, a city of Macedonia, Acts 17:1*. See PhotoGuide.
ἀπολογέομαι: to defend one’s self against a charge, to make a defence, Lk. 12:11; 21:14
ἀπολούω: to cleanse by bathing; mid. to cleanse one’s self; to procure one’s self to be cleansed; met., of sin, Acts 22:16; 1 Cor. 6:11*
ἀπολύτρωσις: redemption, a deliverance, procured by the payment of a ransom; meton. the author of redemption, 1 Cor. 1:30; deliverance, simply, the idea of a ransom being excluded, Lk. 21:28; Heb. 11:35
ἀπολύω: pr. to loose; to release from a tie or burden, Mt. 18:27; to divorce, Mt. 1:19; to remit, forgive, Lk. 6:37; to liberate, discharge, Mt. 27:15; to dismiss, Mt. 15:23; Acts 19:40; to allow to depart, to send away, Mt. 14:15; to permit, or, signal departure from life, Lk. 2:29; mid. to depart, Acts 28:25; pass. to be rid, Lk. 13:12
ἀπομάσσω: to wipe off; mid. to wipe off one’s self, Lk. 10:11*
ἀπονέμω: to portion off; to assign, bestow, 1 Pet. 3:7*
ἀπονίπτω: to cleanse a part of the body by washing; mid., of one’s self, Mt. 27:24*
ἀποπίπτω: to fall off or from, Acts 9:18*
ἀποπλανάω: to cause to wander; met. to deceive, pervert, seduce, Mk. 13:22; pass. to wander; met. to swerve from, apostatize, 1 Tim. 6:10*
ἀποπλέω: to depart by ship, sail away, Acts 13:4; 14:26; 20:15; 27:1*
ἀποπνίγω: to choke, suffocate, Lk. 8:7; to drown, Lk. 8:33*
ἀπορέω: also spelled ἀπορρίπτω, pr. to be without means; met. to hesitate, be at a stand, be in doubt and perplexity, Jn. 13:22; Acts 25:20; 2 Cor. 4:8; Gal. 4:20
ἀπορίπτω: to throw off, throw down, Acts 27:43*
ἀπορφανίζω: lit., to make an orphan; fig., to deprive, bereave, 1 Thess. 2:17*
ἀποσκίασμα: a shadow cast; met. a shade, the slightest trace, Jas. 1:17*
ἀποσπάω: to draw away from; to draw out or forth, Mt. 26:51; to draw away, seduce, Acts 20:30; to separate one’s self, to part, Lk. 22:41; Acts 21:1*
ἀποστασία: a falling away, a rebellion, apostasy, Acts 21:21; 2 Thess. 2:3*
ἀποστάσιον: defection, desertion, as of a freedman from a patron; in NT the act of putting away a wife, repudiation, divorce, Mt. 19:7; Mk. 10:4; meton. a bill of repudiation, deed of divorce, Mt. 5:31*
ἀποστεγάζω: to remove or break through a covering or roof of a place, Mk. 2:4*
ἀποστέλλω: to send forth a messenger, agent, message, or command, Mt. 2:16; 10:5; to put forth into action, Mk. 4:29; to liberate, rid, Lk. 4:19; to dismiss, send away, Mk. 12:3
ἀποστερέω: to deprive, detach; to debar, 1 Cor. 7:5; to deprive in a bad sense, defraud, Mk. 10:19; 1 Cor. 6:7; mid. to suffer one’s self to be deprived or defrauded, 1 Cor. 6:8; pass. to be destitute or devoid of, 1 Tim. 6:5; to be unjustly withheld, Jas. 5:4*
ἀποστολή: a sending, expedition; office or duty of one sent as a messenger or agent; office of an apostle, apostleship, Acts 1:25; Rom. 1:5; 1 Cor. 9:2; Gal. 2:8*
ἀπόστολος: one sent as a messenger or agent, the bearer of a commission, messenger, Jn. 13:16; an apostle, Mt. 10:2
ἀποστοματίζω: pr. to speak or repeat offhand; also, to require or lead others to speak without premeditation, as by questions calculated to elicit unpremeditated answers, to endeavor to entrap into unguarded language, Lk. 11:53*
ἀποστρέφω: to turn away; to remove, Acts 3:26; Rom. 11:26; 2 Tim. 4:4; to turn a people from their allegiance, to their sovereign, pervert, incite to revolt, Lk. 23:14; to replace, restore, Mt. 26:52; to turn away from any one, to slight, reject, repulse, Mt. 5:42; Tit. 1:14; Heb. 12:25; to desert, 2 Tim. 1:15
ἀποστυγέω: to shrink from with abhorrence, detest, Rom. 12:9*
ἀποσυνάγωγος: expelled or excluded from the synagogue, excommunicated, cut off from the rights and privileges of a Jew, excluded from society, Jn. 9:22; 12:42; 16:2*
ἀποτάσσω: middle: to take leave of, bid farewell to, Lk. 9:61; Acts 18:18, 21; 2 Cor. 2:13; to dismiss, send away, Mk. 6:46; fig: to renounce, forsake, Lk. 14:33
ἀποτελέω: to complete; pass. to be perfected, to arrive at full stature or measure, Lk. 13:32; Jas. 1:15*
ἀποτίθημι: mid: to lay off, lay down or aside, as garments, Acts 7:58; me
ἀποτίνω: to pay off what is claimed or due; to repay, refund, make good, Phlm. 19*
ἀποτολμάω: to dare or risk outright; to speak outright, without reserve or restraint, Rom. 10:20
ἀποτομία: pr. abruptness; met. severity, rigor, Rom. 11:22 (2x)*
ἀποτρέπω: mid: to turn any one away from a thing; mid. to turn one’s self away from any one; to avoid, shun, 2 Tim. 3:5*
ἀποφέρω: to bear or carry away, conduct away, Mk. 15:1; Lk. 16:22; Acts 19:12; 1 Cor. 16:3; Rev. 17:3; 21:10*
ἀποφεύγω: to flee from, escape; met. to be rid, be freed from, 2 Pet. 1:4; 2:18, 20*
ἀποφθέγγομαι: to speak out, declare, particularly solemn, weighty, or pithy sayings, Acts 2:4, 14; 26:25*
ἀπόχρησις: a using up, or, a discharge of an intended use, Col. 2:22*
ἀποχωρέω: to go from or away, depart, Mt. 7:23; Lk. 9:39; Acts 13:13*
ἀποχωρίζω: to separate; pass. to be swept aside, Rev. 6:14; mid. to part, Acts 15:39*
ἀποψύχω: pr. to breathe out, faint away, die; met. to faint at heart, be dismayed, Lk. 21:26*
Ἄππιος: the forum or marketplace, of Appius; a village on the Appian road, near Rome, Acts 28:15*
ἀπρόσκοπος: not stumbling or jarring; met. not stumbling or jarring against moral rule, unblamable, clear, Acts 24:16; Phil. 1:10; free from offensiveness, 1 Cor. 10:32*
ἀπροσωπολήμπτως: without respect of persons, impartially, 1 Pet. 1:17*
ἄπταιστος: free from stumbling; met. free from moral stumbling, offence; irreprehensible, Jude 24*
ἅπτω: pr. to bring in contact, fit, fasten; to light, kindle, Mk. 4:21; Lk. 8:16; to touch, Mt. 8:3; to meddle, venture to partake, Col. 2:21; to have intercourse with, to know carnally, 1 Cor. 7:1; by impl. to harm, 1 Jn. 5:18
ἀπωθέω: to thrust away, repel from one’s self, repulse, Acts 7:27; to refuse, reject, cast off, Acts 7:39; 13:46; Rom. 11:1, 2; 1 Tim. 1:19*
ἀπώλεια: consumption, destruction; waste, profusion, Mt. 26:8; Mk. 14:4; destruction, state of being destroyed, Acts 25:6; eternal ruin, perdition, Mt. 7:13; Acts 8:20
ἆρα: inferential particle, used mainly in interrogations, Lk. 18:8; Acts 8:30; Gal. 2:17*
ἀργέω: pr. to be unemployed; to be inoperative, to linger, 2 Pet. 2:3*
ἀργός: pr. inactive, unemployed, Mt. 20:3, 6; idle, averse from labor, 1 Tim. 5:13; Tit. 1:12; met. 2 Pet. 1:8; unprofitable, hollow, or by impl., injurious, Mt. 12:36; Jas. 2:20*
ἀργυροκόπος: a forger of silver, silversmith, Acts 19:24*
ἄργυρος: silver; meton. anything made of silver; money, Jas. 5:3
ἀργυροῦς: made of silver, Acts 19:24; 2 Tim. 2:20; Rev. 9:20*
Ἀρεοπαγίτης: a judge of the court of Areopagus, Acts 17:34*
ἀρεσκεία: a pleasing, desire of pleasing, Col. 1:10*
ἀρέσκω: to please, Mt. 14:6; to be pleasing, acceptable, Acts 6:5; to consult the pleasure of any one, Rom. 15:1, 2, 3; 1 Cor. 10:33; to seek favor with, Gal. 1:10; 1 Thess. 2:4
ἀρεστός: pleasing, acceptable, Acts 12:3; 1 Jn. 3:22; 8:29, deemed proper, Acts 6:2
ἀρετή: goodness, good quality of any kind; a gracious act of God, 1 Pet. 2:9; 2 Pet. 1:3; virtue, uprightness, Phil. 4:8; 2 Pet. 1:5*
Ἁριμαθαία: Arimathea, a town of Palestine, Mt. 27:57; Mk. 15:43; Lk. 23:51; Jn. 19:38*. See PhotoGuide.
Ἀρίσταρχος: Aristarchus, pr. name, Acts 19:29; 20:4; 27:2; Col. 4:10; Phlm. 24*
ἀριστάω: to take the first meal, breakfast, Jn. 21:12, 15; also, to take a mid-day meal, Lk. 11:37*
ἀριστερός: the left hand, Mt. 6:3; so ἐξ ἀριστερῶν, i.e. μερῶν, Lk. 23:33; 2 Cor. 6:7; Mk. 10:37*
ἄριστον: pr. the first meal, breakfast; afterwards extended to signify also a slight mid-day meal, luncheon, Mt. 22:4; Lk. 11:38; 14:12*
ἀρκέω: pr. to ward off; thence; to be of service, avail; to suffice, be enough, Mt. 25:9; pass. to be contented, satisfied, Lk. 3:14; 1 Tim. 6:8; Heb. 13:5; 3 Jn. 10
ἄρκος: also spelled ἄρκτος, a bear, Rev. 13:2*
ἁρμόζω: to fit together; to join, unite, in marriage, espouse, betroth, 2 Cor. 11:2*
ἁρμός: a joint or articulation of the bones, Heb. 4:12*
ἀρνέομαι: to deny, disclaim, disown, Mt. 10:33; to renounce, Tit. 2:12; to decline, refuse, Heb. 11:24; absol. to deny, contradict, Lk. 8:15
ἀρνίον: a young lamb, lamb, Jn. 21:15; Rev. 5:6, 8
ἁρπαγή: plunder, pillage; the act of plundering, Heb. 10:34; prey, spoil, Mt. 23:25; Lk. 11:39*
ἁρπαγμός: eager seizure; in NT, a thing retained with an eager grasp, or eagerly claimed and conspicuously exercised, Phil. 2:6*
ἁρπάζω: to seize, as a wild beast, Jn. 10:12; take away by force, snatch away, Mt. 13:19; Jn. 10:28, 29; Acts 23:10; Jude 23; met. to seize on with avidity, eagerly, appropriate, Mt. 11:12; to convey away suddenly, transport hastily, Jn. 6:15
ἅρπαξ: pr. raveneous, ravening, as a wild beast, Mt. 7:15; met. rapacious, given to extortion and robbery, an extortioner, Lk. 18:11; 1 Cor. 5:10, 11; 6:10*
ἄρρητος: pr. not spoken; what ought not to be spoken, secret; which cannot be spoken or uttered, 2 Cor. 12:4*
ἄρρωστος: ill, sick, an invalid, Mt. 14:14; Mk. 6:5, 13; 16:18; 1 Cor. 11:30
ἀρσενοκοίτης: a male engaging in same-gender sexual activity, a sodomite, pedarest, 1 Cor. 6:9; 1 Tim. 1:10*
ἄρσην: male, of the male sex, Mt. 19:4; Mk. 10:6; Lk. 2:23; Rom. 1:27; Gal. 3:28; Rev. 12:5, 13*
ἀρτέμων: a topsail, foresail; or, according to others, the dolon of Pliny and Pollux, a small sail near the bow of the ship, which was hoisted when the wind was too strong to use the larger sails, Acts 27:40*
ἄρτι: pr. at the present moment, close upon it either before of after; now, at the present juncture, Mt. 3:15; forthwith, presently; just now, recently, 1 Thess. 3:6; ἕως ἄρτι, until now, hitherto, Mt. 11:12; Jn. 2:10; ἀπ’ ἄρτι, or ἀπάρτι, from this time, henceforth, Mt. 23:39
ἄρτιος: entirely suited; complete in accomplishment, ready, 2 Tim. 3:17*
ἄρτος: bread; a loaf or thin cake of bread, Mt. 26:26; food, Mt. 15:2; Mk. 3:20; bread, maintenance, living, necessaries of life, Mt. 6:11; Lk. 11:3; 2 Thess. 3:8
ἀρτύω: pr. to fit, prepare; to season, make savoury, Mk. 9:50; Lk. 14:34; Col. 4:6*
ἀρχάγγελος: an archangel, chief angel, 1 Thess. 4:16; Jude 9*
ἀρχαῖος: old, ancient, of former age, Mt. 5:21, 33; of long standing, old, veteran, Acts 21:16; ἀφ’ ἡμερῶν ἀρχαίων, from early days, from an early period, of the Gospel, Acts 15:7
ἀρχή: a beginning, Mt. 24:8; an extremity, corner, or, an attached cord, Acts 10:11; 11:5; first place, headship; high estate, eminence, Jude 6; authority, Lk. 20:20; an authority, magistrate, Lk. 12:11; a principality, prince, of spiritual existence, Eph. 3:10; 6:12; ἀπ’ ἀρχῆς, ἐξ ἀρχῆς, from the first, originally, Mt. 19:4, 8; Lk. 1:2; Jn. 6:64; 2 Thess. 2:13; 1 Jn. 1:1; 2:7; ἐν ἀρχῇ, κατ’ ἀρχάς, in the beginning of things, Jn. 1:1, 2; Heb. 1:10; ἐν ἀρχῇ, at the first, Acts 11:15; τὴν ἀρχήν, used adverbially, wholly, altogether, Jn. 8:25
ἀρχηγός: a chief, leader, prince, Acts 5:31; a prime author, Acts 3:15; Heb. 2:10; 12:2*
ἀρχιερατικός: belonging to or connected with the high-priest or his office, Acts 4:6*
Ἄρχιππος: Archippus, pr. name, Col. 4:17; Phlm. 2, inscr. and subscr.*
ἀρχισυνάγωγος: a president or moderating elder of a synagogue, Mk. 5:22, 35, 36, 38; Lk. 8:49
ἀρχιτελώνης: a chief publican, chief collector of the customs or taxes, Lk. 19:2*
ἄρχω: (1) pr. (act.) to be first; to rule, Mk. 10:42; Rom. 15:12 (2) mid. to begin, Mt. 4:17; to take commencement, Lk. 24:27; 1 Pet. 4:17
ἄρχων: one invested with power and dignity, chief, ruler, prince, magistrate, Mt. 9:23; 20:25
ἄρωμα: an aromatic substance, spice, etc., Mk. 16:1; Lk. 23:56; 24:1; Jn. 19:40*
ἀσάλευτος: unshaken, immovable, Acts 27:41; met. firm, stable, enduring, Heb. 12:28*
ἄσβεστος: unquenched; inextinguishable, unquenchable, Mt. 3:12; Mk. 9:43; Lk. 3:17*
ἀσέβεια: impiety, ungodliness; dishonesty, wickedness, Rom. 1:18; 11:26; 2 Tim. 2:16; Tit. 2:12; Jude 15, 18*
ἀσεβέω: to be impious, to act impiously or wickedly, live an impious life, 2 Pet. 2:6; Jude 15*
ἀσέλγεια: intemperance; licentiousness, lasciviousness, Rom. 13:13; insolence, outrageous behavior, Mk. 7:22
ἄσημος: pr. not marked; met. not noted, not remarkable, unknown to fame, ignoble, mean, inconsiderable, Acts 21:39*
Ἀσήρ: Asher, pr. name, indecl. (Gen. 30:13; 49:20; 2 Chr. 30:11) Lk. 2:36; Rev. 7:6*
ἀσθένεια: want of strength, weakness, feebleness, 1 Cor. 15:43; bodily infirmity, state of ill health, sickness, Mt. 8:17; Lk. 5:15; met. infirmity, frailty, imperfection, intellectual and moral, Rom. 6:19; 1 Cor. 2:3; Heb. 5:2; 7:28; suffering, affliction, distress, calamity, Rom. 8:26
ἀσθενέω: to be weak, infirm, deficient in strength; to be inefficient, Rom. 8:3; 2 Cor. 13:3; to be sick, Mt. 25:36; met. to be weak in faith, to doubt, hesitate, be unsettled, timid, Rom. 14:1; 1 Cor. 8:9, 11, 12; 2 Cor. 11:29; to be deficient in authority, dignity, or power, be contemptible, 2 Cor. 11:21; 13:3, 9; to be afflicted, distressed, needy, Acts 20:35; 2 Cor. 12:10; 13:4, 9
ἀσθένημα: pr. weakness, infirmity, met. doubt, hesitation, Rom. 15:1*
ἀσθενής: without strength, weak, infirm, Mt. 26:41; Mk. 14:38; 1 Pet. 3:7; helpless, Rom. 5:6; imperfect, inefficient, Gal. 4:9; feeble, without energy, 2 Cor. 10:10; infirm in body, sick, sickly, Mt. 25:39, 43, 44; weak, mentally or spiritually, dubious, hesitating, 1 Cor. 8:7, 10; 9:22; 1 Thess. 5:14; afflicted, distressed, oppressed with calamities, 1 Cor. 4:10
Ἀσιανός: belonging to the Roman province of Asia, Acts 20:4*
Ἀσιάρχης: an Asiarch, an officer in the province of Asia, as in other eastern provinces of the Roman empire, selected, with others, from the more opulent citizens, to preside over the things pertaining to religious worship, and to exhibit annual public games at their own expense in honor of the gods, in the manner of the aediles at Rome, Acts 19:31*
ἀσκέω: pr. to work materials; absol. to train or exert one’s self, make endeavor, Acts 24:16*
ἀσκός: a leather bag or bottle, bottle of skin, Mt. 9:17; Mk. 2:22; Lk. 5:37, 38
ἄσοφος: unwise; destitute of Christian wisdom, Eph. 5:15*
ἀσπάζομαι: to salute, greet, welcome, express good wishes, pay respects, Mt. 10:12; Mk. 9:15, et al. freq.; to bid farewell, Acts 20:1; 21:6; to treat with affection, Mt. 5:47; met. to embrace mentally, welcome to the heart of understanding, Heb. 11:13
ἄσπιλος: spotless, unblemished, pure, 1 Tim. 6:14; Jas. 1:27; 1 Pet. 1:19; 2 Pet. 3:14*
ἀσπίς: an asp, a species of serpent of the most deadly venom, Rom. 3:13*
ἄσπονδος: pr. unwilling to make a treaty; hence, implacable, irreconcilable, 2 Tim. 3:3*
ἀσσάριον: dimin. of the Latin, as, a Roman brass coin with the value of one-tenth of a denarius, or δραχμή, used to convey the idea of a trifle or very small sum, Mt. 10:29; Lk. 12:6*
ἆσσον: nearer; very nigh, close; used as the compar. of ἄγχι, Acts 27:13*
Ἀσσος: Assos, a maritime city of Mysia, in Asia Minor, Acts 20:13-14*
ἀστατέω: to be unsettled, to be a wanderer, be homeless, 1 Cor. 4:11*
ἀστεῖος: pr. belonging to a city; well bred, polite, polished; hence, elegant, fair, comely, beautiful, Acts 7:20; Heb. 11:23*
ἀστήρ: a star, luminous body like a star, luminary, Mt. 2:2, 7, 9, 10; Rev. 1:16
ἀστήρικτος: not made firm; unsettled, unstable, unsteady, 2 Pet. 2:14; 3:16*
ἄστοργος: devoid of natural or instinctive affection, without affection to kindred, Rom. 1:31; 2 Tim. 3:3*
ἀστοχέω: pr. to miss the mark; met. to err, deviate, swerve from, 1 Tim. 1:6; 6:21; 2 Tim. 2:18*
ἀστράπτω: to lighten, flash as lightning, Lk. 17:24; to be bright, shining, Lk. 24:4*
ἄστρον: a constellation; a star, Lk. 21:25; Acts 7:43; 27:20; Heb. 11:12*
ἀσύμφωνος: discordant in sound; met. discordant, at difference, Acts 28:25*
ἀσύνετος: unintelligent, dull, Mt. 15:16; Mk. 7:18; reckless, perverse, Rom. 1:21, 31; unenlightened, heathenish, Rom. 10:19
ἀσύνθετος: unable to be trusted, undutiful, Rom. 1:31*
ἀσφάλεια: pr. state of security from falling, firmness; safety, security, 1 Thess. 5:3; certainty, truth, Lk. 1:4; means of security, Acts 5:23*
ἀσφαλής: pr. firm, secure from falling; firm, sure, steady, immovable, Heb. 6:19; met. certain, sure, Acts 21:34; 22:30; 25:26; safe, making secure, Phil. 3:1*
ἀσφαλίζω: mid: to make fast, safe, or secure, Mt. 27:64, 65, 66; Acts 16:24*
ἀσφαλῶς: securely, safely; without fail, safely, Mk. 14:44; Acts 16:23; certainly, assuredly, Acts 2:36*
ἀσχημονέω: to behave in an unbecoming manner or indecorously, 1 Cor. 13:5; to behave in a manner open to censure, 1 Cor. 7:36*
ἀσχημοσύνη: pr. external indecorum; nakedness, shame, pudenda, Rev. 16:15; indecency, infamous lust or lewdness, Rom. 1:27*
ἀτακτέω: pr. to infringe military order; met. to be irregular, behave disorderly, to be lazy, 2 Thess. 3:7*
ἄτακτος: pr. used of soldiers, disorderly; met. irregular in conduct, disorderly, lazy, 1 Thess. 5:14*
ἀτενίζω: to fix one’s eyes upon, look steadily, gaze intently, Lk. 4:20
ἄτερ: improper prep with the gen., without, Lk. 22:6, 35*
ἀτιμάζω: also spelled ἀτιμάω and ἀντιμόω, to dishonor, slight, Jn. 8:49; Rom. 2:23; Jas. 2:6; to treat with indignity, Mk. 12:4; Lk. 20:11; Acts 5:41; to abuse, debase, Rom. 1:24*
ἀτιμία: dishonor, infamy, Rom. 1:26; shame, 1 Cor. 11:14; meanness, vileness, 1 Cor. 15:43; 2 Cor. 6:8; a dishonorable use, Rom. 9:21; 2 Tim. 2:20; κατὰ ἀτιμίαν, slightingly, disparagingly, 2 Cor. 11:21
ἄτιμος: unhonored, without honor, Mt. 13:57; Mk. 6:4; despised, 1 Cor. 4:10; 12:23*
ἀτμίς: an exhalation, vapor, smoke, Acts 2:19; Jas. 4:14*
ἄτομος: indivisible, and by impl. exceedingly minute; ἐν ἀτόμῳ, i.e. χρόνῳ, in an indivisible point of time, in an instant or moment, 1 Cor. 15:52*
ἄτοπος: pr. out of place; inopportune, unsuitable, absurd; new, unusual, strange; in NT improper, amiss, wicked, Lk. 23:41; Acts 25:5; 2 Thess. 3:2; noxious, harmful, Acts 28:6*
Ἀττάλεια: Attalia, a city of Pamphylia, Acts 14:25*. See PhotoGuide.
αὐγάζω: to see distinctly, discern, or possibly to shine, give light at 2 Cor. 4:4*
αὐθάδης: one who pleases himself, willful, obstinate; arrogant, stubborn, Tit. 1:7; 2 Pet. 2:10*
αὐθαίρετος: pr. one who chooses his own course of action; acting spontaneously, of one’s own accord, 2 Cor. 8:3, 17*
αὐθεντέω: to have authority over, domineer, 1 Tim. 2:12*
αὐλέω: to play on a pipe or flute, pipe, Mt. 11:17; Lk. 7:32; 1 Cor. 14:7*
αὐλή: pr. an unroofed enclosure; court-yard; sheepfold, Jn. 10:1, 16; an exterior court, i.q. προαύλιον, an enclosed place between the door and the street, Rev. 11:2; an interior court, quadrangle, the open court in the middle of Oriental houses, which are commonly built in the form of a square enclosing this court, Mt. 26:58, 69; by synec. a house, mansion, palace, Mt. 26:3; Lk. 11:21
αὐλητής: a player on a pipe or flute, Mt. 9:23; Rev. 18:22*
αὐλίζομαι: pr. to pass the time in a court-yard; to lodge; hence, to pass the night in any place, to lodge at night, pass or remain through the night, Mt. 21:17; Lk. 21:37*
αὐξάνω: also spelled αὔξω, trans. to cause to grow or increase; pass. to be increased, enlarged, Mt. 13:32; 1 Cor. 3:6, 7; intrans. to increase, grow, Mt. 6:28; Mk. 4:8
αὔριον: tomorrow, Mt. 6:30; ἡ αὔριον, i.e. ἡμέρα, the next day, Mt. 6:34
αὐστηρός: pr. harsh, sour in flavor; met. harsh, rigid, ungenerous, Lk. 19:21, 22*
αὐτάρκεια: a competence of the necessaries of life, 2 Cor. 9:8; a frame of mind viewing one’s lot as sufficient, contentedness, 1 Tim. 6:6*
αὐτάρκης: pr. sufficient or adequate in one’s self; contented with one’s lot, Phil. 4:11*
αὐτόματος: self-excited, acting spontaneously, spontaneous, of his own accord, Mk. 4:8; Acts 12:10*
αὐτός: self, very; alone, Mk. 6:31; 2 Cor. 12:13; of one’s self, of one’s own motion, Jn. 16:27; used also in the oblique cases independently as a personal pron. of the third person; ὁ αὐτός, the same; unchangeable, Heb. 1:12; κατὰ τὸ αὐτό, at the same time, together, Acts 14:1; ἐπὶ τὸ αὐτό, in one and the same place, Mt. 22:34; at the same time, together, Acts 3:1
αὐτόφωρος: pr. caught in the act of theft, Jn. 8:4*
αὐτόχειρ: acting or doing anything with one’s own hands, Acts 27:19*
αὐχμηρός: squalid, filthy; by impl. dark, obscure, murky, 2 Pet. 1:19*
ἀφαιρέω: to take away, remove, Lk. 1:25; 10:42; to take off, cut off, remove by cutting off, Mt. 26:15; Mk. 14:47; Lk. 22:50
ἀφανής: out of sight; not manifest, hidden, concealed, Heb. 4:13*
ἀφανίζω: to remove out of sight, cause to disappear; pass. to disappear, vanish, Jas. 4:14; by impl. to destroy, consume, so that nothing shall be left visible, Mt. 6:19, 20; met. to spoil, deform, disfigure, Mt. 6:16; to perish, Acts 13:41*
ἀφανισμός: a disappearing, vanishing away; met. destruction, abolition, abrogation, Heb. 8:13*
ἄφαντος: not appearing, not seen, invisible; hence, ἄφαντος γενέσθαι, to disappear, vanish, Lk. 24:31*
ἀφειδία: pr. the disposition of one who is ἀφειδής, unsparing; hence, in NT unsparingness in the way of rigorous treatment, non-indulgence, Col. 2:23*
ἄφεσις: dismission, deliverance, from captivity, Lk. 4:18 (2x); remission, forgiveness, pardon, Mt. 26:28
ἁφή: a fastening; a ligament, by which the different members are connected, commissure, joint, Eph. 4:16; Col. 2:19*
ἀφθαρσία: incorruptibility, 1 Cor. 15:42, 53, 54; immortality, Rom. 2:7; 2 Tim. 1:10; soundness, purity; ἐν ἀφθαρσίᾳ, purely, sincerely or constantly, unfailingly, Eph. 6:24
ἄφθαρτος: incorruptible, immortal, imperishable, undying, enduring, Rom. 1:23; 1 Cor. 9:25; 15:52
ἀφθορία: pr. incapability of decay; met. incorruptness, integrity, genuineness, purity, Tit. 2:7*
ἀφίημι: to send away, dismiss, suffer to depart; to emit, send forth; τὴν φωνήν, the voice, to cry out, utter an exclamation, Mk. 15:37; τὸ πνεῦμα, the spirit, to expire, Mt. 27:50; to omit, pass over or by; to let alone, care not for, Mt. 15:14; 23:23; Heb. 6:1; to permit, suffer, let, forbid not; to give up, yield, resign, Mt. 5:40; to remit, forgive, pardon; to relax, suffer to become less intense, Rev. 2:4; to leave, depart from; to desert, forsake; to leave remaining or alone; to leave behind, i.e. at one’s death, Mk. 12:19, 20, 21, 22; Jn. 14:27
ἀφικνέομαι: to come, arrive at; to reach as a report, Rom. 16:19*
ἀφιλάγαθος: not a lover of good and good men, 2 Tim. 3:3*
ἀφιλάργυρος: not fond of money, not covetous, generous, 1 Tim. 3:3; Heb. 13:5*
ἀφίστημι: trans. to put away, separate; to draw off or away, withdraw, induce to revolt, Acts 5:37; intrans., and mid., to depart, go away from, Lk. 2:37; met. to desist or refrain from, let alone, Acts 5:38; 22:29; 2 Cor. 12:8; to make defection, fall away, apostatize, Lk. 8:13; 1 Tim. 4:1; Heb. 3:12; to withdraw from, have no intercourse with, 1 Tim. 6:5; to abstain from, 2 Tim. 2:19
ἀφόβως: fearlessly, boldly, intrepidly, Phil. 1:14; securely, peacefully, tranquilly, Lk. 1:74; 1 Cor. 16:10; boldly, shamelessly, Jude 12*
ἀφομοιόω: to assimilate, cause to resemble, Heb. 7:3*
ἀφοράω: to view with undivided attention by looking away from every other object; to regard fixedly and earnestly, Heb. 12:2; to see distinctly, Phil. 2:23*
ἀφορίζω: to limit off; to separate, sever from the rest, Mt. 13:49; to separate from society, cut off from all intercourse, excommunicate, Lk. 6:22; to set apart, select, Acts 13:2; Rom. 1:1; Gal. 1:15
ἀφορμή: pr. a starting point; means to accomplish an object; occasion, opportunity, Rom. 7:8, 11
ἀφροσύνη: inconsiderateness, folly; boastful folly, 2 Cor. 11:1, 17, 21; in NT foolishness, levity, wickedness, impiety, Mk. 7:22*
ἄφρων: unwise, inconsiderate, simple, foolish, Lk. 11:40; 12:20; 1 Cor. 15:36; ignorant, religiously unenlightened, Rom. 2:20; Eph. 5:17; 1 Pet. 2:15; boastfully foolish, vain, 2 Cor. 11:16, 19
ἀφυπνόω: to awake from sleep; in NT to go off into sleep, fall asleep, Lk. 8:23*
ἄφωνος: dumb, destitute of the power of speech, 1 Cor. 12:2; 2 Pet. 2:16; silent, mute, uttering no voice, Acts 8:32; inarticulate, consisting of inarticulate sounds, unmeaning, 1 Cor. 14:10*
Ἀχαία: Achaia, the Roman province, comprehending all Greece to the south of Thessaly
ἀχειροποίητος: not made with hands, Mk. 14:58; 2 Cor. 5:1; Col. 2:11*
ἀχλύς: a mist; darkening, dimness, of the sight, Acts 13:11*
ἀχρεῖος: useless, unprofitable, worthless, Mt. 25:30; unmeritorious, Lk. 17:10*
ἀχρειόω: also ἀχρεόω, pass., to render useless; met., to become corrupt, depraved, Rom. 3:12*
ἄχρηστος: unuseful, useless, unprofitable, and by impl. detrimental, causing loss, Phlm. 11*
ἄχρι: improper prep with the gen., also functioning as a conj, also spelled ἄχρις (Gal. 3:19; Heb. 3:13; Rev. 2:25), with respect to place, as far as; to time, until, during; as a conj., until
ἄχυρον: chaff, straw broken up by treading out the grain, Mt. 3:12; Lk. 3:17*
ἀψευδής: free from falsehood; incapable of falsehood, Tit. 1:2*
ἄψυχος: void of life or sense, inanimate, 1 Cor. 14:7*
Βάαλ: Baal, (Hebrew for Master) pr. name, indecl., Rom. 11:4*
βαθμός: pr. a step, stair; met. grade of dignity, degree, rank, standing, 1 Tim. 3:13*
βάθος: depth; τὸ βάθος, deep water, Lk. 5:4; Mt. 13:5; met. fullness, abundance, immensity, Rom. 11:33; an extreme degree, 2 Cor. 8:2; pl. profundities, deep-laid plans, 1 Cor. 2:10; Rev. 2:24
βαθύς: deep, Jn. 4:11; met. deep, profound, Acts 20:9; Rev. 2:24; ὄρθρου βαθέος, lit. at deep morning twilight, at the earliest dawn, Lk. 24:1*
βαλλάντιον: also spelled βαλάντιον, a bag, purse, Lk. 10:4; 12:33; 22:35, 36*
βάλλω: pluperfect, ἐβεβλήμην, to throw, cast; to lay, Rev. 2:22; Mt. 8:6, 14; to put, place, Jas. 3:3; to place, deposit, Mt. 27:6; Mk. 12:41-44; Lk. 21:1-4; Jn. 12:6; to pour, Jn. 13:5; to thrust, Jn. 18:11; 20:27; Mk. 7:33; Rev. 14:19; to send forth, Mt. 10:34; to assault, strike, Mk. 14:65; met. to suggest, Jn. 13:2; intrans. to rush, beat, as the wind, Acts 27:14
βαπτίζω: pr. to dip, immerse; to cleanse or purify by washing; to administer the rite of baptism, to baptize; met. with various reference to the ideas associated with Christian baptism as an act of dedication, e.g. marked designation, devotion, trial, etc.; mid. to procure baptism for one’s self, to undergo baptism, Acts 22:16
βάπτισμα: pr. immersion; baptism, ordinance of baptism, Mt. 3:7; Rom. 6:4; met. baptism in the trial of suffering, Mt. 20:22, 23; Mk. 10:38, 39
βαπτισμός: pr. an act of dipping or immersion: a baptism, Col. 2:12; Heb. 6:2; an ablution, Mk. 7:4; Heb. 9:10*
βαπτιστής: one who baptizes, a baptist, Mt. 3:1; 11:11, 12
βάπτω: to dip, Jn. 13:26; Lk. 16:24; to dye, Rev. 19:13*
βάρβαρος: pr. one to whom a pure Greek dialect is not native; one who is not a proper Greek, a barbarian, Rom. 1:14; Col. 3:11; Acts 28:2, 4; a foreigner speaking a strange language, 1 Cor. 14:11*
βαρέω: to be heavy upon, weigh down, burden, oppress, as sleep, Mt. 26:43; Mk. 14:40; Lk. 9:32; calamities, 2 Cor. 1:8; 5:4; or, trouble, care, expense, etc. 1 Tim. 5:16*
βαρέως: heavily; met. with difficulty, dully, stupidly, Mt. 13:15; Acts 28:27*
Βαριωνᾶ: also Βὰρ Ἰωνᾶ or Βαριωνᾶς, Bar-jona, pr. name, Mt. 16:17*
βάρος: weight, heaviness; a burden, anything grievous and hard to be borne, Mt. 20:12; Acts 15:28; Gal. 6:2; Rev. 2:24; burden, charge or weight, influence, dignity, honor, 1 Thess. 2:7; with another noun in government, fulness, abundance, excellence, 2 Cor. 4:17*
Βαρσαββᾶς: Bar-sabas, pr. name (1) Joseph, surnamed Justus, Acts 1:23 (2) Judas, Acts 15:22*
βαρύς: heavy; met. burdensome, oppressive or difficult of observance, as precepts, Mt. 23:4; 1 Jn. 5:3; weighty, important, momentous, Mt. 23:23; Acts 25:7; grievous, oppressive, afflictive, violent, Acts 20:29; authoritative, strict, stern, severe, 2 Cor. 10:10*
βασανίζω: pr. to apply the lapis Lydius or touchstone; met. to examine, scrutinize, try, either by words or torture; in NT to afflict, torment; pass. to be afflicted, tormented, pained, by diseases, Mt. 8:6, 29, 35; to be tossed, agitated, as by the waves, Mt. 14:24
βασανισμός: pr. examination by torture; torment, torture, Rev. 9:5; 14:11; 18:7, 10, 15*
βασανιστής: pr. an inquisitor, tormentor; in NT a keeper of a prison, jailer, Mt. 18:34*
βάσανος: pr. lapis Lydius, a species of stone from Lydia, which being applied to metals was thought to indicate any alloy which might be mixed with them, and therefore used in the trial of metals; hence, examination of a person, especially by torture; in NT torture, torment, severe pain, Mt. 4:24; Lk. 16:23, 28*
βασιλεία: a kingdom, realm, the region or country governed by a king; kingly power, authority, dominion, reign; royal dignity, the title and honor of king; ἡ βασιλεία, Mt. 9:35, ἡ βασιλεία τοῦ θεοῦ or τοῦ Χριστοῦ or τοῦ οὐρανοῦ or τῶν οὐρανῶν, the reign or kingdom of the Messiah, both in a false and true conception of it; used also with various limitation, of its administration and coming history, as in the parables; its distinctive nature, Rom. 14:17; its requirements, privileges, rewards, consummation
βασίλειος: royal, regal; met. possessed of high prerogatives and distinction, 1 Pet. 2:9; τὰ βασίλεια, i.e. δώματα, regal mansion, palaces, Lk. 7:25*
βασιλεύς: a king, monarch, one possessing regal authority
βασιλεύω: to possess regal authority, be a king, reign; to rule, govern, Mt. 2:22; met. to be in force, predominate, prevail, Rom. 5:14, 17, 21; met. to be in kingly case, fare royally, 1 Cor. 4:8
βασιλικός: royal, regal, Acts 12:20, 21; βασιλικός, used as a subst. a person attached to the king, courtier, Jn. 4:46, 49; met. royal, of the highest excellence, Jas. 2:8*
βάσις: pr. a step; the foot, Acts 3:7*
βασκαίνω: pr. to slander; thence, to bewitch by spells, or by any other means; to delude, Gal. 3:1*
βαστάζω: pr. to lift, raise, bear aloft; to bear, carry in the hands or about the person; carry as a message, Acts 9:15; to take away, remove, Mt. 8:17; Jn. 20:15; to take up, Jn. 10:31; Lk. 14:27; to bear as a burden endure, suffer; to sustain, Rom. 11:18; to bear with, tolerate; to sustain mentally, comprehend, Jn. 16:12
βάτος: a bath, a measure for liquids, which is stated by Josephus (Ant. 8.57) to contain seventy-two sextarii, or about thirteen and one half gallons. Others estimate it to be nine gallons; and others, seven and one half gallons, Lk. 16:6*
βατταλογέω: also spelled βαττολογέω, pr. to stammer; hence, to babble; to use vain repetitions, Mt. 6:7*
βδέλυγμα: an abomination, an abominable thing, Mt. 24:15; Mk. 13:14; idolatry with all its pollution, Lk. 16:15; Rev. 17:4, 5; 21:27*
βδελύσσομαι: to abominate, loathe, detest, abhor, Rom. 2:22; pass. to be abominable, detestable, Rev. 21:8*
βέβαιος: firm, stable, steadfast, Heb. 3:14; 6:19; sure, certain, established, Rom. 4:16
βεβαιόω: to confirm, establish; to render constant and unwavering, 1 Cor. 1:8; to strengthen or establish by arguments or proofs, ratify, Mk. 16:20; to verify, as promises, Rom. 15:8
βέβηλος: pr. what is open and accessible to all; hence, profane, not religious, not connected with religion; unholy; a despiser, scorner, 1 Tim. 1:9; 4:7
βεβηλόω: to profane, pollute, violate, Mt. 12:5; Acts 24:6*
Βεελζεβούλ: variant spellings of Βεελζεβούβ and βεελζεβούλ, Beelzeboul, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 10:25
βελόνη: pr. the point of a spear; a needle, Lk. 18:25*
βέλος: a missile weapon, dart, arrow, Eph. 6:16*
βελτίων: better; βέλτιον, as an adv., very well, too well to need informing, 2 Tim. 1:18*
Βενιαμίν: Benjamin, pr. name, indecl. Acts 13:21; Rom. 11:1; Phil. 3:5; Rev. 7:8*
Βέροια: Berea, a town of Macedonia, Acts 17:10, 13*. See PhotoGuide.
Βηθανία: Bethany (1) A village near Jerusalem, at the Mount of Olives, Mt. 21:17; Mk. 11:1. (2) A village beyond the Jordan, Jn. 1:28. See PhotoGuide.
Βηθλέεμ: Bethlehem, indecl., a town in Palestine. See PhotoGuide.
Βηθσαϊδά: also spelled Βηθσαϊδάν (G1035) Bethsaida, indecl. (1) A city of Galilee, Mt. 11:21; Mk. 6:45,. (2) A city of Lower Gaulanitis, near the Lake of Gennesareth, Lk. 9:10. See PhotoGuide.
Βηθφαγή: Bethphage, indecl., a part of the Mount of Olives, Mt. 21:1; Mk. 11:1; Lk. 19:29*. See PhotoGuide.
βῆμα: a step, footstep, foot-breadth, space to set the foot on, Acts 7:5; an elevated place ascended by steps, tribunal, throne, Mt. 27:19; Acts 12:21
βήρυλλος: a beryl, a precious stone of a sea-green color, found chiefly in India, Rev. 21:20*
βιάζω: also written as a middle deponent, βιάζομαι, to urge, constrain, overpower by force; to press earnestly forward, to rush, Lk. 16:16; pass. to be an object of a forceful movement, Mt. 11:12*
βιαστής: one who uses violence, or is impetuous; one who is forceful in eager pursuit, Mt. 11:12*
βιβλαρίδιον: a small volume or scroll, a little book, Rev. 10:2, 9, 10*
βιβλίον: a written volume or roll, book, Lk. 4:17, 20; a scroll, bill, billet, Mt. 19:7; Mk. 10:4
βίβλος: pr. the inner bark or rind of the papyrus, which was anciently used instead of paper; hence, a written volume or roll, book, catalogue, account, Mt. 1:1; Mk. 12:26
Βιθυνία: Bithynia, a province of Asia Minor, Acts 16:7; 1 Pet. 1:1*
βίος: life; means of living; sustenance, maintenance, substance, goods, Mk. 12:44, Lk. 8:14, 43; 15:12, 30; 21:4; 1 Tim. 2:2; 2 Tim. 2:4; 1 Jn. 2:16; 3:17*
βιωτικός: pertaining to this life or the things of this life, Lk. 21:34; 1 Cor. 6:3, 4*
βλάπτω: pr. to weaken, hinder, disable; to hurt, harm, injure, Mk. 16:18; Lk. 4:35*
βλαστάνω: also spelled βλαστάω, intrans. to germinate, bud, sprout, spring up, Mt. 13:26; Mk. 4:27; Heb. 9:4; trans. and causative, to cause to shoot, to produce, yield, Jas. 5:18*
βλασφημέω: to defame, revile, slander, Mt. 27:39; to speak of God or divine things in terms of impious irreverence, to blaspheme, Mt. 9:3; 26:65
βλασφημία: slander, railing, reproach, Mt. 15:19; Mk. 7:22; blasphemy, Mt. 12:31; 26:65
βλάσφημος: slanderous, railing, reproachful, 2 Tim. 3:2; 2 Pet. 2:11; blasphemous, Acts 6:11, 13; 1 Tim. 1:13
βλέμμα: a look; the act of seeing, sight, 2 Pet. 2:8*
βλέπω: to have the faculty of sight, to see, Mt. 12:22; to exercise sight, to see, Mt. 6:4; to look towards or at, Mt. 22:16; to face, Acts 27:12; to take heed, Mt. 24:4; in NT, βλέπειν ἀπό, to beware of, shun, Mk. 8:15; trans., to cast a look on, Mt. 5:28; to see, behold, Mt. 13:17; to observe, Mt. 7:3; to have an eye to, see to, Mk. 13:9; Col. 4:17; 2 Jn. 8; to discern mentally, perceive, Rom. 7:23; 2 Cor. 7:8; Jas. 2:22; to guard against, Phil. 3:2; pass., to be an object of sight, be visible, Rom. 8:24
βλητέος: requiring to be cast or put, Lk. 5:38*
βοάω: to cry out; to exclaim, proclaim, Mt. 3:3; 15:34; Acts 8:7; πρός τινα, to invoke, implore the aid of any one, Lk. 18:7
βοήθεια: help, succor, Heb. 4:16; meton. pl. helps, contrivances for relief and safety, Acts 27:17*
βοηθέω: to run to the aid of those who cry for help; to advance to the assistance of any one, help, aid, succor, Mt. 15:25; Mk. 9:22, 24
βόθυνος: a pit, well or cistern, Mt. 12:11; 15:14; Lk. 6:39*
βολή: a cast, a throw; the distance to which a thing can be thrown, Lk. 22:41*
Βόος: also spelled Βόοζ, Boaz, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 3:32*
βορρᾶς: pr. the north or N.N.E. wind; meton. the north, Lk. 13:29; Rev. 21:13*
βόσκω: to feed, pasture, tend while grazing; βόσκομαι, to feed, be feeding, Mt. 8:30, 33; Lk. 8:32, 34
βοτάνη: herb, herbage, produce of the earth, Heb. 6:7*
βότρυς: a bunch or cluster of grapes, Rev. 14:18*
βουλευτής: a counsellor, senator; member of the Sanhedrin, Mk. 15:43; Lk. 23:50*
