βουλεύω: mid., to give counsel; to deliberate, Lk. 14:31; Jn. 12:10; 11:53; to purpose, determine, Acts 27:39; 2 Cor. 1:17 (2x)*
βουλή: counsel, purpose, design, determination, decree, Lk. 7:30; 23:51, et al. freq.; by impl. secret thoughts, cogitations of the mind, 1 Cor. 4:5
βούλημα: purpose, will, determination, Acts 27:43; Rom. 9:19; 1 Pet. 4:3*
βούλομαι: to be willing, disposed, Mk. 15:15; Acts 25:20; 28:18; to intend, Mt. 1:19; Acts 5:28; 12:4; 2 Cor. 1:15; to desire, 1 Tim. 6:9; to choose, be pleased, Jn. 18:39; Acts 18:15; Jas. 3:4; to will, decree, appoint, Lk. 22:42; Jas. 1:18; 1 Cor. 12:11; 1 Tim. 2:8; 5:14; ἐβουλόμην, I could wish, Acts 25:22
βοῦς: an ox, a bull or cow, an animal of the ox kind, Lk. 13:15
βραβεῖον: a prize bestowed on victors in the public games, such as a crown, wreath, chaplet, garland, etc., 1 Cor. 9:24; Phil. 3:14*
βραβεύω: pr. to be a director or arbiter in the public games; in NT to preside, direct, rule, govern, be predominate, Col. 3:15*
βραδύνω: to be slow, to delay, 1 Tim. 3:15; 2 Pet. 3:9*
βραδύς: slow, not hasty, Jas. 1:19; slow of understanding, heavy, stupid, Lk. 24:25*
βραχίων: the arm; the arm as a symbol of power, Lk. 1:51; Jn. 12:38; Acts 13:17*
βραχύς: short, brief; few, small, Lk. 22:58; Jn. 6:7; Acts 5:34; 27:28; Heb. 2:7, 9; 13:22*
βρέφος: a child; whether unborn, an embryo, fetus, Lk. 1:41, 44; or just born, an infant, Lk. 2:12, 16; Acts 7:19; or partly grown, Lk. 18:15; 2 Tim. 3:15; met. a babe in simplicity of faith, 1 Pet. 2:2*
βρέχω: to wet, moisten, Lk. 7:38; to rain, cause or send rain, Mt. 5:45; Lk. 17:29
βρύχω: to grate or gnash the teeth, Acts 7:54*
βρύω: pr. to be full, to swell with anything; to emit, send forth, Jas. 3:11*
βρῶμα: food, Mt. 14:15; Mk. 7:19; solid food, 1 Cor. 3:2
βρώσιμος: eatable, that may be eaten, Lk. 24:41*
βρῶσις: eating, the act of eating, Rom. 14:17; 1 Cor. 8:4; meat, food, Jn. 6:27; Heb. 12:16; a canker or rust, Mt. 6:19, 20
βυθίζω: to immerse, submerge, cause to sink, Lk. 5:7; to plunge deep, drown, 1 Tim. 6:9*
βυθός: the bottom, lowest part; the deep, sea, 2 Cor. 11:25*
βύσσινος: made of fine linen or fine cotton, Rev. 18:16; 18:8 (2x), 14*
βύσσος: byssus, a species of fine cotton highly prized by the ancients, Lk. 16:19*
βωμός: pr. a slightly-elevated spot, base, pedestal; hence, an altar, Acts 17:23*
Γαδαρηνός: an inhabitant of Gadara, the chief city of Perea, Mt. 8:28*
γαζοφυλάκιον: also spelled γαζοφυλακεῖον, a treasury; the sacred treasure, Mk. 12:41, 43; Lk. 21:1; Jn. 8:20*
Γάϊος: Gaius, pr. name. (1) Of Macedonia, Acts 19:29. (2) Of Corinth, 1 Cor. 1:14. (3) Of Derbe, Acts 20:4. (4) A Christian to whom John addressed his third Epistle, 3 Jn. 1; Rom. 16:23*
γάλα: milk, 1 Cor. 9:7; met. spiritual milk, consisting in the elements of Christian instruction, 1 Cor. 3:2; Heb. 5:12, 13; spiritual nutriment, 1 Pet. 2:2*
Γαλάτης: a Galatian, inhabitant of Galatia, Gal. 3:1*
Γαλατία: Galatia or Gallo-Graecia, a province of Asia Minor, 1 Cor. 6:1; Gal. 1:2; 2 Tim. 4:10; 1 Pet. 1:1*
γαλήνη: tranquillity of the sea, a calm, Mt. 8:26; Mk. 4:39; Lk. 8:24*
Γαλιλαία: Galilee, a district of Palestine north of Samaria, Mt. 4:15
Γαλιλαῖος: a native of Galilee, Mt. 26:69; Mk. 14:70; Lk. 13:1; Jn. 4:45; Acts 1:11
γαμέω: to marry, Mt. 5:32, et al.; absol. to marry, enter the marriage state, Mt. 19:10, et al.; mid. to marry, be married, Mk. 10:12; 1 Cor. 7:39
γαμίζω: also spelled γαμίσκω, to give in marriage, permit to marry, 1 Cor. 7:38
γάμος: a wedding; nuptial festivities, a marriage festival, Mt. 22:2; 25:10; Jn. 2:1, 2; Rev. 19:7, 9; any feast or banquet, Lk. 12:36; 14:8; the marriage state, Heb. 13:4
γάρ: for; it is, however, frequently used with an ellipsis of the clause to which it has reference, and its force must then be variously expressed: Mt. 15:27; 27:23, et al.; it is also sometimes epexegetic, or introductory of an intimated detail of circumstances, now, then, Mt. 1:18
γαστήρ: the belly, stomach; the womb, Lk. 1:31; ἐν γαστρὶ ἔχειν, to be with child, Mt. 1:18, 23; 24:19, et al.; γαστέρες, gluttons, Tit. 1:12
γε: an enclitic particle imparting emphasis; indicating that a particular regard is to be had to the term to which it is attached. Its force is to be conveyed, when this is possible, by various expression; at least, indeed, even
γέεννα: Gehenna, pr. the valley of Hinnom, south of Jerusalem, once celebrated for the horrid worship of Moloch, and afterwards polluted with every species of filth, as well as the carcasses of animals, and dead bodies of malefactors; to consume which, in order to avert the pestilence which such a mass of corruption would occasion, constant fires were kept burning; hence, hell, the fires of Tartarus, the place of punishment in Hades, Mt. 5:22, 29, 30; 10:28; 18:9, et al.
Γεθσημανί: Gethsemane, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 26:36; Mk. 14:32*
γελάω: to laugh, smile; by impl. to be merry, happy, to rejoice, Lk. 6:21, 25*
γέλως: laughter; by impl. mirth, joy, rejoicing, Jas. 4:9*
γέμω: to be full, Mt. 23:27; Lk. 11:39, et al.
γενεά: pr. birth; hence, progeny; a generation of mankind, Mt. 11:16; 23:36, et al.; a generation, a step in a genealogy, Mt. 1:17; a generation, an interval of time, an age; in NT course of life, in respect of its events, interests, or character, Lk. 16:8; Acts 13:36
γενεαλογέω: to reckon one’s descent, derive one’s origin, Heb. 7:6*
γενεαλογία: genealogy, catalogue of ancestors, history of descent, 1 Tim. 1:4; Tit. 3:9*
γενέσια: pr. a day observed in memory of the dead; in NT equivalent to γενέθλια, celebration of one’s birthday, birthday-festival, Mt. 14:6; Mk. 6:21*
γένεσις: birth, nativity, Mt. 1:18; Lk. 1:14; Jas. 1:23; successive generation, descent, lineage, Mt. 1:1; meton. life, Mt. 1:18; Jas. 3:6*
γένημα: natural produce, fruit, increase, Mt. 26:29; Mk. 14:25; Lk. 12:18; 22:18; 2 Cor. 9:10*
γεννάω: to beget, generate, Mt. 1:2-16, et al.; of women, to bring forth, bear, give birth to, Lk. 1:13, 57, et al.; pass. to be born, produced, Mt. 2:1, 4, et al.; met. to produce, excite, give occasion to, effect, 2 Tim. 2:23; from the Hebrew, to constitute as son, to constitute as king, or as the representative or viceregent of God, Acts 13:33; Heb. 1:5; 5:5; by impl. to be a parent to any one; pass. to be a son or child to any one, Jn. 1:13; 1 Cor. 4:15, et al.
γέννημα: what is born or produced, offspring, progeny, brood, Mt. 3:7; 12:34, et al.; fruit, produce, Mt. 26:29; Mk. 14:25, et al.; fruit, increase, Lk. 12:18; 2 Cor. 9:10
Γεννησαρέτ: Gennesaret, a lake of Palestine, called also the Sea of Tiberias, Mt. 14:34; Mk. 6:53; Lk. 5:1*
γεννητός: born or produced of, Mt. 11:11; Lk. 7:28*
γένος: offspring, progeny, Acts 17:28, 29; family, kindred, lineage, Acts 7:13, et al.; race, nation, people, Mk. 7:26; Acts 4:36, et al.; kind, sort, species, Mt. 13:47, et al.
Γερασηνός: also spelled Γεργεσηνός, from Gerasene, belonging to the city of Gerasa, Mk. 5:1; Lk. 8:26, 37*. See PhotoGuide
γερουσία: a senate, assembly of elders; the elders of Israel collectively, Acts 5:21*
γεύομαι: to taste, Mt. 27:34; Jn. 2:9; absol. to take food, Acts 10:10, et al.; met. to have perception of, experience, Heb. 6:4, 5; 1 Pet. 2:3; θανάτου γεύεσθαι, to experience death, to die, Mt. 16:28, et al.
γεωργέω: to cultivate, till the earth, Heb. 6:7*
γεώργιον: cultivated field or ground, a farm, 1 Cor. 3:9*
γεωργός: a farmer, one who tills the earth, 2 Tim. 2:6; Jas. 5:7; in NT spc. a vine-dresser, keeper of a vineyard, i.q. ἀμπελουργός, Mt. 21:33, 34, et al.
γῆ: earth, soil, Mt. 13:5; Mk. 4:8, et al.; the ground, surface of the earth, Mt. 10:29; Lk. 6:49, et al.; the land, as opposed to the sea or a lake, Lk. 5:11; Jn. 21:8, 9, 11; the earth, world, Mt. 5:18, 35, et al.; by synec. the inhabitants of the earth, Mt. 5:13; 6:10; 10:34; a land, region, tract, country, territory, Mt. 2:20; 14:34;by way of eminence, the chosen land, Mt. 5:5; 24:30; 27:45; Eph. 6:3; the inhabitants of a region or country, Mt. 10:15; 11:24, et al.
γηράσκω: to be or become old, Jn. 21:18; Heb. 8:13*
γίνομαι: pluperfect, ἐγενόει (3rd sg), to come into existence; to be created, exist by creation, Jn. 1:3, 10; Heb. 11:3; Jas. 3:9; to be born, produced, grow, Mt. 21:19; Jn. 8:58, et al.; to arise, come on, occur, as the phenomena of nature, etc.; Mt. 8:24, 26; 9:16, et al.; to come, approach, as morning or evening, Mt. 8:16; 14:15, 23; to be appointed, constituted, established, Mk. 2:27; Gal. 3:17, et al.; to take place, come to pass, happen, occur, Mt. 1:22; 24:6, 20, 21, 34, et al. freq.; to be done, performed, effected, Mt. 21:42, et al.; to be fulfilled, satisfied, Mt. 6:10; 26:42, et al.; to come into a particular state or condition; to become, assume the character and appearance of anything, Mt. 5:45, et al.; to become or be made anything, be changed or converted, Mt. 4:3; 21:42; Mk. 1:17, et al.; to be, Mt. 11:26; 19:8; γίνεσθαι ὑπό τινα, to be subject to, Gal. 4:4; γίνεσθαι ἐν ἑαυτῷ, to come to one’s self, to recover from a trance or surprise, Acts 12:11; μὴ γένοιτο, let it not be, far be it from, God forbid, Lk. 20:16; Rom. 3:4, 31, et al.; to be kept, celebrated, solemnized, as festivals, Mt. 26:2, et al.; to be finished, completed, Heb. 4:3
γινώσκω: to know, whether the action be inceptive or complete and settled; to perceive, Mt. 22:18; Mk. 5:29; 8:17; 12:12; Lk. 8:46; to mark, discern, Mt. 25:24; Lk. 19:44; to ascertain by examination, Mk. 6:38; Jn. 7:51; Acts 23:28; to understand, Mk. 4:13; Lk. 18:34; Jn. 12:16; 13:7; Acts 8:30; 1 Cor. 14:7, 9; to acknowledge, Mt. 7:23; 2 Cor. 3:2; to resolve, conclude, Lk. 16:4; Jn. 7:26; 17:8; to be assured, Lk. 21:20; Jn. 6:69; 8:52; 2 Pet. 1:20; to be skilled, to be master of a thing, Mt. 16:3; Acts 21:37; to know carnally, Mt. 1:25; Lk. 1:34; from the Hebrew, to view with favor, 1 Cor. 8:3; Gal. 4:9
γλεῦκος: pr. the unfermented juice of grapes; hence, sweet new wine, Acts 2:13*
γλῶσσα: the tongue, Mk. 7:33, 35, et al.; meton. speech, talk, 1 Jn. 3:18; a tongue, language, Acts 2:11; 1 Cor. 13:1, et al.; meton. a language not proper to a speaker, a gift or faculty of such language, Mk. 16:17; 1 Cor. 14:13, 14, 26, et al.; from Hebrew, a nation, as defined by its language, Rev. 5:9, et al.; lit. a tongue-shaped flail, Acts 2:3
γλωσσόκομον: pr. a box for keeping the tongues, mouth-pieces, or reeds of musical instruments; hence, genr. any box or receptacle; in NT a purse, money-bag, Jn. 12:6; 13:29*
γνήσιος: lawful, legitimate, as children; genuine, in faith, etc.; 1 Tim. 1:2; Tit. 1:4; true, sincere, 2 Cor. 8:8; Phil. 4:3*
γνώμη: the mind, as the means of knowing and judging; assent, Phlm. 14; purpose, resolution, Acts 20:3; opinion, judgment, 1 Cor. 1:10; 7:40; suggestion, suggested advice, as distinguished from positive injunction, Acts 20:3; 1 Cor. 7:25; 2 Cor. 8:10
γνωρίζω: to make known, reveal, declare, Jn. 15:15; 17:26, et al.; to know, Phil. 1:22
γνῶσις: knowledge, Lk. 1:77; knowledge of an especial kind and relatively high character, Lk. 11:52; Rom. 2:20; 1 Tim. 6:20; more particularly in respect of Christian enlightenment, Rom. 15:14; 1 Cor. 8:10; 12:8; 2 Cor. 11:6, et al.
γνώστης: one acquainted with a thing, knowing, skilful, Acts 26:3*
γνωστός: known, Jn. 18:15, 16, et al.; certain, incontrovertible, Acts 4:16; τὸ γνωστόν, that which is known or is cognizable, the unquestionable attributes, Rom. 1:19; subst. an acquaintance, Lk. 2:44; 23:49
γογγύζω: to speak privately and in a low voice, mutter, Jn. 7:32; to utter secret and sullen discontent, express indignant complaint, murmur, grumble, Mt. 20:11; Lk. 5:30; Jn. 6:41, 43, 61; 1 Cor. 10:10*
γογγυσμός: a muttering, murmuring, low and suppressed discourse, Jn. 7:12; the expression of secret and sullen discontent, murmuring, complaint, Acts 6:1; Phil. 2:14; 1 Pet. 4:9*
γόης: a juggler, diviner; hence, by impl. an impostor, cheat, 2 Tim. 3:13*
Γολγοθᾶ: Golgotha, pr. name, Mt. 27:33; Mk. 15:22; Jn. 19:17*
Γόμορρα: Gomorrha (Gen. 19), pr. name, Mt. 10:15; Rom. 9:29; 2 Pet. 2:6; Jude 7*
γόμος: the cargo of a ship, Acts 21:3; by impl. merchandise, Rev. 18:11, 12*
γονεύς: a father; pl. in NT parents, Mt. 10:21; Lk. 2:27, 41; 2 Cor. 12:14
γόνυ: the knee, Lk. 22:41; Heb. 12:12, et al.
γονυπετέω: to fall upon one’s knees, to kneel before, Mt. 17:14; 27:29; Mk. 1:40; 10:17*
γράμμα: pr. that which is written or drawn; a letter, character of the alphabet, a writing, book, Jn. 5:47; an acknowledgment of debt, an account, a bill, note, Lk. 16:6, 7; an epistle, letter, Acts 28:21; Gal. 6:11; ἱερὰ γράμματα, the sacred books of the Old Testament, the Jewish Scriptures, 2 Tim. 3:15; spc. the letter of the law of Moses, the bare literal sense, Rom. 2:27, 29; 7:6; 2 Cor. 3:6, 7; pl. letters, learning, Jn. 7:15; Acts 26:24*
γραμματεύς: a scribe; a clerk, town-clerk, registrar, recorder, Acts 19:35; one skilled in the Jewish law, a teacher or interpreter of the law, Mt. 2:4; 5:20, et al. freq.; genr. a religious teacher, Mt. 13:52; by synec. any one distinguished for learning or wisdom, 1 Cor. 1:20
γραφή: a writing; in NT the Holy Scriptures, the Jewish Scriptures, or Books of the Old Testament, Mt. 21:42; Jn. 5:39, et al.; by synec. doctrines, declarations, oracles, or promises contained in the sacred books, Mt. 22:29; Mk. 12:24, et al.; spc. a prophecy, Mt. 26:54; Mk. 14:49; Lk. 4:21; 24:27, 32; with the addition of προφητική, Rom. 16:26; of τῶν προφητῶν, Mt. 26:56
γράφω: to engrave, write, according to the ancient method of writing on plates of metal, waxes tables, etc., Jn. 8:6, 8; to write on parchment, paper, etc., generally, Mt. 27:37, et al.; to write letters to another, Acts 23:25; 2 Cor. 2:9; 13:10, et al.; to describe in writing, Jn. 1:46; Rom. 10:5; to inscribe in a catalogue, etc., Lk. 10:20; Rev. 13:8; 17:8, et al.; to write a law, command, or enact in writing, Mk. 10:5; 12:19; Lk. 2:23, et al.
γραώδης: old-womanish; by impl. silly, absurd, 1 Tim. 4:7*
γρηγορέω: to be awake, to watch, Mt. 26:38, 40, 41; Mk. 14:34; 37, 38; to be alive, 1 Thess. 5:10; met. to be watchful, attentive, vigilant, circumspect, Mt. 25:13; Mk. 13:35, et al.
γυμνάζω: pr. to train in gymnastic discipline; hence, to exercise in anything, train to use, discipline, 1 Tim. 4:7; Heb. 5:14; 12:11; 2 Pet. 2:14*
γυμνασία: pr. gymnastic exercise; hence, bodily discipline of any kind, 1 Tim. 4:8*
γυμνός: naked, without clothing, Mk. 14:51, 52; without the upper garment, and clad only with an inner garment or tunic, Jn. 21:7; poorly or meanly clad, destitute of proper and sufficient clothing, Mt. 25:36, 38, 43, 44; Acts 19:16; Jas. 2:15; met. unclothed with a body, 2 Cor. 5:3; not covered, uncovered, open, manifest, Heb. 4:13; bare, mere, 1 Cor. 15:37; naked of spiritual clothing, Rev. 3:17; 16:15; 17:16
γυμνότης: nakedness; want of proper and sufficient clothing, Rom. 8:35; 2 Cor. 11:27; spiritual nakedness, being destitute of spiritual clothing, Rev. 3:18*
γυναικάριον: a little woman; a trifling, weak, silly woman, 2 Tim. 3:6*
γυνή: a woman, Mt. 5:28, et al.; a married woman, wife, Mt. 5:31, 32; 14:3, et al.; in the voc. ὦ γύναι, O woman! an ordinary mode of addressing females under every circumstance; met. used of the Church, as united to Christ, Rev. 19:7; 21:9
Γώγ: Gog, pr. name of a nation, indecl., Rev. 20:8*
γωνία: an exterior angle, projecting corner, Mt. 6:5; 21:42; an interior angle; by impl. a dark corner, obscure place, Acts 26:26; corner, extremity, or quarter of the earth, Rev. 7:1; 20:8
δαιμονίζομαι: in NT to be possessed, afflicted, vexed, by a demon or evil spirit, i.q. δαιμόνιον ἔχειν, Mt. 4:24; 8:16, 28, 33
δαιμόνιον: a heathen god, deity, Acts 17:18; 1 Cor. 10:20, 21; Rev. 9:20; in NT, a demon, evil spirit, Mt. 7:22; 9:33, 34; 10:8; 12:24
δαιμονιώδης: pertaining to or proceeding from demons; demonic, devilish, Jas. 3:15*
δαίμων: a god, a superior power; in NT a malignant demon, evil angel, Mt. 8:31*
δάκνω: to bite, sting; met. to molest, vex, injure, Gal. 5:15*
δακτύλιος: a ring for the finger, Lk. 15:22*
δάκτυλος: a finger, Mt. 23:4; Mk. 7:33; from Hebrew, power, Lk. 11:20
Δαλμανουθά: Dalmanutha, indecl., a small town on the shore of the Sea of Tiberias, Mk. 8:10*
δαμάζω: also spelled δανείζω, to subdue, tame, Mk. 5:4; Jas. 3:7; met. to restrain within proper limits, Jas. 3:8*
Δαμασκηνός: A Damascene, a native of Damascus, 2 Cor. 11:32*
Δαμασκός: Damascus, the capital city of Syria
δαπανάω: to expend, be at expense, Mk. 5:26; Acts 21:24; 2 Cor. 12:15; to spend, waste, consume by extravagance, Lk. 15:14; Jas. 4:3*
Δαυίδ: also spelled Δανείδ and Δαβίδ, David, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:6; Lk. 1:27; Acts 2:29; Rom. 1:3; 2 Tim. 2:28
δέ: a conjunctive particle, marking the superaddition of a clause, whether in opposition or in continuation, to what has preceded, and it may be variously rendered but, on the other hand, and, also, now, etc.; καὶ δέ, when there is a special superaddition in continuation, too, yea, etc. It sometimes is found at the commencement of the apodosis of a sentence, Acts 11:17. It serves also to mark the resumption of an interrupted discourse, 2 Cor. 2:10; Gal. 2:6
δεῖ: it is binding, it is necessary, it is proper; it is inevitable, Acts 21:22
δεῖγμα: pr. that which is shown, a specimen, sample; met. an example by way of warning, Jude 7*
δειγματίζω: to make a public show or spectacle of, Mt. 1:19; Col. 2:15*
δείκνυμι: also formed as δεικνύω   3x, to show, point out, present to the sight, Mt. 4:8; 8:4; to exhibit, permit to see, cause to be seen, Jn. 2:18; 10:32; 1 Tim. 6:15; to demonstrate, prove, Jas. 2:18; 3:13; met. to teach, make known, declare, announce, Mt. 16:21; Jn. 5:20; Acts 10:28
δειλιάω: to be timid, be in fear, Jn. 14:27*
δειλός: timid, fearful, cowardly, Mt. 8:26; Mk. 4:40; Rev. 21:8*
δεῖνα: such a one, a certain one, Mt. 26:18*
δεινῶς: dreadfully, grievously, greatly, terribly, Mt. 8:6; Lk. 11:53*
δειπνέω: to eat or dine, Lk. 17:8; 22:20; 1 Cor. 11:25; Rev. 3:20
δεῖπνον: pr. a meal; supper, the principal meal taken in the evening, Lk. 14:12; Jn. 13:2, 4; meton. food, 1 Cor. 11:21; a feast, banquet, Mt. 23:6; Mk. 6:21; 12:39
δεισιδαιμονία: fear of the gods; in a bad sense, superstition; a form of religious belief, Acts 25:19*
δεισιδαίμων: reverencing the gods and divine things, religious; in a bad sense, superstitious; in NT careful and precise in the discharge of religious services, Acts 17:22*
δέκα: ten, Mt. 20:24; 25:1; ἡμερῶν δέκα, ten days, a few days, a short time, Rev. 2:10
Δεκάπολις: Decapolis, a district of Palestine beyond Jordan, Mk. 5:20; 7:31; Mt. 4:25*
δέκατος: tenth, Jn. 1:39; Rev. 11:13; 21:20; δεκάτη, i.e. μερίς, a tenth part, tithe, Heb. 7:2, 4, 8, 9*
δεκατόω: to cause to pay tithes; pass. to be tithed, pay tithes, Heb. 7:6, 9*
δεκτός: accepted, acceptable, agreeable, approved, Lk. 4:24; Acts 10:35; Phil. 4:18; by impl. when used of a certain time, marked by divine acceptance, propitious, Lk. 4:19; 2 Cor. 6:2*
δελεάζω: pr. to entrap, take or catch with a bait; met. allure, entice, Jas. 1:14; 2 Pet. 2:14, 18*
δεξιολάβος: one posted on the right hand; a flank guard; a light armed spearman, Acts 23:23*
δεξιός: right, as opposed to left, Mt. 5:29, 30; Lk. 6:6; ἡ δεξιά, i.e. χείρ, the right hand, Mt. 6:3; 27:29; τὰ δεξιά, i.e. μέρη, the parts towards the right hand, the right hand side; καθίζειν, or, καθῆσθαι, or, ἑστάναι, ἐκ δεξιῶν [μερῶν] τινος, to sit or stand at the right hand of any one, as a mark of the highest honor and dignity which he can bestow, Mt. 20:20; 26:64; εἶνι ἐκ δεξιῶν [μερῶν] τινος, to be at one’s right hand, as a helper, Acts 2:25; δεξιὰς (χεῖρας) διδόναι, to give the right hand to any one, as a pledge of sincerity in one’s promises, Gal. 2:9
δέομαι: to be in want, to need; to ask, request, Mt. 9:38; Lk. 5:12; 8:28, 38; in NT absol. to pray, offer prayer, beseech, supplicate, Lk. 21:36; 22:32; Acts 4:31; 8:22, 24
Δέρβη: Derbe, a city of Lycaonia, Acts 14:6, 20; 16:0*. See PhotoGuide.
δέρμα: the skin of an animal, Heb. 11:37*
δερμάτινος: made of skin, leathern, Mt. 3:4; Mk. 1:6*
δέρω: to skin, flay; hence, to eat, scourge, beat, Mt. 21:35; Mk. 12:3, 5; 13:9
δεσμεύω: to bind, bind up, as a bundle, Mt. 23:4; to bind, confine, Lk. 8:29; Acts 22:4*
δέσμη: a bundle, as of tares, Mt. 13:30*
δέσμιος: one bound, a prisoner, Mt. 27:15, 16; Mk. 15:6
δεσμός: a bond, anything by which one is bound, a cord, chain, fetters, etc.; and by meton. imprisonment, Lk. 8:29; Acts 16:26; 20:23; a string or ligament, as of the tongue, Mk. 7:35; met. an impediment, infirmity, Lk. 13:16
δεσμοφύλαξ: a keeper of a prison, jailer, Acts 16:23, 27, 36*
δεσπότης: a lord, master, especially of slaves, 1 Tim. 6:1, 2; 2 Tim. 2:21; Tit. 2:9; 1 Pet. 2:18; by impl. as denoting the possession of supreme authority, Lord, sovereign, used of God, Lk. 2:29; Acts 4:24; Rev. 6:10; and of Christ, 2 Pet. 2:1; Jude 4
δεῦρο: here; used also as a sort of imperative, come, Come here! Mt. 19:21; Mk. 10:21; used of time, ἄχρι τοῦ δεῦρο, i.e. χρόνου, to the present time, Rom. 1:13
δεῦτε: come, Mt. 4:19; 11:28; as a particle of exhortation, incitement, etc., and followed by an imperative, come now, etc., Mt. 21:38; 28:6
δευτεραῖος: on the second day of a certain state or process, and used as an epithet of the subject or agent, Acts 28:13*
δεύτερος: second, Mt. 22:26; τὸ δεύτερον, again, the second time, another time, Jude 5; so ἐκ δευτέρου, Mt. 26:42; and ἐν τῷ δευτέρῳ, Acts 7:13
δέχομαι: to take into one’s hands, etc., Lk. 2:28; 16:6, 7; to receive, Acts 22:5; 28:21; Phil. 4:18; to receive into and retain, contain, Acts 3:21; met. to receive by the hearing, learn, acquire a knowledge of, 2 Cor. 11:4; Jas. 1:21; to receive, admit, grant access to, receive kindly, welcome, Mt. 10:40, 41; 18:5; to receive in hospitality, entertain, Lk. 9:53; Heb. 11:31; to bear with, bear patiently, 2 Cor. 11:16; met. to receive, approve, assent to, Mt. 11:14; Lk. 8:13; Acts 8:14; 11:1; to admit, and by impl. to embrace, follow, 1 Cor. 2:14; 2 Cor. 8:17
δέω: to bind, tie, Mt. 13:30; 21:2; to bind, confine, Mt. 27:2; 14:3; to impede, hinder, 2 Tim. 2:9; to bind with infirmity, Lk. 13:16; to bind by a legal or moral tie, as marriage, Rom. 7:2; 1 Cor. 7:27, 39; by impl. to impel, compel, Acts 20:22; in NT to pronounce or declare to be binding or obligatory, or, to declare to be prohibited and unlawful, Mt. 16:19; 18:18
δή: a particle that adds an intensity of expression to a term or clause. Its simplest and most ordinary uses are when it gives impressiveness to an affirmation, indeed, really, doubtless, Mt. 13:23; or earnestness to a call, injunction, or entreaty, Lk. 2:15; Acts 13:2; 15:36; 1 Cor. 16:20*
δῆλος: pr. clearly visible; plain, manifest, evident, Mt. 26:73; 1 Cor. 15:27; Gal. 3:11*
δηλόω: to render manifest or evident; to make known, to tell, relate, declare, 1 Cor. 1:11; Col. 1:8; to show, point out, bring to light, 1 Cor. 3:13; to indicate, signify, Heb. 9:8; 12:27; 1 Pet. 1:11
Δημᾶς: Demas, pr. name, Col. 4:14; 2 Tim. 4:10; Phlm. 24*
δημηγορέω: to address a public assembly, to deliver a public oration, Acts 12:21*
Δημήτριος: Demetrius, pr. name (1) The Ephesian silversmith, Acts 19:24, 38 (2) A certain Christian, 3 Jn. 12*
δημιουργός: pr. one who labors for the public, or, exercises some public calling; an architect, especially, the Divine Architect of the universe, Heb. 11:10
δημόσιος: public, belonging to the public, Acts 5:18; δημοσίᾳ, publicly, Acts 16:37; 18:28; 20:20*
δηνάριον: Latin denarius, a Roman silver coin; the name originally meant ten asses, Mt. 18:28; Mk. 6:37; Rev. 6:6
δήπου: now in some way, surely, Heb. 2:16*
διά: (1) gen., through, used of place or medium, Mt. 7:13; Lk. 6:1; 2 Cor. 11:33; through, of time, during, in the course of, Heb. 2:15; Acts 5:19; through, of immediate agency, causation, instrumentality, by means of, by, Jn. 1:3; Acts 3:18; of means or manner, through, by, with, Lk. 8:4; 2 Cor. 5:7; 8:8; of state or condition, in a state of, Rom. 4:11; (2) acc., used of causation which is not direct and immediate in the production of a result, on account of, because of, for the sake of, with a view to, Mk. 2:27; Jn. 1:31; rarely, through, while subject to a state of untoward circumstances, Gal. 4:13
διαβαίνω: to pass through or over, Lk. 16:26; Acts 16:9; Heb. 11:29*
διαβάλλω: to throw or convey through or over; to thrust through; to defame, inform against, Lk. 16:1*
διαβεβαιόομαι: to assert strongly, insist, 1 Tim. 1:7; Tit. 3:8*
διαβλέπω: to look through; to view steadily, Mk. 8:25; to see clearly or steadily, Mt. 7:5; Lk. 6:42*
διάβολος: slanderer, 1 Tim. 3:11; 2 Tim. 3:3; Tit. 2:3; a treacherous informer, traitor, Jn. 6:70; ὁ διάβολος, the devil
διαγγέλλω: to publish abroad, Lk. 9:60; Rom. 9:17; to certify to the public, Acts 21:26*
διαγίνομαι: pass., to continue through; to intervene, elapse of time, Mk. 16:1; Acts 25:13; 27:9*
διαγινώσκω: pr. to distinguish; to resolve determinately; to examine, inquire into, judicially, Acts 23:15; 24:22*
διάγνωσις: pr. an act of distinguishing or discernment; a determination; examination judicially, hearing, trial, Acts 25:21*
διαγρηγορέω: to remain awake; to wake thoroughly, Lk. 9:32*
διάγω: to conduct or carry through or over; to pass or spend time, live, 1 Tim. 2:2; Tit. 3:3*
διαδέχομαι: to receive by transmission; to receive in return, Acts 7:45*
διάδημα: pr. a band or fillet; a diadem, the badge of a sovereign, Rev. 12:3; 13:1; 19:12*
διαδίδωμι: to deliver from hand to hand; to distribute, divide, Lk. 11:22; 18:22; Jn. 6:11; Acts 4:35*
διαζώννυμι: to gird firmly round, Jn. 13:4, 5; mid. to gird round one’s self, Jn. 21:7*
διαθήκη: a testamentary disposition, will; a covenant, Heb. 9:16, 17; Gal. 3:15; in NT, a covenant of God with men, Gal. 3:17; 4:24; Heb. 9:4; Mt. 26:28; the writings of the old covenant, 2 Cor. 3:14
διαίρεσις: a division; a distinction, difference, diversity, 1 Cor. 12:4, 5, 6*
διαιρέω: to divide, to divide out, distribute, Lk. 15:12; 1 Cor. 12:11*
διακατελέγχομαι: to maintain discussion strenuously and thoroughly, to totally refute, Acts 18:28*
διακονέω: to wait, attend upon, serve, Mt. 8:15; Mk. 1:31; Lk. 4:39; to be an attendant or assistant, Acts 19:22; to minister to, relieve, assist, or supply with the necessaries of life, provide the means of living, Mt. 4:11; 27:55; Mk. 1:13; 15:41; Lk. 8:3; to fill the office of διάκονος, deacon, perform the duties of deacon, 1 Tim. 3:10, 13; 1 Pet. 4:11; to convey in charge, administer, 2 Cor. 3:3; 8:19, 20; 1 Pet. 1:12; 4:10; pass. to receive service, Mt. 20:28; Mk. 10:45
διακονία: serving, service, waiting, attendance, the act of rendering friendly offices, Lk. 10:40; 2 Tim. 4:11; Heb. 1:14; relief, aid, Acts 6:1; 11:29; 2 Cor. 8:4; 9:1, 12, 13; a commission, Acts 12:25; Rom. 15:31; a commission or ministry in the service of the Gospel, Acts 1:17, 25; 20:24; Rom. 11:13; 2 Cor. 4:1; 5:18; 1 Tim. 1:12; service in the Gospel, Acts 6:4; 21:19; 1 Cor. 16:15; 2 Cor. 6:3; 11:8; Eph. 4:12; Rev. 2:19; a function, ministry, or office in the Church, Rom. 12:7; 1 Cor. 12:5; Col. 4:17; 2 Tim. 4:5; a ministering in the conveyance of a revelation from God, 2 Cor. 3:7, 8, 9
διάκονος: one who renders service to another; an attendant, servant, Mt. 20:26; 22:13; Jn. 2:5, 9; one who executes a commission, a deputy, Rom. 13:4; Χριστοῦ, Θεοῦ, ἐν κυρίῳ, etc. a commissioned minister or preacher of the Gospel, 1 Cor. 3:5; 2 Cor. 6:4; a minister charged with an announcement or sentence, 2 Cor. 3:6; Gal. 2:17; Col. 1:23; a minister charged with a significant characteristic, Rom. 15:8; a servitor, devoted follower, Jn. 12:26; a deacon or deaconess, whose official duty was to superintend the alms of the Church, with other kindred services, Rom. 16:1; Phil. 1:1; 1 Tim. 3:8, 12
διακούω: to hear a thing through; to hear judicially, Acts 23:35*
διακρίνω: to separate, sever; to make a distinction or difference, Acts 15:9; 1 Cor. 11:29; to make to differ, distinguish, prefer, confer a superiority, 1 Cor. 4:7; to examine, scrutinize, estimate, 1 Cor. 11:31; 14:29; to discern, discriminate, Mt. 16:3; to judge, to decide a cause, 1 Cor. 6:5; to dispute, contend, Acts 11:2; Jude 9; to make a distinction mentally, Jas. 2:4; Jude 22; in NT to hesitate, be in doubt, doubt, Mt. 21:21; Mk. 11:23
διάκρισις: a separation; a distinction, or, doubt, Rom. 14:1; a discerning, the act of discerning or distinguishing, Heb. 5:14; the faculty of distinguishing and estimating, 1 Cor. 12:10*
διαλαλέω: to talk with; by impl. to consult, deliberate, Lk. 6:11; to divulge, publish, spread by rumor, Lk. 1:65*
διαλέγομαι: to discourse, argue, reason, Acts 17:2, 17; 24:12; to address, speak to, Heb. 12:5; to contend, dispute, Mk. 9:34; Jude 9
διαλείπω: to leave an interval; to intermit, cease, Lk. 7:45*
διάλεκτος: speech; manner of speaking; peculiar language of a nation, dialect, vernacular idiom, Acts 1:19; 2:6, 8; 21:40; 22:2; 26:14
διαλλάσσομαι: to be reconciled to another, Mt. 5:24*
διαλογίζομαι: pr. to make a settlement of accounts; to reason, deliberate, ponder, consider, Mt. 16:7, 8; Mk. 2:6, 8; Jn. 11:50; to dispute, contend, Mk. 9:33
διαλογισμός: reasoning, thought, cogitation, purpose, Mt. 15:19; Mk. 7:21; discourse, dispute, disputation, contention, Lk. 9:46; doubt, hesitation, scruple, Lk. 24:38
διαμαρτύρομαι: to make solemn affirmation, protest; to make a solemn and earnest charge, Lk. 16:28; Acts 2:40; to declare solemnly and earnestly, Acts 8:25; 18:5
διαμάχομαι: to fight out, to fight resolutely; met. to contend vehemently, insist, Acts 23:9*
διαμένω: to continue throughout; to continue, be permanent or unchanged, Lk. 1:22; Gal. 2:5; Heb. 1:11; 2 Pet. 3:4; to continue, remain constant, Lk. 22:28
διαμερίζω: to divide into parts and distribute, Mt. 27:35; Mk. 15:24; Acts 2:3; pass. in NT to be in a state of dissension, Lk. 11:17, 18; 12:52, 53
διαμερισμός: division; met. in NT disunion, dissension, Lk. 12:51*
διανέμω: to distribute; to divulge, spread abroad, Acts 4:17*
διανεύω: to signify by a nod, beckon, make signs, Lk. 1:22*
διάνοια: pr. thought, intention; the mind, intellect, understanding, Mt. 22:37; Mk. 12:30; Lk. 10:27; an operation of the understanding, thought, imagination, Lk. 1:51; insight, comprehension, 1 Jn. 5:20; mode of thinking and feeling, disposition of mind and heart, the affection, Eph. 2:3; Col. 1:21
διανοίγω: to open, Mk. 7:34, 35; Lk. 2:23; 24:31; Acts 7:56; met. to open the sense of a thing, explain, expound, Lk. 24:32; Acts 17:3; διανοίγειν τὸν νοῦν, τὴν καρδίαν, to open the mind, the heart, so as to understand and receive, Lk. 24:45; Acts 16:14*
διανυκτερεύω: to pass the night, spend the whole night, Lk. 6:12*
διαπεράω: to pass through or over, Mt. 9:1; 14:34; Mk. 5:21; 6:53; Lk. 16:26; Acts 21:2*
διαπλέω: to sail through or over, Acts 27:5*
διαπονέομαι: pr. to be thoroughly exercised with labor; to be wearied; to be vexed, Acts 4:2; 16:18*
διαπορεύομαι: to go or pass through, Lk. 6:1; 13:22; Acts 16:4; to pass by, Lk. 18:36
διαπορέω: to be utterly at a loss; to be in doubt and perplexity, Lk. 9:7; Acts 2:12; 5:24; 10:17
διαπραγματεύομαι: to despatch a matter thoroughly; to make profit in business, gain in trade, Lk. 19:15*
διαπρίω: to divide with a saw, saw asunder; to grate the teeth in a rage; pass. met. to be cut to the heart, to be enraged, Acts 5:33; 7:54*
διαρπάζω: to plunder, spoil, pillage, Mt. 12:29; Mk. 3:27 (2x)*
διασαφέω: to make known, declare, tell plainly, or fully, Mt. 13:36; 18:31*
διασείω: pr. to shake thoroughly or violently; to harass, intimidate, extort from, Lk. 3:14*
διασκορπίζω: to disperse, scatter, Mt. 26:31; Mk. 14:27; to dissipate, waste, Lk. 15:13; 16:1; to winnow, or, to strew, Mt. 25:24, 26
διασπάω: to pull or tear asunder or in pieces, burst, Mk. 5:4; Acts 23:10*
διασπείρω: to scatter abroad or in every direction, as seen; to disperse, Acts 8:1, 4; 11:19*
διασπορά: pr. a scattering, as of seed; dispersion; in NT meton. the dispersed portion of the Jews, specially termed the dispersion, Jn. 7:35; Jas. 1:1; 1 Pet. 1:1*
διαστέλλω: to determine, issue a decision; to state or explain distinctly and accurately; hence, to admonish, direct, charge, command, Acts 15:24; Heb. 12:20; when followed by a negative clause, to interdict, prohibit, Mt. 16:30; Mk. 5:43
διαστρέφω: to distort, turn away; met. to pervert, corrupt, Mt. 17:17; Lk. 9:41; to turn out of the way, cause to make defection, Lk. 23:2; Acts 13:8; διεστραμμένος, perverse, corrupt, erroneous
διασῴζω: to bring safely through; to convey in safety, Acts 23:24; pass. to reach a place or state of safety, Acts 27:43, 44; 28:1, 4; 1 Pet. 3:20; to heal, to restore to health, Mt. 14:36; Lk. 7:3*
διαταγή: an injunction, institute, ordinance, Rom. 13:2; Acts 7:53*
διαταράσσω: to throw into a state of perturbation, to move or trouble greatly, Lk. 1:29*
διατάσσω: pr. to arrange, make a precise arrangement; to prescribe, 1 Cor. 11:34; 16:1; Tit. 1:5; to direct, Lk. 8:55; Acts 20:13; to charge, Mt. 11:1; to command, Acts 18:2; to ordain, Gal. 3:19
διατελέω: to complete, finish; intrans. to continue, persevere, in a certain state or course of action, Acts 27:33*
διατηρέω: to watch carefully, guard with vigilance; to treasure up, Lk. 2:51; ἑαυτὸν ἐκ, to keep one’s self from, to abstain wholly from, Acts 15:29*
διατίθημι: in NT only mid., so some list as διατίθεμαι, to arrange; to arrange according to one’s own mind; to make a disposition, to make a will; to settle the terms of a covenant, to ratify, Acts 3:25; Heb. 8:10; 10:16; to assign, Lk. 22:29
διατρίβω: pr. to rub, wear away by friction; met. to pass or spend time, to remain, stay, tarry, continue, Jn. 3:22; 11:54; Acts 12:19; 14:3, 28
διαυγάζω: to shine through, shine out, dawn, 2 Pet. 1:19*
διαφέρω: to convey through, across, Mk. 11:16; to carry different ways or into different parts, separate; pass. to be borne, driven, or tossed hither and thither, Acts 27:27; to be proclaimed, published, Acts 13:49; intrans. met. to differ, 1 Cor. 15:41; to excel, be better or of greater value, be superior, Mt. 6:26; 10:31; impers. διαφέρει, it makes a difference, it is of consequence; with οὐδέν, it makes no difference, it is nothing, Gal. 2:6
διαφεύγω: to flee through, escape by flight, Acts 27:42*
διαφημίζω: to report, proclaim, publish, spread abroad, Mt. 9:31; 28:15; Mk. 1:45*
διαφθείρω: to corrupt or destroy utterly; to waste, bring to decay, Lk. 12:33; 2 Cor. 4:16; to destroy, Rev. 8:9; 11:18 (2x); met. to corrupt, pervert utterly, 1 Tim. 6:5*
διάφορος: different, diverse, of different kinds, Rom. 12:6; Heb. 9:10; excellent, superior, Heb. 1:4; 8:6*
διαφυλάσσω: to keep or guard carefully or with vigilance; to guard, protect, Lk. 4:10*
διαχειρίζω: pr. to have in the hands, to manage; mid. later, to kill, Acts 5:30; 26:21*
διδακτικός: apt or qualified to teach, 1 Tim. 3:2; 2 Tim. 2:24*
διδακτός: pr. taught, teachable, of things; in NT taught, of person, Jn. 6:45; 1 Cor. 2:13*
διδασκαλία: the act or occupation of teaching, Rom. 12:7; 1 Tim. 4:13; information, instruction, Rom. 15:4; 2 Tim. 3:16; matter taught, precept, doctrine, Mt. 15:9; 1 Tim. 1:10
διδάσκαλος: a teacher, master, Rom. 2:20; in NT as an equivalent, to ῥαββί, Jn. 1:39
διδάσκω: to teach, Mt. 4:23; 22:16; to teach or speak in a public assembly, 1 Tim. 2:12; to direct, admonish, Mt. 28:15; Rom. 2:21
διδαχή: instruction, the giving of instruction, teaching, Mk. 4:2; 12:38; instruction, what is taught, doctrine, Mt. 16:12; Jn. 7:16, 17; meton. mode of teaching and kind of doctrine taught, Mt. 7:28; Mk. 1:27
δίδραχμον: a didrachmon or double drachma, a silver coin equal to the drachma of Alexandria, to two Attic drachmas, to two Roman denarii, and to the half-shekel of the Jews, Mt. 17:24 (2x)*
Δίδυμος: a twin; Didymus, the Greek equivalent to the name Thomas, Jn. 11:16; 20:24; 21:2*
δίδωμι: pluperfect, ἐδεδώκειν, to give, bestow, present, Mt. 4:9; 6:11; Jn. 3:16; 17:2, et al. freq.; to give, cast, throw, Mt. 7:6; to supply, suggest, Mt. 10:19; Mk. 13:11; to distribute alms, Mt. 19:21; Lk. 11:41; to pay tribute, etc., Mt. 22:17; Mk. 12:14; Lk. 20:22; to be the author or source of a thing, Lk. 12:51; Rom. 11:8; to grant, permit, allow, Acts 2:27; 13:35; Mt. 13:11; 19:11; to deliver to, entrust, commit to the charge of anyone, Mt. 25:15; Mk. 12:9; to give or deliver up, Lk. 22:19; Jn. 6:51; to reveal, teach, Acts 7:38; to appoint, constitute, Eph. 1:22; 4:11; to consecrate, devote, offer in sacrifice, 2 Cor. 8:5; Gal. 1:4; Rev. 8:3; to present, expose one’s self in a place, Acts 19:31; to recompense, Rev. 2:23; to attribute, ascribe, Jn. 9:24; Rev. 11:13; from the Hebrew, to place, put, fix, inscribe, Heb. 8:10; 10:16; to infix, impress, 2 Cor. 12:7; Rev. 13:16; to inflict, Jn. 18:22; 19:3; 2 Thess. 1:8; to give in charge, assign, Jn. 5:36; 17:4; Rev. 9:5; to exhibit, put forth, Mt. 24:24; Acts 2:19; to yield, bear fruit, Mt. 13:8; διδόναι ἐργασίαν, to endeavor, strive, Lk. 12:58; διδόναι ἀπόκρισιν, to answer, reply, Jn. 1:22; διδόναι τόπον, to give place, yield, Lk. 14:9; Rom. 12:19
διεγείρω: to arouse or awake thoroughly, Mt. 1:24; Mk. 4:38, 39; Lk. 8:24; pass. to be raised, excited, agitated, as a sea, Jn. 6:18; met. to stir up, arouse, animate, 2 Pet. 1:13; 3:1
διενθυμέομαι: to revolve thoroughly in the mind, consider carefully, ponder, reflect, Acts 10:19*
διέξοδος: a passage throughout; a line of road, a thoroughfare, Mt. 22:9*
διερμηνεύω: to explain, interpret, translate, Lk. 24:27; Acts 9:36; 1 Cor. 14:5, 13, 27; to be able to interpret, 1 Cor. 12:30*
διέρχομαι: to pass through, Mk. 10:25; Lk. 4:30; to pass over, cross, Mk. 4:35; Lk. 8:22; to pass along, Lk. 19:4; to proceed, Lk. 2:15; Acts 9:38; to travel through or over a country, wander about, Mt. 12:43; Lk. 9:6; to transfix, pierce, Lk. 2:35; to spread abroad, be prevalent, as a rumor, Lk. 5:15; met. to extend to, Rom. 5:12
διερωτάω: to sift by questioning, of persons; in NT, of things, to ascertain by inquiry, Acts 10:17*
διετής: of two years; of the age of two years, Mt. 2:16*
διετία: the space of two years, Acts 24:27; 28:30*
διηγέομαι: pr. to lead throughout; to declare thoroughly, detail, recount, relate, tell, Mk. 5:16; 9:9; Lk. 8:39; Acts 8:33; Heb. 11:32
διηνεκής: continuous, uninterrupted; εἰς τὸ διηνεκές, perpetually, Heb. 7:3; 10:1, 12, 14*
διθάλασσος: surrounded on both sides by the sea; τόπος διθάλασσος, a shoal or sand-bank formed by the confluence of opposite currents, Acts 27:41*
διϊκνέομαι: to go or pass through; to penetrate, Heb. 4:12*
διίστημι: to set at an interval, apart; to station at an interval from a former position, Acts 27:28; intrans. to stand apart; to depart, be parted, Lk. 24:51; of time, to intervene, be interposed, Lk. 22:59*
διϊσχυρίζομαι: to feel or express reliance; to affirm confidently, insist, Lk. 22:59; Acts 12:15*
δίκαιος: just, equitable, fair, Mt. 20:4; Lk. 12:57; Jn. 5:30; Col. 4:1; of persons, just, righteous, absolutely, Jn. 17:25; Rom. 3:10, 26; 2 Tim. 4:8; 1 Pet. 3:18; 1 Jn. 1:9; 2:1, 29; Rev. 16:5; righteous by account and acceptance, Rom. 2:13; 5:19; in ordinary usage, just, upright, innocent, pious, Mt. 5:45; 9:13, et al. freq.; ὁ δίκαιος, the Just One, one of the distinctive titles of the Messiah, Acts 3:14; 7:52; 22:14
δικαιοσύνη: fair and equitable dealing, justice, Acts 17:31; Heb. 11:33; Rom. 9:28; integrity, virtue, Lk. 1:75; Eph. 5:9; in NT generosity, alms, 2 Cor. 9:10, v.r.; Mt. 6:1; piety, godliness, Rom. 6:13; investiture with the attribute of righteousness, acceptance as righteous, justification, Rom. 4:11; 10:4, et al. freq.; a provision or mean for justification, Rom. 1:17; 2 Cor. 3:9; an instance of justification, 2 Cor. 5:21
δικαιόω: pr. to make or render right or just; mid. to act with justice, Rev. 22:11; to avouch to be good and true, to vindicate, Mt. 11:19; Lk. 7:29; to set forth as good and just, Lk. 10:29; 16:15; in NT to hold as guiltless, to accept as righteous, to justify, Rom. 3:26, 30; 4:5; 8:30, 33; pass. to be held acquitted, to be cleared, Acts 13:39; Rom. 3:24; 6:7; to be approved, to stand approved, to stand accepted, Rom. 2:13; 3:20, 28
δικαίωμα: pr. a rightful act, act of justice, equity; a sentence, of condemnation, Rev. 15:4; in NT, of acquittal, justification, Rom. 5:16; a decree, law, ordinance, Lk. 1:6; Rom. 1:32; 2:26; 8:4; Heb. 9:1, 10; a meritorious act, an instance of perfect righteousness, Rom. 5:18; Rev. 19:8*
δικαίως: justly, with strict justice, 1 Pet. 2:23; deservedly, Lk. 23:41; as it is right, fit or proper, 1 Cor. 15:34; uprightly, honestly, piously, religiously, 1 Thess. 2:10; Tit. 2:12*
δικαίωσις: pr. a making right or just; a declaration of right or justice; a judicial sentence; in NT, acquittal, acceptance, justification, Rom. 4:25; 5:18*
δίκη: right, justice; in NT judicial punishment, vengeance, 2 Thess. 1:9; Jude 7; sentence of punishment, judgment, Acts 25:15; personified, the goddess of justice or vengeance, Nemesis, Paena, Acts 28:4
δίλογος: pr. saying the same thing twice; in NT double-tongued, speaking one thing and meaning another, deceitful in words, 1 Tim. 3:8*
διό: inferential conj., on which account, wherefore, therefore, Mt. 27:8; 1 Cor. 12:3
διοδεύω: to travel through a place, traverse, Lk. 8:1; Acts 17:1
διόπερ: inferential conj., on this very account, for this very reason, wherefore, 1 Cor. 8:13; 10:14*
διοπετής: which fell from Jupiter, or heaven; τοῦ διοπετοῦς, i.e. ἀγάλματος, image or statue; for discussion of ellipsis see grammars, Acts 19:35*
διορύσσω: to dig or break through, Mt. 6:19, 20; 24:43; Lk. 12:39*
Διόσκουροι: the Dioscuri, Castor and Pollux, sons of Jupiter by Leda, and patrons of sailors, Acts 28:11*
διότι: on the account that, because, Lk. 2:7; 21:28; in as much as, Lk. 1:13; Acts 18:10
διπλόω: to double; to render back double, Rev. 18:6*
δίς: twice, Mk. 14:30, 72; in the sense of entirely, utterly, Jude 12; ἅπαξ καὶ δίς, once and again, repeatedly, Phil. 4:16
δισμυριάς: twice ten thousand, two myriads, Rev. 9:16*
δίστομος: pr. having two mouths; two-edged, Heb. 4:12; Rev. 1:16; 2:12*
διϋλίζω: to strain, filter thoroughly; to strain out or off, Mt. 23:24*
διχάζω: to cut asunder, disunite; met. to cause to disagree, set at variance, Mt. 10:35*
διχοστασία: a standing apart; a division, dissension, Rom. 16:17; Gal. 5:20*
διχοτομέω: pr. to cut into two parts, cut asunder; in NT to inflict a punishment of extreme severity, Mt. 24:51; Lk. 12:46*
διψάω: to thirst, be thirsty, Mt. 25:35, 37, 42, 44; met. to thirst after in spirit, to desire or long for ardently, Mt. 5:6; Jn. 4:14; 6:35
διωγμός: pr. chase, pursuit; persecution (specifically for religious reasons), Mt. 13:21; Mk. 4:17; 10:30
διώκω: to put in rapid motion; to pursue; to follow, pursue the direction of, Lk. 17:23; to follow eagerly, endeavor earnestly to acquire, Rom. 9:30, 31; 12:13; to press forwards, Phil. 3:12, 14; to pursue with malignity, persecute, Mt. 5:10, 11, 12, 44
δόγμα: a decree, statute, ordinance, Lk. 2:1; Acts 16:4; 17:7; Eph. 2:15; Col. 2:14*
δογματίζω: to decree, prescribe an ordinance; mid. to suffer laws to be imposed on one’s self, to submit to, bind one’s self by, ordinances, Col. 2:20*
δοκέω: to think, imagine, suppose, presume, Mt. 3:9; 6:7; to seem, appear, Lk. 10:36; Acts 17:18; it seems; it seems good, best, or right, it pleases, Lk. 1:3; Acts 15:22, 25
δοκιμάζω: to test, assay metals, 1 Pet. 1:7; to prove, try, examine, scrutinize, Lk. 14:19; Rom. 12:2; to put to the proof, tempt, Heb. 3:9; to approve after trial, judge worthy, choose, Rom. 14:22; 1 Cor. 16:3; 2 Cor. 8:22; to decide upon after examination, judge of, distinguish, discern, Lk. 12:56; Rom. 2:18; Phil. 1:10
δοκιμή: trial, proof by trial, 2 Cor. 8:2; the state or disposition of that which has been tried and approved, approved character or temper, Rom. 5:4; 2 Cor. 2:9; Phil. 2:22; proof, document, evidence, 2 Cor. 8:2; 13:3*
δοκίμιον: that by means of which anything is tried, proof, criterion, test; trial, the act of trying or putting to proof, Jas. 1:3; approved character, 1 Pet. 1:7*
δόκιμος: proved, tried; approved after examination and trial, Rom. 16:10; Jas. 1:12; by impl. acceptable, Rom. 14:18
δοκός: a beam or spar of timber, Mt. 7:3, 4, 5; Lk. 6:41, 42*
δολιόω: to deceive, use fraud or deceit, Rom. 3:13*
δόλος: pr. a bait or contrivance for entrapping, fraud, deceit, cunning, guile, Mt. 26:4; Mk. 7:22; 14:1
δολόω: pr. to entrap, beguile; to adulterate, corrupt, falsify, 2 Cor. 4:2*
δόμα: a gift, present, Mt. 7:11; Lk. 11:13; Eph. 4:8; Phil. 4:17*
δόξα: pr. a seeming; appearance; a notion, imagination, opinion; the opinion which obtains respecting one; reputation, credit, honor, glory; in NT honorable consideration, Lk. 14:10; praise, glorification, honor, Jn. 5:41, 44; Rom. 4:20; 15:7; dignity, majesty, Rom. 1:23; 2 Cor. 3:7; a glorious manifestation, glorious working, Jn. 11:40; 2 Pet. 1:3; pl. dignitaries, 2 Pet. 2:10; Jude 8; glorification in a future state of bliss, 2 Cor. 4:17; 2 Tim. 2:10; pride, ornament, 1 Cor. 11:15; 1 Thess. 2:20; splendid array, pomp, magnificence, Mt. 6:29; 19:28; radiance, dazzling lustre, Lk. 2:9; Acts 22:11
δοξάζω: to think, suppose, judge; to extol, magnify, Mt. 6:2; Lk. 4:15; in NT to adore, worship, Rom. 1:21; to invest with dignity or majesty, 2 Cor. 3:10; Heb. 5:5; to signalize with a manifestation of dignity, excellence, or majesty, Jn. 12:28; 13:32; to glorify by admission to a state of bliss, to beatify, Rom. 8:30
Δορκάς: Dorcas, pr. name, signifying a gazelle or antelope, Acts 9:36, 39*
δόσις: pr. giving, outlay; Phil. 4:15; a donation, gift, Jas. 1:17*
δουλαγωγέω: pr. to bring into slavery; to treat as a slave; to discipline into subjection, 1 Cor. 9:27*
δουλεία: slavery, bondage, servile condition; in NT met. with reference to degradation and unhappiness, Rom. 8:15, 21; Gal. 4:24; 5:1; Heb. 2:15*
δουλεύω: to be a slave or servant; to be in slavery or subjection, Jn. 8:33; Acts 7:7; Rom. 9:12; to discharge the duties of a slave or servant, Eph. 6:7; 1 Tim. 6:2; to serve, be occupied in the service of, be devoted, subservient, Mt. 6:24; Lk. 15:29; Acts 20:19; Rom. 14:18; 16:18; met. to be enthralled, involved in a slavish service, spiritually or morally, Gal. 4:9, 25; Tit. 3:3
δοῦλος: a male slave, or servant, of various degrees, Mt. 8:9, et al. freq.; a servitor, person of mean condition, Phil. 2:7; fem. δούλη, a female slave; a handmaiden, Lk. 1:38, 48; Acts 2:18; δοῦλος, used figuratively, in a bad sense, one involved in moral or spiritual thraldom, Jn. 8:34; Rom. 6:17, 20; 1 Cor. 7:23; 2 Pet. 2:19; in a good sense, a devoted servant or minister, Acts 16:17; Rom. 1:1; one pledged or bound to serve, 1 Cor. 7:22; 2 Cor. 4:5
δουλόω: to reduce to servitude, enslave, oppress by retaining in servitude, Acts 7:6; 2 Pet. 2:19; met. to render subservient, 1 Cor. 9:19; pass. to be under restraint, 1 Cor. 7:15; to be in bondage, spiritually or morally, Gal. 4:3; Tit. 2:3; to become devoted to the service of, Rom. 6:18, 22*
δοχή: pr. reception of guests; in NT a banquet, feast, Lk. 5:29; 14:13
δράκων: a dragon or large serpent; met. the devil or Satan, Rev. 12:3, 4, 7, 9, 13, 16, 17; 13:2, 4, 11; 16:13; 20:2
δράσσομαι: pr. to grasp with the hand, clutch; to lay hold of, seize, take, catch, 1 Cor. 3:19*
δραχμή: a drachma, an Attic silver coin of nearly the same value as the Roman denarius, Lk. 15:8, 9*
δρέπανον: an instrument with a curved blade, as a sickle, Mk. 4:29; Rev. 14:14, 15, 16, 17, 18, 19*
δρόμος: a course, race, race-course; met. course of life or ministry, career, Acts 13:25; 20:24; 2 Tim. 4:7*
δύναμαι: to be able, either intrinsically and absolutely, which is the ordinary signification; or, for specific reasons, Mt. 9:15; Lk. 16:2 See ability; (be) able; can.
δύναμις: power; strength, ability, Mt. 25:15; Heb. 11:11; efficacy, 1 Cor. 4:19, 20; Phil. 3:10; 1 Thess. 1:5; 2 Tim. 3:5; energy, Col. 1:29; 2 Tim. 1:7; meaning, purport of language, 1 Cor. 14:11; authority, Lk. 4:36; 9:1; might, power, majesty, Mt. 22:29; 24:30; Acts 3:12; Rom. 9:17; 2 Thess. 1:7; 2 Pet. 1:16; in NT a manifestation or instance of power, mighty means, Acts 8:10; Rom. 1:16; 1 Cor. 1:18, 24; ἡ δύναμις, omnipotence, Mt. 26:64; Lk. 22:69; Mt. 14:62; pl. authorities, Rom. 8:38; Eph. 1:21; 1 Pet. 3:22; miraculous power, Mk. 5:30; Lk. 1:35; 5:17; 6:19; 8:46; 24:49; 1 Cor. 2:4; a miracle, Mt. 11:20, 21, et al. freq.; a worker of miracles, 1 Cor. 12:28, 29; from the Hebrew αἱ δυνάμεις τῶν οὐρανῶν, the heavenly luminaries, Mt. 24:29; Mk. 13:25; Lk. 21:26; αἱ δυνάμεις, the spiritual powers, Mt. 14:2; Mk. 6:14
δυνάστης: a potentate, sovereign; prince, Lk. 1:52; 1 Tim. 6:15; a person of rank and authority, Acts 8:27*
δυνατέω: to be powerful, mighty, to show one’s self powerful, 2 Cor. 9:8; 13:3; Rom. 14:4*
δυνατός: able, having power, powerful, mighty; δυνατὸς εἶναι, to be able, i.q. δύνασθαι, Lk. 14:31; Acts 11:17; ὁ δυνατός, the Mighty One, God, Lk. 1:49; τὸ δυνατόν, power, i.q. δύναμις, Rom. 9:22; valid, powerful, efficacious, 2 Cor. 10:4; distinguished for rank, authority, or influence, Acts 25:5; 1 Cor. 1:26; distinguished for skill or excellence, Lk. 24:19; Acts 7:22; Rom. 15:1; δυνατόν and δυνατά, possible, capable of being done, Mt. 19:26; 24:24 See ability; mighty; possible.
δύνω: to sink, go down, set as the sun, Mk. 1:32; Lk. 4:40*
δύο: two, Mt. 6:24; 21:38, 31, et al. freq.; οἱ δύο, both, Jn. 20:4; δύο ἠ τρεῖς, two or three, some, a few, Mt. 18:20; from the Hebrew, δύο δύο, two and two, Mk. 6:7, i.q. ἀνὰ δύο, Lk. 10:1, and κατὰ δύο, 1 Cor. 14:27
δυσβάστακτος: difficult or grievous to be borne, oppressive, Lk. 11:46
δυσερμήνευτος: difficult to be explained, hard to be understood, Heb. 5:11*
δύσκολος: pr. peevish about food; hard to please, disagreeable; in NT, difficult, Mk. 10:24*
δυσκόλως: with difficulty, hardly, Mt. 19:23; Mk. 10:23; Lk. 18:24*
δυσμή: a sinking or setting; pl. δυσμαί, the setting of the sun; hence, the west, Mt. 8:11; 24:27
δυσφημέω: pr. to use ill words; to reproach, revile, 1 Cor. 4:13*
δυσφημία: ill words; words of ill omen; reproach, contumely, 2 Cor. 6:8*
δώδεκα: twelve, Mt. 9:20; 10:1; οἱ δώδεκα, the twelve apostles, Mt. 26:14, 20
δῶμα: pr. a house; synec. a roof, Mt. 10:27; 24:17
δωρεά: a gift, free gift, benefit, Jn. 4:10; Acts 2:38
δωρεάν: gratis, gratuitously, freely, Mt. 10:8; Rom. 3:24; in NT undeservedly, without cause, Jn. 15:25; in vain, Gal. 2:21
δωρέομαι: to give freely, grant, Mk. 15:45; 2 Pet. 1:3, 4*
δώρημα: a gift, free gift, Rom. 5:16; Jas. 1:17*
δῶρον: a gift, present, Mt. 2:11; Eph. 2:8; Rev. 11:10; an offering, sacrifice, Mt. 5:23, 24; 8:4; δῶρον, i.e. ἐστι[ν], it is consecrated to God, Mt. 15:5; Mk. 7:11; contribution to the temple, Lk. 21:1, 4
ἔα: Ha! an expression of surprise or displeasure, Lk. 4:34*
ἐάν: if, ἐὰν μή, except, unless; also equivalent to ἀλλά, Gal. 2:16. Ἐάν, in NT as in the later Greek, is substituted for ἄν after relative words, Mt. 5:19. Tends to be an indicator for the subjunctive mood.
ἐάνπερ: if it be that, if indeed, if at all events, Heb. 3:6, 14; 6:3
ἑαυτοῦ: himself, herself, itself, Mt. 8:22; 12:26; 9:21; also used for the first and second persons, Rom. 8:23; Mt. 23:31; also equivalent to ἀλλήλων, Mk. 10:26; Jn. 12:19; ἀφ’ ἑαυτοῦ, ἀφ’ ἑαυτῶν, of himself, themselves, voluntarily, spontaneously, Lk. 12:57; 21:30; of one’s own will merely, Jn. 5:19; δι’ ἑαυτοῦ, of itself, in its own nature, Rom. 14:14; ἐξ ἑαυτῶν, of one’s own self, 2 Cor. 3:5; καθ’ ἑαυτόν, by one’s self, alone, Acts 28:16; Jas. 2:17; παρ’ ἑαυτῷ, with one’s self, at home, 1 Cor. 16:2; πρὸς ἑαυτόν, to one’s self, to one’s home, Lk. 24:12; Jn. 20:10; or, with one’s self, Lk. 18:11
ἐάω: to let, allow, permit, suffer to be done, Mt. 24:43; Lk. 4:41; to let be, let alone, desist from, stop, Lk. 22:51; to commit a ship to the sea, let her drive, Acts 27:40
ἑβδομήκοντα: seventy, indecl., Acts 7:14; οἱ ἑβδομήκοντα, the seventy disciples, Lk. 10:1, 17; Acts 23:23*
Ἑβραῖος: a Hebrew, one descended from Abraham the Hebrew, 2 Cor. 11:22; Phil. 3:5; in NT, a Jew of Palestine, one speaking Aramaic, opp. to Ἑλληνιστής, Acts 6:1*
Ἑβραίς: the Hebrew dialect, i.e., the Hebrew-Aramaic dialect of Palestine, Acts 21:40; 22:2; 26:14*
ἐγγίζω: pr. to cause to approach; in NT intrans. to approach, draw near, Mt. 21:1; Lk. 18:35; met. to be at hand, Mt. 3:2; 4:17; μέχρι θανάτου ἐγγίζειν, to be at the point of death, Phil. 2:30; from Hebrew to draw near to God, to offer Him reverence and worship, Mt. 15:8; Heb. 7:19; Jas. 4:8; used of God, to draw near to men, assist them, bestow favors on them, Jas. 4:8
ἐγγράφω: to engrave, inscribe, Lk. 10:20; met. ἐγγεγραμμένος, imprinted, 2 Cor. 3:2, 3*
ἐγγύς: some view as an improper prep., followed by gen. or dat., near, as to place, Lk. 19:11; close at hand, Rom. 10:8; near, in respect of ready interposition, Phil. 4:5; near, as to time, Mt. 24:32, 33; near to God, as being in covenant with him, Eph. 2:13; οἱ ἐγγύς, the people near to God, the Jews, Eph. 2:17
ἐγείρω: to excite, arouse, awaken, Mt. 8:25; mid. to awake, Mt. 2:13, 20, 21; met. mid. to rouse one’s self to a better course of conduct, Rom. 13:11; Eph. 5:14; to raise from the dead, Jn. 12:1; and mid. to rise from the dead, Mt. 27:52; Jn. 5:21; met. to raise as it were from the dead, 2 Cor. 4:14; to raise up, cause to rise up from a prone posture, Acts 3:7; and mid. to rise up, Mt. 17:7; to restore to health, Jas. 5:15; met. et seq. ἐπή, to excite to war; mid. to rise up against, Mt. 24:7; to raise up again, rebuild, Jn. 2:19, 20; to raise up from a lower place, to draw up or out of a ditch, Mt. 12:10; from Hebrew, to raise up, to cause to arise or exist, Acts 13:22, 23; mid. to arise, exist, appear, Mt. 3:9; 11:11
ἔγερσις: pr. the act of waking or rising up; resurrection resuscitation, Mt. 27:53*
ἐγκαίνια: initiation, consecration; in NT the feast of rededication, an annual festival of eight days in the month Kislev, Jn. 10:22*
ἐγκαινίζω: to initiate, consecrate, dedicate, renovate; to institute, Heb. 9:18; 10:20*
ἐγκαλέω: can be followed by a dative, to bring a charge against, accuse; to institute judicial proceedings, Acts 19:38, 40; 23:28, 29; 26:2, 7; Rom. 8:33
ἐγκαταλείπω: to leave, leave behind; to forsake, abandon, Mt. 27:46; Mk. 15:34; Acts 2:27, 30; Rom. 9:29; 2 Cor. 4:9; 2 Tim. 4:10, 16; Heb. 10:25; 13:5* See abandon; desert; forsake.
ἐγκατοικέω: to dwell in, or among, 2 Pet. 2:8*
ἐγκαυχάομαι: to boast in, or of, 2 Thess. 1:4*
ἐγκομβόομαι: pr. to put on a garment which is to be tied; in NT to put on, clothe one’s self with; met. 1 Pet. 5:5*
ἐγκοπή: alsn spelled ἐκκοπή, pr. an incision, e.g. a trench, etc., cut in the way of an enemy; an impediment, hindrance, 1 Cor. 9:12*
ἐγκόπτω: pr. to cut or strike in; hence, to impede, interrupt, hinder, Rom. 15:22; 1 Thess. 2:18; 1 Pet. 3:7; Gal. 5:7; Acts 24:4*
ἐγκράτεια: self-control, continence, temperance, Acts 24:25; Gal. 4:23; 2 Pet. 1:6*
ἐγκρατεύομαι: to possess the power of self-control or continence, 1 Cor. 7:9; to practise abstinence, 1 Cor. 9:25*
ἐγκρατής: strong, stout; possessed of mastery; master of self, Tit. 1:8*
ἐγκρίνω: to judge or reckon among, consider as belonging to, adjudge to the number of; class with, place in the same rank, 2 Cor. 10:12*
ἐγκρύπτω: to conceal in anything; to mix, intermix, Mt. 13:33; Lk. 13:21*
ἐγώ: I, gen., ἐμοῦ [μου], dat., ἐμοί [μοι], acc., ἐμέ [με]
ἐδαφίζω: pr. to form a level and firm surface; to level with the ground, overthrow, raze, destroy, Lk. 19:44*
ἔδαφος: pr. a bottom, base; hence, the ground, Acts 22:7*
ἑδραῖος: sedentary; met. settled, steady, firm, steadfast, constant, 1 Cor. 7:37; 15:58; Col. 1:23*
ἐθελοθρησκία: also spelled ἐθελοθρησκεία, self-made religion, Col. 2:23*
ἐθίζω: to accustom; pass. to be customary, Lk. 2:27*
ἐθνάρχης: a governor, chief of any tribe or nation, 2 Cor. 11:32*
ἐθνικός: national; in NT Gentile, heathen, not Israelites, Mt. 5:47; 6:7; 18:17; 3 Jn. 7*
ἔθνος: a multitude, company, Acts 17:26; 1 Pet. 2:9; Rev. 21:24; a nation, people, Mt. 20:25; 21:43; pl. ἔθνη, from the Hebrew, nations or people as distinguished from the Jews, the heathen, Gentiles, Mt. 4:15; 10:5; Lk. 2:32
ἔθος: a custom, usage, habit, Lk. 2:42; 22:39; an institute, rite, Lk. 1:9; Acts 6:14; 15:1
εἰ: if, Mt. 4:3, 6; 12:7; Acts 27:39, freq.; since, Acts 4:9; whether, Mk. 9:23; Acts 17:11; that, in certain expressions, Acts 26:8, 23; Heb. 7:15; by a suppression of the apodosis of a sentence, εἰ serves to express a wish; O if! O that! Lk. 19:42; 22:42; also a strong negation, Mk. 8:12; Heb. 3:11; 4:3; εἰ καί, if even, though, although, Lk. 18:4; εἰ μή, unless, except, Mt. 11:27; also equivalent to ἀλλά, but, Mt. 12:4; Mk. 13:32; Lk. 4:26, 27; εἰ μήτι, unless perhaps, unless it be, Lk. 9:13; εἴ τις, εἴ τι, pr. if any one; whosoever, whatsoever, Mt. 18:28. The syntax of this particle must be learned from the grammars. As an interrogative particle, whether, Acts 17:11; in NT as a mere note of interrogation, Lk. 22:49
εἶδος: form, external appearance, Lk. 3:22; 9:29; Jn. 5:37; kind, species, 1 Thess. 5:22; sight, perception, 2 Cor. 5:7*
εἰδωλόθυτος: as a noun meat offered to an idol, Acts 15:29; 21:25; 1 Cor. 8:1, 4, 7, 10; 10:19; Rev. 2:14, 20*
εἰδωλολάτρης: an idolater, worshipper of idols, 1 Cor. 5:10, 11; 6:9; 10:7; Eph. 5:5; Rev. 21:8; 22:15*
εἰδωλολατρία: idolatry, worship of idols, 1 Cor. 10:14; Gal. 5:20; Col. 3:5; 1 Pet. 4:3*
εἴδωλον: pr. a form, shape, figure; image or statue; hence, an idol, image of a god, Acts 7:41; a heathen god, 1 Cor. 8:4, 7; for εἰδωλόθυτον, the flesh of victims sacrificed to idols, Acts 15:20; Rom. 2:22; 1 Cor. 10:19; 12:12; 2 Cor. 6:16; 1 Thess. 1:9; 1 Jn. 5:21; Rev. 9:20*
εἰκῇ: without plan or system; without cause, rashly, Col. 2:18; to no purpose, in vain, Rom. 13:4; 1 Cor. 15:2; Gal. 3:4 (2x); 4:11*
εἴκω: (1) to yield, give place, submit, Gal. 2:5. (2) the perfect form ἔοικα (G2036) is from this same root and functions as a present, Jm 1:6, 23 (ἔοικεν, 3 sg). Some list it as a separate word, but see the discussion in Liddell and Scott*
εἰκών: a material image, likeness, effigy, Mt. 22:20; Mk. 12:16; a representation, exact image, 1 Cor. 11:7; 15:49; Rev. 13:14f.; resemblance, Rom. 1:23; 8:29; Col. 3:10; Heb. 10:1
εἰλικρίνεια: clearness, purity; met. sincerity, integrity, ingenuousness, 1 Cor. 5:8; 2 Cor. 1:12; 2:17*
εἰλικρινής: pr. that which being viewed in the sunshine is found clear and pure; met. spotless, sincere, ingenuous, Phil. 1:10; 2 Pet. 3:1*
εἰμί: to be, to exist, Jn. 1:1; 17:5; Mt. 6:30; Lk. 4:25, freq.; ἐστί[ν], it is possible, proper, Heb. 9:5; a simple linking verb (“copula”) to the subject and predicate, and therefore in itself affecting the force of the sentence only by its tense, mood, etc., Jn. 1:1; 15:1, freq.; it also forms a frequent circumlocution with the participles of the present and perfect of other verbs, Mt. 19:22; Mk. 2:6
εἵνεκεν: see ἕνεκα, on account of, Lk. 4:18; Acts 28:20; 2 Cor. 3:10*
εἴπερ: if indeed, if it be so that, granted, Rom. 8:9; 1 Cor. 15:15; since indeed, since, 2 Thess. 1:6; 1 Pet. 2:3; although indeed, 1 Cor. 8:5
εἰρηνεύω: to be at peace; to cultivate peace, concord, or harmony, Mt. 9:50; Rom. 12:18; 2 Cor. 13:11; 1 Thess. 5:13*
εἰρήνη: peace, Lk. 14:32; Acts 12:20; tranquillity, Lk. 11:21; Jn. 16:33; 1 Thess. 5:3; concord, unity, love of peace, Mt. 10:34; Lk. 12:51; meton. the author of peace, Eph. 2:14; from the Hebrew every kind of blessing and good, Lk. 1:79; 2:14, 29; meton. a salutation expressive of good wishes, a benediction, blessing, Mt. 10:13
εἰρηνικός: pertaining to peace; peaceable, disposed to peace, Jas. 3:17; from the Hebrew, profitable, blissful, Heb. 12:11*
εἰρηνοποιός: a peace-maker, one who cultivates peace and concord, Mt. 5:9*
εἱς: numeral one, Mt. 10:29, freq.; only, Mk. 12:6; one virtually by union, Mt. 19:5, 6; Jn. 10:30; one and the same, Lk. 12:52; Rom. 3:30; one in respect of office and standing, 1 Cor. 3:8; equivalent to τις, a certain one, Mt. 8:19; 16:14; a, an, Mt. 21:19; Jas. 4:13; εἱς ἕκαστος, each one, every one, Lk. 4:40; Acts 2:3; εἱς τὸν ἕνα, one another, 1 Thess. 5:11; εἱς καὶ εἱς, the one- and the other, Mt. 20:21; εἱς καθ’ εἱς and ὁδὲ καθ’ εἱς, one by one, one after another, in succession, Mk. 14:19; Jn. 8:9; as an ordinal, first, Mt. 28:1
εἰσάγω: to lead or bring in, introduce, conduct or usher in or to a place or person, Lk. 2:27; 14:21; 22:54; Jn. 18:16; Acts 9:8; 21:28f., 37; Heb. 1:6
εἰσακούω: to hear or hearken to, to heed, 1 Cor. 14:21; to listen to the prayers of any one, accept one’s petition, Mt. 6:7; Lk. 1:13; Acts 10:31; Heb. 5:7*
εἰσδέχομαι: to admit; to receive into favor, receive kindly, accept with favor, 2 Cor. 6:17*
εἴσειμι: to go in, enter, Acts 3:3; 21:18, 26; Heb. 9:6*
εἰσέρχομαι: to go or come in, enter, Mt. 7:13; 8:5, 8; spc. to enter by force, break in, Mk. 3:27; Acts 20:29; met. with εἰς κόσμον, to begin to exist, come into existence, Rom. 5:12; 2 Jn. 7; or, to make one’s appearance on earth, Heb. 10:5; to enter into or take possession of, Lk. 22:3; Jn. 13:27; to enter into, enjoy, partake of, Mt. 19:23, 24; to enter into any one’s labor, be his successor, Jn. 4:38; to fall into, be placed in certain circumstances, Mt. 26:41; to be put into, Mt. 15:11; Acts 11:8; to present one’s self before, Acts 19:30; met. to arise, spring up, Lk. 9:46; from the Hebrew, εἰσέρχεσθαι καὶ ἐξέρχεσθαι, to go in and out, to live, discharge the ordinary functions of life, Acts 1:21
εἰσκαλέομαι: to call in; to invite in, Acts 10:23*
εἴσοδος: a place of entrance; the act of entrance, Heb. 10:19; admission, reception, 1 Thess. 1:9; 2 Pet. 1:11; a coming, approach, access, 1 Thess. 2:1; entrance upon office, commencement or beginning of ministry, Acts 13:24*
εἰσπηδάω: to leap or spring in, rush in eagerly, Acts 16:29*
εἰσπορεύομαι: to go or come in, enter, Mk. 1:21; 5:40; to come to, visit, Acts 28:30; to be put in, Mt. 15:17; Mk. 7:15, 18, 19; to intervene, Mk. 4:19
εἰσφέρω: to bring in or into, Lk. 5:18, 19; 1 Tim. 6:7; Heb. 13:11; to bring to the ears of any one, to announce, Acts 17:20; to lead into, Mt. 6:13; Lk. 11:4; drag in, Lk. 12:11*
εἶτα: then, afterwards, Mk. 4:17, 28; Lk. 8:12; in the next place, 1 Cor. 12:28; besides, furthermore, Heb. 12:9
εἴωθα: perfect of an obsolete present ἔθω, pluperfect is εἰώθειν, to be accustomed, to be usual, Mt. 27:15; Mk. 10:1; Lk. 4:16; Acts 17:2*
ἐκ: ἐχ before vowels, with genitive, from, out of, a place, Mt. 2:15; 3:17; of, from, out of, denoting origin or source, Mt. 1:3; 21:19; of, from some material, Mt. 3:9; Rom. 9:21; of, from, among, partitively, Mt. 6:27; 21:31; Mk. 9:17; from, denoting cause, Rev. 8:11; 17:6; means or instrument, Mt. 12:33, 37; by, through, denoting the author or efficient cause, Mt. 1:18; Jn. 10:32; of, denoting the distinguishing mark of a class, Rom. 2:8; Gal. 3:7; of time, after, 2 Cor. 4:6; Rev. 17:11; from, after, since, Mt. 19:12; Lk. 8:27; for, with, denoting a rate of payment, price, Mt. 20:2; 27:7; at, denoting position, Mt. 20:21, 23; after passive verbs, by, of, from, marking the agent, Mt. 15:5; Mk. 7:11; forming with certain words a periphrasis for an adverb, Mt. 26:42, 44; Mk. 6:51; Lk. 23:8; put after words of freeing, Rom. 7:24; 2 Cor. 1:10; used partitively after verbs of eating, drinking, etc., Jn. 6:26; 1 Cor. 9:7
ἑκατοντάρχης: the text varies between this form and ἑκατόνταρχος, commander of a hundred men, a centurion, Lk. 23:47; Acts 10:1; 27:1ff.
ἐκβαίνω: to go forth, go out of, Heb. 11:15*
ἐκβάλλω: pluperfect, ἐκβεβλήκειν, to cast out, eject by force, Mt. 15:17; Acts 27:38; to expel, force away, Lk. 4:29; Acts 7:58; to refuse, Jn. 6:37; to extract, Mt. 7:4; to reject with contempt, despise, contemn, Lk. 6:22; in NT to send forth, send out, Mt. 9:38; Lk. 10:2; to send away, dismiss, Mt. 9:25; Mk. 1:12; met. to spread abroad, Mt. 12:20; to bring out, produce, Mt. 12:35; 13:52
ἔκβασις: a way out, egress; hence, result, issue, Heb. 13:7; means of clearance or successful endurance, 1 Cor. 10:13*
ἐκβολή: a casting out; especially, a throwing overboard of a cargo, Acts 27:18*
ἔκγονος: born of, descended from; as a noun ἔκγονα, descendants, grandchildren, 1 Tim. 5:4*
ἐκδέχομαι: pr. to receive from another; to expect, look for, Acts 17:16; to wait for, to wait, 1 Cor. 11:33; 16:11; Heb. 11:10; 10:13; Jas. 5:7*
ἐκδημέω: pr. to be absent from home, go abroad, travel; hence, to be absent from any place or person, 2 Cor. 5:6, 8, 9*
ἐκδίδωμι: middle, to give out, to give up; to put out at interest; in NT to let out to tenants, Mt. 21:33, 41; Lark 12:1; Lk. 20:9*
ἐκδικέω: pr. to execute right and justice; to punish, 2 Cor. 10:6; Rev. 6:10; 19:2; in NT to right, avenge a person, Lk. 18:3, 5; Rom. 12:9*
ἐκδίκησις: vengeance, punishment, retributive justice, Lk. 21:22; Rom. 12:19; 2 Cor. 7:11; 1 Pet. 2:14; ἐκδίκησιν ποιεῖν, to vindicate, avenge, Lk. 18:7, 8; διδόναι ἐκδίκησιν, to inflict vengeance, Acts 7:24; 2 Thess. 1:8; Heb. 10:30*
ἔκδικος: an avenger, one who inflicts punishment, Rom. 13:4; 1 Thess. 4:6*
ἐκδιώκω: pr. to chase away, drive out; in NT to persecute, vex, harass, 1 Thess. 2:15*
ἐκδύω: pr. to go out from; to take off, strip, unclothe, Mt. 27:28, 31; mid. to lay aside, to put off, Mk. 15:20; Lk. 10:30; 2 Cor. 5:3f.*
ἐκεῖ: there, in that place, Mt. 2:13, 15; to that place, Mt. 2:22; 17:20
ἐκεῖνος: demonstrative adjective or noun, that, this, he, etc., Mt. 17:27; 10:14; 2 Tim. 4:8; in contrast with οὗτος, referring to the former of two things previously mentioned, Lk. 18:14
ἐκζητέω: to seek out, investigate diligently, scrutinize, 1 Pet. 1:10; to ask for, beseech earnestly, Heb. 12:17; to seek diligently or earnestly after, Acts 15:17; Rom. 3:11; Heb. 10:6; from the Hebrew, to require, exact, demand, Lk. 11:50, 51; Heb. 12:07*
ἐκθαμβέω: pass., to be amazed, astonished, awe-struck, Mk. 9:15; 14:33; 16:5, 6*
ἐκθαυμάζω: to wonder at, wonder greatly, Mk. 12:17*
ἐκκαθαίρω: to cleanse thoroughly, purify, 2 Tim. 2:21; to purge out, eliminate, 1 Cor. 5:7*
ἐκκαίω: pass., to blaze out, to be inflamed, Rom. 1:27*
ἐκκεντέω: to stab, pierce deeply, Jn. 19:37; Rev. 1:7*
ἐκκλάω: to break off, pass., be broken, Rom. 11:17, 19, 20*
ἐκκλείω: to shut out, exclude; to shut of, separate, insulate; Gal. 4:17; to leave no place for, eliminate, Rom. 3:27*
ἐκκλησία: a popular assembly, Acts 19:32, 39, 41; in NT the congregation of the children of Israel, Acts 7:38; transferred to the Christian body, of which the congregation of Israel was a figure, the Church, 1 Cor. 12:28; Col. 1:18; a local portion of the Church, a local church, Rom. 16:1; a Christian congregation, 1 Cor. 14:4
ἐκκλίνω: to deflect, deviate, Rom. 3:12; to decline or turn away from, avoid, Rom. 16:17; 1 Pet. 3:11
ἐκκολυμβάω: to swim out to land, Acts 27:42*
ἐκκομίζω: to carry out, bring out; especially, to carry out a corpse for burial, Lk. 7:12*
ἐκκόπτω: to cut out; to cut off, Mt. 3:10; 5:30; met. to cut off an occasion, remove, prevent, 2 Cor. 11:12; to render ineffectual, Mt. 7:19; 18:8; Lk. 3:9; 12:7, 9; Rom. 11:22, 24; 1 Pet. 3:7*
ἐκκρεμάννυμι: mid., to hang upon a speaker, fondly listen to, be earnestly attentive, Lk. 19:48*
ἐκλαλέω: to speak out; to tell, utter, divulge, Acts 23:22*
ἐκλάμπω: to shine out or forth, Mt. 13:43*
ἐκλανθάνομαι: to make to forget; to forget entirely, Heb. 12:5*
ἐκλέγομαι: to pick out; in NT to choose, select, Lk. 6:13; 10:42; in NT to choose out as the recipients of special favor and privilege, Acts 13:17; 1 Cor. 1:27
ἐκλείπω: to fail, die out, Lk. 22:32; to come to an end, Heb. 1:12; to be defunct, Lk. 16:9; 23:45*
ἐκλεκτός: chosen out, selected; in NT chosen as a recipient of special privilege, elect, Col. 3:12; specially beloved, Lk. 23:35; possessed of prime excellence, exalted, 1 Tim. 5:21; choice, precious, 1 Pet. 2:4, 6
ἐκλογή: the act of choosing out, election; in NT election to privilege by divine grace, Rom. 9:11; 11:5, 28; 1 Thess. 1:4; 2 Pet. 1:10; ἡ ἐκλογή, the elect, Rom. 11:7; ἐκλογῆς, equivalent to ἐκλεκτόν, by Hebraism, Acts 9:15*
ἐκλύω: to be weary, exhausted, faint, Mt. 15:32; Mk. 8:3; Gal. 6:9; to lose courage, to faint, Heb. 12:3, 5*
ἐκμάσσω: to wipe off; to wipe dry, Lk. 7:38, 44; Jn. 11:2; 12:3; 13:5*
ἐκμυκτηρίζω: to mock, deride, scoff at, Lk. 16:14; 23:35*
ἐκνεύω: pr. to swim out, to escape by swimming; hence, generally, to escape, get clear of a place, Jn. 5:13; though ἐκνεύσας, in this place, may be referred to ἐκνεύω, to deviate, withdraw*
ἐκνήφω: pr. to awake sober after intoxication; met. to shake off mental bewilderment, to wake up from delusion and folly, 1 Cor. 15:34*
ἐκπειράζω: to tempt, put to the test, Mt. 4:7; Lk. 4:12; 1 Cor. 10:9; to try, sound, Lk. 10:25*
ἐκπέμπω: to send out, or away, Acts 13:4; 17:10*
ἐκπετάννυμι: pluperfect, ἐκπεπετάκειν, to stretch forth, expand, extend, Rom. 10:21*
ἐκπηδάω: to leap forth, rush out, Acts 14:14*
ἐκπίπτω: to fall off or from, Acts 12:7; 27:32; met. to fall from, forfeit, lose, Gal. 5:4; 2 Pet. 3:17; to be cast ashore, Acts 27:17, 26, 29; to fall to the ground, be fruitless, ineffectual, Rom. 9:6; to cease, come to an end, Jas. 1:11; 1 Pet. 1:24*
ἐκπλέω: to sail out of or from a place, Acts 15:39; 18:18; 20:6*
ἐκπληρόω: to fill out, complete, fill up; met. to fulfil, perform, accomplish, Acts 13:33*
ἐκπλήρωσις: pr. a filling up, completion; hence, a fulfilling, accomplishment, Acts 21:26*
ἐκπλήσσω: pr. to strike out of; hence, to strike out of one’s wits, to astound, amaze; pass., overwhelmed, Mt. 7:28; 13:54
ἐκπνέω: to breathe out; to expire, die, Mk. 15:37, 39; Lk. 23:46*
ἐκπορεύομαι: to go from or out of a place, depart from, Mk. 11:19; 13:1; to be voided, Mk. 7:19; to be cast out, Mt. 17:21; to proceed from, be spoken, Mt. 4:4; 15:11; to burst forth, Rev. 4:5; to be spread abroad, Lk. 4:37; to flow out, Rev. 22:1; from the Hebrew, ἐκπορεύομαι καὶ εἰσπορεύομαι. see εἰσέρχομαι, Acts 9:28
ἐκπορνεύω: to be given to fornication, indulge in immorality, Jude 7*
ἐκπτύω: lit., to spit out; met. to reject, Gal. 4:14*
ἐκριζόω: to root up, eradicate, pull out by the roots, Mt. 13:29; 15:13; Lk. 17:6; Jude 12*
ἔκστασις: pr. a displacement; hence, a displacement of the mind from its ordinary state and self-possession; amazement, astonishment, Mk. 5:42; excess of fear; fear, terror, Mk. 16:8; Lk. 5:26; Acts 3:10; in NT an ecstasy, a trance, Acts 10:10; 11:5; 22:17*
ἐκστρέφω: pr. to turn out of, to turn inside out; hence, to change entirely; in NT pass. to be perverted, Tit. 3:11*
ἐκταράσσω: to disturb, disquiet, throw into confusion, Acts 16:20*
ἐκτείνω: to stretch out, Mt. 8:3; 12:13; to lay hands on any one, Lk. 22:53; to exert power and energy, Acts 4:30; to cast out, let down an anchor, Acts 27:30
ἐκτελέω: to bring to an end, to finish, complete, Lk. 14:29, 30*
ἐκτένεια: pr. extension; in NT intenseness, intentness; ἐν ἐκτενείᾳ, intently, perseverance, earnestness, Acts 26:7*
ἐκτενής: pr. extended; met. intense, earnest, fervent, eager, 1 Pet. 4:8*
ἐκτενῶς: intensely, fervently, earnestly, Lk. 22:44; Acts 12:5; 1 Pet. 1:22*
ἐκτίθημι: pr. to place outside, put forth; to expose an infant, Acts 7:21; met. to set forth, declare, explain, Acts 11:4; 18:26; 28:23*
ἐκτινάσσω: to shake out, shake off, Mt. 10:14; Mk. 6:11; Acts 13:51; 18:6*
ἐκτρέπω: mid. and pass., to turn out or aside, Heb. 12:13; to turn aside or away, swerve, 1 Tim. 1:6; 5:15; 2 Tim. 4:4; to turn from, avoid, 1 Tim. 6:20*
ἐκτρέφω: to nourish, promote health and strength, Eph. 5:29; to bring up, educate, Eph. 6:4*
ἔκτρωμα: an abortion, baby prematurely born, 1 Cor. 15:8*
ἐκφέρω: to bring forth, carry out, Lk. 15:22; Acts 5:15; 1 Tim. 6:7; to carry out for burial, Acts 5:6, 9, 10; to produce, yield, Mk. 8:23; Heb. 6:8*
ἐκφεύγω: intrans. to flee out, to make an escape, Acts 16:27; 19:16; trans. to escape, avoid, Lk. 21:36; Rom. 2:3
ἐκφύω: lit. to cause to grow, to generate; to put forth, shoot, Mt. 24:32; Mk. 13:28*
ἐκχέω: also formed as ἐκχύννομαι (11x), to pour out, Rev. 16:1, 2, 3; to shed blood, Mt. 26:28; Mk. 14:24; pass. to gush out, Acts 1:18; to spill, scatter, Mt. 9:17; Jn. 2:15; met. to give largely, bestow liberally, Acts 2:17, 18, 33; 10:45; pass. to rush headlong into anything, be abandoned to, Jude 11
ἐκχύννομαι: some list as the active ἐκχύννω; see ἐκχέω (G1772)
ἐκχωρέω: to go out, depart from, flee, Lk. 21:21*
ἐκψύχω: to expire, give up one’s spirit, Acts 5:5, 10; 12:23*
ἐλαία: an olive tree, Mt. 21:1; 24:3; an olive, fruit of the olive tree, Jas. 3:12, ὄρος τῶν ἐλαιῶν, the Mount of Olives, Mt. 21:1
ἐλαιών: an olive garden; in NT the mount Olivet, Lk. 19:29; 21:37; Acts 1:12*
Ἐλαμίτης: an Elamite; an inhabitant of Elam, a province of Persia, Acts 2:9*
ἐλάσσων: ἐλάττων (G1784) is the Attic form of this word. Twice it is used with σσ (Jn. 2:10; Rom. 9:12) and twice with ττ (1 Tim. 5:9; Heb. 7:7). It is used as the comparative of μικρός, less; less in age, younger, Rom. 9:12; less in dignity, inferior, Heb. 7:7; less in quality, inferior, worse, Jn. 2:10; 1 Tim. 5:9*
ἐλαττονέω: trans. to make less; intrans. to be less, inferior; to have too little, want, lack, 2 Cor. 8:15*
ἐλαττόω: to make less or inferior, Heb. 2:7; pass. to be made less or inferior, Heb. 2:9; to decline in importance, Jn. 3:30*
ἐλαύνω: to drive, urge forward, spur on, Lk. 8:29; Jas. 3:4; 2 Pet. 2:17; to impel a vessel by oars, to row, Mk. 6:48; Jn. 6:19*
ἐλαφρία: lightness in weight; hence, lightness of mind, levity, 2 Cor. 1:17*
ἐλάχιστος: used as the superlative of μικρός, smallest, least, Mt. 2:6; 5:19
ἐλεάω: see ἐλεέω, have mercy on, Rom. 9:16; 12:8; Jude 22, 23*
ἐλεγμός: reproof, 2 Tim. 3:16, a later equivalent to ἔλεγχος*
ἔλεγχος: pr. a trial in order to proof, a proof; meton. a certain persuasion, Heb. 11:1*
ἐλέγχω: to put to proof, to test; to convict, Jn. 8:46; Jas. 2:9; to refute, confute, 1 Cor. 14:24; Tit. 1:9; to detect, lay bare, expose, Jn. 3:20; Eph. 5:11, 13; to reprove, rebuke, Mt. 18:15; Lk. 3:19; 1 Tim. 5:20; to discipline, chastise, Heb. 12:5; Rev. 3:19; pass. to experience conviction, Jn. 3:20; 1 Cor. 14:24
ἐλεέω: also formed as ἐλεάω   4x, to pity, have compassion on; pass. to receive pity, experience compassion, Mt. 5:7; 9:27; 15:22; to be gracious to any one, show gracious favor and saving mercy towards; pass. to be an object of gracious favor and saving mercy, Rom. 11:30, 31; spc. to obtain pardon and forgiveness, 1 Tim. 1:13, 16
ἐλεημοσύνη: pity, compassion; in NT an act of kindness, alms, almsgiving, Mt. 6:2, 3, 4; Lk. 11:41
ἔλεος: pity, mercy, compassion, Mt. 9:13; 12:7; Lk. 1:50, 78; meton. benefit which results from compassion, kindness, mercies, blessing, Lk. 1:54, 58, 72; 10:37; Rom. 9:23
ἐλεύθερος: free, in a state of freedom as opposed to slavery, 1 Cor. 12:13; Gal. 3:28; free, exempt, Mt. 17:26; 1 Cor. 7:39; unrestricted, unfettered, 1 Cor. 9:1; free from the dominion of sin, etc., Jn. 8:36; Rom. 6:20; free in the possession of Gospel privileges, 1 Pet. 2:16
Ἐλιακίμ: also spelled Ἐλιακείμ, Eliakim, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:13; Lk. 3:30*
Ἐλιούδ: Eliud, the father of Eleazar, Mt. 1:14, 15*
Ἐλισάβετ: Elizabeth, the wife of Zechariah and mother of John the Baptist, Lk. 1:5, 13, 24, 36, 57
Ἐλισαῖος: also spelled Ἐλισσαῖος, Elisha, pr. name, Lk. 4:27*
ἑλίσσω: to roll, fold up, as garments, Heb. 1:12; Rev. 6:14*
ἕλκος: pr. a wound; hence, an ulcer, sore, Lk. 16:21; Rev. 16:2, 11*
ἑλκόω: pass. to be afflicted with ulcers, Lk. 16:20*
Ἑλλάς: Hellas, Greece; in NT the southern portion of Greece as distinguished from Macedonia, Acts 20:2*
Ἕλλην: a Greek, Acts 18:17; Rom. 1:14; one not a Jew, a Gentile, Acts 14:1; 16:1, 3
Ἑλληνιστής: pr. one who uses the language and follows the customs of the Greeks; in NT a Jew by blood, but a native of a Greek-speaking country, Hellenist, Acts 6:1; 9:29; 11:20*
Ἑλληνιστί: in the Greek language, Jn. 19:20; Acts 21:37*
ἐλλογέω: to enter in an account, to put or charge to one’s account, Phlm. 18; in NT to impute, Rom. 5:13*
Ἐλμαδάμ: also spelled Ἐλμωδάμ, Elmadam, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 3:28*
ἐλπίζω: to hope, expect, Lk. 23:8; 24:21; to repose hope and confidence in, trust, confide, Mt. 12:21; Jn. 5:45
ἐλπίς: pr. expectation; hope, Acts 24:15; Rom. 5:4; meton. the object of hope, thing hoped for, Rom. 8:24; Gal. 5:5; the author or source of hope, Col. 1:27; 1 Tim. 1:1; trust, confidence, 1 Pet. 1:21; ἐπ’ ἐλπίδι, in security, with a guarantee, Acts 2:26; Rom. 8:20
ἐμβαίνω: to step in; to go on board a ship, embark, Mt. 8:23; 9:1; 13:2
ἐμβάπτω: to dip in, Mt. 26:23; to dip for food in a dish, Mk. 14:20*
ἐμβατεύω: pr. to step into or upon; met. to search into, investigate; to pry into intrusively, Col. 2:18*
ἐμβιβάζω: to cause to step into or upon; to set in or upon; especially, to put on board, Acts 27:6*
ἐμβλέπω: to look attentively, gaze earnestly, at an object, followed by εἰς, Mk. 6:26; Acts 1:11; to direct a glance, to look searchingly or significantly, at a person, followed by the dat., Mk. 10:21; 14:67; Lk. 22:61; absol. to see clearly, Mk. 8:25; Acts 22:11
ἐμβριμάομαι: Attic spelling, ἐμβριμόομαι, to be greatly agitated, Jn. 11:33, 38; to charge or forbid sternly or vehemently, Mt. 9:30; Mk. 1:43; to express indignation, to censure, Mk. 14:5*
ἐμμαίνομαι: to be mad against, be furious toward, Acts 26:11*
Ἐμμαοῦς: Emmaus, pr. name, indecl., of a village near Jerusalem, Lk. 24:13*. See PhotoGuide.
ἐμμένω: pr. to remain in a place; met. to abide by, to continue firm in, persevere in, Acts 14:22; 28:30; Gal. 3:10; Heb. 8:9*
Ἑμμώρ: also spelled Ἑμμόρ, Hamor, pr. name, indecl., Acts 7:16
ἐμπαίζω: to play upon, deride, mock, treat with scorn, ridicule, Mt. 20:19; 27:29; by impl. to delude, deceive, Mt. 2:16
ἐμπαίκτης: a mocker, derider, scoffer, 2 Pet. 3:3; Jude 18*
ἐμπεριπατέω: pr. to walk about in a place; met. in NT to live among, be conversant with, 2 Cor. 6:16*
ἐμπίπλημι: also spelled ἐμπίμπλημι (G1855) and ἐμπιμπλάω (G1857), to fill, Acts 14:17; pass. to be satisfied, satiated, full, Lk. 1:53; 6:25; Jn. 6:12; met. to have the full enjoyment of, Rom. 15:24*
ἐμπίμπρημι: also spelled ἐμπίπρημι and ἐμπρήθω, to set on fire, burn down, Mt. 22:7*
ἐμπίπτω: to fall into, Mt. 12:11; Lk. 14:5; to encounter, Lk. 10:36; to be involved in, 1 Tim. 3:6, 7; 6:9; εἰς χεῖρας, to fall under the chastisement of, Heb. 10:31
ἐμπλέκω: pr. to intertwine; met. to implicate, entangle, involve; pass. to be implicated, involved, or to entangle one’s self in, 2 Tim. 2:4; 2 Pet. 2:20*
ἐμπλοκή: braiding or plaiting of hair, 1 Pet. 3:3*
ἐμπνέω: gen., to breathe into or upon; to respire, breathe; met. to breathe of, be animated with the spirit of, Acts 9:1*
ἐμπορεύομαι: to travel; to travel for business’ sake; to trade, traffic, Jas. 4:13; by impl., trans., to make a gain of, deceive for one’s own advantage, 2 Pet. 2:3*
ἐμπόριον: a mart, marketplace, emporium; met. traffic, Jn. 2:16*
ἔμπορος: pr. a passenger by sea; a traveller; one who travels about for traffic, a merchant, Mt. 13:45; Rev. 18:3, 11, 15, 23*
ἔμπροσθεν: also an improper prep., before, in front of, Lk. 19:4; Phil. 3:14; before, in the presence of, in the face of, Mt. 5:24; 23:14; before, previous to, Jn. 1:15, 27, 30; from the Hebrew, in the sight or estimation of, Mt. 11:26; 18:14
ἐμπτύω: followed by the dat., or εἰς and the acc., to spit upon, Mt. 26:67; 27:30
ἐμφανής: apparent, conspicuous, obvious to the sight, Acts 10:40; met. manifest, known, comprehended, Rom. 10:20*
ἐμφανίζω: to cause to appear clearly; to communicate, report, Acts 23:15, 22; to bring charges against, Acts 24:1; 25:2, 15, to manifest, intimate plainly, Heb. 11:14; to reveal, make known, Jn. 14:21, 22; pass. to appear, be visible, Mt. 27:53; to present one’s self, Heb. 9:24*
ἔμφοβος: terrible; in NT terrified, Lk. 24:5, 37; Acts 10:4; 24:25; Rev. 11:13*
ἐμφυσάω: to blow or breathe into, inflate; in NT to breathe upon, Jn. 20:22*
