ἐν: followed by the dat., in, Mt. 8:6; Mk. 12:26; Rev. 6:6,; upon, Lk. 8:32; among, Mt. 11:11; before, in the presence of, Mk. 8:38; in the sight, estimation of, 1 Cor. 14:11; before, judicially, 1 Cor. 6:2; in, of state, occupation, habit, Mt. 21:22; Lk. 7:25; Rom. 4:10; in the case of, Mt. 17:12; in respect of, Lk. 1:7; 1 Cor. 1:7; on occasion of, on the ground of, Mt. 6:7; Lk. 1:21; used of the thing by which an oath is made, Mt. 5:34; of the instrument, means, efficient cause, Rom. 12:21; Acts 4:12; equipped with, furnished with, 1 Cor. 4:21; Heb. 9:25; arrayed with, accompanied by, Lk. 14:31; Jude 14; of time, during, in the course of, Mt. 2:1; in NT of demoniacal possession, possessed by, Mk. 5:2
ἐναγκαλίζομαι: to take into or embrace in one’s arms, Mk. 9:36; 10:16*
ἐνάλιος: marine, living in the sea, Jas. 3:7*
ἔναντι: also an improper prep, over against, in the presence of, Lk. 1:8; Acts 8:21*
ἐναντίον: acc sg neut of ἐναντίος used adverbially; the adj. does not appear in the NT, improper prep., before, in the presence of, Lk. 1:6; 20:26; Acts 8:32; 2 Cor. 2:7; Gal. 2:7; 1 Pet. 3:9; from the Hebrew, in the sight or estimation of, Acts 7:10; with τοῦ θεοῦ, an intensive expression, Lk. 24:19*
ἐναντίος: opposite to, over against, Mk. 15:39; contrary, as the wind, Mt. 14:24; Acts 26:9; 28:17; ὁ ἐξ ἐναντίας, an adverse party, enemy, Tit. 2:8; adverse, hostile, counter, 1 Thess. 2:15
ἐνδείκνυμι: to manifest, display, Rom. 9:17, 22; Heb. 6:10; to give outward proof of, Rom. 2:15; to display a certain bearing towards a person; hence, to perpetrate openly, 2 Tim. 4:14*
ἔνδειξις: a pointing out; met. manifestation, public declaration, Rom. 3:25, 26; a token, sign, proof, i.q. ἔνδειγμα, 2 Cor. 8:24; Phil. 1:28*
ἕνδεκα: eleven, indecl. numeral, Mt. 28:16; Mk. 16:14; Lk. 24:9, 33; Acts 1:26; 2:14*
ἐνδέχομαι: to admit, approve; to be possible, impersonal, it is possible, Lk. 13:33*
ἐνδημέω: to dwell in a place, be at home, 2 Cor. 5:6, 8, 9*
ἐνδιδύσκω: a later form, equivalent to ἐνδύω, to dress (oneself), Mark 15:17; 16:19*
ἐνδοξάζομαι: to invest with glory; pass. to be glorified, to be made a subject of glorification, 2 Thess. 1:10, 12*
ἔνδοξος: honored, 1 Cor. 4:10; notable, memorable, Lk. 13:17; splendid, gorgeous, Lk. 7:25; in unsullied array, Eph. 5:27*
ἔνδυμα: clothing, a garment, Mt. 6:25, 28; 22:11, 12; in particular, an outer garment, cloak, mantle, Mt. 3:4; 7:15; 28:3; Lk. 12:23*
ἐνδυναμόω: to empower, invigorate, Phil. 4:13; 1 Tim. 1:12; 2 Tim. 4:17; mid. to summon up vigor, put forth energy, Eph. 6:10; 2 Tim. 2:1; pass. to acquire strength, be invigorated, be strong, Acts 9:22; Rom. 4:20*
ἔνδυσις: a putting on, or wearing of clothes, 1 Pet. 3:3*
ἐνδύω: to enter, 2 Tim. 3:6; to put on, clothe, invest, array, Mt. 27:31; Mk. 15:17, 20; mid. clothe one’s self, be clothed, Mt. 22:11, 27, 31; trop. to be clothed with spiritual gifts, graces, or character, Lk. 24:49; Rom. 13:14
ἐνέδρα: pr. a sitting in or on a spot; an ambush, or lying in wait, Acts 23:16; 25:3*
ἐνεδρεύω: to lie in wait or ambush for, Acts 23:21; to endeavor to entrap, Lk. 11:54*
ἔνειμι: to be in or within; τὰ ἐνόντα, those things which are within, Lk. 11:41*
ἐνέργεια: energy, efficacy, power, Phil. 3:21; Col. 2:12; active energy, operation, Eph. 1:19; 3:7; 4:16; Col. 1:29; 2 Thess. 2:9, 11*
ἐνεργέω: to effect, 1 Cor. 12:6, 11; Gal. 3:5; Eph. 1:11; Phil. 2:13; to put into operation, Eph. 1:20; absol. to be active, Mt. 14:2; Mk. 6:14; Eph. 2:2; in NT to communicate energy and efficiency, Gal. 2:8; pass. or mid. to come into activity, be actively developed; to be active, be in operation, towards a result, 2 Cor. 4:12; 2 Thess. 2:7; to be an active power or principle, Rom. 7:5; 1 Thess. 2:12; instinct with activity; in action, operative, 2 Cor. 1:6; Gal. 5:6; Eph. 3:20; Col. 1:29; earnest, Jas. 5:16
ἐνέργημα: an effect, thing effected, activity, 1 Cor. 12:6; operation, working, 1 Cor. 12:10*
ἐνεργής: active, Phlm. 6; efficient, energetic, Heb. 4:12; adapted to accomplish a thing, effectual, 1 Cor. 16:9*
ἐνευλογέω: to bless in respect of, or by means of, Acts 3:25; Gal. 3:8*
ἐνέχω: to hold within; to fix upon; in NT intrans. (i.e. χόλον) to entertain a grudge against, Mk. 6:19; to be exasperated against, Lk. 11:53; pass. to be entangled, held fast in, Gal. 5:1*
ἐνθάδε: pr. to this place, Jn. 4:15, 16; also, here, in this place, Lk. 24:41; Acts 10:8; 16:28; 17:6; 25:17, 24*
ἐνθυμέομαι: to ponder in one’s mind, think of, meditate on, Mt. 1:20; 9:4*
ἐνθύμησις: the act of thought, reflection, Mt. 9:4; 12:25; Heb. 4:12; the result of thought, invention, device, Acts 17:29*
ἐνιαυτός: a year, more particularly as being a cycle of seasons, and in respect of its revolution, Jn. 11:49, 51; 18:13; in NT an era, Lk. 4:19
ἐνίστημι: to place in or upon; intrans., to stand close upon; to be at hand, impend, to be present, Rom. 8:38; 2 Thess. 2:2; Heb. 9:9
ἐνισχύω: to strengthen, impart strength and vigor, Lk. 22:43; intrans. to gain, acquire, or recover strength and vigor, be strengthened, Acts 9:19*
ἐννεύω: to nod at, signify by a nod; to make signs; to intimate by signs, Lk. 1:62*
ἔννοια: notion, idea; thought, purpose, intention, Heb. 4:12; 1 Pet. 4:1*
ἔννομος: within law; lawful, legal, Acts 19:39; in NT subject or under a law, obedient to a law, 1 Cor. 9:21*
ἐνοικέω: to dwell in, inhabit; in NT met. to be indwelling spiritually, Rom. 8:11; Col. 3:16; 2 Tim. 1:14; to be infixed mentally, 2 Tim. 1:5; of the Deity, to indwell, by special presence, 2 Cor. 6:16*
ἐνοχλέω: to trouble, annoy; to be a trouble, Lk. 6:18; Heb. 12:15*
ἔνοχος: held in or by; subjected to, Heb. 2:15; subject to, liable to, guilty, deserving, Mt. 5:21, 22; 26:66; Mk. 3:29; 14:64; an offender against, 1 Cor. 11:27; Jas. 2:10*
ἔνταλμα: a precept, commandment, ordinance, Mt. 15:9; Mk. 7:7; Col. 2:22*
ἐνταφιάζω: to prepare a body for burial, Mt. 26:12; absol. to make the ordinary preparations for burial, Jn. 19:40*
ἐνταφιασμός: preparation of a corpse for burial, burial itself, Mk. 14:8; Jn. 12:7*
ἐντέλλω: some list as ἐντέλλομαι, mid., to enjoin, charge, command, Mt. 4:6; 15:4; 17:9; to direct, Mt. 19:7; Mk. 10:3
ἐντεῦθεν: hence, from this place, Mt. 17:20; Lk. 4:9; ἐντεῦθεν καὶ ἐντεῦθεν, on each side, Rev. 22:2; hence, from this cause, Jas. 4:1
ἔντευξις: pr. a meeting with; hence address; prayer, supplication, intercession, 1 Tim. 2:1; 4:5*
ἔντιμος: honored, estimable, dear, Lk. 7:2; 14:8; Phil. 2:29; highly-valued, precious, costly, 1 Pet. 2:4, 6*
ἐντολή: an injunction; a precept, commandment, law, Mt. 5:19; 15:3, 6; an order, direction, Acts 17:15; an edict, Jn. 11:57; a direction, Mk. 10:5; a commission, Jn. 10:18, a charge of matters to be proclaimed or received, Jn. 12:49, 50; 1 Tim. 6:14; 2 Pet. 2:21
ἐντόπιος: in or of a place; an inhabitant, citizen, Acts 21:12*
ἐντός: improper prep., gen., inside, within, Lk. 17:21; τὸ ἐντός, the interior, inside, Mt. 23:26*
ἐντρέπω: mid., to revere, reverence, regard, Mt. 21:37; Mk. 12:6; absol. to feel shame, be put to shame, 2 Thess. 3:14; Tit. 2:8; pass., be put to shame, 2 Thess. 3:14; Tit. 3:8
ἐντρέφω: to nourish in, bring up or educate in, 1 Tim. 4:6*
ἐντρυφάω: to live luxuriously, riot, revel, 2 Pet. 2:13*
ἐντυγχάνω: to fill in with, meet; to have conversation with, address; to address or apply to any one, Acts 25:24; ὑπέρ τινος, to intercede for any one, plead the cause of, Rom. 8:27, 34; Heb. 7:25; κατά τινος, to address a representation or suit against any one, to accuse, complain of, Rom. 11:2*
ἐντυλίσσω: to wrap up in, inwrap, envelope, Mt. 27:59; Lk. 23:53; to wrap up, roll or fold together, Jn. 20:7*
ἐντυπόω: to impress a figure, instamp, engrave, 2 Cor. 3:7*
ἐνυπνιάζομαι: to dream, in NT to dream under supernatural impression, Acts 2:17; to dream delusion, have visions, Jude 8*
ἐνύπνιον: a dream; in NT a supernatural suggestion or impression received during sleep, a sleep-vision, Acts 2:17*
ἐνώπιον: gen., before, in the presence of, Lk. 5:25; 8:47; in front of, Rev. 4:5, 6; immediately preceding as a forerunner, Lk. 1:17; Rev. 16:19; from the Hebrew, in the presence of, metaphysically, i.e. in the sphere of sensation or thought, Lk. 12:9; 15:10; Acts 10:31; in the eyes of, in the judgment of, Lk. 16:15; 24:11; Acts 4:19
ἐνωτίζομαι: to give ear, listen, pay attention to, Acts 2:14*
Ἑνώχ: Enoch, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 3:37; Heb. 11:5; 1 Pet. 3:19; Jude 14*
ἐξαγγέλλω: to tell forth, divulge, publish; to declare abroad, celebrate, 1 Pet. 2:9, shorter ending of Mark*
ἐξαγοράζω: to buy out of the hands of a person; to redeem, set free, Gal. 3:13; 4:5; mid. to redeem, buy off, to secure for one’s self or one’s own use; to rescue from loss or misapplication, Eph. 5:16; Col. 4:5*
ἐξάγω: to bring or lead out, conduct out of, Mk. 8:23; 15:20; Lk. 24:50
ἐξαιρέω: to take out of; to pluck out, tear out, Mt. 5:29; 18:9; mid. to take out of, select, choose, Acts 26:17; to rescue, deliver, Acts 7:10, 34; 12:11; 23:27; Gal. 1:4*
ἐξαίρω: pr. to lift up out of; in NT to remove, eject, 1 Cor. 5:13*
ἐξαιτέω: to ask for; to demand; mid. to demand for one’s self, Lk. 22:31; also, to obtain by asking*
ἐξακολουθέω: to follow out; to imitate, 2 Pet. 2:2, 15; to observe as a guide, 2 Pet. 1:16*
ἐξαλείφω: pr. to anoint or smear over; hence, to wipe off or away, Rev. 7:17; 21:4; to blot out, obliterate, Col. 2:14; Rev. 3:5; met. to wipe out guilt, Acts 3:19*
ἐξάλλομαι: to leap or spring up or forth, Acts 3:8*
ἐξανάστασις: a raising up; a dislodgment; a rising up; a resurrection from the dead, Phil. 3:11*
ἐξανατέλλω: to raise up, make to spring up; intrans. to rise up, sprout, spring up or forth, Mt. 13:5; Mk. 4:5*
ἐξανίστημι: to cause to rise up, raise up; from the Hebrew, to raise up into existence, Mk. 12:19; Lk. 20:28; intrans. to rise up from, stand forth, Acts 15:5*
ἐξαπατάω: pr. to deceive thoroughly; to deceive, delude, Rom. 7:11; 16:18; 1 2 Cor. 3:18; 11:3; 2 Thess. 2:3; 1 Tim. 2:14*
ἐξαπορέω: some list as a deponent ἐξαπορέομαι, pass., to be in the utmost perplexity or despair, 2 Cor. 1:8; 4:8*
ἐξαποστέλλω: to send out or forth; to send away, dismiss, Lk. 1:53; to dispatch on a service or agency, Acts 7:12; to send forth as a pervading influence, Gal. 4:6
ἐξαρτίζω: to equip or furnish completely, 2 Tim. 3:17; to complete time, Acts 21:5*
ἐξαστράπτω: pr. to flash forth; hence, to glisten as lightning, Lk. 9:29*
ἐξαυτῆς: at the very time; presently, instantly, immediately, Mk. 6:25; Acts 10:33; 11:11
ἐξεγείρω: to raise up from the dead, 1 Cor. 6:14; to raise up into existence, or into a certain condition, Rom. 9:17*
ἔξειμι: to go out or forth, Acts 13:42; to depart, Acts 17:15; 20:7; ἐπὶ τὴν γῆν, to get to land, from the water, Acts 27:43
ἐξέλκω: to draw or drag out; met. to withdraw, allure, hurry away, Jas. 1:14*
ἐξεραυνάω: to search out, to examine closely, 1 Pet. 1:10*
ἐξέρχομαι: to go or come out of; to come out, Mt. 5:26; 8:34; to proceed, emanate, take rise from, Mt. 2:6; 15:18; 1 Cor. 14:36; to come abroad, 1 Jn. 4:1; to go forth, go away, depart, Mt. 9:31; Lk. 5:8; to escape, Jn. 10:39; to pass away, come to an end, Acts 16:19
ἔξεστιν: 3rd person sing of the unused ἔχειμι (#1997) used impersonally, it is possible; it is permitted, it is lawful, Mt. 12:2, 4; Mk. 3:4; Lk. 6:9; Acts 22:25; 1 Cor. 6:12
ἐξετάζω: to search out; to inquire by interrogation, examine strictly, Mt. 2:8; 10:11; to interrogate, Jn. 21:12*
ἐξηγέομαι: to be a leader; to detail, to set forth in language; to tell, narrate, recount, Lk. 24:35; Acts 10:8; to make known, reveal, Jn. 1:18; Acts 15:12, 14; 21:19*
ἑξῆς: successively, in order; in NT with the article ὁ, ἡ, τό, ἑχῆς, next, Lk. 7:11; 9:37; Acts 21:1; 25:17; 27:18*
ἐξηχέω: act., to make to sound forth; pass., to sound forth, 1 Thess. 1:8*
ἕξις: a condition of body or mind, strictly, as resulting from practice; habit, Heb. 5:14*
ἐξίστημι: pr. to put out of its place; to astonish, amaze, Lk. 24:22; Acts 8:9, 11; intrans. to be astonished, Mt. 12:23; to be beside one’s self, Mk. 3:21; 2 Cor. 5:13
ἐξισχύω: to be fully able, be strong, Eph. 3:18*
ἔξοδος: a way out, a going out; a going out, departure, the exodus, Heb. 11:22; met. a departure from life, decease, death, Lk. 9:31; 2 Pet. 1:15*
ἐξολεθρεύω: to destroy utterly, root out, Acts 3:23*
ἐξομολογέομαι: to agree, bind one’s self, promise, Lk. 22:6; mid. to confess, Mt. 3:6; to profess openly, Phil. 2:11; Rev. 3:5; to make open avowal of benefits; to praise, celebrate, Mt. 11:25; Lk. 10:21
ἐξορκίζω: to put an oath to a person, to adjure, Mt. 26:63*
ἐξορκιστής: pr. one who puts an oath; in NT an exorcist, one who by various kinds of incantations, etc., pretended to expel demons, Acts 19:13*
ἐξορύσσω: to dig out or through, force up, Mk. 2:4; to pluck out the eyes, Gal. 4:15*
ἐξουδενέω: also spelled ἐξουδενόω, to treat with contempt, Mk. 9:12*
ἐξουθενέω: also spelled ἐξουθενόω, to make light of, set at naught, despise, treat with contempt and scorn, Lk. 18:9; to neglect, disregard, 1 Thess. 5:20; ἐξουθενημένος, contemptible, 2 Cor. 10:10; of small account, 1 Cor. 1:28; 6:4; by impl. to reject with contempt, Acts 4:11
ἐξουσία: power, ability, faculty, Mt. 9:8; 10:1; efficiency, energy, Lk. 4:32; liberty, licence, Jn. 10:18; Acts 5:4; authority, rule, dominion, jurisdiction, Mt. 8:9; 28:18; meton. pl. authorities, potentates, powers, Lk. 12:11; 1 Cor. 15:24; Eph. 1:21; right, authority, full power, Mt. 9:6; 21:23; privilege, prerogative, Jn. 1:12; perhaps, a veil, 1 Cor. 11:10
ἐξουσιάζω: to have or exercise power or authority over anyone, Lk. 22:25; to possess independent control over, 1 Cor. 7:4 (2x); pass. to be subject to, under the power or influence of, 1 Cor. 6:12*
ἐξοχή: pr. prominence, anything prominent; in NT eminence, distinction, Acts 25:23*
ἐξυπνίζω: to awake, arouse from sleep, Jn. 11:11*
ἔξω: can function as an improper prep., without, out of doors; Mt. 12:46, 47; ὁ, ἡ, τὸ ἔξω, outer, external, foreign, Acts 26:11; 2 Cor. 4:16; met. not belonging to one’s community, Mk. 4:11; 1 Cor. 5:12, 13; out, away, from a place or person, Mt. 5:13; 13:48; as a prep., out of, Mk. 5:10
ἔξωθεν: can function as an improper prep., outwardly, externally, Mt. 23:27, 28; Mk. 7:15; ὁ, ἡ, τὸ ἔξωθεν, outer, external, Mt. 23:25; Lk. 11:39; τὸ ἔξωθεν, the exterior, Lk. 11:40; οἱ ἔξωθεν, those who are without the Christian community, 1 Tim. 3:7
ἐξωθέω: to expel, drive out, Acts 7:45; to propel, urge forward, Acts 27:39*
ἐξώτερος: comparative in form but used as a superlative, outer, exterior, external, Mt. 8:12; 22:13; 25:30*
ἔοικα: see εἴκω (1634a), dat., to be like, Jas. 1:6, 23*
ἑορτάζω: to keep a feast, celebrate a festival, 1 Cor. 5:8*
ἑορτή: a solemn feast, public festival, Lk. 2:41; 22:1; Jn. 13:1; spc. used of the passover, Mt. 26:5; 27:15
ἐπαγγελία: annunciation, 2 Tim. 1:1; a promise, act of promising, Acts 13:23, 32; 23:21; meton. the thing promised, promised favor and blessing, Lk. 24:49; Acts 1:4
ἐπαγγέλλομαι: to declare, to promise, undertake, Mk. 14:11; Rom. 4:21; to profess, 1 Tim. 2:10
ἐπάγγελμα: a promise, 2 Pet. 3:13; meton. promised favor or blessing, 2 Pet. 1:4*
ἐπάγω: to bring upon, cause to come upon, 2 Pet. 2:1, 5; met. to cause to be imputed or attributed to, to bring guilt upon, Acts 5:28*
ἐπαγωνίζομαι: to contend strenuously in defence of, Jude 3*
ἐπαθροίζω: act., to gather together, to collect close upon, or beside; pass., to crowd upon, Lk. 11:29*
ἐπαινέω: to praise, commend, applaud, Lk. 16:8; Rom. 15:11; 1 Cor. 11:2, 17, 22 (2x)*
ἔπαινος: praise, applause, honor paid, Rom. 2:29; 2 Cor. 8:18; meton. ground or reason of praise or commendation, Phil. 4:8; approval, Rom. 13:3; 1 Pet. 2:14; 1 Cor. 4:5
ἐπαίρω: to lift up, raise, elevate; to hoist, Acts 27:40; τὴν φωνήν, to lift up the voice, to speak in a loud voice, Lk. 11:27; τὰς χεῖρας, to lift up the hands in prayer, Lk. 24:50; 1 Tim. 2:8; τοὺς ὀφθαλμούς, to lift up the eyes, to look, Mt. 17:8; τὴν κεφαλήν, to lift up the head, to be encouraged, animated, Lk. 21:28; τὴν πτέρναν, to lift up the heel, to attack, assault; or, to seek one’s overthrow or destruction, Jn. 13:18; pass. to be borne upwards, Acts 1:9; met. mid. to exalt one’s self, assume consequence, be elated, 2 Cor. 10:5
ἐπαιτέω: to prefer a suit or request in respect of certain circumstances; to ask alms, beg, Lk. 16:3; 18:35*
ἐπακολουθέω: to follow upon; to accompany, be attendant, Mk. 16:20; to appear later, 1 Tim. 5:24; met. to follow one’s steps, to imitate, 1 Pet. 2:21; to follow a work, pursue, prosecute, be studious of, devoted to, 1 Tim. 5:10*
ἐπακούω: gen., to listen or hearken to; to hear with favor, 2 Cor. 6:2*
ἐπακροάομαι: gen., to hear, hearken, listen to, Acts 16:25*
ἐπάν: with subj., whenever, as soon as, Mt. 2:8; Lk. 11:22, 34*
ἐπάναγκες: of necessity, necessarily; τὰ ἐπάναγκες, necessary things, Acts 15:28*
ἐπανάγω: to bring up or back; intrans. to return, Mt. 21:18; a nautical term, to put off from shore, Lk. 5:3, 4*
ἐπαναμιμνῄσκω: to remind, put in remembrance, Rom. 15:15*
ἐπαναπαύομαι: pr. to make to rest upon; mid. to rest upon; to abide with, Lk. 10:6; to rely on, confide in, abide by confidingly, Rom. 2:17*
ἐπανίστημι: to raise up against; mid. to rise up against in rebellion, Mt. 10:21; Mk. 13:12*
ἐπάνω: can function as an improper prep., above, over, upon, of place, Mt. 2:9; 5:14; over, of authority, Lk. 19:17, 19; above, more than, Mk. 14:5
ἐπαρκέω: dat., pr. to ward off; to assist, relieve, succor; 1 Tim. 5:10, 16 (2x)*
ἔπαυλις: pr. a place to pass the night in; cottage, farm; in NT a dwelling, habitation, farm, Acts 1:20*
ἐπαύριον: tomorrow; ἡ ἐπαύριον, i.e. ἡμέρα, the next or following day, Mt. 27:62; Mk. 11:12
ἐπαφρίζω: to foam out; to pour out like foam, vomit forth, Jude 13*
ἐπεγείρω: to raise or stir up against, excite or instigate against, Acts 13:50; 14:2*
ἐπεί: when, after, since, because, in as much as, Mt. 18:32; 27:6; for, for then, for else, since in that case, Rom. 3:6; 11:6
ἐπειδή: since, because, in as much as, Mt. 21:46; Lk. 11:6; Acts 13:46
ἐπειδήπερ: since now, since indeed, considering that, Lk. 1:1*
ἔπειμι: to come upon; to come after; to succeed immediately, Acts 7:26; 16:11; 20:15; 21:18; 23:11*
ἐπεισαγωγή: a superinduction, a further introduction, whether by way of addition or substitution, Heb. 7:19*
ἐπεισέρχομαι: to come in upon, invade, surprise, Lk. 21:35*
ἔπειτα: thereupon, then, after that, in the next place, afterwards, Mk. 7:5; Lk. 16:7
ἐπέκεινα: BDAG 361, say it is an adverb with the gen.; others classify it as an improper prep., gen., on yonder side, beyond, Acts 7:43*
ἐπεκτείνομαι: pr. to stretch out farther; in NT mid. to reach out towards, strain for, Phil. 3:13*
ἐπενδύομαι: to put on over or in addition to; mid. to put on one’s self in addition; to be further invested, 2 Cor. 5:2, 4*
ἐπενδύτης: the outer or upper tunic, worn between the inner tunic and the external garments, Jn. 21:7*
ἐπέρχομαι: to come to, Acts 14:19; to come upon, Lk. 1:35; 21:26; Acts 1:8; Jas. 5:1; to be coming on, to succeed, Eph. 2:7; to occur, happen to, Acts 8:24; 13:40; to come against, attack, Lk. 11:22*
ἐπερωτάω: to interrogate, question, ask, Mt. 12:10; 17:10; in NT to request, require, Mt. 16:1; from the Hebrew, ἐπερωτᾶν τὸν θεόν, to seek after, desire an acquaintance with God, Rom. 10:20
ἐπερώτημα: pr. an interrogation, question; in NT profession, pledge, 1 Pet. 3:21*
ἐπέχω: trans. to hold out, present, exhibit, display, Phil. 2:16; intrans. to observe, take heed to, attend to, Lk. 14:7; Acts 3:5; 1 Tim. 4:16; to stay, delay, Acts 19:22*
ἐπηρεάζω: to harass, insult, Lk. 6:28; to mistreat, abuse, 1 Pet. 3:16*
ἐπί: (1) with the gen., upon, on, Mt. 4:6; 9:2; 27:19; in, of locality, Mk. 8:4; near upon, by, at, Mt. 21:19; Jn. 21:1; upon, over, of authority, Mt. 2:22; Acts 8:27; in the presence of, especially in a judicial sense, 2 Cor. 7:14; Acts 25:9; in the case of, in respect of, Jn. 6:2; Gal. 3:16; in the time of, at the time of, Acts 11:28; Rom. 1:10; ἐπ’ ἀληθείας, really, bona fide, Mk. 12:32; (2) with the dat., upon, on, Mt. 14:8; Mk. 2:21; Lk. 12:44; close upon, by, Mt. 24:33; Jn. 4:6; in the neighborhood or society of, Acts 28:14; over, of authority, Mt. 24:47; to, of addition, besides, Mt. 25:20; Eph. 6:16; Col. 3:14; supervening upon, after, 2 Cor. 1:4; 7:4; immediately upon, Jn. 4:27; upon, of the object of an act, towards, to, Mk. 5:33; Lk. 18:7; Acts 5:35; against, of hostile posture or disposition, Lk. 12:52; in dependence upon, Mt. 4:4; Lk. 5:5; Acts 14:3; upon the ground of, Mt. 19:9; Lk. 1:59; Phil. 1:3; Heb. 7:11; 8:6; 9:17; with a view to, Gal. 5:13; 1 Thess. 4:7; (3) with the acc., upon, with the idea of previous or present motion, Mt. 4:5; 14:19, 26; towards, of place, to, Mt. 3:13; 22:34; towards, of the object of an action, Lk. 6:35; 9:38; against, of hostile movement, Mt. 10:21; over, of authority, Lk. 1:33; to the extent of, both of place and time, Rev. 21:16; Rom. 7:1; near, by, Mt. 9:9; about, at, of time, Acts 3:1; in order to, with a view to, for the purpose of, Mt. 3:7; Lk. 7:44
ἐπιβαίνω: pr. to step upon; to mount, Mt. 21:5; to go on board, Acts 21:2; 27:2, to enter, Acts 20:18; to enter upon, Acts 21:4; 25:1*
ἐπιβάλλω: to cast or throw upon, Mk. 11:7; 1 Cor. 7:35; to lay on, apply to, Lk. 9:62; to put on, sew on, Mt. 9:16; Lk. 5:36; τὰς χεῖρας, to lay hands on, offer violence to, seize, Mt. 26:50; also, to lay hand to, undertake, commence, Acts 12:1; intrans. to rush, dash, beat into, Mk. 4:37; to ponder, reflect on, Mk. 14:72; to fall to one’s share, pertain to, Lk. 15:12
ἐπιβαρέω: to burden; met. to be burdensome, chargeable to, 1 Thess. 2:9; 2 Thess. 3:8; to bear hard upon, overcharge, 2 Cor. 2:5*
ἐπιβιβάζω: to cause to ascend or mount, to set upon, Lk. 10:34; 19:35; Acts 23:24*
ἐπιβλέπω: to look upon; to regard with partiality, Jas. 2:3; to regard with kindness and favor, Lk. 1:48; 9:38*
ἐπίβλημα: that which is put over or upon; in NT a patch, Mt. 9:16; Mk. 2:21; Lk. 5:36 (2x)*
ἐπιβουλή: a purpose or design against any one; conspiracy, plot, Acts 9:24; 20:3, 19; 23:30*
ἐπιγαμβρεύω: to marry a wife by the law of affinity, Mt. 22:24*
ἐπίγειος: pr. on the earth, Phil. 2:10; earthly, terrestrial, Jn. 3:12; 1 Cor. 15:40; 2 Cor. 5:1; Phil. 3:19; earthly, low, grovelling, Jas. 3:15*
ἐπιγίνομαι: to come on, spring up, as the wind, Acts 28:13*
ἐπιγινώσκω: pr. to make a thing a subject of observation; hence, to arrive at knowledge from preliminaries; to attain to a knowledge of, Mt. 11:27; to ascertain, Lk. 7:37; 23:7; to perceive, Mk. 2:8; 5:30; to discern, detect, Mt. 7:16, 20; to recognize, Mk. 6:33; Lk. 24:16, 31; Acts 3:10; to acknowledge, admit, 1 Cor. 14:37; 1 Tim. 4:3; pass. to have one’s character discerned and acknowledged, 2 Cor. 6:9; from the Hebrew, to regard with favor and kindness, 1 Cor. 16:18
ἐπίγνωσις: the coming at the knowledge of a thing, ascertainment, Rom. 3:20; a distance perception or impression, acknowledgment, insight, Col. 2:2
ἐπιγραφή: an inscription; a legend of a coin, Mt. 22:20; Mk. 12:16; Lk. 20:24; a label of a criminal’s name and offence, Mk. 15:26; Lk. 23:38*
ἐπιγράφω: pluperfect pass., ἐπεγεγράμμην, to imprint a mark on; to inscribe, engrave, write on, Mk. 15:26; Acts 17:23; Rev. 21:12; met. to imprint, impress deeply on, Heb. 8:10; 10:16*
ἐπιδείκνυμι: to exhibit, Mt. 16:1; Acts 9:39; to show, Mt. 22:19; Lk. 17:14; to point out, Mt. 24:1; to demonstrate, prove, Acts 18:28; Heb. 6:17*
ἐπιδέχομαι: to admit; to receive kindly, welcome, entertain, 3 Jn. 10; met. to admit, approve, assent to, 3 Jn. 9*
ἐπιδημέω: to dwell among a people; to be at home among one’s own people; and in NT to sojourn as a stranger among another people, Acts 2:10; 17:21*
ἐπιδιατάσσομαι: to enjoin anything additional, superadd an injunction, Gal. 3:15*
ἐπιδίδωμι: to give in addition; also, to give to, deliver to, give into one’s hands, Mt. 7:9, 10; Lk. 4:17; 11:11f.; 24:30, 42; Acts 15:30; intrans. probably a nautical term, to commit a ship to the wind, let her drive, Acts 27:15*
ἐπιδιορθόω: to set further to rights, to carry on an amendment, correct, Tit. 1:5*
ἐπιδύω: to set upon, to set during, Eph. 4:26*
ἐπιείκεια: also spelled ἐπιεικία, reasonableness, equity; in NT gentleness, mildness, 2 Cor. 10:1; clemency, Acts 24:4*
ἐπιεικής: pr. suitable; fair, reasonable; gentle, mild, patient, 1 Tim. 3:3; Tit. 3:2; Jas. 3:17; 1 Pet. 2:18; τὸ ἐπιεικές, mildness, gentleness, Phil. 4:5*
ἐπιζητέω: to seek for, make search for, Acts 12:19; to require, demand, Mt. 12:39; 16:4; Acts 19:39; to desire, endeavor to obtain, Rom. 11:7; Heb. 11:14; to seek with care and anxiety, Mt. 6:32
ἐπιθανάτιος: condemned to death, under sentence of death, 1 Cor. 4:9*
ἐπίθεσις: the act of placing upon, imposition of hands, Acts 8:18; 1 Tim. 4:14; 2 Tim. 1:6; Heb. 6:2*
ἐπιθυμέω: with the gen. or acc., to set the heart upon; to desire, long for, have earnest desire, Mt. 13:17; Lk. 15:16; to lust after, Mt. 5:28; spc. to covet, Rom. 13:9
ἐπιθυμητής: one who has an ardent desire for anything, 1 Cor. 10:6*
ἐπιθυμία: earnest desire, Lk. 22:15; irregular or violent desire, Mk. 4:19; spc. impure desire, lust, Rom. 1:24; met. the object of desire, what enkindles desire, 1 Jn. 2:16, 17
ἐπικαθίζω: to cause to sit upon, seat upon, Mt. 21:7 (where some mss read ἐπεκάθισεν, intrans. to sit upon)*
ἐπικαλέω: pluperfect, ἐπεκέκλητο (3 sg), to call on; to attach or connect a name, Acts 15:17; Jas. 2:7; to attach an additional name, to surname, Mt. 10:3; pass. to receive an appellation or surname, Heb. 11:16; mid. to call upon, invoke, 2 Cor. 1:23; to appeal to, Acts 25:11, 12, 21
ἐπικάλυμμα: a covering, veil; met. a cloak, 1 Pet. 2:16*
ἐπικαλύπτω: to cover over; met. to cover or veil by a pardon, Rom. 4:7*
ἐπικατάρατος: cursed, accursed; subject to the curse of condemnation, Gal. 3:10; infamous, Gal. 3:13*
ἐπίκειμαι: to lie upon, be placed upon, Jn. 11:38; 21:9; to press, urge upon, Lk. 5:1; Acts 27:20; be urgent, importunate upon, Lk. 23:23; to be imposed upon, be imposed by law, Heb. 9:10; by necessity, 1 Cor. 9:16
ἐπικέλλω: to push a ship to shore, Acts 27:41*
Ἐπικούρειος: an Epicurean, follower of the philosophy of Epicurus, Acts 17:18*
ἐπιλαμβάνομαι: to take hold of, Mt. 14:31; Mk. 8:23; to lay hold of, seize, Lk. 23:26; Acts 16:19; met. to seize on as a ground of accusation, Lk. 20:20, 26; to grasp, obtain as if by seizure, 1 Tim. 6:12, 19; to assume a portion of, to assume the nature of, or, to attach or ally one’s self to, Heb. 2:16
ἐπιλανθάνομαι: to forget, Mt. 16:5; to be forgetful, neglectful of, to disregard, Phil. 3:13; Heb. 6:10; in NT in a passive sense, forgotten, Lk. 12:6
ἐπιλέγω: to call, Jn. 5:2; mid. to select for one’s self, choose, Acts 15:40*
ἐπιλείπω: to be insufficient, to run short, to fail, Heb. 11:32*
ἐπίλυσις: a loosing, liberation; met. interpretation of what is enigmatical and obscure, 2 Pet. 1:20*
ἐπιλύω: to loose what has previously been fastened or entangled, as a knot; met. to solve, to explain, what is enigmatical, as a parable, Mk. 4:34; to settle, put an end to a matter of debate, Acts 19:39*
ἐπιμαρτυρέω: to bear testimony to; to testify solemnly, 1 Pet. 5:12*
ἐπιμελέομαι: gen., to take care of, Lk. 10:34f.; 1 Tim. 3:5*
ἐπιμένω: to stay longer, prolong a stay, remain on, Acts 10:48; 15:34; to continue, persevere, Jn. 8:7; Acts 12:16; to adhere to, continue to embrace, Acts 13:43; Rom. 11:22; to persist in, Rom. 6:1; 1 Cor. 16:8
ἐπινεύω: to nod to; met. to assent to, consent, Acts 18:20*
ἐπιορκέω: to forswear one’s self, to fail of observing one’s oath, Mt. 5:33*
ἐπίορκος: one who violates his oath, perjured, 1 Tim. 1:10*
ἐπιούσιος: This word occurs nowhere else in Greek literature except in the context of the Lord’s prayer. Guesses include, necessary for today, necessary for tomorrow, daily, sufficient, Mt. 6:11; Lk. 11:3*
ἐπιπίπτω: to fall upon; to throw one’s self upon, Lk. 15:20; Jn. 13:25; Acts 20:10, 37; to press, urge upon, Mk. 3:10; to light upon, Rom. 15:3; to come over, Acts 13:11; to come upon, fall upon mentally or spiritually, Lk. 1:12; Acts 8:16; 10:10, 44; 11:15; 19:17
ἐπιπλήσσω: pr. to inflict blows upon; met. to chide, reprove, 1 Tim. 5:1*
ἐπιποθέω: to desire besides; also, to desire earnestly, long for, 2 Cor. 5:2; to have a strong bent, Jas. 4:5; by impl. to love, have affection for, 2 Cor. 9:14
ἐπιπορεύομαι: to travel to; to come to, Lk. 8:4*
ἐπιράπτω: also ἐπιρράπτω, to sew on, Mk. 2:21*
ἐπιρίπτω: to throw upon, cast upon, Lk. 19:35; 1 Pet. 5:7*
ἐπίσημος: pr. bearing a distinctive mark or device; noted, eminent, Rom. 16:7; notorious, Mt. 27:16*
ἐπισκέπτομαι: to look at observantly, to inspect; to look out, select, Acts 6:3; to go see, visit, Acts 7:23; 15:36; to visit for the purpose of comfort and relief, Mt. 25:36, 43; Jas. 1:27; from the Hebrew, of God, to visit, Lk. 1:68, 78
ἐπισκευάζομαι: to prepare for a journey, Acts 21:15*
ἐπισκηνόω: to quarter in or at; met. to abide upon, 2 Cor. 12:9*
ἐπισκιάζω: to overshadow, Mt. 17:5; met. to shed influence upon, Lk. 1:35
ἐπισκοπέω: to look at, inspect; met. to be circumspect, heedful, Heb. 12:15; to oversee, to exercise the office of ἐπίσκοπος, 1 Pet. 5:2*
ἐπισκοπή: inspection, oversight, visitation; of God, visitation, interposition, whether in mercy or judgment, Lk. 19:44; 1 Pet. 2:12; the office of an ecclesiastical overseer, 1 Tim. 3:1; from the Hebrew, charge, function, Acts 1:20*
ἐπίσκοπος: pr. an inspector, overseer; a watcher, guardian, 1 Pet. 2:25; in NT an ecclesiastical overseer, Acts 20:28; Phil. 1:1; 1 Tim. 3:2; Tit. 1:7*
ἐπισπάομαι: to draw upon or after; in NT mid. to obliterate circumcision by artificial extension of the foreskin, 1 Cor. 7:18*
ἐπισπείρω: to sow in or among, Mt. 13:25*
ἐπίσταμαι: to be versed in, to be master of, 1 Tim. 6:4; to be acquainted with, Acts 18:25; 19:15; Jude 10: to know, Acts 10:28; to remember, comprehend, understand, Mk. 14:68
ἐπίστασις: pr. care of, attention to, 2 Cor. 11:28
ἐπιστάτης: pr. one who stands by; one who is set over; in NT in voc., equivalent to διδάσκαλε, or ῥαββί, master, doctor, Lk. 5:5; 8:24, 45; 9:33, 49; 17:13*
ἐπιστέλλω: to send word to, to send injunctions, Acts 15:20; 21:25; to write to, write a letter, Heb. 13:22*
ἐπιστηρίζω: pr. to cause to rest or lean on, to settle upon; met. to conform, strengthen, establish, 14:22; 15:32, 41; 18:23*
ἐπιστολή: word sent; an order, command; an epistle, letter, Acts 9:2; 15:30
ἐπιστομίζω: to apply a curb or muzzle; met. to put to silence, Tit. 1:11*
ἐπιστρέφω: trans. to turn towards; to turn round; to bring back, convert, Lk. 1:16, 17; Jas. 5:19, 20; intrans. and mid. to turn one’s self upon or towards, Acts 9:40; Rev. 1:12; to turn about, Mt. 9:22; to turn back, return, Mt. 12:44; met. to be converted, Acts 28:27
ἐπιστροφή: a turning towards, a turning about; in NT met. conversion, Acts 15:3*
ἐπισυνάγω: to gather to a place; to gather together, assemble, convene, Mt. 23:37; 24:31; Lk. 17:37
ἐπισυναγωγή: the act of being gathered together or assembled, 2 Thess. 2:1; an assembling together, Heb. 10:25*
ἐπισυντρέχω: to run together to a place, Mk. 9:25*
ἐπισφαλής: on the verge of falling, unsteady; met. insecure, hazardous, dangerous, Acts 27:9*
ἐπισχύω: to strengthen; intrans. to gather strength; met. to be urgent, to press on a point, insist, Lk. 23:5*
ἐπισωρεύω: to heap up, accumulate largely; met. to procure in abundance, 2 Tim. 4:3*
ἐπιταγή: injunction, 1 Cor. 7:6, 25; 2 Cor. 8:8; a decree, Rom. 16:26; 1 Tim. 1:1; Tit. 1:3; authoritativeness, strictness, Tit. 2:15*
ἐπιτάσσω: with dat., to set over or upon; to enjoin, charge, Mk. 1:27; 6:39; Lk. 4:36
ἐπιτελέω: to bring to an end; to finish, complete, perfect, Rom. 15:28; 2 Cor. 8:6, 11; to perform, Lk. 13:32; to carry into practice, to realize, 2 Cor. 7:1; to discharge, Heb. 9:6; to execute, Heb. 8:5; to carry out to completion, Phil. 1:6; mid. to end, make an end, Gal. 3:3; pass. to be fully undergone, endured, 1 Pet. 5:9
ἐπιτίθημι: to put, place, or lay upon, Mt. 9:18; Lk. 4:40; to impose a name, Mk. 3:16, 17; to inflict, Acts 16:23; Lk. 10:30; Rev. 22:18; mid. to impose with authority, Acts 15:28; 28:10; to set or fall upon, assail, assault, attack, Acts 18:10
ἐπιτιμάω: pr. to set a value upon; to assess a penalty; to allege as a crimination; hence, to reprove, chide, censure, rebuke, reprimand, Mt. 19:13; Lk. 23:40; in NT to admonish strongly, enjoin strictly, Mt. 12:16; Lk. 17:3
ἐπιτρέπω: to give over, to leave to the entire trust or management of any one; hence, to permit, allow, suffer, Mt. 8:21; Mk. 5:13
ἐπιτροπή: a trust; a commission, permission, Acts 26:12*
ἐπίτροπος: one to whose charge or control a thing is left; a steward, bailiff, agent, manager, Mt. 20:8; steward or overseer of the revenue, treasurer, Lk. 8:3; a guardian of children, Gal. 4:2*
ἐπιτυγχάνω: to light upon, find; to hit, reach; to acquire, obtain, attain, Rom. 11:7 (2x); Heb. 6:15; 11:33; Jas. 4:2*
ἐπιφαίνω: to make to appear, to display; pass. to be manifested, revealed, Tit. 2:11; 3:4; intrans. to give light, shine, Lk. 1:79; Acts 27:20*
ἐπιφάνεια: appearance, manifestation, 1 Tim. 6:14; 2 Tim. 1:10; glorious display, 2 Thess. 2:8; 2 Tim. 4:1, 8; Tit. 2:13*
ἐπιφαύσκω: to shine upon, give light to, enlighten, Eph. 5:14*
ἐπιφέρω: to bring upon or against, Jude 9; to inflict, Rom. 3:5*
ἐπιφωνέω: to cry aloud, raise a shout at a speaker, whether applaudingly, Acts 12:22; or the contrary, to clamor at, Lk. 23:21; Acts 21:34; 22:24*
ἐπιφώσκω: to dawn, Mt. 28:1; hence, used of the reckoned commencement of the day, to be near commencing, to dawn on, Lk. 23:54*
ἐπιχειρέω: to put hand to a thing; to undertake, attempt, Lk. 1:1; Acts 9:29; 19:13*
ἐπιχορηγέω: to supply further; to superadd, 2 Pet. 1:5; to supply, furnish, give, 2 Cor. 9:10; Gal. 3:5; 2 Pet. 1:11; pass. to gather vigor, Col. 2:19*
ἐπιχρίω: to smear upon, to anoint, Jn. 9:6, 11*
ἐποικοδομέω: to build upon, 1 Cor. 3:10, 12, 14; pass. met. to be built upon as parts of a spiritual structure, Eph. 2:20; to build up, carry up a building; met. to build up in spiritual advancement,Col. 2:7; Jude 20*
ἐπονομάζω: to attach a name to; pass. to be named, Rom. 2:17*
ἐποπτεύω: to look upon, observe, watch; to witness, be an eye-witness of, 1 Pet. 2:12; 3:2*
ἔπος: a word, that which is expressed by words; ὡς ἔπος εἰπεῖν, so to say, if the expression may be allowed, Heb. 7:9*
ἐπουράνιος: heavenly, in respect of locality, Eph. 1:20; Phil. 2:10; τὰ ἐπουράνια, the upper regions of the air, Eph. 6:12; heavenly, in respect of essence and character, unearthly, 1 Cor. 15:48, 49; met. divine, spiritual, Jn. 3:12
ἑπτά: seven, indecl. numeral, Mt. 15:34, 37; by Jewish usage for a round number, Mt. 12:45; Lk. 11:26
Ἔραστος: Erastus, pr. name, Acts 19:22; Rom. 16:23; 2 Tim. 4:20*
ἐραυνάω: to search, examine, investigate, Jn. 5:39; 7:52; Rom. 8:27; 1 Cor. 2:10; 1 Pet. 1:11; Rev. 2:23*
ἐργάζομαι: intrans. to work, labor, Mt. 21:28; Lk. 13:14; to trade, traffic, do business, Mt. 25:16; Rev. 18:17; to act, exert one’s power, be active, Jn. 5:17; trans. to do, perform, commit, Mt. 26:10; Jn. 6:28; to be engaged in, occupied upon, 1 Cor. 9:13; Rev. 18:17; to acquire, gain by one’s labor, Jn. 6:27
ἐργασία: work, labor; in NT ἐργασίαν διδόναι, to endeavor, strive, Lk. 12:58; performance, practice, Eph. 4:19; a trade, business, craft, Acts 19:25, gain acquired by labor or trade, profit, Acts 16:16, 19; 19:24*
ἐργάτης: a workman, laborer, Mt. 9:37, 38; 20:1, 2, 8; met. a spiritual workman or laborer, 2 Cor. 11:13; an artisan, artificer, Acts 19:25; a worker, practicer, Lk. 13:27
ἔργον: anything done or to be done; a deed, work, action, Jn. 3:21; Eph. 2:10; 2 Cor. 9:8, et al. freq.; duty enjoined, office, charge, business, Mk. 13:34; Jn. 4:34, et al. freq.; a process, course of action, Jas. 1:4; a work, product of an action or process, Acts 7:41; Heb. 1:10; substance in effect, Rom. 2:15
ἐρεθίζω: to provoke, to irritate, exasperate, Col. 3:21; to incite, stimulate, 2 Cor. 9:2*
ἐρείδω: to make to lean upon; to fix firmly; intrans. to become firmly fixed, stick fast, Acts 27:41*
ἐρεύγομαι: to vomit; met. to utter, declare openly, Mt. 13:35*
ἐρημία: a solitude, uninhabited region, waste, desert, Mt. 15:33; Mk. 8:4; 2 Cor. 11:26; Heb. 11:38*
ἔρημος: lone, desert, waste, uninhabited, Mt. 14:13, 15; Mk. 6:31, 32, 35; lone, abandoned to ruin, Mt. 23:38; Lk. 13:35; met. lone, unmarried, Gal. 4:27; as a subst. a desert, uninhabited region, waste, Mt. 3:1; 24:26; Acts 7:36
ἐρημόω: to lay waste, make desolate, bring to ruin, Mt. 12:25; Lk. 11:17; Rev. 17:16; 18:17, 19*
ἐρίζω: to quarrel; to wrangle; to use the harsh tone of a wrangler or brawler, to grate, Mt. 12:19*
ἐριθεία: the service of a party, party spirit; feud, faction, 2 Cor. 12:20; contentious disposition, selfish ambition, Gal. 5:20; Phil. 1:17; 2:3; Jas. 3:14; by impl. untowardness, disobedience, Rom. 2:8; Jas. 3:16*
ἔρις: altercation, strife, Rom. 13:13; contentious disposition, Rom. 1:29; Phil. 1:15
ἑρμηνεία: interpretation, explanation, 1 Cor. 14:26; meton. the power or faculty of interpreting, 1 Cor. 12:10*
ἑρμηνεύω: to explain, interpret, translate, Jn. 1:42; 9:7; Heb. 7:2*
Ἑρμῆς: Hermes or Mercury, son of Jupiter and Maia, the messenger and interpreter of the gods, and the patron of eloquence, learning, etc., Acts 14:12; Rom. 16:14*
ἑρπετόν: a creeping animal, a reptile, Acts 10:12; 11:6; Rom. 1:23; Jas. 3:7*
ἔρχομαι: to come, to go, to pass. By the combination of this verb with other terms, a variety of meaning results, which, however, is due, not to a change of meaning in the verb, but to the adjuncts. Ὁ ἐρχόμενος, He who is coming, the expected Messiah, Mt. 11:3
ἐρωτάω: to ask, interrogate, inquire of, Mt. 21:24; Lk. 20:3; in NT to ask, request, beg, beseech, Mt. 15:23; Lk. 4:38; Jn. 14:16
ἐσθής: also spelled ἔσθησις, a robe, vestment, raiment, garment, Lk. 23:11; 24:4; Acts 1:10; 10:30; 12:21; Jas. 2:2, 3*
ἐσθίω: to eat, Mt. 12:1; 15:27; ἐσθίειν καὶ πίνειν, to eat and drink, to eat and drink in the usual manner, follow the common mode of living, Mt. 11:18; also with the associated notion of supposed security, Lk. 17:27; to feast, banquet, Mt. 24:49; met. to devour, consume, Heb. 10:27; Jas. 5:3; from the Hebrew, ἄρτον ἐσθίειν, to eat bread, to take food, take the usual meals, Mt. 15:2
Ἑσρώμ: Hezron, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:3; Lk. 3:33*
ἔσχατος: farthest; last, latest, Mt. 12:45; Mk. 12:6; lowest, Mt. 19:30; 20:16; in the lowest plight, 1 Cor. 4:9
ἐσχάτως: to be in the last extremity, Mk. 5:23*
ἔσω: can function as an improper prep., in, within, in the interior of, Mt. 26:58; Jn. 20:26; ὁ, ἡ, τὸ ἔσω, inner, interior, internal; met. within the pale of community, 1 Cor. 5:12; ὁ ἐσω ἄνθρωπος, the inner man, the mind, soul, Rom. 7:22
ἔσωθεν: from within, from the interior, Mk. 7:21, 23; within, in the internal parts, Mt. 7:15; ὁ, ἡ, τὸ ἔσωθεν, interior, internal, Lk. 11:39, 40; ὁ ἔσωθεν ἄνθρωπος, the mind, soul, 2 Cor. 4:16
ἑταῖρος: a companion, associate, fellow-comrade, friend, Mt. 20:13; 22:12; 26:50*
ἑτερόγλωσσος: one who speaks another or foreign language, 1 Cor. 14:21*
ἑτεροδιδασκαλέω: to teach other or different doctrine, and spc. what is foreign to the Christian religion, 1 Tim. 1:3; 6:3*
ἑτεροζυγέω: to be unequally yoked or matched, 2 Cor. 6:14*
ἕτερος: other, Mt. 12:45; another, some other, Mt. 8:21; besides, Lk. 23:32; ὁ ἕτερος, the other of two, Mt. 6:24; τῇ ἑτέρᾳ, on the next day, Acts 20:15; 27:3; ὁ ἕτερος, one’s neighbor, Rom. 13:8; different, Lk. 9:29; foreign, strange, Acts 2:4; 1 Cor. 14:21; illicit, Jude 7
ἔτι: yet, still, Mt. 12:46; still, further, longer, Lk. 16:2; further, besides, in addition, Mt. 18:16; with a compar. yet, still, Phil. 1:9
ἑτοίμως: in readiness, preparedly, Acts 21:13; 2 Cor. 2:14; 1 Pet. 4:5*
εὐαγγελίζω: to address with good tidings, Rev. 10:7; 14:6; but elsewhere to proclaim as good tidings, to announce good tidings of, Lk. 1:19; to address with good tidings, Acts 13:32; 14:15; to address with the Gospel teaching, evangelize, Acts 16:10; Gal. 1:9; absol. to announce the good tidings of the Gospel, Lk. 4:18; 9:6; pass. to be announced as good tidings, Lk. 16:16; to be addressed with good tidings, Mt. 11:5; Lk. 7:22; Heb. 4:2
εὐαγγέλιον: glad tidings, good or joyful news, Mt. 4:23; 9:35; the Gospel; doctrines of the Gospel, Mt. 26:13; Mk. 8:35; meton. the preaching of, or instruction in, the Gospel, 1 Cor. 4:15; 9:14
εὐαγγελιστής: pr. one who announces glad tidings; an evangelist, preacher of the Gospel, teacher of the Christian religion, Acts 21:8; Eph. 4:11; 2 Tim. 4:5*
εὐαρεστέω: to please, Heb. 11:5, 6; pass. to take pleasure in, be well pleased with, Heb. 13:16*
εὐγενής: well-born, of high rank, honorable, Lk. 19:12; 1 Cor. 1:26; generous, candid, Acts 17:11*
εὐδία: serenity of the heavens, a cloudless sky, fair or fine weather, Mt. 16:2*
εὐδοκέω: to think well, approve, consent, take delight or pleasure, Mt. 3:17; 17:5; Mk. 1:11; Lk. 3:22; 12:32
εὐδοκία: good will, favor, Lk. 2:14; good pleasure, purpose, intention, Mt. 11:26; Lk. 10:21; Eph. 1:5, 9; Phil. 2:13; by impl. desire, Rom. 10:1; Phil. 1:15; 2 Thess. 1:11*
εὐεργεσία: well-doing, a good deed, benefit conferred, Acts 4:9; duty, good offices, 1 Tim. 6:2*
εὐεργετέω: to do good, exercise beneficence, Acts 10:38*
εὔθετος: pr. well arranged, rightly disposed; fit, proper, adapted, Lk. 9:62; 14:35; useful, Heb. 6:7*
εὐθυδρομέω: to run on a straight course; to sail on a direct course, Acts 16:11; 21:1*
εὐθυμέω: to be cheerful, be in good spirits, take courage, Acts 27:22, 25; Jas. 5:13*
εὔθυμος: good cheer or courage, cheerful, Acts 27:36*
εὐθύνω: to guide straight; to direct, guide, steer a ship, Jas. 3:4; to make straight, Jn. 1:23*
εὐθύς: straight forwards; directly, immediately, instantly, Mt. 3:16; 13:20, 21
εὐκαιρέω: to have convenient time or opportunity, have leisure, Mk. 6:31; 1 Cor. 16:12; to be at leisure for a thing, to be disposed to attend, to give time, Acts 17:21*
εὐκαιρία: convenient opportunity, favorable occasion, Mt. 26:16; Lk. 22:6*
εὔκαιρος: timely, opportune, seasonable, convenient, Mk. 6:21; Heb. 4:16*
εὐλάβεια: the disposition of one who is εὐλαβής, caution, circumspection; in NT reverence to God, piety, Heb. 5:7; 12:28*
εὐλαβέομαι: to fear, be afraid or apprehensive; in NT absol. to reverence God, to be influenced by pious awe, Heb. 11:7*
εὐλαβής: pr. taking hold of well, i.e., warily; hence, cautious, circumspect; full of reverence towards God, devout, pious, religious, Lk. 2:25; Acts 2:5; 8:2; 22:12*
εὐλογέω: pr. to speak well of, in NT to bless, ascribe praise and glorification, Lk. 1:64; to bless, invoke a blessing upon, Mt. 5:44; to bless, confer a favor or blessing upon, Eph. 1:3; Heb. 6:14; pass. to be blessed, to be an object of favor or blessing, Lk. 1:28
εὐλογητός: worthy of praise or blessing, blessed, Mk. 14:61; Lk. 1:68
εὐλογία: pr. good speaking; fair speech, flattery, Rom. 16:18; in NT blessing, praise, celebration, 1 Cor. 10:16; Rev. 5:12, 13; invocation of good, benediction, Jas. 3:10; a divine blessing, Rom. 15:29; a gift, benevolence, 2 Cor. 9:5; a frank gift, as opposed to πλεονεξία, 2 Cor. 9:5; ἐπ’ εὐλογίαις, liberally, 2 Cor. 9:6
εὐνοέω: to have kind thoughts, be well affected or kindly disposed towards, make friends, Mt. 5:25*
εὔνοια: good will, kindliness; heartiness, enthusiasm, Eph. 6:7*
εὐνοῦχος: pr. one who has charge of the bedchamber; hence, a eunuch, one emasculated, Mt. 19:12; as eunuchs in the East often rose to places of power and trust, hence, a minister of a court, Acts 8:27, 34, 36, 38f.*
εὐοδόω: to give a prosperous journey; cause to prosper or be successful; pass. to have a prosperous journey, to succeed in a journey, Rom. 1:10; met. to be furthered, to prosper, temporally or spiritually, 1 Cor. 16:2; 3 Jn. 2 (2x)*
εὐπάρεδρος: constantly attending; devoted to; τὸ εὐπάρεδρον, devotedness, 1 Cor. 7:35*
εὐπορέω: to be in prosperous circumstances, enjoy plenty, Acts 11:29*
εὐπρόσδεκτος: acceptable, grateful, pleasing, Rom. 15:16, 31; 2 Cor. 6:2; 8:12; 1 Pet. 2:5; in NT gracious*
εὐπροσωπέω: to carry or make a fair appearance, Gal. 6:12*
εὐρακύλων: also spelled εὐρυκλύδων and εὐροκλύδων, which BDAG 411, says was probably due to scribal error, euracylon, the name of a tempestuous southeast wind, Acts 27:14*
εὑρίσκω: to find, to meet with; Mt. 18:28; 20:6; to find out, to detect, discover, Lk. 23:2, 4, 14; to acquire, obtain, win, gain, Lk. 1:30; 9:12; to find mentally, to comprehend, recognize, Acts 17:27; Rom. 7:21; to find by experience, observe, gather, Rom. 7:18; to devise as feasible, Lk. 5:19; 19:48
εὐσέβεια: reverential feeling; piety, devotion, godliness, Acts 3:12; 1 Tim. 2:2; 4:7, 8; religion, the Christian religion, 1 Tim. 3:16
εὐσεβέω: to exercise piety; towards a deity, to worship, Acts 17:23; towards relatives, to be dutiful towards, 1 Tim. 5:4*
εὐσεβής: reverent; pious, devout, religious, Acts 10:2, 7; 2 Pet. 2:9*
εὔσημος: pr. well marked, strongly marked; met. significant, intelligible, 1 Cor. 14:9*
εὐσχημόνως: in a becoming manner, with propriety, decently, gracefully, Rom. 13:13; 1 Cor. 14:40; 1 Thess. 4:12*
εὐσχημοσύνη: comeliness, gracefulness; artificial comeliness, ornamental array, embellishment, 1 Cor. 12:23*
εὐσχήμων: of good appearance, pleasing to look upon, comely, 1 Cor. 12:24; met. becoming, decent, τὸ εὔσχημον, decorum, propriety, 1 Cor. 7:35; honorable, reputable, of high standing and influence, Mk. 15:43; Acts 13:50; 17:12*
εὐτραπελία: facetiousness, pleasantry; hence, buffoonery, coarse laughter, Eph. 5:4*
εὐφημία: pr. use of words of good omen; hence, favorable expression, praise, commendation, 2 Cor. 6:8*
εὔφημος: pr. of good omen, auspicious; hence, of good report, commendable, laudable, reputable, Phil. 4:8*
εὐφορέω: to bear or bring forth well or plentifully, yield abundantly, Lk. 12:16*
εὐφραίνω: to gladden, 2 Cor. 2:2; pass. to be glad, exult, rejoice, Lk. 12:19; Acts 2:26; mid. to feast in token of joy, keep a day of rejoicing, Lk. 15:23, 24, 29, 32
εὐχαριστέω: to thank, Lk. 17:16; absol. to give thanks, Mt. 15:36; 26:27; pass. to be made a matter of thankfulness, 2 Cor. 1:11
εὐχαριστία: gratitude, thankfulness, Acts 24:3; thanks, the act of giving thanks, thanksgiving, 1 Cor. 14:16; conversation marked by the gentle cheerfulness of a grateful heart, as contrasted with the unseemly mirth of εὐτραπελία, Eph. 5:4
εὐχάριστος: grateful, pleasing; mindful of benefits, thankful, Col. 3:15*
εὐχή: a wish, prayer, Jas. 5:15; a vow, Acts 21:23; Acts 18:18*
εὔχομαι: to pray, offer prayer, Acts 26:29; 2 Cor. 13:7, 9; Jas. 5:16; to wish, desire, Acts 27:29; Rom. 9:3; 3 Jn. 2*
εὔχρηστος: highly useful, very profitable, 2 Tim. 2:21; 4:11; Phlm. 11*
εὐψυχέω: to be animated, encouraged, in good spirits, Phil. 2:19*
εὐωδία: a sweet smell, grateful odor, fragrance, 2 Cor. 2:15; Eph. 5:2; Phil. 4:18*
εὐώνυμος: of good name or omen; used also as an euphemism by the Greeks instead of ἀριστερός, which was a word of bad import, as all omens on the left denoted misfortune; the left, Mt. 20:21, 23; 25:33, 41
ἐφάλλομαι: to leap or spring upon, assault, Acts 19:16*
ἐφάπαξ: once for all, Rom. 6:10; Heb. 7:27; 9:12; 10:10; at once, 1 Cor. 15:6*
Ἔφεσος: Ephesus, a celebrated city of Asia Minor, Acts 18:19, 21, 24; 1 Cor. 15:32*
ἐφημερία: pr. daily course; the daily service of the temple; a class of priests to which the daily service for a week was allotted in rotation, Lk. 1:5, 8*
ἐφήμερος: lasting for a day; daily sufficient for a day, necessary for every day, Jas. 2:15*
ἐφικνέομαι: to come or reach to, to reach a certain point or end; to reach, arrive at, 2 Cor. 10:13, 14*
ἐφίστημι: trans. to place upon, over, close by; intrans. to stand by or near, Lk. 2:38; 4:39; to come suddenly upon, Lk. 2:9; 24:4; to come upon, assault, Acts 6:12; 17:5; to come near, approach, Lk. 10:40; to impend, be instant, to be at hand, 1 Thess. 5:3; to be present, Acts 28:2; to be pressing, urgent, earnest, 2 Tim. 4:2
ἐφοράω: a proposed lexical form for the second aorist ἐπεῖδον
Ἐφραίμ: Ephraim, pr. name, indecl. Jn. 11:54*. See PhotoGuide.
ἔχθρα: enmity, discord, feud, Lk. 23:12; Gal. 5:20; alienation, Eph. 2:14, 16; a principle or state of enmity, Rom. 8:7; Jas. 4:4*
ἐχθρός: hated, under disfavor, Rom. 11:28; inimical, hostile, Mt. 13:28; Col. 1:21; as a subst., an enemy, adversary, Mt. 5:43, 44; 10:36; Lk. 27:35
ἔχιδνα: a viper, poisonous serpent, Acts 28:3; used also fig. of persons, Mt. 3:7; 12:34; 23:33; Lk. 3:7*
ἔχω: pluperfect., ἐσχήκειν, to hold, Rev. 1:16; to seize, possess a person, Mk. 16:8; to have, possess, Mt. 7:29, et al. freq.; to have, have ready, be furnished with, Mt. 5:23; Jn. 5:36; 6:68; to have as a matter of crimination, Mt. 5:23; Mk. 11:25; to have at command, Mt. 27:65; to have the power, be able, Mt. 18:25; Lk. 14:14; Acts 4:14; to have in marriage, Mt. 14:4; to have, be affected by, subjected to, Mt. 3:14; 12:10; Mk. 3:10; Jn. 12:48; 15:22, 24; 16:21, 22; Acts 23:29; 1 Tim. 5:12; Heb. 7:28; 1 Jn. 1:8; 4:18; χάραν ἔχειν, to feel gratitude, be thankful, 1 Tim. 1:12; 2 Tim. 1:3; Phlm. 7; to hold, esteem, regard, Mt. 14:5; Lk. 14:18, 19; to have or hold as an object of knowledge, faith, or practice, Jn. 5:38, 42; 14:21; 1 Jn. 5:12; 2 Jn. 9; to hold on in entire possession, to retain, Rom. 15:4; 2 Tim. 1:13; Heb. 12:28; intrans. with adverbs or adverbial expression, to be, to fare, Mt. 9:12; Mk. 2:17; 5:23; Lk. 5:31; Jn. 4:52; Acts 7:1; 12:15; 15:36; 21:13; 2 Cor. 10:6; 12:14; 1 Tim. 5:25; 1 Pet. 4:5; τὸ νῦν ἔχον, for the present; in NT ἔχειν ἐν γαστρί, to be pregnant, Mt. 1:18; as also ἔχειν κοίτην, Rom. 9:10; ἔχειν δαιμόνιον, to be possessed, Mt. 11:18; of time, to have continued, to have lived, Jn. 5:5, 6; 8:57; of space, to embrace, be distant, Acts 1:12; mid. pr. to hold by, cling to; hence, to border upon, be next, Mk. 1:38; Lk. 13:33; Acts 20:15; 21:26; to tend immediately to, Heb. 6:9
ἕως: can function as an improper prep., while, as long as, Jn. 9:4; until, Mt. 2:9; Lk. 15:4; as also in NT ἕως οὗ, ἕως ὅτου, Mt. 5:18, 26; ἕως ἄρτι, until now, Mt. 11:12; ἕως πότε, until when, how long, Mt. 17:17; ἕως σήμερον, until this day, to this time, 2 Cor. 3:15; as a prep. of time, until, Mt. 24:21; of place, unto, even to, Mt. 11:23; Lk. 2:15; ἕως ἄνω, to the brim, Jn. 2:7; ἕως εἰς, even to, as far as, Lk. 24:50; ἕως κάτω, to the bottom; ἕως ὥδε, to this place, Lk. 23:5; of state, unto, even to, Mt. 26:38; of number, even, so much as, Rom. 3:12, et al. freq.
Ζαβουλών: Zebulun, pr. name, indecl., an Israelite tribe, Mt. 4:13, 15; Rev. 7:8*
Ζαχαρίας: Zacharias, pr. name. (1) Son of Barachias, Mt. 23:35; Lk. 11:51. (2) Father of Jn. the Baptist, Lk. 1:5
ζάω: to live, to be possessed of vitality, to exercise the functions of life, Mt. 27:63; Acts 17:28; τὸ ζῆν, life, Heb. 2:15; to have means of subsistence, 1 Cor. 9:14; to live, to pass existence in a specific manner, Lk. 2:36; 15:13; to be instinct with life and vigor; hence, ζῶν, living, an epithet of God, in a sense peculiar to Himself; ἐλπὶς ζῶσα, a living hope vigor and constancy, 1 Pet. 1:3; ὕδωρ ζῶν, living water in respect of a full and unfailing flow, Jn. 4:10, 11; to be alive with cheered and hopeful feelings, 1 Thess. 3:8; to be alive in a state of salvation from spiritual death, 1 Jn. 4:9
Ζεβεδαῖος: Zebedee, pr. name, the father of Jas. and John, Mt. 4:21; Mk. 10:35; Lk. 5:10; Jn. 21:1*
ζεστός: pr. boiled; boiling, boiling hot; met. glowing with zeal, fervent, Rev. 3:15, 16*
ζεῦγος: a yoke of animals; a pair, couple, Lk. 2:24; 14:19*
Ζεύς: the supreme god of the Greeks answering to the Jupiter of the Romans, Acts 14:12, 13*
ζέω: to boil, to be hot, in NT met. to be fervent, ardent, zealous, Acts 18:25; Rom. 12:11*
ζηλεύω: to be zealous, earnest, eager, Rev. 3:19*
ζῆλος: generous rivalry; noble aspiration; in NT zeal, ardor in behalf of, ardent affection, Jn. 2:17; Rom. 10:2; in a bad sense, jealousy, envy, malice, Acts 13:45; Rom. 13:13; indignation, wrath, Acts 5:17
ζηλόω: to have strong affection towards, be ardently devoted to, 2 Cor. 11:2; to make a show of affection and devotion towards, Gal. 4:17; to desire earnestly, aspire eagerly after, 1 Cor. 12:31; 14:1, 39; absol. to be fervent, to be zealous, Rev. 3:19; to be jealous, envious, spiteful, Acts 7:9; 17:5; 1 Cor. 13:4; Jas. 4:2; pass. to be an object of warm regard and devotion, Gal. 4:18
ζηλωτής: pr. a generous rival, an imitator; in NT an aspirant, 1 Cor. 14:12; Tit. 2:14; a devoted adherent, a zealot, Acts 21:20; 22:3; Gal. 1:14
ζητέω: to seek, look for, Mt. 18:12; Lk. 2:48, 49; to search after, Mt. 13:45; to be on the watch for, Mt. 26:16; to pursue, endeavor to obtain, Rom. 2:7; 1 Pet. 3:11; to desire, wish, want, Mt. 12:47; to seek, strive for, Mt. 6:33; to endeavor, Mt. 21:46; to require, demand, ask for, Mk. 8:11; Lk. 11:16; 12:48; to inquire or ask questions, question, Jn. 16:19; to deliberate, Mk. 11:18; Lk. 12:29; in NT from Hebrew, ζητεῖν τὴν ψυχήν, to seek the life of any one, to seek to kill, Mt. 2:20
ζήτημα: a question; a subject of debate or controversy, Acts 15:2; 18:15; 23:29; 25:19; 26:3*
ζήτησις: a seeking; an inquiry, a question; a dispute, debate, discussion, Jn. 3:25; 1 Tim. 6:4; a subject of dispute or controversy, Acts 15:2, 7; 25:20; 2 Tim. 2:23; Tit. 3:9
ζιζάνιον: zizanium, darnel, spurious wheat, a plant found in Palestine, which resembles wheat both in its stalk and grain, but is worthless, Mt. 13:25, 26, 27, 29, 30, 36, 38, 40*
Ζοροβαβέλ: Zorobabel, pr. name, indecl. (Ezra 2:2; 3:8), Mt. 1:12, 13; Lk. 3:27*
ζόφος: gloom, thick darkness, Heb. 12:18; 2 Pet. 2:4, 17; Jude 6, 13*
ζυγός: also spelled ζυγόν, ου, τό (n-2c), pr. a cross bar or band; a yoke; met. a yoke of servile condition, 1 Tim. 6:1; a yoke of service or obligation, Mt. 11:29, 30; Acts 15:10; Gal. 5:1; the beam of a balance; a balance, Rev. 6:5*
ζύμη: leaven, yeast, Mt. 16:12; 13:33; met. leaven of the mind and conduct, by a system of doctrine or morals, used in a bad sense, Mt. 16:6, 11; 1 Cor. 5:6
ζυμόω: to leaven, cause to ferment, Mt. 13:33; Lk. 13:21; 1 Cor. 5:6; Gal. 5:9*
ζωγρέω: pr. to take alive, take prisoner in war instead of killing; to take captive, enthral, 2 Tim. 2:26; also, to catch animals, as fish; in which sense it is used figuratively, Lk. 5:10*
ζωή: life, living existence, Lk. 16:25; Acts 17:25; in NT spiritual life of deliverance from the proper penalty of sin, which is expressed by θάνατος, Jn. 6:51; Rom. 5:18; 6:4; the final life of the redeemed, Mt. 25:46; life, source of spiritual life, Jn. 5:39; 11:25; Col. 3:4
ζώνη: a zone, belt, girdle, Mt. 3:4; 10:9; Mk. 1:6; 6:8; Acts 21:11; Rev. 1:13; 15:6*
ζώννυμι: also spelled ζωννύω, to gird, gird on, put on one’s girdle, Jn. 21:18 (2x), Acts 12:8*
ζῳογονέω: pr. to bring forth living creatures; in NT to preserve alive, save, Lk. 17:33; Acts 7:19; 1 Tim. 6:13*
ζῷον: a living creature, animal, Heb. 13:11; 2 Pet. 2:12
ζῳοποιέω: pr. to engender living creatures; to quicken, make alive, Rom. 4:17; 8:11; 1 Cor. 15:36; in NT met. to quicken with the life of salvation, Jn. 6:63; 2 Cor. 3:6
ἤ: can function as a conj (298x), either, or, Mt. 6:24; after comparatives, and ἄλλος, ἕτερος, expressed or implied, than, Mt. 10:15; 18:8; Acts 17:21; 24:21; intensive after ἀλλά and πρίν, Lk. 12:51; Mt. 1:18; it also serves to point an interrogation, Rom. 3:29
ἡγεμονεύω: to be a guide, leader, chief; in NT to hold the office of a Roman provincial governor, Lk. 2:2; 3:1*
ἡγεμονία: leadership, sovereignty; in NT a reign, Lk. 3:1*
ἡγεμών: a guide; a leader; a chieftain, prince, Mt. 2:6; a Roman provincial governor, under whatever title, Mt. 10:18; 27:2; Lk. 20:20; Acts 23:24
ἡγέομαι: to lead the way; to take the lead, Acts 14:12; to be chief, to preside, govern, rule, Mt. 2:6; Acts 7:10; ἡγούμενος, a chief officer in the church, Heb. 13:7, 17, 24; also, to think, consider, count, esteem, regard, Acts 26:2; 2 Cor. 9:5
ἡδέως: with pleasure, gladly, willingly, Mk. 6:20; 12:37; 2 Cor. 11:19
ἤδη: before now, now, already, Mt. 3:10; 5:28; ἤδη ποτέ, at length, Rom. 1:10; Phil. 4:10
ἡδονή: pleasure, gratification; esp. sensual pleasure, Lk. 8:14; Tit. 3:3; Jas. 4:3; 2 Pet. 2:13; a passion, Jas. 4:1*
ἦθος: pr. a place of customary resort; hence, a settled habit of mind and manners, 1 Cor. 15:33*
ἥκω: to become, have arrived, Mt. 8:11; Mk. 8:3; Lk. 15:27; Rev. 15:4*
Ἠλί: Heli, the father of Joseph, Lk. 3:23*
ἡλικία: a particular period of life; the period fitted for a particular function, prime, Heb. 11:11; full age, years of discretion, Jn. 9:21, 23; perhaps, the whole duration of life, Mt. 6:27; Lk. 12:25; otherwise, stature, Lk. 2:52; 19:3; Eph. 4:13*
ἡλίκος: as great as; how great, Col. 2:1; Jas. 3:5 (2x)*
ἥλιος: the sun, Mt. 13:43; 17:2; Mk. 1:32; meton. light of the sun, light, Acts 13:11
ἡμέρα: day, a day, the interval from sunrise to sunset, opp. to νύξ, Mt. 4:2; 12:40; Lk. 2:44; the interval of twenty-four hours, comprehending day and night, Mt. 6:34; 15:32; from the Hebrew, ἡμέρᾳ καὶ ἡμέρᾳ, day by day, every day, 2 Cor. 4:16; ἡμέραν ἐξ ἡμέρας, from day to day, continually, 2 Pet. 2:8; καθ’ ἡμέραν, every day, daily, Acts 17:17; Heb. 3:13; a point or period of time, Lk. 19:42; Acts 15:7; Eph. 6:13; a judgement, trial, 1 Cor. 4:3
ἡμιώριον: also spelled ἡμίωρον, half an hour, Rev. 8:1*
ἤπερ: strengthened form of ἤ, than, Jn. 12:43*
Ἡρῴδης: Herod, pr. name. (1) Herod the Great, Mt. 2:1. (2) Herod Antipas, tetrarch of Galilee and Peraea, Mt. 14:1. (3) Herod Agrippa, Acts 12:1
Ἡρῳδιανοί: Herodians, partisans of Ἡρῴδης, Herod Antipas, Mt. 22:16; Mk. 3:6; 12:13*
Ἡρῳδιάς: Herodias, pr. name, the wife of Herod Antipas, Mt. 14:3, 6; Mk. 6:17, 19, 22; Lk. 3:19*
Ἠσαῦ: Esau, pr. name, indecl. (Gen. 27-28), Rom. 9:13; Heb. 11:20; 12:16*
ἡσυχάζω: to be still, at rest; to live peaceably, be quiet, 1 Thess. 4:11; to rest from labor, Lk. 23:56; to be silent or quiet, acquiesce, to desist from discussion, Lk. 14:4; Acts 11:18; 21:14*
ἡσυχία: rest, quiet, tranquillity; a quiet, tranquil life, 2 Thess. 3:12; silence, silent attention, Acts 22:2; 1 Tim. 2:11, 12*
ἤτοι: whether, with an elevated tone, Rom. 6:16*
ἡττάομαι: to be less, inferior to; to fare worse; by impl. to be overcome, vanquished, 2 Pet. 2:19, 20*
ἥττημα: an inferiority, to a particular standard; default, defeat, failure, shortcoming, Rom. 11:12; 1 Cor. 6:7*
θάλασσα: the sea, Mt. 23:15, Mk. 9:42; a sea, Acts 7:36; an inland sea, lake, Mt. 8:24
θάλπω: to impart warmth; met. to cherish, nurse, foster, comfort, Eph. 5:29; 1 Thess. 2:7*
θαμβέω: to be astonished, amazed, awestruck Mt. 1:27; 10:24, 32*
θανατηφόρος: bringing or causing death, deadly, fatal, Jas. 3:8*
θάνατος: death, the extinction of life, whether naturally, Lk. 2:26; Mk. 9:1; or violently, Mt. 10:21; 15:4; imminent danger of death, 2 Cor. 4:11, 12; 11:23; in NT spiritual death, as opposed to ζωή in its spiritual sense, in respect of a forfeiture of salvation, Jn. 8:51; Rom. 6:16
θανατόω: to put to death, deliver to death, Mt. 10:21; 26:59; Mk. 13:12; pass. to be exposed to imminent danger of death, Rom. 8:36; in NT met. to subdue, Rom. 8:13; pass. to be dead to, to be rid, parted from, as if by the intervention of death, Rom. 7:4
Θάρα: Terah, Abraham’s father, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 3:34*
θαρρέω: to be confident, courageous, 2 Cor. 5:6, 8; 7:16; 10:1, 2; Heb. 13:6*
θαρσέω: to be of good courage, be of good cheer, Mt. 9:2; to be confident, hopeful; to be bold, maintain a bold bearing, Mt. 9:22; 14:27; Mk. 6:50; 10:49; Jn. 16:33; Acts 23:11*
θαῦμα: a wonder; wonder, admiration, astonishment, 2 Cor. 11:14; Rev. 17:6*
θαυμάζω: to admire, regard with admiration, wonder at, Lk. 7:9; Acts 7:31; to reverence, adore, 2 Thess. 1:10; absol. to wonder, be filled with wonder, admiration, or astonishment, Mt. 8:10; Lk. 4:22
θαυμάσιος: wonderful, admirable, marvellous; τὸ θαυμάσιον, a wonder, wonderful work, Mt. 21:15*
θαυμαστός: wondrous, glorious, 1 Pet. 2:9; Rev. 15:1; marvellous, strange, uncommon, Mt. 21:42; Mk. 12:11; Jn. 9:30; Rev. 15:3*
θεάομαι: to gaze upon, Mt. 6:1; 23:5; Lk. 7:24; to see, discern with the eyes, Mk. 16:11, 14; Lk. 5:27; Jn. 1:14, 32, 38; to see, visit, Rom. 15:24
θεατρίζω: to be exposed as in a theater, to be made a gazing-stock, object of scorn, Heb. 10:33*
θέατρον: a theater, a place where public games and spectacles are exhibited, Acts 19:29, 31; meton. a show, gazing-stock, 1 Cor. 4:9*
θεῖος: divine, pertaining to God, 2 Pet. 1:3, 4; τὸ θεῖον, the divine nature, divinity, Acts 17:29*
θειότης: divinity, deity, godhead, divine majesty, Rom. 1:20*
θέλημα: will, bent, inclination, 1 Cor. 16:12; Eph. 2:3; 1 Pet. 4:3; resolve, 1 Cor. 7:37; will, purpose, design, 2 Tim. 2:26; 2 Pet. 1:21; will, sovereign pleasure, behest, Mt. 18:14; Lk. 12:47; Acts 13:22, et al. freq.; ἐν τῷ θελήματι θεοῦ, Deo permittente, if God please or permit, Rom. 1:10
θέλω: to exercise the will, properly by an unimpassioned operation; to be willing, Mt. 17:4; to be inclined, disposed, Rom. 13:3; to choose, Lk. 1:62; to intend, design, Lk. 14:28; to will, Jn. 5:21; 21:22; ἤθελον, I could wish, Gal. 4:20
θεμέλιον: in Acts 16:26 themelion is used as a neuter noun from themelios (G2529), foundation such as the foundation of a prison*
θεμέλιος: see θεμέλιον (G2528) a foundation, Lk. 6:48, 49; Heb. 11:10; met. a foundation laid in elementary instruction, Heb. 6:1; a foundation of a superstructure of faith, doctrine, or hope, 1 Cor. 3:10, 11, 12; Eph. 2:20; 1 Tim. 6:19; a foundation laid in the commencement of the preaching of the Gospel, Rom. 15:20*
θεμελιόω: to found, lay the foundation of, Mt. 7:25; Heb. 1:10; met. to ground, establish, render firm and unwavering, Eph. 3:17; Col. 1:23; 1 Pet. 5:10*
θεοδίδακτος: taught of God, divinely instructed, 1 Thess. 4:9*
θεομάχος: fighting against God, in conflict with God, Acts 5:39*
θεός: a deity, Acts 7:43; 1 Cor. 8:5; an idol, Acts 7:40; God, the true God, Mt. 3:9, et al. freq.; God, possessed of true godhead, Jn. 1:1; Rom. 9:5; from the Hebrew, applied to potentates, Jn. 10:34, 35; τῷ θεῷ, an intensive term, from the Hebrew, exceedingly, Acts 7:20, and, perhaps, 2 Cor. 10:4
θεοσέβεια: worshipping of God, reverence towards God, piety, 1 Tim. 2:10*
θεοσεβής: reverencing God, pious, godly, devout, a sincere worshipper of God, Jn. 9:31*
θεοστυγής: God-hated; in NT a hater and despiser of God, Rom. 1:30*
θεραπεία: service, attendance; healing, cure, Lk. 9:11; Rev. 22:2; meton. those who render service, servants, domestics, family household, Lk. 12:42*
θεραπεύω: to heal, cure, Mt. 4:23, 24; 8:16; pass. to receive service, Acts 17:25; to serve, minister to, render service and attendance; to render divine service, worship, Acts 17:25
θεράπων: an attendant, a servant; a minister, Heb. 3:5*
θερίζω: to gather in harvest, reap, Mt. 6:26; 25:24, 26; met. to reap the reward of labor, 1 Cor. 9:11; 2 Cor. 9:6; to reap the harvest of vengeance, Rev. 14:15, 16
θερισμός: a harvest, the act of gathering in the harvest, reaping, Jn. 4:35; met. the harvest of the Gospel, Mt. 9:37, 38; Lk. 10:2; a crop; met. the crop of vengeance, Rev. 14:15
θεριστής: one who gathers in the harvest, a reaper, Mt. 13:30, 39*
θερμαίνω: to warm; mid. to warm one’s self, Mt. 14:54, 67; Jn. 18:18, 25; Jas. 2:16*
θέρμη: also formed as θέρμα, heat, warmth, Acts 28:3*
θέρος: the warm season of the year, summer, Mt. 24:32; Mk. 13:28; Lk. 21:30*
Θεσσαλονικεύς: Thessalonian, of Thessalonica, Acts 20:4; 27:2; inscription to 1 and 2 Thess.*
Θεσσαλονίκη: Thessalonica, a city of Macedonia, Acts 17:1, 11, 13; Phil. 4:16; 2 Tim. 4:10*. See PhotoGuide.
θεωρέω: to be a spectator, to gaze on, contemplate; to behold, view with interest and attention, Mt. 27:55; 28:1; to contemplate mentally, consider, Heb. 7:4; in NT to see, perceive, Mk. 3:11; to come to a knowledge of, Jn. 6:40; from the Hebrew, to experience, undergo, Jn. 8:51
θεωρία: a beholding; a sight, spectacle, Lk. 23:48*
θήκη: a repository, receptacle; a case, sheath, scabbard, Jn. 18:11*
θηλάζω: to suckle, give suck, Mt. 24:19; Mk. 13:17; Lk. 21:23; to suck, Mt. 21:16; Lk. 11:27*
θῆλυς: female; τὸ θῆλυ, i.e. γένος, a female, Mt. 19:4; Mk. 10:6; Gal. 3:28; ἡ θήλεια, woman, Rom. 1:26, 27*
θήρα: hunting, the chase; met. means of capture, a cause of destruction, Rom. 11:9*
θηρεύω: to hunt, catch; met. to seize on, lay hold of, Lk. 11:54*
θηριομαχέω: to fight with wild beasts; met. to be exposed to furious hostility, 1 Cor. 15:32*
θηρίον: a beast, wild animal, Mk. 1:13; Acts 10:12; met. a brute, brutish man, Tit. 1:12
θησαυρίζω: to collect and lay up stores or wealth, treasure, Mt. 6:19, 20; Lk. 12:21; 2 Cor. 12:14; Jas. 5:3; to heap up, accumulate, Rom. 2:5; 1 Cor. 16:2; to reserve, keep in store, 2 Pet. 3:7
θησαυρός: a treasury, a store, treasure, precious deposit, Mt. 6:19, 20, 21; a receptacle in which precious articles are kept, a casket, Mt. 2:11; a storehouse, Mt. 12:35
θιγγάνω: to touch, Col. 2:21; Heb. 12:20; to harm, Heb. 11:28*
θλίβω: to squeeze, press; to press upon, encumber, throng, crowd, Mk. 3:9; met. to distress, afflict, 2 Cor. 1:6; 4:8; pass. to be compressed, narrow, Mt. 7:14
θλῖψις: pr. pressure, compression; met. affliction, distress of mind, 2 Cor. 2:4; distressing circumstances, trial, affliction, Mt. 25:9
θνῄσκω: to die; in NT to be dead, Mt. 2:20; Mk. 15:44
θνητός: mortal, subject to death, Rom. 6:12; 8:11; 2 Cor. 4:11; τὸ θνητόν, mortality, 1 Cor. 15:53, 54; 2 Cor. 5:4*
θορυβέω: to make a din, uproar; trans. to disturb, throw into commotion, Acts 17:5; in NT mid. to manifest agitation of mind, to raise a lament, Mt. 9:23; Mk. 5:39; Acts 20:10*
θόρυβος: an uproar, din; an outward expression of mental agitation, outcry, Mk. 5:38; a tumult, commotion, Mt. 26:5
θραύω: to break, shiver; met., shattered, crushed by cruel oppression, Lk. 4:18*
θρέμμα: that which is reared (especially sheep and goats); pl. cattle, Jn. 4:12*
θρηνέω: to lament, bewail, Mt. 11:17; Lk. 7:32; 23:27; Jn. 16:20*
θρησκεία: religious worship, Col. 2:18; religion, a religious system, Acts 26:5; religion, piety, Jas. 1:26, 27*
θριαμβεύω: pr. to celebrate a triumph; trans. to lead in triumph, celebrate a triumph over, Col. 2:15; in NT to cause to triumph, or, to render conspicuous, 2 Cor. 2:14*
θρίξ: a hair; the hair of the head, Mt. 5:36; 10:30; of an animal, Mt. 3:4; Mk. 1:6
θροέω: to cry aloud; in NT pass., to be disturbed, disquieted, alarmed, terrified, Mt. 24:6; Mk. 13:7; 2 Thess. 2:2*
θρόμβος: a lump; esp. a clot of blood, drop, Lk. 22:44*
θρόνος: a seat, a throne, Mt. 5:34; 19:28; Lk. 1:52; meton. power, dominion, Lk. 1:32; Heb. 1:8; a potentate, Col. 1:16
Θυάτειρα: Thyatira, a city of Lydia, Acts 16:14; Rev. 1:11; 2:18, 24*. See PhotoGuide.
θυγάτηρ: a daughter, Mt. 9:18; 10:35, 37; in the vocative, an expression of affection and kindness, Mt. 9:22; from the Hebrew, one of the female posterity of any one, Lk. 1:5; met. a city, Mt. 21:5; Jn. 12:15; pl. female inhabitants, Lk. 23:28
θυγάτριον: a little daughter, female child, Mk. 5:23; 7:25*
θύϊνος: thyme, of θυία, thya, an aromatic evergreen tree, arbor vitae, resembling the cedar, and found in Libya, Rev. 18:12*
θυμίαμα: incense, any odoriferous substance burnt in religious worship, Rev. 5:8; 8:3, 4; 18:13; or, the act of burning incense, Lk. 1:10, 11*
θυμιατήριον: an altar of burning incense, Heb. 9:4*
θυμομαχέω: to wage war fiercely; to be warmly hostile to, be enraged against, Acts 12:20*
θυμός: pr. the soul, mind; hence, a strong passion or emotion of the mind; anger, wrath, Lk. 4:28; Acts 19:28; pl. swellings of anger, 2 Cor. 12:20; Gal. 5:20
θυμόω: to provoke to anger; pass. to be angered, enraged, Mt. 2:16*
θύρα: a door, gate, Mt. 6:6; Mk. 1:33; an entrance, Mt. 27:60; in NT met. an opening, occasion, opportunity, Acts 14:27; 1 Cor. 16:9; meton. a medium or means of entrance, Jn. 10:7, 9
θυρεός: a stone or other material employed to close a doorway; later, a large oblong shield, Eph. 6:16*
θυρίς: a small opening; a window, Acts 20:9; 2 Cor. 11:33*
θυσία: sacrifice, the act of sacrificing, Heb. 9:26; the thing sacrificed, a victim, Mt. 9:13; 12:7; the flesh of victims eaten by the sacrificers, 1 Cor. 10:18; in NT an offering or service to God, Phil. 4:18
θυσιαστήριον: an altar, Mt. 5:23, 24; Lk. 1:11; spc. the altar of burnt-offering, Mt. 23:35; Lk. 11:51; meton. a class of sacrifices, Heb. 13:10
θύω: to offer; to kill in sacrifice, sacrifice, immolate, Acts 14:13, 18; in NT to slaughter for food, Mt. 22:4
θώραξ: a breast-plate, armor for the body, consisting of two parts, one covering the breast and the other the back, Eph. 6:14; 1 Thess. 5:8; Rev. 9:9, 17*
Ἰάϊρος: also spelled Ἰάειρος, Jairus, pr. name, Mk. 5:22; Lk. 8:41*
Ἰακώβ: Jacob, pr. name, indecl. (1) Son of Issac, Matt 1:2. (2) Father of Joseph, Mary’s husband, Matt 1:15, 16
Ἰάκωβος: James, pr. name (1) Son of Zebedee, Mt. 4:21. (2) Son of Alphaeus and Mary, brother of Jude, Mt. 10:3. (3) James the less, brother of Jesus, Gal. 1:19
ἰάομαι: to heal, cure, Mt. 8:8; Lk. 9:2; met. to heal, spiritually, restore from a state of sin and condemnation, Mt. 13:15; Heb. 12:13
ἴασπις: jasper, a precious stone of various colors, as purple, cerulian green, etc. Rev. 4:3; 21:11, 18, 19*
ἴδε: the imperative of εἶδον used as a particle, Lo! Behold! Jn. 16:29; 19:4, 5
ἴδιος: one’s own, Mk. 15:20; Jn. 7:18; due, proper, specially assigned, Gal. 6:9; 1 Tim. 2:6; 6:15; Tit. 1:3; also used in NT as a simple possessive, Eph. 5:22; τὰ ἴδια, one’s home, household, people, Jn. 1:11; 16:32; 19:17; οἱ ἴδιοι, members of one’s own household, friends, Jn. 1:11; Acts 24:23; ἰδίᾳ, adverbially, respectively, 1 Cor. 12:11; κατ’ ἰδίαν, adv., privately, aside, by one’s self, alone, Mt. 14:13, 23
ἰδιώτης: pr. one in private life, one devoid of special learning or gifts, a plain person, Acts 4:13; 2 Cor. 11:6; ungifted, 1 Cor. 14:16, 23, 24*
ἰδού: aorist middle imperative of εἶδον used as an interjection, Look! See! Lo! Mt. 1:23; Lk. 1:38; Acts 8:36
Ἰδουμαία: Idumaea, a country south of Judea, Mk. 3:8*
Ἰεζάβελ: Jezebel, (1 Ki. 16:31), pr. name, indecl., Rev. 2:20*
Ἱεράπολις: Hierapolis, a city of Phrygia, Col. 4:13*. See PhotoGuide.
ἱεράτευμα: a priesthood; meton. a body of priests, 1 Pet. 2:5, 9*
ἱερατεύω: to officiate as a priest, perform sacred rites, Lk. 1:8*
ἱερεύς: a priest, one who performs sacrificial rites, Mt. 8:4; Lk. 1:5; Jn. 1:19
Ἰεριχώ: Jericho, a city of Palestine, Mt. 20:29; Mk. 10:46; Lk. 10:30; 18:35; 19:1; Heb. 11:30*. See PhotoGuide.
ἱερός: holy, divine, set apart, 2 Tim. 3:15; tὰ ἱερά, sacred rites, 1 Cor. 9:13*
Ἱεροσολυμίτης: a native of Jerusalem, Mk. 1:5; Jn. 7:25*
ἱεροσυλέω: to despoil temples, commit sacrilege, Rom. 2:22*
ἱερόσυλος: one who despoils temples, commits sacrilege, Acts 19:37*
ἱερουργέω: to officiate as priest, perform sacred rites; in NT to minister in a divine commission, Rom. 15:16*
Ἰερουσαλήμ: Jerusalem, pr. name, indecl., also spelled Ἱεροσόλυμα   62x in our text. See PhotoGuide.
Ἰεσσαί: Jesse, father of David (1 Sam. 16), pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:5f.; Lk. 3:32; Acts 13:22; Rom. 15:12*
Ἰησοῦς: a Savior, Jesus, Mt. 1:21, 25; 2:1, et al. freq.; Joshua, Acts 7:45; Heb. 4:8; Jesus, a Jewish Christian, Col. 4:11
ἱκανός: befitting; sufficient, enough, Lk. 22:38; ἱκανὸν ποιεῖν τινί, to satisfy, gratify, Mk. 15:15; τὸ ἱκανὸν λαμβάνειν, to take security or bail of any one, Acts 17:9; or persons, adequate, competent, qualified, 2 Cor. 2:16; fit, worthy, Mt. 3:11; 8:8; of number or quantity, considerable, large, great, much, and pl. many, Mt. 28:12; Mk. 10:46
ἱκανόω: to make sufficient or competent, qualify, 2 Cor. 3:6; Col. 1:12*
ἱκετηρία: pr. an olive branch borne by suppliants in their hands; prayer, supplication, Heb. 5:7*
Ἰκόνιον: Iconium, a city of Lycaonia, in Asia Minor, Acts 13:51; 14:1, 19, 21; 16:2; 2 Tim. 3:11*. See PhotoGuide.
ἱλάσκομαι: to appease, render propitious; in NT to expiate, make an atonement or expiation for, Heb. 2:17;  ἱλάσθητι, be gracious, show mercy, pardon, Lk. 18:13*
ἱλασμός: atoning sacrifice, sin offering, propitiation, expiation; one who makes propitiation/expiation, 1 Jn. 2:2; 4:10*
ἱλαστήριον: the cover of the ark of the covenant, the mercy-seat, the place of propitiation, Rom. 3:25; Heb. 9:5*
ἵλεως: propitious, favorable, merciful, gracious, Heb. 8:12; from the Hebrew, ἵλεως σοι (ὁ θεός) God have mercy on thee, God forbid, far be it from thee, Mt. 16:22*
Ἰλλυρικόν: Illyricum, a country between the Adriatic and the Danube, Rom. 15:19*
ἱμάς: a strap or thong of leather, Acts 22:25; a shoe-latchet, Mk. 1:7; Lk. 3:16; Jn. 1:27*
ἱματίζω: to clothe; pass. to be clothed, Mk. 5:15; Lk. 8:35*
ἱμάτιον: a garment; the upper garment, mantle, Mt. 5:40; 9:16, 20, 21; pl. the mantle and tunic together, Mt. 26:65; pl. genr. garments, raiment, Mt. 11:8; 24:18
ἱματισμός: garment; raiment, apparel, clothing, Lk. 7:25; 9:29; Jn. 19:24; Acts 20:33; 1 Tim. 2:9*
ἵνα: that, in order that, Mt. 19:13; Mk. 1:38; Jn. 1:22; 3:15; 17:1; ἵνα μή, that not, lest, Mt. 7:1; in NT equivalent to ὥστε, so that, so as that, Jn. 9:2; also, marking a simple circumstance, the circumstance that, Mt. 10:25; Jn. 4:34; 6:29; 1 Jn. 4:17; 5:3
ἱνατί: Why is it that? For what reason? Why? Mt. 9:4; 27:46; Lk. 13:7; Acts 4:25; 7:26; 1 Cor. 10:29*
Ἰόππη: Joppa, a city of Palestine, Acts 9:36, 38, 42f.; 10:5, 8, 23, 32; 11:5, 13*. See PhotoGuide.
Ἰορδάνης: the river Jordan, Mt. 3:5; Mk. 10:1; Lk. 4:1; Jn. 3:26
ἰός: a missile weapon, arrow, dart; venom, poison, Rom. 3:13; Jas. 3:8; rust, Jas. 5:3*
Ἰουδαία: Judea, the southern party of the country, below Samaria, Mt. 2:1, 5, 22; 3:1; meton. the inhabitants of Judea
Ἰουδαϊκός: Jewish, current among the Jews, Tit. 1:14*
Ἰουδαϊκῶς: in the manner of Jews, according to Jewish custom, Gal. 2:14*
Ἰουδαῖος: Jewish, Mk. 1:5; Jn. 3:22; Acts 16:1; 24:24; pr. one sprung from the tribe of Judah, or a subject of the kingdom of Judah; in NT a descendant of Jacob, a Jew, Mt. 28:15; Mk. 7:3; Acts 19:34; Rom. 2:28, 29
Ἰουδαϊσμός: Judaism, the character and condition of a Jew; practice of the Jewish religion, Gal. 1:13, 14*
Ἰούδας: Judas, Jude, pr. name. (1) Judah, son of Jacob; the tribe of Judah, Mt. 1:2; Lk. 1:39. (2) Juda, son of Joseph, of the ancestry of Jesus, Lk. 3:30. (3) Juda, son of Joanna, of the ancestry of Jesus, Lk. 3:26. (4) Judas, brother of James, Jude, Lk. 6:16; Jude 1. (5) Judas Iscariot, son of Simon, Mt. 10:4; Jn. 6:71. (6) Judas, brother of Jesus, Mt. 13:55; Mk. 6:3. (7) Judas of Galilee, Acts 5:37 . (8) Judas, surnamed Barsabas, Acts 15:22. (9) Judas of Damascus, Acts 9:11
Ἰοῦστος: Justus, pr. name (1) Joseph Barsabas, Acts 1:23 (2) Justus of Corinth, Acts 18:7 (3) Jesus, called Justus, Col. 4:11*
ἱππεύς: a horseman; pl. ἱππεῖς, horsemen, cavalry, Acts 23:23, 32*
ἱππικός: equestrian; τὸ ἱππικόν, cavalry, horse, Rev. 9:16*
Ἰσαάκ: Isaac, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:2; 8:11; 23:32; Acts 3:13;. Rom. 9:7f.; Gal. 4:28; Heb. 11:9ff.; Jas. 2:21
ἰσάγγελος: equal or similar to angels, Lk. 20:36*
ἴσος: equal, like, Mt. 20:12; Lk. 6:34; on an equality, Phil. 2:6; met. correspondent, consistent, Mk. 14:56, 59
ἰσότης: equality, equal proportion, 2 Cor. 8:13, 14; fairness, equity, what is equitable, Col. 4:1*
ἰσότιμος: of equal price, equally precious or valuable, 2 Pet. 1:1*
ἰσόψυχος: likeminded, of the same mind and spirit, Phil. 2:20*
Ἰσραηλίτης: an Israelite, a descendant of Ἰσραήλ, Israel or Jacob, Jn. 1:47; Acts 2:22
ἵστημι: pluperfect, ἑστάμην, also formed as στήκω   10x, trans. to make to stand, set, place, Mt. 4:5; to set forth, appoint, Acts 1:23; to fix, appoint, Acts 17:31; to establish, confirm, Rom. 10:3; Heb. 10:9; to set down, impute, Acts 7:60; to weigh out, pay, Mt. 26:15; intrans. to stand, Mt. 12:46; to stand fast, be firm, be permanent, endure, Mt. 12:25; Eph. 6:13; to be confirmed, proved, Mt. 18:16; 2 Cor. 13:1; to stop, Lk. 7:14; 8:44; Acts 8:38
ἱστορέω: to ascertain by inquiry and examination; to inquire of; in NT to visit in order to become acquainted with, Gal. 1:18*
ἰσχυρός: strong, mighty, robust, Mt. 12:29; Lk. 11:21; powerful, mighty, 1 Cor. 1:27; 4:10; 1 Jn. 2:14; strong, fortified, Rev. 18:10; vehement, Mt. 14:20; energetic, 2 Cor. 10:10; sure, firm, Heb. 6:18
ἰσχύς: strength, might, power, Rev. 18:2; Eph. 1:19; faculty, ability, 1 Pet. 4:11; Mk. 12:30, 33; Lk. 10:27
ἰσχύω: to be strong, be well, be in good health, Mt. 9:12; to have power, be able, Mt. 8:28; 26:40; to have power or efficiency, avail, be valid, Gal. 5:6; Heb. 9:17; to be of service, be serviceable, Mt. 5:13; meton. to prevail, Acts 19:16; Rev. 12:8
ἴσως: equally; perhaps, it may be that, Lk. 20:13*
Ἰτουραῖος: Ituraea, a district of Palestine beyond Jordan, Lk. 3:1*
ἴξνος: a footstep, track; in NT pl. footsteps, line of conduct, Rom. 4:12; 2 Cor. 12:18; 1 Pet. 2:21*
Ἰωάννα: also spelled Ἰωάνα, Joanna, pr. name, Lk. 8:3; 24:10*
Ἰωάννης: also spelled Ἰωάνης, Joannes, John, pr. name (1) John the Baptist, Mt. 3:1, et al. (2) John, son of Zebedee, the apostle, Mt. 4:21, et al. (3) John, surnamed Mark, Acts 12:12, et al. (4) John, the high-priest, Acts 4:6
Ἰωβήδ: Obed, David’s grandfather, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:5; Lk. 3:32*
Ἰωήλ: Joel, an Old Testament prophet, pr. name, indecl., Acts 2:16*
Ἰωνᾶς: Jonas, pr. name Jonah, the prophet, Mt. 12:39; Lk. 11:29
Ἰωράμ: Joram, king of Judah (2 Ki. 8:16ff.), pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:8*
Ἰωσαφάτ: Josaphat, king of Judah (1 Ki. 22:41), pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:8*
Ἰωσῆς: Joses, Joseph pr. name Mt. 27:56; Mk. 6:3; 15:40, 47*
Ἰωσήφ: Joseph, pr. name, indecl. (1) Joseph, son of Jacob, Jn. 4:5. (2) Joseph, son of Jonan, Lk. 3:30. (3) Joseph, son of Judas, Lk. 3:26. (4) Joseph, son of Mattathias, Lk. 3:24. (5) Joseph, the husband of Mary, Mt. 1:16. (6) Joseph of Arimathea, Mt. 27:57. (7) Joseph Barsabas, Acts 1:23. (8) Joseph Barnabas, Acts 4:36
Ἰωσίας: Josiah, king of Judah (2 Ki. 22), Mt. 1:10, 11*
ἰῶτα: iota; in NT used like the Hebrew/Aramaic yod, the smallest letter in the Hebrew/Aramaic alphabet, as an expression for the least or minutest part; a jot, Mt. 5:18*
κἀγώ: and I, I also, but I, a crasis of καί and ἐγώ, dat., κἀμοί, acc., κἀμέ
καθά: can function as an adverb, just as, Mt. 27:10*
καθαιρέω: take or bring down, Mk. 15:36, 46; Lk. 1:52; 23:53; Acts 13:29; tear down, destroy, Lk. 12:18; Acts 13:19; 19:27; 2 Cor. 10:4*
καθαίρω: to cleanse from filth; to clear by pruning, prune, Jn. 15:2; met. to cleanse from sin, make expiation
καθάπτω: trans. to fasten or fit to; in NT equivalent to καθάπτομαι, to fix one’s self upon, fasten upon, take hold of, seize, Acts 28:3*
καθαρίζω: to cleanse, render pure, purify, Mt. 23:25; Lk. 11:39; to cleanse from leprosy, Mt. 8:2, 3; 10:8; met. to cleanse from sin, purify by an expiatory offering, make expiation for, Heb. 9:22, 23; 1 Jn. 1:7; to cleanse from sin, free from the influence of error and sin, Acts 15:9; 2 Cor. 7:1; to pronounce ceremonially clean, Acts 10:15; 11:9
καθαρισμός: ceremonial cleansing, purification, Lk. 2:22; 5:14; mode of purification, Jn. 2:6; 3:25; cleansing of lepers, Mk. 1:44; met. expiation, Heb. 1:3; 2 Pet. 1:9*
καθαρός: clean, pure, unsoiled, Mt. 23:26; 27:59; met. clean from guilt, guiltless, innocent, Acts 18:6; 20:26; sincere, upright, virtuous, void of evil, Mt. 5:8; Jn. 15:3; clean ceremonially and morally, Lk. 11:41
καθέζομαι: to seat one’s self, sit down, Mt. 26:55; Lk. 2:46; Jn. 4:6; 1:20; 20:12; Acts 6:15; 20:9*
καθεξῆς: in a continual order or series, successively, consecutively, Lk. 1:3; Acts 11:4; 18:23; ὁ, ἡ, καθεξῆς, succeeding, subsequent, Lk. 8:1; Acts 3:24*
καθεύδω: to sleep, be fast asleep, Mt. 8:24; 9:24; met. to sleep in spiritual sloth, Eph. 5:14; 1 Thess. 5:6; to sleep the sleep of death, to die, 1 Thess. 5:10
καθηγητής: pr. a guide, leader; in NT a teacher, instructor, Mt. 23:10*
καθήκω: to reach, extend to; καθήκει, impers. it is fitting, meet, Acts 22:22; τὸ καθῆκον, what is fit, right, duty; τὰ μὴ καθήκοντα, by litotes for what is abominable or detestable, Rom. 1:28*
κάθημαι: to sit, be sitting, Mt. 9:9; Lk. 10:13; to be seated, 1 Cor. 14:30; to be enthroned, Rev. 18:7; to dwell, reside, Mt. 4:16; Lk. 1:79; 21:35
