καθίζω: (1) trans. to cause to sit, place; καθίζομαι, to be seated, sit, Mt. 19:28; Lk. 22:30; to cause to sit as judges, place, appoint, 1 Cor. 6:4; (2) intrans. to sit, sit down, Mt. 13:48; 26:36; to remain, settle, stay, continue, live, Lk. 24:49
καθίημι: to let down, lower, Lk. 5:19; Acts 9:25; 10:11; 11:5*
καθίστημι: also formed as καθιστάνω, to place, set, Jas. 3:6; to set, constitute, appoint, Mt. 24:45, 47; Lk. 12:14; to set down in a place, conduct, Acts 17:15; to make, render, or cause to be, 2 Pet. 1:8; pass. to be rendered, Rom. 5:19
καθό: as, Rom. 8:26; according as, in proportion as, to the degree that, 2 Cor. 8:12; 1 Pet. 4:13*
καθόλου: on the whole, entirely, in general, altogether, completely; with a negative, not at all, Acts 4:18*
καθοράω: pr. to look down upon, in the NT to mark, perceive, discern, Rom. 1:20*
καθότι: as, just as, according as, in proportion as, Acts 2:45; 4:35; inasmuch as, Lk. 1:7; 19:9; Acts 2:24; 17:31*
καθώς: as, just as, in the manner that, Mt. 21:6; 26:24; how, in what manner, Acts 15:14; according as, Mk. 4:33; inasmuch as, Jn. 17:2; of time, when, Acts 7:17
καί: (1) and, Mt. 2:2, 3, 11; 4:22; (2) καί ... καί, both ... and; (3) as a cumulative particle, also, too, Mt. 5:39; Jn. 8:19; 1 Cor. 11:6; (4) emphatic, even, also, Mt. 10:30; 1 Cor. 2:10; in NT adversative, but, Mt. 11:19; also introductory of the apodosis of a sentence, Gal. 3:28; Jas. 2:4
Καϊάφας: Caiaphas, pr. name, the high priest from A.D. 18-36, Mt. 26:3, 57; Lk. 3:2; Jn. 11:49; 18:13f., 24, 28; Acts 4:6*
Κάϊν: Cain, pr. name, indecl., Heb. 11:4; 1 Jn. 3:12; Jude 11*
καινός: new, recently made, Mt. 9:17; Mk. 2:22; new in species, character, or mode, Mt. 26:28, 29; Mk. 14:24, 25; Lk. 22:20; Jn. 13:34; 2 Cor. 5:17; Gal. 6:15; Eph. 2:15; 4:24; 1 Jn. 2:7; Rev. 3:12; novel, strange, Mk. 1:27; Acts 17:19; new to the possessor, Mk. 16:17; unheard of, unusual, Mk. 1:27; Acts 17:19; met. renovated, better, of higher excellence, 2 Cor. 5:17; Rev. 5:9
καιρός: pr. fitness, proportion, suitableness; a fitting situation, suitable place, 1 Pet. 4:17; a limited period of time marked by a suitableness of circumstances, a fitting season, 1 Cor. 4:5; 1 Tim. 2:6; 6:15; Tit. 1:3; opportunity, Acts 24:25; Gal. 6:10; Heb. 11:15; a limited period of time marked by characteristic circumstances, a signal juncture, a marked season, Mt. 16:3; Lk. 12:56; 21:8; 1 Pet. 1:11; a destined time, Mt. 8:29; 26:18; Mk. 1:15; Lk. 21:24; 1 Thess. 5:1; a season in ordinary succession, equivalent to ὥρα, Mt. 13:30; Acts 14:17; in NT a limited time, a short season, Lk. 4:13; simply, a point of time, Mt. 11:25; Lk. 13:1
Καισάρεια: Caesarea (1) Caesarea Philippi, Mt. 16:13; Mk. 8:27; (2) Caesarea Augusta, Acts 8:40
καίτοι: and yet, though, although, Acts 14:17; Heb. 4:3*
καίω: to cause to burn, kindle, light, Mt. 5:15; pass. to be kindled, burn, flame, Lk. 12:35; met. to be kindled into emotion, Lk. 24:32; to consume with fire, Jn. 15:6; 1 Cor. 13:3
κἀκεῖ: crasis, and there, Mt. 5:23; 10:11; there also, Acts 17:13
κἀκεῖθεν: crasis, and there, Mk. 10:1; Acts 7:4; 14:26; 20:15; 21:1; 27:4, 12; 28:15; and then, afterwards, Acts 13:21
κἀκεῖνος: crasis, and he, she, it; and this, and that, Mt. 15:18; 23:23; he, she, it also; this also, that also, Mt. 20:4
κακία: malice, malignity, Rom. 1:29; Eph. 4:31; wickedness, depravity, Acts 8:22; 1 Cor. 5:8; in NT evil, trouble, calamity, misfortune, Mt. 6:34
κακοήθεια: disposition for mischief, misfortune, malignity, Rom. 1:29*
κακολογέω: to speak evil of, revile, abuse, insult, Mk. 9:39; Acts 19:9; to address with offensive language, to treat with disrespect, Matt, 15:4; Mk. 7:10*
κακοπάθεια: a state of suffering, affliction, trouble, in NT endurance in affliction, perseverance, Jas. 5:10*
κακοπαθέω: to suffer evil or afflictions, 2 Tim. 2:9; to be afflicted, troubled, dejected, Jas. 5:13; in NT to show endurance in trials and afflictions, 2 Tim. 4:5*
κακοποιέω: to cause evil, injure, do harm, Mk. 3:4; Lk. 6:9; to do evil, commit sin, 1 Pet. 3:17; 3 Jn. 11*
κακός: bad, of a bad quality or disposition, worthless, corrupt, depraved, Mt. 21:41; 24:48; Mk. 7:21; wicked, criminal, morally bad; τὸ κακόν, evil, wickedness, crime, Mt. 27:23; Acts 23:9; deceitful, 1 Pet. 3:10; mischievous, harmful, destructive; τὸ κακόν, evil mischief, harm, injury, Tit. 1:12; afflictive; τὸ κακόν, evil, misery, affliction, suffering, Lk. 16;25
κακοῦργος: an evil-doer, malefactor, criminal, Lk. 23:32, 33, 39; 2 Tim. 2:9*
κακουχέω: to torment, afflict, harass; pass. to be afflicted, be oppressed with evils, Heb. 11:37 13:3*
κακόω: to harm, mistreat, cause evil to, oppress, Acts 7:6, 19; 12:1; 18:10; 1 Pet. 3:13; in NT to make angry, embitter, Acts 14:2*
κακῶς: ill, badly; physically ill, sick, Mt. 4:24; 8:16; grievously, vehemently, Mt. 15:22; wretchedly, miserably, Mt. 21:41; wickedly, reproachfully, Acts 23:5; wrongly, criminally, Jn. 18:23; amiss, Jas. 4:3
κάκωσις: ill treatment, affliction, oppression, misery, Acts 7:34*
καλάμη: the stalk of grain, straw, stubble, 1 Cor. 3:12*
κάλαμος: a reed, cane, Mt. 11:7; 12:20; Lk. 7:24; a reed in its various appliances, as, a wand, a staff, Mt. 27:29, 30, 48; Mk. 15:19, 36; a measuring-rod, Rev. 11:1; 21:15f.; a writer’s reed, 3 Jn. 13*
καλέω: to call, call to, Jn. 10:3; to call into one’s presence, send for a person, Mt. 2:7; to summon, Mt. 2:15; 25:14; to invite, Mt. 22:9; to call to the performance of a certain thing, Mt. 9:13; Heb. 11:8; to call to a participation in the privileges of the Gospel, Rom. 8:30; 9:24; 1 Cor. 1:9; 7:18; to call to an office or dignity, Heb. 5:4; to name, style, Mt. 1:21; pass. to be styled, regarded, Mt. 5:9, 19
καλλιέλαιος: pr. adj. productive of good oil; as subst. a cultivated olive tree, Rom. 11:24*
καλοδιδάσκαλος: teaching what is good; a teacher of good, Tit. 2:3*
καλοποιέω: to do well, do good, do what is right, 2 Thess. 3:13*
καλός: pr. beautiful; good, of good quality or disposition; fertile, rich, Mt. 13:8, 23; useful, profitable, Lk. 14:34; καλόν ἐστι[ν], it is profitable, it is well, Mt. 18:8, 9; excellent, choice, select, goodly, Mt. 7:17, 19; καλόν ἐστι[ν], it is pleasant, delightful, Mt. 17:4; just, full measure, Lk. 6:38; honorable, distinguished, Jas. 2:7; good, possessing moral excellence, worthy, upright, virtuous, Jn. 10:11, 14; 1 Tim. 4:6; τὸ καλόν, and τὸ καλόν ἔργον, what is good and right, a good deed, rectitude, virtue, Mt. 5:16; Rom. 7:18, 21; right, duty, propriety, Mt. 15:26; benefit, favor, Jn. 10:32, 33
κάλυμμα: a covering; a veil, 2 Cor. 3:13; met. a veil, a blind to spiritual vision, 2 Cor. 3:14, 15, 16*
καλύπτω: to cover, Mt. 8:24; Lk. 8:16; 23:30; to hide, conceal, Mt. 10:26; 2 Cor. 4:3; met. to cover, throw a veil of oblivion over, Jas. 5:20; 1 Pet. 4:8
καλῶς: well, rightly, suitable, with propriety, becomingly, 1 Cor. 7:37; 14:17; Gal. 4:17; 5:7; truly, justly, correctly, Mk. 12:32; Lk. 20:39; Jn. 4:17; appositely, Mt. 15:7; Mk. 7:6; becomingly, honorably, Jas. 2:3; well, effectually, Mk. 7:9, 37; καλῶς εἰπεῖν, to speak well, praise, applaud, Lk. 6:26; καλῶς ἔχειν, to be convalescent, Mk. 16:18; καλῶς ποιεῖν, to do good, confer benefits, Mt. 5:44; 12:12; to do well, act virtuously, Phil. 4:14
κάμινος: a furnace, oven, kiln, Mt. 13:42, 50; Rev. 1:15; 9:2*
καμμύω: to shut, close the eyes, Mt. 13:15; Acts 28:27*
κάμνω: to tire with exertion, labor to weariness; to be wearied, tired out, exhausted, be discouraged, Heb. 12:3; to labor under disease, be sick, Jas. 5:15*
κάμπτω: trans. to bend, inflect the knee, Rom. 11:4; Eph. 3:14 intrans. to bend, bow, Rom. 14:11; Phil. 2:10*
κἄν: crasis, and if, Mk. 16:18; also if, Mt. 21:21; even if, if even, although, Jn. 10:38; if so much as, Heb. 12:20; also in NT simply equivalent to καί, as a particle of emphasis, by a pleonasm of ἄν, at least, at all events, Mk. 6:56; Acts 5:15; 2 Cor. 11:16
Κανά: indecl. Cana, a town in Galilee, Jn. 2:1, 11; 4:46; 21:2*. See PhotoGuide.
κανών: a measure, rule; in NT prescribed range of action or duty, 2 Cor. 10:13, 15, 16; met. rule of conduct or doctrine, Gal. 6:16*
καπηλεύω: pr. to be κάπηλος, a retailer; to peddle with; to corrupt, adulterate, 2 Cor. 2:17*
Καππαδοκία: Cappadocia, a district of Asia Minor, Acts 2:9; 1 Pet. 1:1*
καρδία: the heart, regarded as the seat of feeling, impulse, affection, desire, Mt. 6:21; 22:37; Phil. 1:7; the heart, as the seat of intellect, Mt. 13:15; Rom. 1:21; the heart, as the inner and mental frame, Mt. 5:8; Lk. 16:15; 1 Pet. 3:4; the conscience, 1 Jn. 3:20, 21; the heart, the inner part, middle, center, Mt. 12:40
καρπός: fruit, Mt. 3:10; 21:19, 34; from the Hebrew, καρπὸς κοιλίας, fruit of the womb, offspring, Lk. 1:42; καρπὸς ὀσφύος, fruit of the loins, offspring, posterity, Acts 2:30; καρπὸς χειλέων, fruit of the lips, praise, Heb. 13:15; met. conduct, actions, Mt. 3:8; 7:16; Rom. 6:22; benefit, profit, Rom. 1:13; 6:21; reward, Phil. 4:17
καρποφορέω: to bear fruit, yield, Mk. 4:28; met, to bring forth the fruit of action or conduct, Mt. 13:23; Rom. 7:5; mid. to expand by fruitfulness, to develop itself by success, Col. 1:6, 10
καρποφόρος: fruitful, adapted to bring forth fruit, Acts 14:17*
καρτερέω: to be stout; to endure patiently, persevere, bear up with fortitude, Heb. 11:27*
κάρφος: any small dry thing, as chaff, stubble, splinter; Mt. 7:3, 4, 5; Lk. 6:41, 42*
κατά: down from, Mt. 8:32; down upon, upon, Mk. 14:3; Acts 27:14; down into; κατὰ βάθους, profound, deepest, 2 Cor. 8:2; down over, throughout a space, Lk. 4:14; 23:5; concerning, in cases of pointed allegation, 1 Cor. 15:15; against, Mt. 12:30; by, in oaths, Mt. 26:63; with an acc. of place, in the quarter of, about, near, at, Lk. 10;32; Acts 2:10; throughout, Lk. 8:39; in, Rom. 16:5; among, Acts 21:21; in the presence of, Lk. 2:31; in the direction of, towards, Acts 8:26; Phil. 3:14; of time, within the range of; during, in the course of, at, about, Acts 12:1; 27:27; distributively, κατ’ οἶκον, by houses, from house to house, Acts 2:46; kata; duvo, two and two, 1 Cor. 14:27; καθ’ ἡμέραν, daily, Mt. 26:55; trop., according to, conformable to, in proportion to, Mt. 9:29; 25:15; after the fashion or likeness of. Heb. 5:6; in virtue of, Mt. 19:3; as respects, Rom. 11:3; Acts 25;14; Heb. 9:9
καταβαίνω: to come or go down, descend, Mt. 8:1; 17:9; to lead down, Acts 8:26; to come down, fall, Mt. 7:25, 27; to be let down, Acts 10:11; 11:5
καταβάλλω: to cast down, 2 Cor. 4:9; mid. to lay down, lay a foundation, Heb. 6:1*
καταβαρέω: pr. to weigh down, met. to burden, be burdensome to, 2 Cor. 12:16*
καταβαρύνω: to weigh down, depress, pass., be heavy, Mk. 14:40*
κατάβασις: the act of descending; a way down, descent, Lk. 19:37*
καταβολή: pr. a casting down; laying the foundation, foundation; beginning, commencement, Mt. 13:35; 25:34; conception in the womb, Heb. 11:11
καταβραβεύω: pr. to give an unfavorable decision as respects a prize; hence, to decide against, Col. 2:18*
καταγγελεύς: one who announces anything, a proclaimer, publisher, Acts 17:18*
καταγγέλλω: to announce, proclaim, Acts 13:38; in NT to laud, celebrate, Rom. 1:8
καταγελάω: to deride, laugh at, jeer, Mt. 9:24; Mk. 5:40; Lk. 8:53*
καταγινώσκω: to determine against, condemn, blame, reprehend, Gal. 2:11; 1 Jn. 3:20, 21
κατάγνυμι: to break in pieces, crush, break in two, Mt. 12:20; Jn. 19:31, 32, 33*
καταγράφω: to trace, draw in outline, write, Jn. 8:6*
κατάγω: to lead, bring, or conduct down, Acts 9:30; 22:30; 23:15, 20, 28; to bring a ship to land; pass. κατάγομαι, aor. κατήχθην, to come to land, land, touch, Lk. 5:11
καταγωνίζομαι: to subdue, vanquish, overcome, conquer, Heb. 11:33*
καταδέω: to bind up; to bandage a wound, Lk. 10:34*
καταδικάζω: to give judgment against, condemn, Mt. 12:7, 37; Lk. 6:37; Jas. 5:6*
καταδιώκω: to follow hard upon; to track, search for, follow perseveringly, Mk. 1:36*
καταδουλόω: to reduce to absolute servitude, make a slave of, 2 Cor. 11:20; Gal. 2:4*
καταδυναστεύω: to tyrannize over, oppress, exploit, Acts 10:38; Jas. 2:6*
κατάθεμα: an execration, curse; by meton. what is worthy of cursing or condemnation, Rev. 22:3*
καταισχύνω: to humiliate, shame, put to shame, 1 Cor. 1:27; pass. to be ashamed, be put to shame, Lk. 13:17; to dishonor, disgrace, 1 Cor. 11:4, 5; from the Hebrew, to frustrate, disappoint, Rom. 5:5; 9:33; 1 Pet. 2:6
κατακαίω: to burn up, consume with fire, Mt. 3:12; 13:30, 40
κατακαλύπτω: to veil; mid. to veil one’s self, be veiled or covered, 1 Cor. 11:6, 7. In the pres act ind., 2nd sg, the personal ending σαι does not simplify as normal, κατακαυχᾶσαι*
κατακαυχάομαι: to boast, glory over, assume superiority over, Rom. 11:18 (2x); Jas. 2:13; 3:14*
κατάκειμαι: to lie, be in a recumbent position, be laid down, Mk. 1:30; 2:4; Lk. 5:25; Jn. 5:3, 6; Acts 9:33; 28:8; to recline at table, Mk. 2:15; 14:3; Lk. 5:29; 7:37; 1 Cor. 8:10*
κατακλάω: to break, break in pieces, Mk. 6:41; Lk. 9:16*
κατακλείω: to close, shut fast; to shut up, confine, Lk. 3:20; Acts 26:10*
κατακλίνω: to cause to lie down, cause to recline at table, Lk. 9:14, 15; mid. to lie down, recline, Lk. 7:36; 14:8; 24:30*
κατακολουθέω: to follow closely or earnestly, Lk. 23:55; Acts 16:17*
κατακόπτω: to cut or dash in pieces; to mangle, wound, Mk. 5:5*
κατακρίνω: to give judgment against, condemn, Mt. 27:3; Jn. 8:10, 11; to condemn, to place in a guilty light by contrast, Mt. 12:41, 42; Lk. 11:31, 32; Heb. 11:7
κατακυριεύω: to get into one’s power; in NT to bring under, master, overcome, Acts 19:16; to domineer over, Mt. 20:25; Mk. 10:42; 1 Pet. 5:3*
καταλαλέω: to blab out; to speak against, slander, Jas. 4:11; 1 Pet. 2:12; 3:16*
καταλαλιά: evil-speaking, detraction, backbiting, slandering, 2 Cor. 12:20; 1 Pet. 2:1*
καταλαμβάνω: to lay hold of, grasp; to obtain, attain, Rom. 9:30; 1 Cor. 9:24; Phil. 3:12, 13; to seize, to take possession of, Mk. 9:18; to come suddenly upon; overtake, surprise, Jn. 12:35; 1 Thess. 5:4; to detect in the act, seize, Jn. 8:3, 4; met. to comprehend, apprehend, Jn. 1:5; mid. to understand, perceive, Acts 4:13; 10:34; 25:25; Eph. 3:18*
καταλέγω: to select, enter in a list or catalog, enroll, 1 Tim. 5:9*
καταλείπω: to leave behind; to leave behind at death, Mk. 12:19; to relinquish, let remain, Mk. 14:52; to quit, depart from, forsake, Mt. 4:13; 16:4; to neglect, Acts 6:2; to leave alone, or without assistance, Lk. 10:40; to reserve, Rom. 11:4
καταλιθάζω: to stone, kill by stoning, Lk. 20:6*
καταλλαγή: pr. an exchange; reconciliation, restoration to favor, Rom. 5:11; 11:15; 2 Cor. 5:18, 19*
καταλλάσσω: to change, exchange; to reconcile; pass. to be reconciled, Rom. 5:10 (2x); 1 Cor. 7:11; 2 Cor. 5:18, 19, 20*
κατάλοιπος: remaining; οἱ κατάλοιποι, the rest, Acts 15:17*
κατάλυμα: lodging, inn, Lk. 2:7; a guest-chamber, Mk. 14:14; Lk. 22:11*
καταλύω: to dissolve; to destroy, demolish, overthrow, throw down, Mt. 24:2; 26:61; met. to nullify, abrogate, Mt. 5:17; Acts 5:38, 39; absol. to unloose harness, etc., to halt, to stop for the night, lodge, Lk. 9:12
καταμανθάνω: to learn or observe thoroughly; to consider accurately and diligently, contemplate, Mt. 6:28*
καταμαρτυρέω: to witness or testify against, Mt. 26:62; 27:13; Mk. 14:60*
καταμένω: to remain; to abide, dwell, Acts 1:13*
καταναρκάω: in NT to be burdensome to the disadvantage of any one, to be a dead weight upon; by impl. to be troublesome, burdensome to, in respect of maintenance, 2 Cor. 11:9; 12:13, 14*
κατανεύω: pr. to nod, signify assent by a nod; genr. to make signs, beckon, Lk. 5:7*
κατανοέω: to perceive, understand, apprehend, Lk. 20:23; to observe, consider, contemplate, Lk. 12:24, 27; to discern, detect, Mt. 7:3; to have regard to, make account of, Rom. 4:19
καταντάω: to come to, arrive at, Acts 16:1; 20:15; of an epoch, to come upon, 1 Cor. 10:11; met. to reach, attain to, Acts 26:7
κατάνυξις: in NT deep sleep, stupor, dullness, Rom. 11:8*
κατανύσσομαι: to pierce through; to pierce with compunction and pain of heart, Acts 2:37*
καταξιόω: to consider worthy of, Lk. 20:35; Acts 5:41; 2 Thess. 1:5*
καταπατέω: to trample upon, tread down or under feet, Mt. 5:13; 7:6; Lk. 8:5; 12:1; met. to trample on by indignity, spurn, Heb. 10:29*
κατάπαυσις: pr. the act of giving rest; a state of settled or final rest, Heb. 3:11, 18; 4:1, 3, 4, 5, 11; a place of rest, place of abode, dwelling, habitation, Acts 7:49*
καταπαύω: to cause to cease, restrain, Acts 14:18; to cause to rest, give final rest to, settle finally, Heb. 4:8; intrans. to rest, desist from, Heb. 4:4, 10*
καταπίνω: to drink, swallow, gulp down, Mt. 23:24; to swallow up, absorb, Rev. 12:16; 2 Cor. 5:4; to engulf, submerge, overwhelm, Heb. 11:29; to swallow greedily, devour, 1 Pet. 5:8; to destroy, annihilate, 1 Cor. 15:54; 2 Cor. 2:7*
καταπίπτω: to fall down, fall prostrate, Lk. 8:6; Acts 26:14; 28:6*
καταπλέω: to sail towards land, to come to land, Lk. 8:26*
καταπονέω: to exhaust by labor or suffering; to wear out, 2 Pet. 2:7; to overpower, oppress, Acts 7:24*
καταποντίζω: to sink in the sea; pass. to sink, Mt. 14:30; to be plunged, submerged, drowned, Mt. 18:6*
κατάρα: a cursing, execration, imprecation, Jas. 3:10; from the Hebrew, condemnation, doom, Gal. 3:10; Heb. 6:8; 2 Pet. 2:14; meton., a doomed one, one on whom condemnation falls, Gal. 3:13*
καταράομαι: to curse, to wish evil to, imprecate evil upon, Mk. 11:21; Lk. 6:28; Rom. 12:14; Jas. 3:9; in NT pass. to be cursed, Mt. 25:41*
καταργέω: to render useless or unproductive, occupy unprofitable, Lk. 13:7; to render powerless, Rom. 6:6; to make empty and unmeaning, Rom. 4:14; to render null, to abrogate, cancel, Rom. 3:3, 31; Eph. 2:15; to bring to an end, 1 Cor. 2:6; 13:8; 15:24, 26; 2 Cor. 3:7; to destroy, annihilate, 2 Thess. 2:8; Heb. 2:14; to free from, dissever from, Rom. 7:2, 6; Gal. 5:4
καταριθμέω: to enumerate, number with, count with, Acts 1:17*
καταρτίζω: to adjust thoroughly; to knit together, unite completely, 1 Cor. 1:10; to frame, Heb. 11:3; to prepare, provide, Mt. 21:16; Heb. 10:5; to qualify fully, to complete in character, Lk. 6:40; Heb. 13:21; 1 Pet. 5:10; perf. pass. κατηρτισμένα, fit, ripe, Rom. 9:22; to repair, refit, Mt. 4:21; Mk. 1:19; to supply, make good, 1 Thess. 3:10; to restore to a forfeited condition, to reinstate, Gal. 6:1; 2 Cor. 13:11*
κατάρτισις: pr. a complete adjustment; completeness of character, perfection, 2 Cor. 13:9*
καταρτισμός: a perfectly adjusted adaptation; complete qualification for a specific purpose, Eph. 4:12*
κατασείω: to shake down or violently, Acts 19:33; τὴν χεῖρα, or τῇ χειρι, to wave the hand, beckon; to signal silence by waving the hand, Acts 12:17; 13:16; 21:40*
κατασκάπτω: pr. to dig down under, undermine; by impl. to overthrow; demolish, raze, Rom. 11:3; τὰ κατεσκαμμένα, ruins, Acts 15:16*
κατασκευάζω: to prepare, put in readiness, Mt. 11:10; Mk. 1:2; Lk. 1:17; 7:27; to construct, form, build, Heb. 3:3, 4; 9:2, 6; 11:7; 1 Pet. 3:20*
κατασκηνόω: to pitch one’s tent; in NT to rest in a place, settle, abide, Acts 2:26; to haunt, roost, Mt. 13:32; Mk. 4:32; Lk. 13:19*
κατασκήνωσις: pr. the pitching a tent; a tent; in NT a dwelling place, Mt. 8:20; Lk. 9:58*
κατασκοπέω: to view closely and accurately; to spy out, Gal. 2:4*
κατασοφίζομαι: to exercise cleverness to the detriment of any one, to outwit; to make a victim of subtlety, to practice on the insidious dealing, Acts 7:19*
καταστέλλω: to arrange, dispose in regular order; to appease, quiet, pacify, Acts 19:35, 36*
κατάστημα: determinate state, behavior, condition; personal appearance, Tit. 2:3*
καταστολή: pr. an arranging in order; adjustment of dress; in NT apparel, dress, 1 Tim. 2:9*
καταστρέφω: to invert; to overturn, upset, overthrow, throw down, Mt. 21:12; Mk. 11:15*
καταστρηνιάω: to be headstrong or wanton towards, 1 Tim. 5:11*
καταστροφή: an overthrow, destruction, 2 Pet. 2:6; met. overthrow of right principle or faith, utter detriment, perversion, 2 Tim. 2:14*
καταστρώννυμι: to lay flat; pass. to be laid prostrate in death, 1 Cor. 10:5*
κατασύρω: to drag down, to drag away by force, Lk. 12:58*
κατασφάζω: also spelled κατασφάττω, to slaughter, slay, Lk. 19:27*
κατατίθημι: mid. to ay up for one’s self; χάριν, or χάριτας, to lay up a store of favor for one’s self, earn a title to favor at the hands of a person, to curry favor with, Acts 24:27; 25:9*
καταφέρω: to bear down; to overpower, as sleep, Acts 20:9; καταφέρειν ψῆφον, to give a vote or verdict, Acts 26:10; to bring charges, Acts 25:7*
καταφεύγω: to flee to for refuge, Acts 14:6; Heb. 6:18*
καταφιλέω: to kiss affectionately or with a semblance of affection, to kiss with earnest gesture, Mt. 26:49; Mk. 14:45; Lk. 7:38, 45; 15:20; Acts 20:37*
καταφρονέω: pr. to look down on; to scorn, despise, Mt. 18:10; Rom. 2:4; to slight, Mt. 6:24; Lk. 16:13; 1 Cor. 11:22; 1 Tim. 4:12; 6:2; 2 Pet. 2:10; to disregard, Heb. 12:2*
καταχέω: to pour out or down upon, Mt. 26:7; Mk. 14:3*
καταχθόνιος: under the earth, subterranean, infernal, Phil. 2:10*
καταχράομαι: to use downright; to use up, consume; to make an unrestrained use of, use eagerly, 1 Cor. 7:31; to use to the full, stretch to the utmost, exploit, 1 Cor. 9:18*
κατείδωλος: rife with idols, sunk in idolatry, grossly idolatrous, Acts 17:16*
κατέναντι: can function as an improper prep., over against, opposite to, Mk. 11:2; 12:41; 13:3; ὁ, ἡ, τό, κατέναντι, opposite, Lk. 19:30; before, in the presence of, in the sight of, Rom. 4:17
κατενώπιον: can function as an improper prep., in the presence of, in the sight of, before; Eph. 1:4; Col. 1:22; Jude 24*
κατεξουσιάζω: to exercise lordship or authority over, domineer over, Mt. 20:25; Mk. 10:42*
κατεργάζομαι: to work out; to effect, produce, bring out as a result, Rom. 4:15; 5:3; 7:13; 2 Cor. 4:17; 7:10; Phil. 2:12; 1 Pet. 4:3; Jas. 1:3; to work, practice, realize in practice, Rom. 1:27; 2:9; to work or mould into fitness, 2 Cor. 5:5, despatch, Eph. 6:13
κατέρχομαι: to come or go down, Lk. 4:31; 9:37; Acts 8:5; 9:32; to land at, touch at, Acts 18:22; 27:5
κατεσθίω: also spelled κατέσθω, to eat up, devour, Mt. 13:4; to consume, Rev. 11:5, to expend, squander, Lk. 15:30; met. to make a prey of, plunder, Mt. 23:13; Mk. 12:40; Lk. 20:47; 2 Cor. 11:20; to annoy, injure, Gal. 5:15
κατευθύνω: optative, κατευθύναι (3rd sg), to make straight; to direct, guide aright, Lk. 1:79; 1 Thess. 3:11; 2 Thess. 3:5*
κατεφίσταμαι: to come upon suddenly, rush upon, assault, Acts 18:12*
κατέχω: (1) transitive, to hold down; to detain, retain, Lk. 4:42; Rom. 1:18; Phlm. 13; to hinder, restrain, 2 Thess. 2:6, 7; to hold downright, hold in a firm grasp, to have in full and secure possession, 1 Cor. 7:30; 2 Cor. 6:10; to come into full possession of, seize upon; to keep, retain, 1 Thess. 5:21; to occupy, Lk. 14:9; met. to hold fast mentally, retain, Lk. 8:15; 1 Cor. 11:2; 15:2; to maintain, Heb. 3:6, 14; 10:23; (2) intransitive, a nautical term, to land, touch, Acts 27:40; pass. to be in the grasp of, to be bound by, Rom. 7:6*
κατηγορέω: to speak against, accuse, Mt. 12:10; 27:12; Jn. 5:45
κατηγορία: an accusation, crimination, Jn. 18:29; 1 Tim. 5:19; Tit. 1:6*
κατήγωρ: an accuser, Rev. 12:10, a barbarous form for κατήγορος*
κατηχέω: pr. to sound in the ears, make the ears ring; to instruct orally, to instruct, inform, 1 Cor. 14:19; pass. to be taught, be instructed, Lk. 1:4; Rom. 2:18; Gal. 6:6; to be made acquainted, Acts 18:25; to receive information, hear report, Acts 21:21, 24*
κατιόω: to cover with rust; pass. to rust, become rusty or tarnished, Jas. 5:3*
κατισχύω: to overpower, Mt. 16:18; absol. to predominate, get the upper hand, Lk. 21:36; 23:23*
κατοικέω: trans. to inhabit, Acts 1:19; absol. to have an abode, dwell, Lk. 13:4; Acts 11:29; to take up or find an abode, Acts 7:2; to indwell, Eph. 3:17; Jas. 4:5
κατοικητήριον: an abode, dwelling, habitation, the same as κατοίκησις, Eph. 2:22; Rev. 18:2*
κατοπτρίζω: to show in a mirror; to present a clear and correct image of a thing, mid. to have presented in a mirror, to have a clear image presented, or, to reflect, 2 Cor. 3:18*
κάτω: (1) down, downwards, Mt. 4:6; Lk. 4:9; Jn. 8:6; Acts 20:9; (2) beneath, below, under, Mt. 27:51; Mk. 14:66; 15:38; Acts 2:19; ὁ, ἡ, τό, κάτω, what is below, earthly, Jn. 8:23*
κατωτέρω: lower, farther down; of time, under, Mt. 2:16*
Καῦδα: also spelled Κλαῦδα (G3084) and Κλαῦδη (G3085), Cauda, indecl. pr. name of an island, Acts 27:16*
καῦμα: heat, scorching or burning heat, Rev. 7:16; 16:9*
καυματίζω: to scorch, burn, Mt. 13:6; Mk. 4:6; Rev. 16:8, 9*
καυσόω: to be on fire, burn intensely, 2 Pet. 3:10, 12*
καυστηριάζω: also spelled καυτηριάζω, to cauterize, brand; pass. met. to be branded with marks of guilt, or, to be seared into insensibility, 1 Tim. 4:2*
καύσων: fervent scorching heat; the scorching of the sun, Mt. 20:12; hot weather, a hot time, Lk. 12:55; the scorching wind of the East, Eurus, Jas. 1:11*
καυχάομαι: to glory, boast, Rom. 2:17, 23; ὑπέρ τινος, to boast of a person or thing, to undertake a complimentary testimony to, 2 Cor. 12:5; to rejoice, exult, Rom. 5:2, 3, 11
καύχημα: a glorying, boasting, 1 Cor. 5:6; a ground or matter of glorying or boasting, Rom. 4:2; joy, exultation, Phil. 1:26; complimentary testimony, 1 Cor. 9:15, 16; 2 Cor. 9:3
καύχησις: boasting, pride, a later equivalent to καύχημαι, Rom. 3:27; 2 Cor. 7:4, 14; 11:10
Καφαρναούμ: indecl. pr. name, Capernaum. See PhotoGuide.
Κεγχρεαί: Cenchreae, the port of Corinth on the Saronic Gulf; Acts 18:18; Rom. 16:1*
Κεδρών: indecl. pr. name, Kidron, a valley near Jerusalem, Jn. 18:1*
κεῖμαι: to lie, to be laid; to recline, to be lying, to have been laid down, Mt. 28:6; Lk. 2:12; to have been laid, placed, set, Mt. 3:10; Lk. 3:9; Jn. 2:6; to be situated, as a city, Mt. 5:14; Rev. 21:16; to be in store, Lk. 12:19; met. to be constituted, established as a law, 1 Tim. 1:9; in NT of persons, to be specially set, solemnly appointed, destined, Lk. 2:34; Phil. 1:16; 1 Thess. 3:3; to lie under an influence, to be involved in, 1 Jn. 5:19
κειρία: a bandage, swath, in NT pl. graveclothes, Jn. 11:44*
κείρω: to cut off the hair, shear, shave, Acts 8:32; 18:18; 1 Cor. 11:6 (2x)*
κέλευσμα: a word of command; a mutual cheer; hence, in NT a loud shout, an arousing outcry, 1 Thess. 4:16*
κελεύω: to order, command, direct, bid, Mt. 8:18; 14:19, 28
κενός: empty; having nothing, empty-handed, Mk. 12:3; met. vain, fruitless, void of effect, Acts 4:25; 1 Cor. 15:10; εἰς κενόν, in vain, to no purpose, 2 Cor. 6:1; hollow, fallacious, false, Eph. 5:6; Col. 2:8; inconsiderate, foolish, 1 Thess. 3:5; Jas. 2:20
κενοφωνία: vain, empty babbling, vain disputation, fruitless discussion, 1 Tim. 6:20; 2 Tim. 2:16*
κενόω: to empty, evacuate; ἑαυτόν, to divest one’s self of one’s prerogatives, abase one’s self, Phil. 2:7; to deprive a thing of its proper functions, Rom. 4:14; 1 Cor. 1:17; to show to be without foundation, falsify, 1 Cor. 9:15; 2 Cor. 9:3*
κέντρον: a sharp point; a sting of an animal, Rev. 9:10; a prick, stimulus, goad, Acts 26:14; met. of death, destructive power, deadly venom, 1 Cor. 15:55, 56*
κεντυρίων: in its original signification, a commander of a hundred foot-soldiers, a centurion, Mk. 15:39, 44, 45*
κενῶς: in vain, to no purpose, unmeaning, Jas. 4:5*
κεραία: pr. a horn-like projection, a point, extremity; in NT an apex, or fine point; as of letters, used for the minutest part, a tittle, Mt. 5:18; Lk. 16:17*
κεραμικός: made by a potter, earthen, Rev. 2:27*
κεράμιον: an earthenware vessel, a pitcher, jar, Mk. 14:13; Lk. 22;10*
κέραμος: potter’s clay; earthenware; a roof, tile, tiling, Lk. 5:19*
κεράννυμι: to mix, mingle, drink; to prepare for drinking, Rev. 14:10; 18:6 (2x)*
κέρας: a horn, Rev. 5:6; 12:3; a horn-like projection at the corners of an altar, Rev. 9:13; from the Hebrew, a horn as a symbol of power, Lk. 1:69
κεράτιον: pr. a little horn; in NT a pod, the pod of the carob tree, or Ceratonia siliqua of Linnaeus, a common tree in the East and the south of Europe, growing to a considerable size, and producing long slender pods, with a pulp of a sweetish taste, and several brown shining seeds like beans, sometimes eaten by the poorer people in Syria and Palestine, and commonly used for fattening swine, Lk. 15:16*
κερδαίνω: to gain as a matter of profit, Mt. 25:17; to win, acquire possession of, Mt. 16:26; to profit in the avoidance of, to avoid, Acts 27:21; in NT Χριστόν, to win Christ, to become possessed of the privileges of the Gospel, Phil. 3:8; to win over from estrangement, Mt. 18:15; to win over to embrace the Gospel, 1 Cor. 9:19, 20, 21, 22; 1 Pet. 3:1; absol. to make gain, Jas. 4:13
κέρμα: something clipped small; small change, small pieces of money, coin, Jn. 2:15*
κεφάλαιον: a sum total; a sum of money, capital, Acts 22:28; the crowning or ultimate point to preliminary matters, Heb. 8:1*
κεφαλή: the head, Mt. 5:36; 6:17; the head, top; κεφαλὴ γωνίας, the head of the corner, the chief corner-stone, Mt. 21:42; Lk. 20:17; met. the head, superior, chief, principal, one to whom others are subordinate, 1 Cor. 11:3; Eph. 1:22
κεφαλίς: in NT a roll, volume, division of a book, Heb. 10:7*
κῆνσος: a census, assessment, enumeration of the people and a valuation of their property; in NT tribute, tax, Mt. 17:25; poll-tax, Mt. 22:17, 19; Mk. 12:14*
κῆπος: a garden, any place planted with trees and herbs, Lk. 13:19; Jn. 18:1, 26; 19:41*
κήρυγμα: proclamation, proclaiming, public annunciation, Mt. 12:41; public inculcation, preaching, 1 Cor. 2:4; 15:14; meton. what is publicly inculcated, doctrine, Rom. 16:25; Tit. 1:3*
κῆρυξ: a herald, public messenger; in NT a proclaimer, publisher, preacher, 1 Tim. 2:7; 2 Tim. 1:11; 2 Pet. 2:5*
κηρύσσω: to publish, proclaim, as a herald, 1 Cor. 9:27; to announce openly and publicly, Mk. 1:4; Lk. 4:18; to noise abroad, Mk. 1:45; 7:36; to announce as a matter of doctrine, inculcate, preach, Mt. 24:14; Mk. 1:38; 13:10; Acts 15:21; Rom. 2:21
κῆτος: a large fish, sea monster, whale, Mt. 12:40*
Κηφᾶς: Cephas, Rock, rendered into Greek by Πέτρος, Jn. 1:42; 1 Cor. 1:12; 3:22; 9:5; 15:5; Gal. 1:18; 2:9, 11, 14*
κιβωτός: a chest, coffer; the ark of the covenant, Heb. 9:4; Rev. 11:19; the ark of Noah, Mt. 24:38; Lk. 17:27; Heb. 11:7; 1 Pet. 3:20*
κιθαρίζω: to play on a lyre or harp, 1 Cor. 14:7; Rev. 14:2*
κιθαρῳδός: one who plays on the lyre and accompanies it with his voice, Rev. 14:2; 18:22*
Κιλικία: Cilicia, a province of Asia Minor, Gal. 1:21
κινδυνεύω: to be in danger or peril, Lk. 8:23; Acts 19:27, 40; 1 Cor. 15:30*
κινέω: to move, Mt. 23:4; to excite, agitate, Acts 21:30; 24:5; to remove, Rev. 2:5; 6:14; in NT κεφαλήν, to shake the head in derision, Mt. 27:39; Mk. 15:29; mid., to move, possess the faculty of motion, exercise the functions of life, Acts 17:28*
Κίς: Kish, the father of Saul, pr. name, indecl., Acts 13:21*
κλάδος: a bough, branch, shoot, Mt. 13:32; 21:8; met. a branch of a family stock, Rom. 11:16, 21
κλαίω: intrans. to weep, shed tears, Mt. 26:75; Mk. 5:38, 39; Lk. 19:41; 23:28; trans. to weep for, bewail, Mt. 2:18
κλάσις: a breaking, the act of breaking, Lk. 24:35; Acts 2:42
κλάσμα: a piece broken off, fragment, Mt. 14:20; 15:37; Mk. 6:43; 8:8, 19, 20; Lk. 9:17; Jn. 6:12f.*
Κλαύδιος: Claudius, pr. name (1) The fourth Roman Emperor, Acts 11:28; 18:2. (2) Claudius Lysias, a Roman captain, Acts 23:26*
κλάω: to break off; in NT to break bread, Mt. 14:19; with figurative reference to the violent death of Christ, 1 Cor. 11:24
κλείς: a key, used in NT as the symbol of power, authority, etc. Mt. 16:19; Rev. 1:18; 3:7; 9:1; 20:1; met. the key of entrance into knowledge, Lk. 11:52*
κλείω: to close, shut, Mt. 6:6; 25:10; to shut up a person, Rev. 20:3; met. of the heavens, Lk. 4:25; Rev. 11:6; κλεῖσαι τὰ σπλάγχνα, to shut one’s bowels, to be hard-hearted, void of compassion, 1 Jn. 3:17; κλείειν τὴν βασιλεία τῶν οὐρανῶν, to endeavor to prevent entrance into the kingdom of heaven, Mt. 23:13
κλέος: pr. rumor, report; good report, praise, credit, 1 Pet. 2:20*
κλέπτης: a thief, Mt. 6:19, 20; 24:43; trop. a thief by imposture, Jn. 10:8
κλέπτω: to steal, Mt. 6:19, 20; 19:18; to take away stealthily, remove secretly, Mt. 27:64; 28:13
κλῆμα: a branch, shoot, twig, esp. of the vine, Jn. 15:2, 4-6*
Κλήμης: Clemens, Clement, pr. name, Latin, Phil. 4:3*
κληρονομέω: pr. to acquire by lot; to inherit, obtain by inheritance; in NT to obtain, acquire, receive possession of, Mt. 5:5; 19:29; absol. to be heir, Gal. 4:30
κληρονομία: an inheritance, patrimony, Mt. 21:38; Mk. 12:7; a possession, portion, property, Acts 7:5; 20:32; in NT a share, participation in privileges, Acts 20:32; Eph. 1:14; 5:5
κληρονόμος: an heir, Mt. 21:38; Gal. 4:1; a possessor, Rom. 4:13; Heb. 11:7; Jas. 2:5
κλῆρος: a lot, die, a thing used in determining chances, Mt. 27:35; Mk. 15:24; Lk. 23:34; Jn. 19:24; Acts 1:26; assignment, investiture, Acts 1:17; allotment, destination, Col. 1:12; a part, portion, share, Acts 8:21; 26:18; a constituent portion of the Church, 1 Pet. 5:3*
κληρόω: to obtain by lot or assignment; to obtain a portion, receive a share, Eph. 1:11*
κλῆσις: a call, calling, invitation; in NT the call or invitation to the privileges of the Gospel, Rom. 11:29; Eph. 1:18; the favor and privilege of the invitation, 2 Thess. 1:11; 2 Pet. 1:10; the temporal condition in which the call found a person, 1 Cor. 1:26; 7:20
κλητός: called, invited, in NT called to privileges or function, Mt. 20:16; 22:14; Rom. 1:1, 6, 7; 8:28; 1 Cor. 1:1, 2, 24; Jude 1; Rev. 17:14
κλίμα: pr. a slope; a portion of the ideal slope of the earth’s surface; a tract or region of country, Rom. 15:23; 2 Cor. 11:10; Gal. 1:21*
κλινάριον: a small bed or couch, Acts 5:15*
κλίνη: a couch, bed, Mt. 9:2, 6; Mk. 4:21; Rev. 2:22
κλινίδιον: a small couch or bed, Lk. 5:19, 24*
κλίνω: pr. trans. to cause to slope or bend; to bow down, Lk. 24:5; Jn. 19:30; to lay down to rest, Mt. 8:20; Lk. 9:58; to put to flight troops, Heb. 11:34; intrans. of the day, to decline, Lk. 9:12; 24:29*
κλισία: pr. a place for reclining; a tent, seat, couch; in NT a group of persons reclining at a meal. Lk. 9:14*
κλύδων: a wave, billow, surge, Lk. 8:24; Jas. 1:6*
κλυδωνίζομαι: to be tossed by waves; met. to fluctuate in opinion, be agitated, tossed to and fro, Eph. 4:14*
κνήθω: to scratch; to tickle, cause titillation; in NT mid. met. to procure pleasurable excitement for, to indulge an itching, 2 Tim. 4:3*
Κνίδος: Cnidus, a city of Caria, in Asia Minor, Acts 27:7*
κοδράντης: a Roman brass coin, equivalent to the fourth part of an as, or ἀσσάριον, or to δύο λεπτά, Mt. 5:26; Mk. 12:42*
κοιλία: a cavity; the belly, Mt. 15:17; Mk. 7:19; the stomach, Mt. 12:40; Lk. 15:16; the womb, Mt. 19:12; Lk. 1:15; from the Hebrew, the inner self, Jn. 7:38
κοιμάω: to lull to sleep; pass. to fall asleep, be asleep, Mt. 28:13; Lk. 22:45; met. to sleep in death, Acts 7:60; 13:36; 2 Pet. 3:4
κοινός: common, belonging equally to several, Acts 2:44; 4:32; in NT common, profane, Heb. 10:29; Rev. 21:27; ceremonially unclean, Mk. 7:2; Acts 10:14
κοινόω: to make common, in NT to profane, desecrate, Acts 21:28; to render ceremonially unclean, defile, pollute, Mt. 15:11, 18, 20; 7:15, 18, 20, 23; Heb. 9:13; to pronounce unclean ceremonially, Acts 10:15; 11:9*
κοινωνέω: to have in common, share, Heb. 2:14; to be associated in, to become a sharer in, Rom. 15:27; 1 Pet. 4:13; to become implicated in, be a party to, 1 Tim. 5:22; 2 Jn. 11; to associate one’s self with by sympathy and assistance, to communicate with in the way of aid and relief, Rom. 12:13; Gal. 6:6; Phil. 4:15*
κοινωνία: fellowship, partnership, Acts 2:42; 2 Cor. 6:14; 13:13; Gal. 2:9; Phil. 3:10; 1 Jn. 1:3; participation, communion, 1 Cor. 10:16; aid, relief, Heb. 13:16; contribution in aid, Rom. 15:26
κοινωνικός: social; in NT generous, liberal, beneficent, 1 Tim. 6:18*
κοινωνός: a fellow, partner, companion, Mt. 23:30; Lk. 5:10; 1 Cor. 10:18, 20; 2 Cor. 8:23; Phlm. 17; Heb. 10:33; a sharer, partaker, 2 Cor. 1:7; 1 Pet. 5:1; 2 Pet. 1:4*
κοίτη: a bed, Lk. 11:7; the conjugal bed, Heb. 13:4; meton. sexual intercourse, concubitus; hence, lewdness, whoredom, chambering, Rom. 13:13; in NT conception, Rom. 9:10*
κόκκινος: dyed with coccus, crimson, scarlet, Mt. 27:28; Heb. 9:19; Rev. 17:3, 4; 18:12, 16*
κολάζω: pr. to curtail, to coerce; to chastise, punish, Acts 4:21; 2 Pet. 2:9*
κόλασις: chastisement, punishment, Mt. 25:46; painful disquietude, torment, 1 Jn. 4:18*
κολαφίζω: to beat with the fist, buffet, Mt. 26:67; Mk. 14:65; met. to maltreat, treat with excessive force, 1 Cor. 4:11; to punish, 1 Pet. 2:20; to buffet, fret, afflict, 2 Cor. 12:7*
κολλάω: to glue or weld together; mid. to adhere to, Lk. 10:11; met. to attach one’s self to, unite with, associate with, Lk. 15:15; Acts 5:13; Rev. 18:5
κολλούριον: also spelled κολλύριον, collyrium, eye-salve, Rev. 3:18*
κολοβόω: in NT of time, to cut short, shorten, Mt. 24:22; Mk. 13:20*
Κολοσσαί: also spelled Κολασσαεύς, Colossae, a city of Phrygia, Col. 1:2*. See PhotoGuide.
κόλπος: the bosom, Lk. 16:22, 23; Jn. 1:18; 13:23; the bosom of a garment, Lk. 6:38; a bay, creek, inlet, Acts 27:39*
κολυμβάω: to dive; in NT to swim, Acts 27:43*
κολυμβήθρα: a place where any one may swim; a pond, pool, Jn. 5:2, 4, 7; 9:7*
κομάω: to have long hair, wear the hair long, 1 Cor. 11:14, 15*
κόμη: the hair; a head of long hair, 1 Cor. 11:15*
κομίζω: pr. to take into kindly keeping, to provide for; to convey, bring, Lk. 7:37; mid. to bring for one’s self; to receive, obtain, 2 Cor. 5:10; Eph. 6:8; to receive again, recover, Mt. 25:27; Heb. 11:19
κομψότερον: in NT in better health, Jn. 4:52*
κονιάω: to whitewash, or, plaster, Mt. 23:27; Acts 23:3*
κοπάζω: pr. to grow weary, suffer exhaustion; to abate, be stilled, Mt. 14:32; Mk. 4:39; 6:51*
κοπετός: pr. a beating of the breast, etc., in token of grief; a wailing, lamentation, Acts 8:2*
κοπή: a stroke, smiting; in NT slaughter, Heb. 7:1*
κοπιάω: to be wearied or spent with labor, faint from weariness, Mt. 11:28; Jn. 4:6; in NT to labor hard, to toil, Lk. 5:5; Jn. 4:38
κόπος: trouble, difficulty, uneasiness, Mt. 26:10; Mk. 14:6; labor, wearisome labor, travail, toil, 1 Cor. 3:8; 15:58; meton. the fruit or consequence of labor, Jn. 4:38; 2 Cor. 10:15
κόπτω: to smite, cut; to cut off or down, Mt. 21:8; Mk. 11:8; mid. to beat one’s self in mourning, lament, bewail, Mt. 11:17; 24:30; Lk. 8:52; 23:27; Rev. 1:7; 18:9*
κορβᾶν: corban, a gift, offering, oblation, anything consecrated to God, Mk. 7:11*
κορβανᾶς: temple treasury, the sacred treasury, Mt. 27:6*
Κορίνθιος: Corinthian; an inhabitant of Κόρινθος, Corinth, Acts 18:8; 2 Cor. 6:11*
Κόρινθος: Corinth, a celebrated city of Greece, Acts 18:1; 19:1; 1 Cor. 1:2; 2 Cor. 1:1, 23; 2 Tim. 4:20*
Κορνήλιος: Cornelius, a Latin pr. name, Acts 10:1, 3, 17, 22, 24f., 30f.*
κόρος: a cor, the largest Jewish measure for things dry, equal to the homer, and about fifteen bushels English, according to Josephus, Lk. 16:7*
κοσμέω: pluperfect, ἐκεκόσμητο (3 sg), to arrange, set in order; to adorn, decorate, embellish, Mt. 12:44; 23:29; to prepare, put in readiness, trim, Mt. 25:7; met. to honor, dignify, Tit. 2:10
κοσμικός: pr. belonging to the universe, in NT accommodated to the present state of things, adapted to this world, worldly, Tit. 2:12; τὸ κοσμικόν, as a subst. the apparatus for the service of the tabernacle, Heb. 9:1*
κοσμοκράτωρ: pr. monarch of the world; in NT a worldly prince, a power paramount in the world of the unbelieving and ungodly, Eph. 6:12*
κόσμος: (1) pr. order, regular disposition; ornament, decoration, embellishment, 1 Pet. 3:3; (2) the world, the material universe, Mt. 13:35; the world, the aggregate of sensitive existence, 1 Cor. 4:9; the lower world, the earth, Mk. 16:15; the world, the aggregate of mankind, Mt. 5:14; the world, the public, Jn. 7:4; in NT the present order of things, the secular world, Jn. 18:36; the human race external to the Jewish nation, the heathen world, Rom. 11:12, 15; the world external to the Christian body, 1 Jn. 3:1, 13; the world or material system of the Mosaic covenant, Gal. 4:3; Col. 2:8, 20
Κούαρτος: Quartus, a Latin pr. name, Rom. 16:23*
κοῦμ: an Aramaic imperative, also spelled κοῦμι, stand up, Mk. 5:41*
κουφίζω: to lighten, make light or less heavy, Acts 27:38*
κράβαττος: also spelled κράββατος, mattress, pallet, bed, Mk. 2:4, 9, 11f.; 6:55; Jn. 5:8-11; Acts 5:15; 9:33*
κράζω: to utter a cry, Mt. 14:26; to exclaim, cry out, Mt. 9:27; Jn. 1:15; to cry for vengeance, Jas. 5:4; to cry in supplication, Rom. 8:15; Gal. 4:6
κραιπάλη: also spelled κρεπάλη, drunken dissipation, Lk. 21:34*
κράσπεδον: a margin, border, edge, in NT a fringe, tuft, tassel, Mt. 9:20; 14:36; 23:5; Mk. 6:56; Lk. 8:44*
κραταιόω: to strengthen, render strong, corroborate, confirm; pass. to grow strong, acquire strength, Lk. 1:80; 2:40; Eph. 3:16; to be firm, resolute, 1 Cor. 16:13*
κρατέω: pr. to be strong; to be superior to any one, subdue, vanquish, Acts 2:24; to get into one’s power, lay hold of, seize, apprehend, Mt. 14:3; 18:28; 21:46; to gain, compass, attain, Acts 27:13; in NT to lay hold of, grasp, clasp, Mt. 9:25; Mk. 1:31; 5:41; to retain, keep under reserve, Mk. 9:10; met, to hold fast, observe, Mk. 7:3, 8; 2 Thess. 2:15; to hold to, adhere to, Acts 3:11; Col. 2:19; to restrain, hinder, repress, Lk. 24:16; Rev. 7:1; to retain, not to remit, sins, Jn. 20:23
κράτιστος: strongest; in NT κράτιστε, a term of respect, most excellent, noble, or illustrious, Lk. 1:3; Acts 23:26; 24:3; 26:25*
κράτος: strength, power, might, force, Acts 19:20; Eph. 1:19; meton. a display of might, Lk. 1:51; power, sway, dominion, Heb. 2:14; 1 Pet. 4:11; 5:11
κραυγάζω: to cry out, exclaim, shout, Mt. 12:19; Acts 22:23
κραυγή: a cry, outcry, clamor, shouting, Mt. 25:6; Lk. 1:42; Acts 23:9; Eph. 4:31; a cry of sorrow, wailing, lamentation, Rev. 21:4; a cry for help, earnest supplication, Heb. 5:7*
κρέας: flesh, meat, a later form of κρέατος, Rom. 14:21; 1 Cor. 8:13*
κρείττων: can also be spelled κρείσσων, better, more useful or profitable, more conducive to good, 1 Cor. 7:8, 38; superior, more excellent, of a higher nature, more valuable, Heb. 1:4; 6:9; 7:7, 19, 22
κρεμάννυμι: also spelled κρέμαμαι and κρεμάζω, to hang, suspend, Acts 5:30; 10:39; pass. to be hung, suspended, Mt. 18:6; Lk. 23:39; mid. κρέμαμαι, to hang, be suspended, Acts 28:4; Gal. 3:13; met. κρέμαμαι ἐν, to hang upon, to be referable to as an ultimate principle, Mt. 22:40
κρημνός: a hanging steep, precipice, a steep bank, Mt. 8:32; Mk. 5:13; Lk. 8:33*
Κρής: a Cretan, an inhabitant of Κρήτη, Acts 2:11; Tit. 1:12*
Κρήσκης: Crescens, a Latin pr. name, 2 Tim. 4:10*
Κρήτη: Crete, a large island in the eastern part of the Mediterranean, Acts 27:7, 12f., 21, Tit. 1:5*
κρίμα: judgment; a sentence, award, Mt. 7:2; a judicial sentence, Lk. 23:40; 24:20; Rom. 2:2; 5:16; an adverse sentence, Mt. 23:14; Rom. 13:2; 1 Tim. 5:12; Jas. 3:1; judgment, administration of justice, Jn. 9:39; Acts 24:25; execution of justice, 1 Pet. 4:17; a lawsuit; 1 Cor. 6:7; in NT judicial visitation, 1 Cor. 11:29; 2 Pet. 2:3; an administrative decree, Rom. 11:33
κρίνω: pluperfect, κεκρίκει (3 sg), pr. to separate; to make a distinction between; to exercise judgment upon; to estimate, Rom. 14:5; to judge, to assume censorial power over, to call to account, Mt. 7:1; Lk. 6:37; Rom. 2:1, 3; 14:3, 4, 10, 13; Col. 2:16; Jas. 4:11, 12; to bring under question, Rom. 14:22; to judge judicially, to try as a judge, Jn. 18:31; to bring to trial, Acts 13:27; to sentence, Lk. 19:22; Jn. 7:51; to resolve on, decree, Acts 16:4; Rev. 16:5; absol. to decide, determine, resolve, Acts 3:13; 15:19; 27:1; to deem, Acts 13:46; to form a judgment, pass judgment, Jn. 8:15; pass. to be brought to trial, Acts 25:10, 20; Rom. 3:4; to be brought to account, to incur arraignment, be arraigned, 1 Cor. 10:29; mid. to go to law, litigate, Mt. 5:40; in NT to judge, to visit judicially, Acts 7:7; 1 Cor. 11:31, 32; 1 Pet. 4:6; to judge, to right, to vindicate, Heb. 10:30; to administer government over, to govern, Mt. 19:28; Lk. 22:30
κρίσις: pr. distinction; discrimination; judgment, decision, award, Jn. 5:30; 7:24; 8:16; a judicial sentence, Jn. 3:19; Jas. 2:13; an adverse sentence, Mt. 23:33; Mk. 3:29; judgment, judicial process, trial, Mt. 10:15; Jn. 5:24; 12:31; 16:8; judgment, administration of justice, Jn. 5:22, 27; in NT a court of justice, tribunal, Mt. 5:21, 22; an impeachment, 2 Pet. 2:11; Jude 9; from the Hebrew, justice, equity, Mt. 12:18, 20; 23:23; Lk. 11:42
Κρίσπος: Crispus, a Latin pr. name, Acts 18:8; 1 Cor. 1:14*
κριτήριον: pr. a standard or means by which to judge, criterion; a court of justice, tribunal, Jas. 2:6; a cause, controversy, 1 Cor. 6:2, 4*
κριτής: a judge, Mt. 5:25; from the Hebrew, a magistrate, ruler, Acts 13:20; 24:10
κριτικός: able or quick to discern or judge, Heb. 4:12*
κρύπτη: a vault or closet, a cell for storage, dark secret place, Lk. 11:33*
κρυπτός: hidden, concealed, secret, clandestine, Mt. 6:4, 6; τὰ κρυπτά, secrets, Rom. 2:16; 1 Cor. 14:25
κρύπτω: to hide, conceal, Mt. 5:14; in NT to lay up in store, Col. 3:3; Rev. 2:17; κεκρυμμέμος, concealed, secret, Jn. 19:38
κρυσταλλίζω: to be clear, brilliant like crystal, Rev. 21:11*
κρυφῇ: in secret, secretly, not openly, Eph. 5:12*
κτάομαι: to get, procure, provide, Mt. 10:9; to make gain, gain, Lk. 18:12; to purchase, Acts 8:20; 22:28; to be the cause or occasion of purchasing, Acts 1:18; to preserve, save, Lk. 21:19; to get under control, to be winning the mastery over, 1 Thess. 4:4; perf. κέκτημαι, to possess*
κτῆμα: a possession, property, field, Mt. 19:22; Mk. 10:22; Acts 2:45; 5:1*
κτῆνος: pr. property, generally used in the plural, τὰ κτήνη; property in animals; a beast of burden, domesticated animal, Lk. 10:34; Acts 23:24; beasts, cattle, 1 Cor. 15:39; Rev. 18:13*
κτίζω: pr. to reduce from a state of disorder and wildness; in NT to call into being, to create, Mk. 13:19; to call into individual existence, to frame, Eph. 2:15; to create spiritually, to invest with a spiritual frame, Eph. 2:10; 4:24
κτίσις: (1) pr. a framing, founding; (2) in NT creation, the act of creating, Rom. 1:20; creation, the material universe, Mk. 10:6; 13:19; Heb. 9:11; 2 Pet. 3:4; a created thing, a creature, Rom. 1:25; 8:39; Col. 1:15; Heb. 4:13; the human creation, Mk. 16:15; Rom. 8:19, 20, 21, 22; Col. 1:23; a spiritual creation, 2 Cor. 5:17; Gal. 6:15; (3) an institution, ordinance, 1 Pet. 2:13
κτίσμα: pr. a thing founded; in NT a created being, creature, 1 Tim. 4:4; Jas. 1:18; Rev. 5:13; 8:9*
κτίστης: a founder; in NT a creator, 1 Pet. 4:19*
κυβεία: also spelled κυβία, pr. dice playing; met. craftiness, trickery, Eph. 4:14*
κυβέρνησις: government, office of a governor or director; meton. a director, 1 Cor. 12:28*
κυκλόω: to encircle, surround, encompass, come around. Jn. 10:24; Acts 14:20; spc. to lay siege to, Lk. 21:20; to march round, Heb. 11:30*
κύκλῳ: from κύκλος, functions in the NT only as an improper prep., a circle; in NT κύκλῳ functions adverbially, round, round about, around, Mk. 3:34; 6:6, 36
κυλισμός: also spelled κύλισμα, a rolling, wallowing, 2 Pet. 2:22*
κυλίω: to roll; mid. to roll one’s self, to wallow, Mk. 9:20
κυλλός: pr. crooked, bent, maimed, lame, crippled, Mt. 18:8; Mk. 9:43, used as a noun meaning cripple, Mt. 15:30ff.*
κῦμα: a wave, surge, billow, Mt. 8:24; 14:24; Mk. 4:37; Acts 27:41; Jude 13*
κύμινον: cumin, cuminum salivum of Linnaeus, a plant, a native of Egypt and Syria, whose seeds are of an aromatic, warm, bitterish taste, with a strong but not disagreeable smell, and used by the ancients as a condiment, Mt. 23:23*
κυνάριον: a little or worthless dog, Mt. 15:26, 27; Mk. 7:27, 28*
Κύπριος: a Cypriot, an inhabitant of Cyprus, Acts 4:36; 11:20; 21:16*
Κύπρος: Cyprus, an island in the eastern part of the Mediterranean, Acts 11:19; 13:4; 15:39; 21:3; 27:4*
κύπτω: to bend forwards, stoop down, Mk. 1:7; Jn. 8:6*
Κυρηναῖος: a Cyrenian, an inhabitant of Cyrene, Mt. 27:32; Mk. 15:21; Lk. 23:26; Acts 6:9; 11:20; 13:1*
Κυρήνη: Cyrene, a city founded by a colony of Greeks, in Northern Africa, Acts 2:10*
Κυρήνιος: Cyrenius (perhaps Quirinus) pr. name, the governor of Syria, Lk. 2:2*
κυριακός: pertaining to the Lord Jesus Christ, the Lord’s, 1 Cor. 11:20; Rev. 1:10*
κυριεύω: to be lord over, to be possessed of, mastery over, Rom. 6:9, 14; 7:1; 14:9; 2 Cor. 1:24; 1 Tim. 6:15; to exercise control over, Lk. 22:25*
κύριος: a lord, master, Mt. 12:8; an owner, possessor, Mt. 20:8; a potentate, sovereign, Acts 25:26; a power, deity, 1 Cor. 8:5; the Lord, Jehovah, Mt. 1:22; the Lord Jesus Christ, Mt. 24:42; Mk. 16:19; Lk. 10:1; Jn. 4:1; 1 Cor. 4:5; freq.; κύριε, a term of respect of various force, Sir, Lord, Mt. 13:27; Acts 9:6, et al. freq.
κυριότης: lordship; constituted authority, Eph. 1:21; 2 Pet. 2:10; Jude 8; pl. authorities, potentates, Col. 1:16. The Ephesian and Colossian passage could also be speaking about angelic powers.*
κυρόω: to confirm, ratify, Gal. 3:15; to reaffirm, assure, 2 Cor. 2:8*
κύων: a dog, Mt. 7:6; Lk. 16:21; 2 Pet. 2:22; met. a dog, a religious corrupter, Phil. 3:2; miscreant, Rev. 22:15*
κῶλον: lit., a member or limb of the body, fig., dead body, corpse, Heb. 3:17*
κωλύω: to hinder, restrain, prevent, Mt. 19:14; Acts 8:36; Rom. 1:13
κώμη: a village, a country town, Mt. 9:35; 10:11; Lk. 8:1
κωμόπολις: a large village, market town, Mk. 1:38*
κῶμος: pr. a festive procession, a merry-making; in NT a revel, lewd, immoral feasting, Rom. 13:13; Gal. 5:21; 1 Pet. 4:3*
κώνωψ: a gnat, mosquito, which is found in wine when becoming sour, Mt. 23:24*
κωφός: pr. blunt, dull, as a weapon; dull of hearing, deaf, Mt. 11:5; Mk. 7:32, 37; 9:25; Lk. 7:22; dumb, mute, Mt. 9:32, 33; 12:22; 15:30, 31; Lk. 1:22; meton. making dumb, causing dumbness, Lk. 11:14*
λαγχάνω: to have assigned to one, to obtain, receive, Acts 1:17; 2 Pet. 1:1; to have fall to one by lot, Lk. 1:9; absol. to cast lots, Jn. 19:24*
λαῖλαψ: a squall of wind, a hurricane, Mk. 4:37; Lk. 8:23; 2 Pet. 2:17*
λαλέω: to make vocal utterance; to babble, to talk; in NT absol. to exercise the faculty of speech, Mt. 9:33; to speak, Mt. 10:20; to hold converse with, to talk with, Mt. 12:46; Mk. 6:50; Rev. 1:12; to discourse, to make an address, Lk. 11:37; Acts 11:20; 21:39; to make announcement, to make a declaration, Lk. 1:55; to make mention, Jn. 12:41; Acts 2:31; Heb. 4:8; 2 Pet. 3:16; trans. to speak, address, preach, Mt. 9:18; Jn. 3:11; Tit. 2:1; to give utterance to, utter, Mk. 2:7; Jn. 3:34; to declare, announce, reveal, Lk. 24:25 et al.; to disclose, 2 Cor. 12:4
λαλιά: talk, speech; in NT matter of discourse, Jn. 4:42; 8:43; language, dialect, Mt. 26:73*
λαμβάνω: to take, take up, take in the hand, Mt. 10:38; 13:31, 33; to take on one’s self, sustain, Mt. 8:17; to take, seize, seize upon, Mt. 5:40; 21:34; Lk. 5:26; 1 Cor. 10:13; to catch, Lk. 5:5; 2 Cor. 12:16; to assume, put on, Phil. 2:7; to make a rightful or successful assumption of, Jn. 3:27; to conceive, Acts 28:15; to take by way of provision, Mt. 16:5; to get, get together, Mt. 16:9; to receive as payment, Mt. 17:24; Heb. 7:8; to take to wife, Mk. 12:19; to admit, give reception to, Jn. 6:21; 2 Jn. 10; met. to give mental reception to, Jn. 3:11; to be simply recipient of, to receive, Mt. 7:8; Jn. 7:23, 39; 19:30; Acts 10:43; in NT λαμβάνειν πεῖραν, to make encounter of a matter of difficulty or trial, Heb. 11:29, 36; λαμβάνειν ἀρχήν, to begin, Heb. 2:3; λαμβάνειν συμβούλιον, to take counsel, consult, Mt. 12:14; λαμβάνειν λήθην, to forget, 2 Pet. 1:9; λαμβάνειν ὑπόμνησιν, to recollect, call to mind, 2 Tim. 1:5; λαμβάνειν περιτομήν, to receive circumcision, be circumcised, Jn. 7:23; λαμβάνειν καταλλαγήν, to be reconciled, Rom. 5:11; λαμβάνειν κρίμα, to receive condemnation or punishment, be punished, Mk. 12:40; from the Hebrew, πρόσωπον λαμβάνειν, to accept the person of any one, show partiality towards, Lk. 20:21
λαμπάς: a light, Acts 20:8; a lamp, Rev. 4:5; 8:10, a portable lamp, lantern, torch, Mt. 25:1, 3, 4, 7, 8; Jn. 18:3*
λαμπρός: bright, resplendent, shining, Rev. 22:16; clear, transparent, Rev. 22:1; white, glistening, Acts 10:30; Rev. 15:6; Rev. 19:8; of a bright color, gaudy, Lk. 23:11; by impl. splendid, magnificent, sumptuous, Jas. 2:2, 3; Rev. 18:14*
λάμπω: to shine, give light, Mt. 5:15, 16; 17:2; to flash, shine, Lk. 17:24; Acts 12:7; 2 Cor. 4:6*
λανθάνω: to be unnoticed; to escape the knowledge or observation of a person, Acts 26:26; 2 Pet. 3:5, 8; absol. to be concealed or hidden, escape detection, Mk. 7:24; Lk. 8:47; with a participle of another verb, to be unconscious of an action while being the subject or object of it, Heb. 13:2*
λαξευτός: cut in stone, hewn out of stone or rock, Lk. 23:53*
Λαοδίκεια: Laodicea, a city of Phrygia in Asia Minor, Rev. 3:14*. See PhotoGuide.
Λαοδικεύς: a Laodicean, an inhabitant of Laodicea, Col. 4:16*
λαός: a body of people; a concourse of people, a multitude, Mt. 27:25; Lk. 8:47; the common people, Mt. 26:5; a people, nation, Mt. 2:4; Lk. 2:32; Tit. 2:14; ὁ λαός, the people of Israel, Lk. 2:10
Λασαία: Lasaea, also spelled Λασέα, a maritime town in Crete, Acts 27:8. See PhotoGuide.
λατομέω: to hew stones; to cut out of stone, hew from stone, Mt. 27:60; Mk. 15:46; Lk. 23:53*
λατρεία: service, servitude; religious service, worship, Jn. 16:2; Rom. 9:4; 12:1; Heb. 9:1, 6*
λατρεύω: to be a servant, to serve, Acts 27:23; to render religious service and homage, worship, Mt. 4:10; Lk. 1:74; spc. to offer sacrifices, present offerings, Heb. 8:5; 9:9
λάχανον: a garden herb, vegetable, Mt. 13:32; Mk. 4:32; Lk. 11:42; Rom. 14:2*
λεγιών: also spelled λεγεών, a Roman legion; in NT used indefinitely for a great number, Mt. 26:53; Mk. 5:9, 15, Lk. 8:30*
λέγω: to lay, to arrange, to gather; to say, Mt. 1:20; to speak, make an address or speech, Acts 26:1; to say mentally, in thought, Mt. 3:9; Lk. 3:8; to say in written language, Mk. 15:28; Lk. 1:63; Jn. 19:37; to say, as distinguished from acting, Mt. 23:3; to mention, speak of, Mk. 14:71; Lk. 9:31; Jn. 8:27; to tell, declare, narrate, Mt. 21:27; Mk. 10:32; to express, Heb. 5:11; to put forth, propound, Lk. 5:36; 13:6; Jn. 16:29; to mean, to intend to signify, 1 Cor. 1:12; 10:29; to say, declare, affirm, maintain, Mt. 3:9; 5:18; Mk. 12:18; Acts 17:7; 26:22; 1 Cor. 1:10; to enjoin, Acts 15:24; 21:21; Rom. 2:22; to term, designate, cull, Mt. 19:17; Mk. 12:37; Lk. 20:37; 23:2; 1 Cor. 8:5; to call by a name, Mt. 2:23; pass. to be further named, to be surnamed, Mt. 1:16; to be explained, interpreted, Jn. 4:25; 20:16, 24; in NT σὺ λέγεις, you say, a form of affirmative answer to a question Mt. 27:11; Mk. 15:2; Jn. 18:37
λεῖμμα: pr. a remnant; in NT a small residue, Rom. 11:5*
λείπω: trans. to leave, forsake; pass. to be left, deserted; by impl. to be destitute of, deficient in, Jas. 1:4, 5; 2:15; intrans. to fail, be wanting, be deficient, Lk. 18:22; Tit. 1:5; 3:13*
λειτουργέω: pr. to perform some public service at one’s own expense; in NT to officiate as a priest, Heb. 10:11; to minister in the Christian Church, Acts 13:2; to minister to, assist, succor, Rom. 15:27*
λειτουργία: pr. a public service discharged by a citizen at his own expense; in NT a sacred ministration, Lk. 1:23; Phil. 2:17; Heb. 8:6; 9:21; a kind office, aid, relief, 2 Cor. 9:12; Phil. 2:30*
λειτουργικός: ministering; engaged in holy service, Heb. 1:14*
λειτουργός: pr. a person of property who performed a public duty or service to the state at his own expense; in NT a minister or servant, Rom. 13:6; 15:16; Heb. 1:7; 8:2; one who ministers relief, Phil. 2:25*
λεμά: Aramaic for Why? Wherefore? Mt. 27:46; Mk. 15:34*
λέντιον: a coarse cloth, with which servants were girded, a towel, napkin, apron, Jn. 13:4, 5*
λεπίς: a scale, shell, rind, crust, incrustation, Acts 9:18*
Λευί: Levi, also spelled Λευίς (G3323), pr. name. When the NT refers to the Λευί of the OT, the word is indecl. (n-3g[2]); when it refers to a NT person, it is partially declined (n-3g[1]): Λευίς (nom); Λευίν (acc). (1) Levi, son of Jacob, Heb. 7:5, 9; Rev. 7:7. (2) Levi, son of Symeon, Lk. 3:29 (3) Levi, son of Melchi, Lk. 3:24
Λευίτης: a Levite, one of the posterity of Levi, Jn. 1:19; Lk. 10:32; Acts 4:36*
Λευιτικός: Levitical, pertaining to the Levites, Heb. 7:11*
λευκαίνω: to brighten, to make white, Mk. 9:3; Rev. 7:14*
λευκός: pr. light, bright; white, Mt. 5:36; 17:2; whitening, growing white, Jn. 4:35
λέων: a lion, Heb. 11:33; 1 Pet. 5:8; Rev. 4:7; 9:8, 17; 10:3; 13:2; met. a lion, cruel adversary, tyrant, 2 Tim. 4:17; a lion, a hero, deliverer, Rev. 5:5*
λῆμψις: also spelled λῆψις, taking, receiving, Phil. 4:15*
ληνός: pr. a tub, trough; a wine-press, into which grapes were cast and trodden, Rev. 14:19, 20; 19:15; a wine-vat, i.q. ὑπολήνιον, the lower vat into which the juice of the trodden grapes flowed, Mt. 21:33*
λῆρος: idle talk; an empty tale, nonsense, Lk. 24:11*
λῃστής: a plunderer, robber, highwayman, Mt. 21:13; 26:55; Mk. 11:17; Lk. 10:30; 2 Cor. 11:26; a bandit, brigand, Mt. 27:38, 44; Mk. 15:27; Jn. 18:40; trop. a robber, rapacious imposter, Jn. 10:1, 8
λίβανος: arbor thurifera, the tree producing frankincense, growing in Arabia and Mount Lebanon; in NT frankincense, the transparent gum that distils from incisions in the tree, Mt. 2:11; Rev. 18:13*
λιβανωτός: frankincense; in NT a censer, Rev. 8:3, 5*
Λιβερτῖνος: a freedman, one who having been a slave has obtained his freedom, or whose father was a freed-man; in NT the λιβερτῖνοι probably denote Jews who had been carried captive to Rome, and subsequently manumitted, Acts 6:9*
Λιβύη: Libya, a part of Africa, bordering on the west of Egypt, Acts 2:10*
λιθάζω: to stone, pelt or kill with stones, Jn. 8:5; 10:31, 32, 33; 11:8; Acts 5:26; 14:19; 2 Cor. 11:25; Heb. 11:37*
λίθινος: made of stone, Jn. 2:6; 2 Cor. 3:3; Rev. 9:20*
λιθοβολέω: to stone, pelt with stones, in order to kill, Mt. 21:35; 23:37
λίθος: a stone, Mt. 3:9; 4:3, 6; used figuratively, of Christ, Eph. 2:20; 1 Pet. 2:6; of believers, 1 Pet. 2:5; meton. a tablet of stone, 2 Cor. 3:7; a precious stone, Rev. 4:3
λιθόστρωτος: a pavement made of blocks of stone, Jn. 19:13*
λικμάω: pr. to winnow grain; in NT to scatter like chaff, crush, Mt. 21:44; Lk. 20:18*
λιμήν: a port, haven, harbor, Καλὰ Λιμένες, Acts 27:8, 12*
λίμνη: a tract of standing water; a lake, Lk. 5:1; Rev. 20:14
λιμός: famine, scarcity of food, want of grain, Mt. 24:7; famine, hunger, famishment, Lk. 15:17; Rom. 8:35
λίνον: flax; by meton. a flaxen wick, Mt. 12:20; linen, Rev. 15:6*
Λίνος: some accent as Λῖνος, Linus, pr. name, 2 Tim. 4:21*
λιπαρός: lit., fat; fig., rich, sumptuous, Rev. 18:14*
λίτρα: a pound, libra, equivalent to about twelve ounces (American), Jn. 12:3; 19:39*
λίψ: pr. the south-west wind; meton. the south-west quarter of the heavens, Acts 27:12*
λογίζομαι: (1) pr. to count, calculate; to count, enumerate, Mk. 15:28; Lk. 22:37; to set down as a matter of account, 1 Cor. 13:5; 2 Cor. 3:5; 12:6; to impute, Rom. 4:3; 2 Cor. 5:19; 2 Tim. 4:16; to account, Rom. 2:26; 8:36; εἰς οὐδὲν λογισθῆναι, to be set at nought, despised, Acts 19:27; to regard, deem, consider, Rom. 6:11; 14:14; 1 Cor. 4:1; 2 Cor. 10:2; Phil. 3:13; (2) to infer, conclude, presume, Rom. 2:3; 3:28; 8:18; 2 Cor. 10:2, 7, 11; Heb. 11:19; 1 Pet. 5:12; (3) to think upon, ponder, Phil. 4:8; absol. to reason, Mk. 11:31; 1 Cor. 13:11
λογικός: pertaining to speech; pertaining to reason; in NT rational, spiritual, pertaining to the mind and soul, Rom. 12:1; 1 Pet. 2:2*
λόγιον: an oracle, a divine communication or revelation, Acts 7:38; Rom. 3:2; Heb. 5:12; 1 Pet. 4:11*
λόγιος: gifted with learning or eloquence, Acts 18:24*
λογισμός: pr. a computation, act of computing; a thought, cogitation, Rom. 2:15; a conception, device, 2 Cor. 10:4*
λογομαχέω: to contend about words; by impl. to dispute about trivial things, 2 Tim. 2:14*
λογομαχία: contention or strife about words; by impl. a dispute about trivial things, unprofitable controversy, 1 Tim. 6:4*
λόγος: a word, a thing uttered, Mt. 12:32, 37; 1 Cor. 14:19; speech, language, talk, Mt. 22:15; Lk. 20:20; 2 Cor. 10:10; Jas. 3:2; converse, Lk. 24:17; mere talk, wordy show, 1 Cor. 4:19, 20; Col. 2:23; 1 Jn. 3:18; language, mode of discourse, style of speaking, Mt. 5:37; 1 Cor. 1:17; 1 Thess. 2:5; a saying, a speech, Mk. 7:29; Eph. 4:29; an expression, form of words, formula, Mt. 26:44; Rom. 13:9; Gal. 5:14; a saying, a thing propounded in discourse, Mt. 7:24; 19:11; Jn. 4:37; 6:60; 1 Tim. 1:15; a message, announcement, 2 Cor. 5:19; a prophetic announcement, Jn. 12:38; an account, statement, 1 Pet. 3:15; a story, report, Mt. 28:15; Jn. 4:39; 21:23; 2 Thess. 2:2; a written narrative, a treatise, Acts 1:1; a set discourse, Acts 20:7; doctrine, Jn. 8:31, 37; 2 Tim. 2:17; subject-matter, Acts 15:6; reckoning, account, Mt. 12:36; 18:23; 25:19; Lk. 16:2; Acts 19:40; 20:24; Rom. 9:28; Phil. 4:15, 17; Heb. 4:13; a plea, Mt. 5:32; Acts 19:38; a motive, Acts 10:29; reason, Acts 18:14; ὁ λόγος, the word of God, especially in the Gospel, Mt. 13:21, 22; Mk. 16:20; Lk. 1:2; Acts 6:4; ὁ λόγος, the divine WORD, or Logos, Jn. 1:1
λόγχη: pr. the head of a javelin; a spear, lance, Jn. 19:34*
λοιδορέω: to revile, rail at, abuse, Jn. 9:28; Acts 23:4; 1 Cor. 4:12; 1 Pet. 2:23*
λοιδορία: reviling, railing, verbal abuse, 1 Tim. 5:14; 1 Pet. 3:9*
λοίδορος: reviling, railing; as a subst. a reviler, railer, 1 Cor. 5:11; 6:10*
λοιμός: a pestilence, plague, Lk. 21:11; met. a pest, pestilent fellow, Acts 24:5*
λοιπός: remaining; the rest, remainder, Mt. 22:6; as an adv., οῦ λοιποῦ, henceforth, Gal. 6:17; τὸ λοιπόν, or λοιπόν, henceforward, Mt. 26:45; 2 Tim. 4:8; Acts 27:20; as to the rest, besides, 1 Cor. 1:16; finally, Eph. 6:10; ὁ δὲ λοιπόν, but, now, furthermore, 1 Cor. 4:2
Λούκιος: Lucius, pr. name, (1) a person from Cyrene of Antioch, Acts 13:1. (2) a person who sends his greeting with Paul, Rom. 16:21*
λουτρόν: a bath, water for bathing; a bathing, washing, ablution, Eph. 5:26; Tit. 3:5*
λούω: pr. to bathe the body, as distinguished from washing only the extremities, Jn. 13:10; to bathe, wash, Acts 9:37; 16:33; Heb. 10:22; 2 Pet. 2:22*
Λύδδα: Lydda, a town in Palestine, Acts 9:32, 35, 38*. See PhotoGuide.
Λυδία: Lydia, pr. name of a woman, Acts 16:14, 40*
Λυκαονία: Lycaonia, a province of Asia Minor, Acts 14:6*
Λυκαονιστί: in the dialect of Lycaonia, Acts 14:11*
Λυκία: Lycia, a province of Asia Minor, Acts 27:5*
λύκος: a wolf, Mt. 10:16; Lk. 10:3; Jn. 10:12; met. a person of wolf-like character, Mt. 7:15; Acts 20:29*
λυμαίνω: some list as a deponent, λυμαίνομαι, to outrage, harm, violently maltreat; in NT to make havoc of, ruin, Acts 8:3*
λυπέω: to occasion grief or sorrow to, to distress, 2 Cor. 2:2, 5; 7:8; pass. to be grieved, pained, distressed, sorrowful, Mt. 17:23; 19:22; to aggrieve, cross, vex, Eph. 4:30; pass. to feel pained, Rom. 14:15
λύπη: pain, distress, Jn. 16:21; grief, sorrow, Jn. 16:6, 20, 22; meton. cause of grief, trouble, affliction, 1 Pet. 2:19
λύσις: a loosing; in NT a release from the marriage bond, a divorce, 1 Cor. 7:27*
λυσιτελέω: pr. to compensate for incurred expense; by impl. to be advantageous to, to profit, advantage; impers. Lk. 17:2*
Λύστρα: Lystra, a city of Lycaonia, in Asia Minor, Acts 14:6, 8, 21; 16:1f.; 2 Tim. 3:11*. See PhotoGuide.
λύτρον: pr. price paid; a ransom, Mt. 20:28; Mk. 10:45*
λυτρόω: to release for a ransom; mid, to ransom, redeem, deliver, liberate, Lk. 24:21; Tit. 2:14; 1 Pet. 1:18*
λυχνία: a candlestick, lampstand, Mt. 5:15; met. a candlestick, as a figure of a Christian church, Rev. 1:12, 13, 20; of a teacher or prophet, Rev. 11:4
λύχνος: a light, lamp, candle, etc., Mt. 5:15; Mk. 4:21; met. a lamp, as a figure of a distinguished teacher, Jn. 5:35
λύω: to loosen, unbind, unfasten, Mk. 1:7; to loose, untie, Mt. 21:2; Jn. 11:44; to disengage, 1 Cor. 7:27; to set free, set at liberty, deliver, Lk. 13:16; to break, Acts 27:41; Rev. 5:2, 5; to break up, dismiss, Acts 13:43; to destroy, demolish, Jn. 2:19; Eph. 2:14; met to infringe, Mt. 5:19; Jn. 5:18; 7:23; to make void, nullify, Jn. 10:35; in NT to declare free, of privileges, or, in respect of lawfulness, Mt. 16:19
Λωίς: Lois, pr. name of a woman, 2 Tim. 1:5*
Λώτ: Lot, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 17:28, 29, 32; 2 Pet. 2:7*
μαγεία: pr. the system of the magians; magic, Acts 8:11*
μαγεύω: to be a magician; to use magical arts, practise magic, sorcery, Acts 8:9*
μάγος: (1) a magus, sage of the magician religion, magician, astrologer, wise man, Mt. 2:1, 7, 16; (2) a magician, sorcerer, Acts 13:6, 8*
Μαδιάμ: Madian, a district of Arabia Petra, Acts 7:29*
μαθητεύω: intrans. to be a disciple, follow as a disciple, Mt. 27:57; in NT trans. to make a disciple of, to train in discipleship, Mt. 28:19; Acts 14:21; pass. to be trained, disciplined, instructed, Mt. 13:52*
μαθήτρια: a female disciple; a female Christian, Acts 9:36*
Μαθθάτ: also spelled Ματθάτ, Mathat, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 3:24, 29*
Μαθθίας: also spelled Ματθίας, BDAG 611, suggest it is a shortened form of Ματταθίας, Matthias, pr. name, Acts 1:23, 26*
μαίνομαι: to be disordered in mind, mad, Jn. 10:20; Acts 12:15; 26:24, 25; 1 Cor. 14:23*
μακαρίζω: to pronounce happy, fortunate, Lk. 1:48; Jas. 5:11*
μακάριος: happy, blessed, as a noun it can depict someone who receives divine favor, Mt. 5:3, 4, 5, 7; Lk. 1: 45
μακαρισμός: a happy calling, the act of pronouncing happy, Rom. 4:6, 9; self-congratulation, Gal. 4:15*
Μακεδονία: Macedonia, Acts 16:9; Rom. 15:26; 1 Cor. 16:5; 1 Thess. 1:7; 1 Tim. 1:3
Μακεδών: a native of Macedonia, Acts 16:9; 19:29; 27:2; 2 Cor. 9:2, 4*
μάκελλον: meat market, marketplace, slaughter house, 1 Cor. 10:25*
μακράν: far, far off, at a distance, far distant, Mt. 8:30; Mk. 12:34; met. οἱ μακράν, remote, alien, Eph. 2:13, 17; so οἱ εἰς μακράν, Acts 2:39
μακρόθεν: far off, at a distance, from afar, from a distance, Mk. 8:3; 11:13; preceded by ἀπό, in the same sense, Mt. 26:58
μακροθυμέω: to be slow towards, be long-enduring; to exercise patience, be long-suffering, clement, or indulgent, to forbear, Mt. 18:26, 29; 1 Cor. 13:4; 1 Thess. 5:14; 2 Pet. 3:9; to have patience, endure patiently, wait with patient expectation, Heb. 6:15; Jas. 5:7, 8; to bear long with entreaties for deliverance and avengement, Lk. 18:7*
μακροθυμία: patience; patient enduring of evil, fortitude, Col. 1:11; Col. 3:12; 1 Tim. 1:16; 1 Pet. 3:20; slowness of avenging injuries, long-suffering, forbearance, clemency, Rom. 2:4; 9:22; 2 Cor. 6:6; Gal. 5:22; Eph. 4:2; 2 Tim. 4:2; Jas. 5:10; patient expectation, 2 Tim. 3:10; Heb. 6:12; 2 Pet. 3:15*
μακρός: long; of space, far, distant, remote, Lk. 15:13; 19:12; of time, of long duration, Mk. 12:40; Lk. 20:47*
μαλακία: softness; listlessness, indisposition, weakness, infirmity of body, Mt. 4:23; 9:35; 10:1*
μαλακός: soft; soft to the touch, delicate, Mt. 11:8; Lk. 7:25; met. an instrument of unnatural lust, effeminate, 1 Cor. 6:9*
μάλιστα: most, most of all, chiefly, especially, Acts 20:38; 25:26
μᾶλλον: more, to a greater extent, in a higher degree, Mt. 18:13; 27:24; Jn. 5:18; 1 Cor. 14:18; rather, in preference, Mt. 10:6; Eph. 4:28; used in a periphrasis for the comparative, Acts 20:35; as an intensive with a comparative term, Mt. 6:26; Mk. 7:36; 2 Cor. 7:13; Phil. 1:23; μᾶλλον δέ, yea rather, or, more properly speaking, Rom. 8:34; Gal. 4:9; Eph. 5:11
μάμμη: a mother; later, a grandmother, 2 Tim. 1:5*
μαμωνᾶς: wealth, riches, Lk. 16:9, 11; personified, like the Greek Πλοῦτος, Mammon, Mt. 6:24; Lk. 16:13*
Μανασσῆς: Manasses, pr. name (1) the tribe of Manasseh, Rev. 7:6 (2) Manasseh, king of Judah, Mt. 1:10*
μανθάνω: to learn, be taught, Mt. 9:13; 11:29; 24:32; to learn by practice or experience, acquire a custom or habit, Phil. 4:11; 1 Tim. 5:4, 13; to ascertain, be informed, Acts 23:27; to understand, comprehend, Rev. 14:3
μάννα: manna, the miraculous food of the Israelites while in the desert, Jn. 6:31, 49; Heb. 9:4; Rev. 2:17*
μαντεύομαι: to speak oracles, to divine, Acts 16:16*
μαραίνω: to quench, cause to decay, fade, or wither; pass. to wither, waste away, met. to fade away, disappear, perish, Jas. 1:11*
Μαρία: Mary, pr. name (1) The mother of Jesus, Mt. 1:16; Acts 1:14. (2) Mary, wife of Clopas, mother of James, Mk. 15:40; Lk. 24:10; Jn. 19:25. (3) Mary Magdalene, Mt. 27:56; Lk. 20:18. (4) Sister of Martha and Lazarus, Lk. 10:39; Jn. 11:1; 12:3. (5) Mother of Jn. surnamed Mark, Acts 12:12 (6) A Christian at Rome, Rom. 16:6
μάρμαρος: a white glistening stone; marble, Rev. 18:12*
μαρτυρέω: trans. to testify, depose, Jn. 3:11, 32; 1 Jn. 1:2; Rev. 1:2; 22:20; absol. to give evidence, Jn. 18:23; to bear testimony, testify, Lk. 4:22; Jn. 1:7, 8; to bear testimony in confirmation, Acts 14:3; to declare distinctly and formally, Jn. 4:44; pass. to be the subject of testimony, to obtain attestation to character, Acts 6:3; 10:22; 1 Tim. 5:10; Heb. 11:2, 4; mid. equivalent to μαρτύρομαι, to make a solemn appeal, Acts 26:22; 1 Thess. 2:12
μαρτυρία: judicial evidence, Mk. 14:55, 56, 59; Lk. 22:71; testimony in general, Tit. 1:13; 1 Jn. 5:9 testimony, declaration in a matter of fact or doctrine, Jn. 1:19; 3:11; Acts 22:18; attestation to character, Jn. 5:34, 36; reputation, 1 Tim. 3:7
μαρτύριον: testimony, evidence, Acts 4:33; 2 Cor. 1:12; Jas. 5:3; in NT testimony, mode of solemn declaration, Mt. 8:4; Lk. 9:5; testimony, matter of solemn declaration, 1 Cor. 1:6; 2:1; 1 Tim. 2:6; σκηνὴ τοῦ μαρτυρίου, a title of the Mosaic tabernacle, Acts 7:44; Rev. 15:5
μαρτύρομαι: to call to witness; intrans. to make a solemn affirmation or declaration, Acts 20:26; 26:22; Gal. 5:3; to make a solemn appeal, Eph. 4:17; 1 Thess. 2:12*
μάρτυς: (1) a judicial witness, deponent, Mt. 18:16; Heb. 10:28; (2) generally, a witness to a circumstance, Lk. 24:48; Acts 10:41; in NT a witness, a testifier, of a doctrine, Rev. 1:5; 3:14; 11:3; (3) a martyr, Acts 22:20; Rev. 2:13
μασάομαι: to chew, masticate, in NT to gnaw, Rev. 16:10*
μαστιγόω: to scourge, whip, Mt. 10:17; 20:19; 23:34; Mk. 10:34; Lk. 18:33; Jn. 19:1; met. to chastise, Heb. 12:6*
μάστιξ: a scourge, whip, Acts 22:24; Heb. 11:36; met. a scourge of disease, Mk. 3:10; 5:29, 34; Lk. 7:21*
ματαιολόγος: a vain talker, given to vain talking or trivial disputation, Tit. 1:10*
μάταιος: idle, ineffective, worthless, 1 Cor. 3:20; groundless, deceptive, fallacious, 1 Cor. 15:17; useless, fruitless, unprofitable, Tit. 3:9; Jas. 1:26; from the Hebrew, erroneous in principle, corrupt, perverted, 1 Pet. 1:18; τὰ μάταια, superstition, idolatry, Acts 14:15*
ματαιότης: vanity, folly, futility, from the Hebrew, religious error, Eph. 4:17; 2 Pet. 2:18; false religion, Rom. 8:20*
ματαιόω: to make vain; from the Hebrew, pass. to fall into religious error, to be perverted, Rom. 1:21*
μάτην: in vain, fruitlessly, without profit, Mt. 15:9; Mk. 7:7*
Ματταθίας: see also Μαθθίας, Mattathias, pr. name, Lk. 3:25, 26*
μάχαιρα: a large knife, dagger; a sword, Mt. 26:47, 51; the sword of the executioner, Acts 12:2; Rom. 8:35; Heb. 11:37; hence, φορεῖν μάχαιραν, to bear the sword, to have the power of life and death, Rom. 13:4; meton. war, Mt. 10:34
μάχη: a fight, battle, conflict; in NT contention, dispute, strife, controversy, 2 Cor. 7:5; 2 Tim. 2:23; Tit. 3:9; Jas. 4:1*
μάχομαι: to fight; to quarrel, Acts 7:26; 2 Tim. 2:24; to contend, dispute, Jn. 6:52; Jas. 4:2*
μεγαλεῖος: magnificent, splendid; τὰ μεγαλεῖα, great things, wonderful works, Acts 2:11*
μεγαλειότης: majesty, magnificence, glory, Lk. 9:43; Acts 19:27; 2 Pet. 1:16*
μεγαλοπρεπής: pr. becoming a great man; magnificent, glorious, most splendid, 2 Pet. 1:17*
μεγαλύνω: lit., to enlarge, amplify, Mt. 23:5; 2 Cor. 10:15; to manifest in an extraordinary degree, Lk. 1:58; fig., to magnify, exalt, extol, Lk. 1:46; Acts 5:13; Acts 10:46; 19:17; Phil. 1:20*
μεγαλωσύνη: greatness, majesty, Heb. 1:3; 8:1; ascribed majesty, Jude 25*
μέγας: great, large in size, Mt. 27:60; Mk. 4:32; great, much, numerous, Mk. 5:11; Heb. 11:26; great, grown up, adult, Heb. 11:24; great, vehement, intense, Mt. 2:10; 28:8; great, sumptuous, Lk. 5:29; great, important, weighty, of high importance, 1 Cor. 9:11; 13:13; great, splendid, magnificent, Rev. 15:3; extraordinary, wonderful, 2 Cor. 11:15; great, solemn, Jn. 7:37; 19:31; great in rank, noble, Rev. 11:18; 13:16; great in dignity, distinguished, eminent, illustrious, powerful, Mt. 5:19; 18:1, 4; great, arrogant, boastful, Rev. 13:5
μεγιστάν: great men, lords, chiefs, nobles, princes, Mk. 6:21; Rev. 6:15; 18:23*
μεθερμηνεύω: to translate, interpret, Mt. 1:23; Mk. 5:41; 15:22, 34; Jn. 1:38, 41; Acts 4:36; 13:8*
μέθη: strong drink; drunkenness, Lk. 21:34; an indulgence in drinking, Rom. 13:13; Gal. 5:21*
μεθίστημι: to cause a change of position; to remove, transport, 1 Cor. 13:2; to transfer, Col. 1:13; met. to cause to change sides; by impl. to pervert, mislead, Acts 19:26; to remove from office, dismiss, discard, Lk. 16:4; Acts 13:22*
μεθύσκω: to inebriate, make drunk; pass. to be intoxicated, to be drunk, Lk. 12:45; Eph. 5:18; 1 Thess. 5:7; Rev. 17:2; to drink freely, Jn. 2:10*
μεθύω: to be intoxicated, be drunk, Mt. 24:49; Acts 2:15; 1 Cor. 11:21; 1 Thess. 5:7; Rev. 17:6*
μέλας: black, Mt. 5:36; Rev. 6:5, 12, the form μέλαν means ink, 2 Cor. 3:3; 2 Jn. 12; 3 Jn. 13
μέλει: there is a care, it concerns, Mt. 22:16; Acts 18:17; 1 Cor. 7:21; 9:9
μελετάω: to care for; to bestow careful thought upon, to give painful attention to, be earnest in, 1 Tim. 4:15; to devise, Acts 4:25*
Μελίτη: also spelled Μελιτήνη, Malta, an island in the Mediterranean, Acts 28:1*
μέλλω: to be about to, be on the point of, Mt. 2:13; Jn. 4:47; it serves to express in general a settled futurity, Mt. 11:14; Lk. 9:31; Jn. 11:51; to intend, Lk. 10:1; participle μέλλων, μέλλουσα, μέλλον, future as distinguished from past and present, Mt. 12:32; Lk. 13:9; to be always, as it were, about to do, to delay, linger, Acts 22:16
μέλος: a member, limb, any part of the body, Mt. 5:29, 30; Rom. 12:4; 1 Cor. 6:15; 12:12
μέμφομαι: to find fault with, blame, censure; to intimate dissatisfaction with, Heb. 8:8; absol. to find fault, Rom. 9:19*
μεμψίμοιρος: finding fault or being discontented with one’s lot, querulous; a discontented, querulous person, a complainer, Jude 16*
μέν: a particle serving to indicate that the term or clause with which it is used stands distinguished from another, usually in the sequel, and then mostly with δέ correspondent, Mt. 3:11; 9:39; Acts 1:1; ὁ μὲν ... ὁ δέ, this ... that, the one ... the other, Phil. 1:16, 17; one ... another, οἱ μὲν ... οἱ δέ, some ... others, Matt 22:5; ὅλλος μὲν ... ὅλλος δέ, one ... another, pl. some ... others, Matt 13:8; 21:35; ὅλλος μὲν ... ὅλλος δέ, one ... another, 1 Cor. 15:39; ὡδε μὲν ... ἐκεῖ δέ, here ... there, Heb. 7:8; τοῦτο μὲν ... τοῦτο δέ, partly ... partly, Heb. 10:33
μενοῦνγε: also spelled as two words, μενοῦν γε (Lk. 11:28), a combination of particles serving to take up what has just preceded, with either emphasize or to correct; indeed, really, truly, rather, Rom. 9:20; 10:18; Phil. 3:8*
μένω: pluperfect, μεμενήκειν, to stay, Mt. 26:38; Acts 27:31; to continue; 1 Cor. 7:11; 2 Tim. 2:13; to dwell, lodge, sojourn, Jn. 1:39; Acts 9:43; to remain, Jn. 9:41; to rest, settle, Jn. 1:32, 33; 3:36; to last, endure, Mt. 11:23; Jn. 6:27; 1 Cor. 3:14; to survive, 1 Cor. 15:6; to be existent, 1 Cor. 13:13; to continue unchanged, Rom. 9:11; to be permanent, Jn. 15:16; 2 Cor. 3:11; Heb. 10:34; 13:14; 1 Pet. 1:23; to persevere, be constant, be steadfast, 1 Tim. 2:15; 2 Tim. 3:14; to abide, to be in close and settled union, Jn. 6:56; 14:10; 15:4; to indwell, Jn. 5:38; 1 Jn. 2:14; trans. to wait for, Acts 20:5, 23 See abide; await; remain; stay; wait for.
μερίζω: to divide; to divide out, distribute, Mk. 6:41; to assign, bestow, Rom. 12:3; 1 Cor. 7:17; 2 Cor. 10:13; Heb. 7:2; mid. to share, Lk. 12:13; pass. to be subdivided, to admit distinctions, Mk. 3:24-26; 1 Cor. 1:13; to be severed by discord, be at variance, Mt. 12:25, 26; to differ, 1 Cor. 7:34*
μέριμνα: care, Mt. 13:22; Mk. 4:19; Lk. 8:14; 21:34; anxiety, anxious interest, 2 Cor. 11:28; 1 Pet. 5:7*
μεριμνάω: to be anxious, or solicitous, Phil. 4:6; to expend careful thought, Mt. 6:27, 28, 31, 34a; 10:19; Lk. 10:41; 12:11, 22, 25, 26; to concern one’s self, Mt. 6:25; 1 Cor. 12:25; to have the thoughts occupied with, 1 Cor. 7:32, 33, 34; to feel an interest in, Phil. 2:20*
μερίς: a part; a division of a country, district, region, tract, Acts 16:12; a portion, Lk. 10:42; an allotted portion, Col. 1:12; a portion in common, share, Acts 8:21; 2 Cor. 6:15*
μερισμός: a dividing, act of dividing, Heb. 4:12; distribution, gifts distributed, Heb. 2:4*
μέρος: a part, portion, division, of a whole, Lk. 11:36; 15:12; Acts 5:2; Eph. 4:16; a piece, fragment, Lk. 24:42; Jn. 19:23; a party, faction, Acts 23:9; allotted portion, lot, destiny, Mt. 24:51; Lk. 12:46; a calling, craft, Acts 19:27; a partner’s portion, partnership, fellowship, Jn. 13:8; pl. μέρη, a local quarter, district, region, Mt. 2:22; 16:13; Acts 19:1; Eph. 4:9; side of a ship, Jn. 21:6; ἐν μέρει, in respect, 2 Cor. 3:10; 9:3; Col. 2:16; 1 Pet. 4:16; μέρος τι, partly, in some part, 1 Cor. 11:18; ἀνὰ μέρος, alternately, one after another, 1 Cor. 14:27; ἀπὸ μέρους, partly, in some part or measure, 2 Cor. 1:14; ἐκ μέρους, individually, 1 Cor. 12:27; partly, imperfectly, 1 Cor. 13:9; κατὰ μέρος, particularly, in detail, Heb. 9:5
μεσημβρία: mid-day, noon, Acts 22:6; meton. the south, Acts 8:26*
μεσιτεύω: to perform offices between two parties; to intervene, interpose, Heb. 6:17*
μεσίτης: one that acts between two parties; a mediator, one who interposes to reconcile two adverse parties, 1 Tim. 2:5; an arbitrator, one who is the medium of communication between two parties, a mid-party, Gal. 3:19, 20; Heb. 8:6; 9:15; 12:24*
Μεσοποταμία: Mesopotamia, the country lying between the rivers Tigris and Euphrates, Acts 2:9; 7:2*
μέσος: mid, middle, Mt. 25:6; Acts 26:13; ἀνὰ μέσον, in the midst; from the Hebrew, in, among, Mt. 13:25; between, 1 Cor. 6:5; διὰ μέσου, through the midst of, Lk. 4:30; εἰς τὸ μέσον, into, or in the midst, Mk. 3:3; Lk. 6:8; ἐκ μέσου, from the midst, out of the way, Col. 2:14; 2 Thess. 2:7; from the Hebrew, from, from among, Mt. 13:49; ἐν τῷ μέσῳ, in the midst, Mt. 10:16; in the midst, in public, publicly, Mt. 14:6 ἐν μέσῳ, in the midst of; among, Mt. 18:20; κατὰ μέσον τῆς νυκτός, about midnight, Acts 27:27
μεσότοιχον: a middle wall; a partition wall, a barrier, Eph. 2:14*
μεσόω: to be in the middle or midst; to be advanced midway, Jn. 7:14*
Μεσσίας: the Messiah, the Anointed One, i.q. ὁ Χριστός, Jn. 1:42, 4:25*
μεστός: full, full of, filled with, Jn. 19:29; 21:11; replete, Mt. 23:28; Rom. 1:29; 15:14; Jas. 3:8, 17; 2 Pet. 2:14*
μεστόω: to fill; pass. to be filled, be full, Acts 2:13*
μετά: (1) gen., with, together with, Mt. 16:27; 12:41; 26:55; with, on the same side or party with, in aid of, Mt. 12:30; 20:20; with, by means of, Acts 13:17; with, of conflict, Rev. 11:7; with, among, Lk. 24:5; with, to, towards, Lk. 1:58, 72; (2) acc., after, of place, behind, Heb. 9:3; of time, after, Mt. 17:1; 24:29; followed by an infin. with the neut. article, after, after that, Mt. 26:32; Lk. 22:20
μεταβαίνω: to go or pass from one place to another, Jn. 5:24; to pass away, be removed, Mt. 17:20; to go away, depart, Mt. 8:34
μεταβάλλω: to change; mid. to change one’s mind, Acts 28:6*
μετάγω: to lead or move from one place to another; to change direction, turn about, Jas. 3:3, 4*
μεταδίδωμι: to give a part, to share, Lk. 3:11; to impart, bestow, Rom. 1:11; 12:8; Eph. 4:28; 1 Thess. 2:8*
μετάθεσις: a removal, translation, Heb. 11:5; 12:27; a transmutation, change by the abolition of one thing, and the substitution of another, Heb. 7:12*
μεταίρω: to remove, transfer; in NT intrans. to go away, depart, Mt. 13:53; 19:1*
μετακαλέω: to call from one place into another; mid. to call or send for, invite to come to oneself, Acts 7:14; 10:32; 20:17; 24:25*
μετακινέω: to move away, remove; pass. met. to stir away from, to swerve, Col. 1:23*
