μεταλαμβάνω: to partake of, share in, Acts 2:46; 27:33f.; 2 Tim. 2:6; Heb. 6:7; 12:10; to get, obtain, find, Acts 24:25*
μετάλημψις: a partaking of, a being partaken of, 1 Tim. 4:3*
μεταλλάσσω: to exchange, change for or into, transmute, Rom. 1:25, 26*
μεταμέλομαι: to change one’s judgment on past points of conduct; to change one’s mind and purpose, Heb. 7:21; to repent, regret, Mt. 21:29, 32; 27:3; 2 Cor. 7:8*
μεταμορφόω: to change the external form, transfigure; mid. to change one’s form, be transfigured, Mt. 17:2; Mk. 9:2; to undergo a spiritual transformation Rom. 12:2; 2 Cor. 3:18*
μετανοέω: to undergo a change in frame of mind and feeling, to repent, Lk. 17:3, 4; to make a change of principle and practice, to reform, Mt. 3:2
μετάνοια: a change of mode of thought and feeling, repentance, Mt. 3:8; Acts 20:21; 2 Tim. 2:25; practical reformation, Lk. 15:7; reversal of the past, Heb. 12:17
μεταξύ: can function as an improper prep., between, Mt. 23:35; Lk. 11:51; 16:26; Acts 15:9; ἐν τῷ μεταξύ, i.e. χρόνῷ, in the meantime, meanwhile, Jn. 4:31; in NT ὁ μεταξύ, following, succeeding, Acts 13:42
μεταπέμπω: to send after; mid. to send after or for any one, invite to come to one’s self, Acts 10:5, 22, 29; 11:13; 20:1; 24:24, 26; 25:3*
μεταστρέφω: to turn about; convert into something else, change, Acts 2:20; by impl. to pervert, Gal. 1:7*
μετασχηματίζω: to remodel, transfigure, Phil. 3:21; mid. to transform one’s self, 2 Cor. 11:13, 14, 15; to transfer an imagination, 1 Cor. 4:6*
μετατίθημι: to transport, Acts 7:16; to transfer, Heb. 7:12; to translate out of the world, Heb. 11:5; met. to transfer to other purposes, to pervert, Jude 4; mid. to transfer one’s self, to change over, Gal. 1:6*
μετατρέπω: to turn around, change, alter, Jas. 4:9*
μετέχω: to share in, partake, 1 Cor. 9:10, 12; 10:17, 21; 1 Cor. 10:30; Heb. 2:14; 5:13; to be a member of, Heb. 7:13*
μετεωρίζομαι: to raise aloft; met. to unsettle in mind; pass. to be excited with anxiety, be in anxious suspense, Lk. 12:29*
μετοικεσία: change of abode or country, migration, Mt. 1:11, 12, 17*
μετοικίζω: to cause to change abode, cause to emigrate, Acts 7:4, 43*
μετοχή: a sharing, partaking; communion, fellowship, 2 Cor. 6:14*
μέτοχος: a partaker, Heb. 3:1, 14; 6:4; 12:8; an associate, partner, fellow, Lk. 5:7; Heb. 1:9*
μετρέω: to allot, measure, Mt. 7:2; Mk. 4:24; Lk. 6:38; Rev. 11:1, 2; 21:15-17; met. to estimate, 2 Cor. 10:12*
μετρητής: pr. a measurer; also, metretes, Latin metreta, equivalent to the Attic ἀμφορεύς, i.e., three-fourths of the Attic μέδιμνος, and therefore equal to about nine gallons, Jn. 2:6*
μετριοπαθέω: to moderate one’s passions; to be gentle, compassionate, Heb. 5:2*
μετρίως: moderately; slightly; οὐ μετρίως no little, not a little, much, greatly, Acts 20:12*
μέτρον: measure, Mt. 7:2; Mk. 4:24; Lk. 6:38; Rev. 21:17; measure, standard, Eph. 4:13; extent, compass, 2 Cor. 10:13; allotted measure, specific portion, Rom. 12:3; Eph. 4:7, 16; ἐκ μέτρον, by measure, with definite limitation, Jn. 3:34
μέχρι: improper prep. and a conj (until), can also spelled μέχρις, unto, even to, Rom. 15:19; of time, until, till, Mt. 11:23; Mk. 13:30
μή: a negative particle, can function as a conj, not, for the particulars of its usage, especially as distinguished from that of οὐ, consult a grammar; as a conj., lest, that not, Mt. 5:29, 30; 18:10; 24:6; Mk. 13:36; μή, or μήτι, or μήποτε, when prefixed to an interrogative clause, it expresses an intimation either of the reality of the matters respecting which the question is asked, Mt. 12:23; or the contrary, Jn. 4:12
μηδέ: negative disjunctive particle, can function as an adverb and a conj, neither, and repeated, neither-nor, Mt. 6:25; 7:6; 10:9, 10; not even, not so much as, Mk. 2:2
μηδείς: not one, none, no one, Mt. 8:4
μηδέποτε: not at any time, never, 2 Tim. 3:7*
μηδέπω: not yet, not as yet, Heb. 11:7*
Μῆδος: a Mede, a native of Media in Asia, Acts 2:9*
μηκύνω: to lengthen, prolong; mid. to grow up, as plants, Mk. 4:27*
μήν: a month, Lk. 1:24, 26, 36, 56; in NT the new moon, the day of the new moon, Gal. 4:10
μηνύω: to disclose what is secret, Jn. 11:57; Acts 23:30; 1 Cor. 10:28; to declare, indicate, Lk. 20:37*
μήποτε: can function as an adverb, BDAG 648, lists it as a negative part., conj., and interrogative part., same signif. and usage as μή, Mt. 4:6; 13:15; Heb. 9:17; also, whether, Lk. 3:15
μήπω: not yet, not as yet, Rom. 9:11; Heb. 9:8*
μήτε: neither; μήτε ... μήτε, or μὴ ... μήτε, or μηδὲ ... μητέ, neither ... nor, Mt. 5:34, 35, 36; Acts 23:8; 2 Thess. 2:2; in NT also equivalent to μηδέ, not even, not so much as, Mk. 3:20
μήτηρ: a mother, Mt. 1:18; 12:49, 50, et al. freq.; a parent city, Gal. 4:26; Rev. 17:5
μήτι: interrogative particle, used in questions expecting a negative answer; has the same use as μή in the form εἰ μήτε, Lk. 9:3; also when prefixed to an interrogative clause, Mt. 7:16; Jn. 4:29
μητρολῴας: one who murders or  strikes his mother, matricide, 1 Tim. 1:9*
μιαίνω: pr. to tinge, dye, stain; to pollute, defile, ceremonially, Jn. 18:28; to corrupt, deprave, Tit. 1:15 (2x); Heb. 12:15; Jude 8*
μίγνυμι: also spelled μείγνυμι, to mix, mingle, Mt. 27:34; Lk. 13:1; Rev. 8:7
μικρός: little, small in size quantity, etc. Mt. 13:32; Lk. 12:32; Rev. 3:8; small, little in age, young, not adult, Mk. 15:40; little, short in time, Jn. 7:33; μικρόν, i.e. χρόνον, a little while, a short time, Jn. 13:33; μετὰ μικρόν, after a little while, a little while afterwards, Mt. 26:73; little in number, Lk. 12:32; small, little in dignity, low, humble, Mt. 10:42; 11:11; μικρόν, as an adv., little, a little, Mt. 26:39
Μίλητος: Miletus, a seaport city of Caria, on the west coast of Asia Minor, Acts 20:15, 17; 2 Tim. 4:20*
μίλιον: a Roman mile, which contained mille passuum, 1000 paces, or 8 stadia, 4,854 feet, Mt. 5:41*
μιμέομαι: to imitate, follow as an example, strive to resemble, 2 Thess. 3:7, 9; Heb. 13:7; 3 Jn. 11*
μιμητής: an imitator, follower, 1 Cor. 4:16; 11:1; Eph. 5:1; 1 Thess. 1:6; 2:14; Heb. 6:12*
μιμνῄσκομαι: to remember, recollect, call to mind, Mt. 26:75; Lk. 1:54, 72; 16:25; in NT, in a passive sense, to be called to mind, be borne in mind, Acts 10:31; Rev. 16:19
μισέω: to hate, regard with ill-will, Mt. 5:43, 44; 10:22; to detest, abhor, Jn. 3:20; Rom. 7:15; in NT to regard with less affection, love less, esteem less, Mt. 6:24; Lk. 14:26
μισθαποδοσία: pr. the discharge of wages; requital; reward, Heb. 10:35; 11:26; punishment, Heb. 2:2*
μισθαποδότης: a bestower of remuneration; recompenser, rewarder, Heb. 11:6*
μίσθιος: hired; as a subst., a hired servant, hireling, Lk. 15:17, 19*
μισθός: hire, wages, Mt. 20:8; Jas. 5:4; reward, Mt. 5:12, 46; 6:1, 2, 5, 16; punishment, 2 Pet. 2:13
μισθόω: to hire out, let out to hire; mid. to hire, Mt. 20:1, 7*
μίσθωμα: hire, rent; in NT a hired dwelling, Acts 28:30*
Μιτυλήνη: Mitylene, the capital city of Lesbos, in the Aegean sea, Acts 20:14*
Μιχαήλ: Michael, the archangel, indecl., Jude 9; Rev. 12:7*
μνᾶ: Latin mina; a weight, equivalent to 100 drachmas; also a sum, equivalent to 100 drachmas and the sixtieth part of a talent, Lk. 19:13, 16, 18, 20, 24f.*
μνεία: remembrance, recollection, Phil. 1:3; 1 Thess. 3:6; 2 Tim. 1:3; mention; μνείαν ποιεῖσθαι, to make mention, Rom. 1:9; Eph. 1:16; 1 Thess. 1:2; Phlm. 4*
μνῆμα: pr. a memorial, monument; a tomb, sepulchre, Mk. 5:3, 5; Lk. 8:27; 23:53; 24:1; Acts 2:29; 7:16; Rev. 11:9*
μνημεῖον: monument, memorial, Lk. 11:47; grave, tomb, Mt. 23:39; Mk. 5:2; Lk. 11:44; Jn. 11:17, 31, 38; Acts 13:29
μνήμη: remembrance, recollection, memory; μνήμην ποιεῖσθαι, to make mention, 2 Pet. 1:15*
μνημονεύω: to remember, recollect, call to mind, Mt. 16:9; Lk. 17:32; Acts 20:31; to be mindful of, to fix the thoughts upon, Heb. 11:15; to make mention, mention, speak of, Heb. 11:22
μνημόσυνον: a record, memorial, Acts 10:4; honorable remembrance, Mt. 26:13; Mk. 14:9*
μνηστεύω: to ask in marriage; to betroth; pass. to be betrothed, engaged, Mt. 1:18; Lk. 1:27; 2:5*
μογιλάλος: having an impediment in one’s speech, speaking with difficulty, a stammerer, Mk. 7:32*
μόδιος: a modius, a Roman measure for things dry, containing 16 sextarii, and equivalent to about a peck (8.75 liters); in NT a corn measure, Mt. 5:15; Mk. 4:21; Lk. 11:33*
μοιχαλίς: an adulteress, Rom. 7:3; Jas. 4:4; by meton., an adulterous appearance, lustful significance, 2 Pet. 2:14; from the Hebrew, spiritually adulterous, faithless, ungodly, Mt. 12:39; 16:4; Mk. 8:38*
μοιχάω: act., to cause to commit adultery, pass., to commit or be guilty of adultery, Mt. 5:32; 19:9; Mk. 10:11f.*
μοιχεύω: trans. to commit adultery with, debauch, Mt. 5:28; absol. and mid. to commit adultery, Mt. 5:27; Jn. 8:4; to commit spiritual adultery, be guilty of idolatry, Rev. 2:22
μόλις: with difficulty, scarcely, hardly, Acts 14:18; 27:7, 8, 16; Rom. 5:7; 1 Pet. 4:18*
μολύνω: pr. to stain, sully; to defile, contaminate morally, 1 Cor. 8:7; Rev. 14:4; to soil, Rev. 3:4*
μομφή: a complaint, cause or ground of complaint, Col. 3:13*
μονή: a stay in any place; an abode, dwelling, mansion, Jn. 14:2, 23*
μονογενής: only-begotten, only-born, Lk. 7:12; 8:42; 9:38; Heb. 11:17; only-begotten in respect of peculiar generation, unique, Jn. 1:14, 18; 3:16, 18; 1 Jn. 4:9*
μόνον: the accusative singular form of monos (G3668) used as an adverb meaning only, alone
μόνος: without accompaniment, alone, Mt. 14:23; 18:15; Lk. 10:40; singly existent, sole, only, Jn. 17:3; lone solitary, Jn. 8:29; 16:32; alone in respect of restriction, only, Mt. 4:4; 12:4; alone in respect of circumstances, only, Lk. 24:18; not multiplied by reproduction, lone, barren, Jn. 12:24
μονόφθαλμος: one-eyed; deprived of an eye, Mt. 18:9; Mk. 9:47*
μονόω: to leave alone; pass. to be left alone, be lone, 1 Tim. 5:5*
μορφόω: to give shape to, mold, fashion, Gal. 4:19*
μόρφωσις: pr. a shaping, moulding; in NT external form, appearance, 2 Tim. 3:5; a settled form. prescribed system, Rom. 2:20*
μοσχοποιέω: to form an image of a calf, Acts 7:41*
μόσχος: pr. a tender branch, shoot; a young animal; a calf, young bull, Lk. 15:23, 27, 30; Heb. 12:19; Rev. 4:7*
μουσικός: pr. devoted to the arts of the Muses; a musician; in NT, perhaps, a singer, Rev. 18:22*
μόχθος: wearisome labor, toil, travail, 2 Cor. 11:27; 1 Thess. 2:9; 2 Thess. 3:8*
μυέω: to initiate, instruct in the sacred mysteries; in NT pass. to be disciplined in a practical lesson, to learn a lesson, Phil. 4:12*
μῦθος: a word, speech, a tale; a fable, figment, 1 Tim. 1:4; 4:7; 2 Tim. 4:4; Tit. 1:14; 2 Pet. 1:16*
μυκάομαι: to low, bellow, as a bull; also, to roar, as a lion, Rev. 10:3*
μυκτηρίζω: to contract the nose in contempt and derision, toss up the nose; to mock, deride, Gal. 6:7*
μυλικός: of a mill, belonging to a mill, Lk. 17:2*
Μύρα: neuter plural, Myra, a city of Lycia, Acts 27:5*
μυριάς: a myriad, ten thousand, Acts 19:19; indefinitely, a vast multitude, Lk. 12:1; Acts 21:20; Heb. 12:22; Jude 14; Rev. 5:11; 9:16*
μύριοι: indefinitely, a great number; specifically, μύριοι, a myriad, ten thousand, Mt. 18:24*
μύρον: pr. aromatic juice which distills from trees; ointment, unguent, usually perfumed, Mt. 26:7, 12; Mk. 14:3, 4
Μυσία: Mysia, a province of Asia Minor, Acts 16:7f.*
μυστήριον: a matter to the knowledge of which initiation is necessary; a secret which would remain such but for revelation, Mt. 3:11; Rom. 11:25; Col. 1:26; a concealed power or principle, 2 Thess. 2:7; a hidden meaning of a symbol, Rev. 1:20; 17:7
μυωπάζω: pr. to close the eyes, contract the eyelids, wink; to be nearsighted, partially blinded, slow to understand, 2 Pet. 1:9*
μώλωψ: the mark of a blow; a stripe, a wound, 1 Pet. 2:24*
μωμάομαι: to find fault with, censure, blame, 2 Cor. 8:20; passively, 2 Cor. 6:3*
μῶμος: blame, ridicule; a disgrace to society, a stain, 2 Pet. 2:13*
μωραίνω: to be foolish, to play the fool; in NT trans. to make foolish, convict of folly, 1 Cor. 1:20; pass. to be convicted of folly, to incur the character of folly, Rom. 1:22; to be rendered insipid, Mt. 5:13; Lk. 14:34*
μωρός: pr. dull; foolish, Mt. 7:26; 23:17; 25:2f., 8; 1 Cor. 1:25, 27; 3:18; 4:10; 2 Tim. 2:23; Tit. 3:9; from the Hebrew, a fool in senseless wickedness, Mt. 5:22*
Μωϋσῆς: also spelled Μωσῆς, Moses, pr. name, Mt. 8:4; Jn. 1:17; Rom. 5:14
Ναασσών: Naasson, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:4; Lk. 3:32*
Ναγγαί: Naggai, Nagge, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 3:25*
Ναζαρά: see Ναζαρέθ, Mt. 4:13; Lk. 4:16*. See PhotoGuide.
Ναζαρέθ: an indecl. form, Nazareth, is spelled Ναζαρέτ (4x) and Ναζαρά (2x). See PhotoGuide.
Ναζαρέτ: see Ναζαρέθ, Mt. 2:23; Mk. 1:9; Jn. 1:45, 46*. See PhotoGuide.
Ναζαρηνός: an inhabitant of Nazareth, Mk. 1:24; 10:47; 4:67; 16:6; Lk. 4:34; 24:19*
Ναζωραῖος: also spelled Ναζαρηνός, a Nazarite; an inhabitant of Nazareth, Mt. 2:23; 26:71; Lk. 18:37; Jn. 18:5, 7; 19:19; Acts 2:22; 3:6; 4:10; 6:14; 22:8; 24:5; 26:9*
Ναθάμ: also spelled Ναθάν, Nathan, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 3:31*
ναί: a particle, used to strengthen an affirmation, certainly, Rev. 22:20; to make an affirmation, or express an assent, yea, yes, Mt. 5:37; Acts 5:8
Ναιμάν: also spelled Νεεμάν, Naaman, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 4:27*
Ναίν: Nain, a town of Palestine, indecl., Lk. 7:11*. See PhotoGuide.
ναός: pr. a dwelling; the dwelling of a deity, a temple, Mt. 26:61; Acts 7:48; used figuratively of individuals, Jn. 2:19; 1 Cor. 3:16; spc. the cell of a temple; hence, the Holy Place of the Temple of Jerusalem, Mt. 23:35; Lk. 1:9; a model of a temple, a shrine, Acts 19:24
νάρδος: spikenard, a species of aromatic plant with grassy leaves and a fibrous root, of which the best and strongest grows in India; in NT oil of spikenard, an oil extracted from the plant, which was highly prized and used as an ointment either pure or mixed with other substances, Mk. 14:3; Jn. 12:3*
ναυαγέω: to make shipwreck, be shipwrecked, 2 Cor. 11:25; 1 Tim. 1:19*
ναύκληρος: the master or owner of a ship, Acts 27:11*
νεανίας: a young man, youth, Acts 20:9; 23:17; used of one who is in the prime of life, Acts 7:58*
νεανίσκος: a young man, youth, Mk. 14:51; 16:5; used of one in the prime of life, Mt. 19:20, 22; νεανίσκοι, soldiers, Mk. 14:51
Νέα πόλις: Neapolis, a city of Thrace on the Strymonic gulf, Acts 16:11*. See PhotoGuide.
νεκρός: dead, without life, Mt. 11:5; 22:31; met. νεκρός τινι, dead to a thing, no longer devoted to, or under the influence of a thing, Rom. 6:11; dead in respect of fruitlessness, Jas. 2:17, 20, 26; morally or spiritually dead, Rom. 6:13; Eph. 5:14; dead in alienation from God, Eph. 2:1, 5; Col. 2:13; subject to death, mortal, Rom. 8:10; causing death and misery, fatal, having a destructive power, Heb. 6:1; 9:14
νεκρόω: pr. to put to death, kill; in NT met. to deaden, mortify, Col. 3:5; pass. to be rendered impotent, Rom. 4:19; Heb. 11:12*
νέκρωσις: pr. a putting to death; dying, abandonment to death, 2 Cor. 4:10; deadness, impotency, Rom. 4:19*
νεομηνία: new moon, first of the month, Col. 2:16*
νέος: recent, new, fresh, Mt. 9:17; 1 Cor. 5:7; Col. 3:10; Heb. 12:24; young, youthful, Tit. 2:4. In Acts 16:11 is used in the name Νέαν πόλις, which some lexicons list as its own lexical form. This occurrence is not included in the word’s frequency count.
νεόφυτος: newly or recently planted met. a neophyte, one newly implanted into the Christian Church, a new convert, 1 Tim. 3:6*
νεύω: to nod; to intimate by a nod or significant gesture, Jn. 13:24; Acts 24:10*
Νεφθαλίμ: Nephthalim, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 4:13, 15; Rev. 5:6*
νέφος: a cloud; trop. a cloud, a throng of persons, Heb. 12:1*
νεφρός: a kidney; pl. νεφροί, the kidneys, reins; from the Hebrew the reins regarded as a seat of desire and affection, Rev. 2:23*
νεωκόρος: pr. one who sweeps or cleanses a temple; generally, one who has the charge of a temple; in NT a devotee city, as having specially dedicated a temple to some deity, Acts 19:35*
νεωτερικός: juvenile, natural to youth, youthful, 2 Tim. 2:22*
νή: by, BDAG 690, calls it a “particle of strong affirmation,” and is followed by the person or thing (in the acc) by which the person swears, 1 Cor. 15:31*
νήπιος: pr. not speaking, Latin infans; an infant, babe, child, Mt. 21:16; 1 Cor. 13:11; one below the age of manhood, a minor, Gal. 4:1; met. a babe in knowledge, unlearned, simple, Mt. 11:25; Rom. 2:20
νηστεία: fasting, want of food, 2 Cor. 6:5; 11:27; a fast, religious abstinence from food, Mt. 17:21; Lk. 2:37; spc. the annual public fast of the Jews, the great day of atonement, occurring in the month Tisri, corresponding to the new moon of October, Acts 27:9*
νῆστις: can also be masc. with a gen. in ιδος (n-3c[2]), fasting, hungry, Mt. 15:32; Mk. 8:3*
νηφάλιος: somber, temperate, abstinent in respect to wine, etc.; in NT met., vigilant, circumspect, self-controlled, 1 Tim. 3:2, 11; Tit. 2:2*
νήφω: to be sober, not intoxicated; in NT met., to be vigilant, circumspect, 1 Thess. 5:6, 8
Νίγερ: Niger, pr. name, probably not declined, Acts 13:1*
νικάω: to conquer, overcome, vanquish, subdue, Lk. 1:22; Jn. 16:33; absol. to overcome, prevail, Rev. 5:5; to come off superior in a judicial cause, Rom. 3:4
νίκη: victory; meton. a victorious principle, 1 Jn. 5:4*
Νικολαίτης: a Nicolaitan, or follower of Nicolaus, a heresy of the Apostolic age, Rev. 2:6, 15*
Νικόπολις: Nicopolis, a city of Macedonia, Tit. 3:12*. See PhotoGuide.
Νινευίτης: a Ninevite, an inhabitant of Nineveh, Mt. 12:41; Lk. 11:30, 32*
νιπτήρ: a basin for washing some part of the person, Jn. 13:5*
νίπτω: to wash; spc. to wash some part of the person, as distinguished from λούω, Mt. 6:17; Jn. 13:8
νοέω: to perceive, observe; to mark attentively, Mt. 24:15; Mk. 13:14; 2 Tim. 2:7; to understand, comprehend, Mt. 15:17; to conceive, Eph. 3:20
νόημα: the mind, the understanding, intellect, 2 Cor. 3:14; 4:4; Phil. 4:7; the heart, soul, affections, feelings, disposition, 2 Cor. 11:3; a conception of the mind, thought, purpose, device, 2 Cor. 2:11; 10:5*
νομή: pasture, pasturage, Jn. 10:9; ἔχειν νομήν, to eat its way, spread corrosion, 2 Tim. 2:17*
νομίζω: to own as settled and established; to deem, 1 Cor. 7:26; 1 Tim. 6:5; to suppose, presume, Mt. 5:17; 20:10; Lk. 2:44; to be usual, customary, Acts 16:13
νομικός: pertaining to law; relating to the Mosaic law, Tit. 3:9; as a subst., one skilled in law, a jurist, lawyer, Tit. 3:13; spc. an interpreter and teacher of the Mosaic law, Mt. 22:35
νομίμως: lawfully, agreeably to law or custom, rightfully, 1 Tim. 1:8; 2 Tim. 2:5*
νόμισμα: pr. a thing sanctioned by law or custom; lawful money, coin, Mt. 22:19*
νομοδιδάσκαλος: a teacher and interpreter of the Mosaic law, Lk. 5:17; Acts 5:34; 1 Tim. 1:7
νομοθεσία: legislation; ἡ νομοθεσία, the gift of the Divine law, or the Mosaic law itself, Rom. 9:4*
νομοθετέω: to impose a law, give laws; in NT pass., to have a law imposed on one’s self, receive a law, Heb. 7:11; to be enacted, constituted, Heb. 8:6*
νόμος: a law, Rom. 4:15; 1 Tim. 1:9; the Mosaic law, Mt. 5:17, et al. freq.; the Old Testament Scripture, Jn. 10:34; a legal tie, Rom. 7:2, 3; a law, a rule, standard, Rom. 3:27; a rule of life and conduct, Gal. 6:2, Jas. 1:25
νοσέω: to be sick; met. to have a diseased appetite or craving for a thing, have an excessive and vicious fondness for a thing, 1 Tim. 6:4*
νοσσιά: a brood of young birds, Lk. 13:34*
νοσσίον: the young of birds, a chick; pl. a brood of young birds, Mt. 23:37*
νοσσός: also spelled νεοσσός, the young of birds, a young bird, chick, Lk. 2:24*
νοσφίζω: to deprive, rob; mid. to misappropriate; to make secret reservation, Acts 5:2, 3; to purloin, Tit. 2:10*
νότος: the south wind, Lk. 12:55; Acts 27:13; 28:13; meton. the south, the southern quarter of the heavens, Mt. 12:42; Lk. 11:31; 13:29; Rev. 21:13*
νουθετέω: pr. to put in mind; to admonish, warn, Acts 20:31; Rom. 15:14
νοῦς: the mind, intellect, 1 Cor. 14:15, 19; understanding, intelligent faculty, Lk. 24:45; intellect, judgment, Rom. 7:23, 25; opinion, sentiment, Rom. 14:5; 1 Cor. 1:10; mind, thought, conception, Rom. 11:34; 1 Cor. 2:16; Phil. 4:7; settled state of mind, 2 Thess. 2:2; frame of mind, Rom. 1:28; 12:2; Col. 2:18; Eph. 4:23; 1 Tim. 6:5; 2 Tim. 3:8; Tit. 1:15
νύμφη: a bride, Jn. 3:29; Rev. 18:23; 21:2, 9; 22:17; opposed to πενθερά, a daughter-in-law, Mt. 10:35; Lk. 12:53*
νυμφών: a bridal-chamber; in NT υἱοὶ τοῦ νυμφῶνος, sons of the bridal-chamber, the bridegroom’s attendant friends, groomsmen, Mt. 9:15; Mk. 2:19; Lk. 5:34*
νῦν: now, at the present time, Mk. 10:30; Lk. 6:21, et al. freq.; just now, Jn. 11:8; forthwith, Jn. 12:31; καὶ νῦν, even now, as matters stand, Jn. 11:22; now, expressive of a marked tone of address, Acts 7:34; 13:11; Jas. 4:13; 5:1; τὸ νῦν, the present time, Lk. 1:48; τανῦν, or τὰ νῦν, now, Acts 4:29
νυνί: of time, now, at this very moment, an emphatic form of νῦν although it now carries the same meaning
νύξ: night, Mt. 2:14; 28:13; Jn. 3:2; met. spiritual night, moral darkness, Rom. 13:12; 1 Thess. 5:5
νυστάζω: to nod; to nod in sleep; to sink into a sleep, Mt. 25:5; to slumber in inactivity, 2 Pet. 2:3*
νυχθήμερον: a day and night, twenty-four hours, 2 Cor. 11:25*
Νῶε: Noah, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 24:37ff; Lk. 3:36; 17:26f.; Heb. 11:7; 1 Pet. 3:20; 2 Pet. 2:25*
νῶτος: the back of men or animals, Rom. 11:10*
χενία: pr. state of being a guest; then, the reception of a guest or stranger, hospitality, in NT a lodging, Acts 28:23; Phlm. 22*
χενίζω: to receive as a guest, entertain, Acts 10:23; 28:7; Heb. 13:2; pass. to be entertained as a guest, to lodge or reside with, Acts 10:6, 18, 32; 21:16; to strike with a feeling of strangeness, to surprise; pass. or mid. to be struck with surprise, be staggered, be amazed, 1 Pet. 4:4, 12; intrans. to be strange; χενίζοντα, strange matters, novelties, Acts 17:20*
χενοδοχέω: to receive and entertain strangers, exercise hospitality, 1 Tim. 5:10*
χένος: strange, foreign, alien, Eph. 2:12, 19; strange, unexpected, surprising, 1 Pet. 4:12; novel, Heb. 13:9; subst. a stranger, Mt. 25:35, et al.; a host, Rom. 16:23
χέστης: a sextarius, a Roman measure, containing about one pint English; in NT used for a small vessel, cup, pot, Mk. 7:4*
χηραίνω: to dry up, parch, Jas. 1:11; pass. to be parched, Mt. 13:6, et al.; to be ripened as corn, Rev. 14:15; to be withered, to wither, Mk. 11:20; of parts of the body, to be withered, Mk. 3:1, 3; to pine, Mk. 9:18
χηρός: dry, withered, Lk. 23:31; ἡ χηρά, i.e. γῆ, the dry land, land, Mt. 23:15; Heb. 11:29; of parts of the body, withered, Mt. 12:10
χύλινος: wooden, of wood, made of wood, 2 Tim. 2:20; Rev. 9:20*
χύλον: wood, timber, 1 Cor. 3:12; Rev. 18:12; stocks, Acts 16:24; a club, Mt. 26:47, 55; a post, cross, gibbet, Acts 5:30; 10:29; 13:29; a tree, Lk. 23:31; Rev. 2:7
χυράω: to cut off the hair, shear, shave, Acts 21:24; 1 Cor. 11:5, 6*
ὁ: the prepositive article, answering, to a considerable extent, to the English definite article; but, for the principle and facts of its usage, consult a grammar; ὁ μὲν ... ὁ δέ, the one ... the other, Phil. 1:16, 17; Heb. 7:5, 6, 20, 21, 23, 24; pl. some ... others, Mt. 13:23; 22:5, 6; ὁ δέ, but he, Mt. 4:4; 12:48; οἱ δέ, but others, Mt. 28:17; used, in a poetic quotation, for a personal pronoun, Acts 17:28
ὄγδοος: the eighth, Lk. 1:59; Acts 7:8; 2 Pet. 2:5; Rev. 17:11; 21:20*
ὄγκος: pr. bulk, weight; a burden, impediment, Heb. 12:1*
ὅδε: this, that, he, she, it, Lk. 10:39; 16:25; Acts 15:23
ὁδηγέω: to lead, guide, Mt. 15:14; Lk. 6:39; Rev. 7:17; met. to instruct, teach, Jn. 16:13; Acts 8:31*
ὁδηγός: a guide, leader, Acts 1:16; met. an instructor, teacher, Mt. 15:14; 23:16, 24; Rom. 2:19*
ὁδοιπορία: to journey, journeying, travel, Jn. 4:6; 2 Cor. 11:26*
ὁδός: a way, road, Mt. 2:12; 7:13, 14; 8:28; 22:9, 10; means of access, approach, entrance, Jn. 14:6; Heb. 9:8; direction, quarter, region, Mt. 4:15; 10:5 the act of journeying, a journey, way, course, Mt. 10:10; Mk. 2:23; 1 Thess. 3:11; a journey, as regards extent, Acts 1:12; met. a way, systematic course of pursuit, Lk. 1:79; Acts 2:28; 16:17; a way, systematic course of action or conduct, Mt. 21:32; Rom. 11:33; 1 Cor. 4:17; a way, system of doctrine, Acts 18:26; ἡ ὁδός, the way of the Christian faith, Acts 19:9, 23, 24:22
ὀδυνάω: to pain either bodily or mentally; pass. to be in an agony, be tormented, Lk. 2:48; 16:24, 25; to be distressed, grieved, Acts 20:38*
ὀδύνη: pain of body of mind; sorrow, grief, Rom. 9:2; 1 Tim. 6:10*
ὀδυρμός: bitter lamentation, wailing, Mt. 2:18; meton. sorrow, mourning, 2 Cor. 7:7*
ὄζω: to smell, emit an odor; to have an offensive smell, stink, Jn. 11:39*
ὅθεν: whence, Mt. 12:44; Acts 14:26; from the place where, Mt. 25:24, 26; whence, from which circumstance, 1 Jn. 2:18; wherefore, whereupon, Mt. 14:7
ὀθόνη: pr. fine linen; a linen cloth; a sheet, Acts 10:11; 11:5*
ὀθόνιον: a linen cloth; in NT a swath, bandage for a corpse, Lk. 24:12
οἶδα: to know, Mt. 6:8; to know how, Mt. 7:11; from the Hebrew, to regard with favor, 1 Thess. 5:12. οἶδα is actually a perfect form functioning as a present, and ᾔδειν is actually a pluperfect form functioning as an aorist.
οἰκεῖος: belonging to a house, domestic; pl. members of a family, immediate kin, 1 Tim. 5:8; members of a spiritual family, Eph. 2:19; members of a spiritual brotherhood, Gal. 6:10*
οἰκετεία: the members, of a household, Mt. 24:45*
οἰκέτης: pr. an inmate of a house; a domestic servant, household slave, Lk. 16:13; Acts 10:7; Rom. 14:4; 1 Pet. 2:18*
οἰκέω: to dwell in, inhabit, 1 Tim. 6:16; intrans. to dwell, live; to cohabit, 1 Cor. 7:12, 13; to be indwelling, indwell, Rom. 7:17, 18, 20; 8:9, 11; 1 Cor. 3:16*
οἴκημα: a dwelling; used in various conventional senses, and among them, a prison, cell, Acts 12:7*
οἰκητήριον: a habitation, dwelling, an abode, Jude 6; trop. the personal abode of the soul, 2 Cor. 5:2*
οἰκία: a house, dwelling, an abode, Mt. 2:11; 7:24, 27; trop. the bodily abode of the soul, 2 Cor. 5:1; meton. a household, family, Mt. 10:13; 12:25; meton. goods, property, means, Mt. 23:13
οἰκιακός: belonging to a house; pl. the members of a household or family, kindred, Mt. 10:25, 36*
οἰκοδεσποτέω: pr. to be master of a household; to occupy one’s self in the management of a household, 1 Tim. 5:14*
οἰκοδεσπότης: the master or head of a house or family, Mt. 10:25; 13:27, 52
οἰκοδομέω: pluperfect, ὧκοδόμητο (3 sg), to build a house; to build, Mt. 7:24; to repair, embellish, and amplify a building, Mt. 23:29; to construct, establish, Mt. 16:18; met. to contribute to advancement in religious knowledge, to edify, 1 Cor. 14:4, 17; to advance a person’s spiritual condition, to edify, 1 Cor. 8:1; pass. to make spiritual advancement, be edified, Acts 9:31; to advance in presumption, 1 Cor. 8:10
οἰκοδομή: pr. the act of building; a building, structure, Mt. 24:1; in NT a spiritual structure, as instanced in the Christian body, 1 Cor. 3:9; Eph. 2:21; religious advancement, edification, Rom. 14:19; 1 Cor. 14:3
οἰκονομέω: to manage a household; to manage the affairs of any one, be steward, Lk. 16:2*
οἰκονομία: pr. the management of a household; a stewardship, Lk. 16:2, 3, 4; in NT an apostolic stewardship, a ministerial commission in the publication and furtherance of the Gospel, 1 Cor. 9:17; 3:2; Col. 1:25; or, an arranged plan, a scheme, Eph. 1:10; a due discharge of a commission, 1 Tim. 1:4, Eph. 3:9*
οἰκονόμος: the manager of a household; a steward, Lk. 12:42; 16:1, 3, 8; 1 Cor. 4:2; a manager, trustee, Gal. 4:2; a public steward, treasurer, Rom. 16:23; a spiritual steward, the holder of a commission in the service of the Gospel, 1 Cor. 4:1; Tit. 1:7; 1 Pet. 4:10*
οἶκος: a house, dwelling, Mt. 9:6, 7; Mk. 2:1, 11; 3:20; place of abode, seat, site, Mt. 23:38; Lk. 13:35; met. a spiritual house or structure, 1 Pet. 2:5; meton. a household, family, Lk. 10:5; 11:17; a spiritual household, 1 Tim. 3:15; Heb. 3:6; family, lineage, Lk. 1:27, 69; 2:4; from the Hebrew, a people, nation, Mt. 10:6; 15:24
οἰκουμένη: some list as a participle, the habitable earth, world, Matt. 24:14; Rom. 10:18; Heb. 1:6; used, however, with various restrictions of meaning, according to the context, Lk. 2:1; Acts 17:6; meton. the inhabitants of the earth, the whole human race, mankind, Acts 17:31; 19:27; Rev. 3:10. Some view this word as a participial form of οἰκέω.
οἰκουργός: one who is occupied in domestic affairs, Tit. 2:5*
οἰκτιρμός: compassion; kindness, in relieving sorrow and want, Phil. 2:1; Col. 3:12; Heb. 10:28; favor, grace, mercy, Rom. 12:1; 2 Cor. 1:3*
οἰκτίρω: also spelled οἰκτείρω, to have compassion on, exercise grace or favor towards, Rom. 9:15*
οἰνοπότης: wine-drinking; in a bad sense, a wine-bibber, tippler, Mt. 11:19; Lk. 7:34*
οἶνος: wine, Mt. 9:17; Mk. 2:22; meton. the vine and its clusters, Rev. 6:6 met. οἶνος, a potion, οἶνος τοῦ θυμοῦ, a furious potion, Rev. 14:8, 10; 16:19; 17:2, 18:3
οἴομαι: to think, suppose, imagine, presume, Jn. 21:25; Phil. 1:17. οἰέσθω in Jas. 1:7 formed from the contracted form οἶμαι*
οἱος: what, of what kind or sort, as, Mt. 24:21; Mk. 9:3; οὐχ οἶον, not so as, not as implying, Rom. 9:6
ὀκνέω: to be slow; to delay, hesitate, Acts 9:38*
ὀκνηρός: slow; slothful, indolent, idle, Mt. 25:26; Rom. 12:11; tedious, troublesome, Phil. 3:1*
ὄλεθρος: perdition, destruction, 1 Cor. 5:5, 1 Thess. 5:3; 2 Thess. 1:9; 1 Tim. 6:9*
ὀλιγοπιστία: littleness or imperfectness of faith, Mt. 17:20*
ὀλιγόπιστος: scant of faith, of little faith, one whose faith is small and weak, Mt. 6:30; 8:26; 14:31; 16:18; Lk. 12:28*
ὀλίγος: little, small, in number, etc.; pl. few, Mt. 7:14; 9:37; 20:16; Lk. 13:23; δι’ ὀλίγων, i.e. λόγων, in a few words, briefly, 1 Pet. 5:12; little in time, short, brief, Acts 14:28; Rev. 12:12; πρὸς ὀλίγον, i.e. χρόνον, for a short time, for a little while, Jas. 4:14; little, small, light, etc., in magnitude, amount, etc., Lk. 7:47; Acts 12:18; 15:2; ἐν ὀλίγῳ, concisely, briefly, Eph. 3:3; almost, Acts 26:28, 29
ὀλιγωρέω: to neglect, regard slightly, make light of, despise, Heb. 12:5*
ὀλοθρεύω: also spelled ὀλεθρεύω, to destroy, cause to perish, Heb. 11:28*
ὁλοκαύτωμα: a holocaust, whole burnt-offering, Mk. 12:33; Heb. 10:6, 8*
ὁλόκληρος: whole, having all its parts, sound, perfect, complete in every part; in NT the whole, 1 Thess. 5:23; morally, perfect, faultless, blameless, Jas. 1:4*
ὀλολύζω: pr. to cry aloud in invocation; to howl, utter cries of distress, lament, bewail, Jas. 5:1*
ὄλυνθος: an unripe or unseasonable fig, such as, shaded by the foliage, does not ripen at the usual season, but hangs on the trees during winter, Rev. 6:13*
ὅλως: wholly, altogether; actually, really, 1 Cor. 5:1; 6:7; 15:29; with a negative, at all, Mt. 5:34*
ὄμβρος: rain, a storm of rain, Lk. 12:54*
ὁμείρομαι: also spelled ἱμείρομαι, to desire earnestly, have a strong affection for, 1 Thess. 2:8*
ὁμιλέω: to be in company with, associate with; to converse with, talk with, Lk. 24:14, 15; Acts 20:11; 24:26*
ὁμίχλη: a mist, fog, a cloud, 2 Pet. 2:17*
ὀμνύω: to swear, Mt. 5:34; to promise with an oath, Mk. 6:23; Acts 2:30; 7:17
ὁμοθυμαδόν: with one mind, with one accord, unanimously, Acts 1:14; Rom. 15:6; together, at once, at the same time, Acts 2:1, 46; 4:24
ὁμοιοπαθής: being affected in the same way as another, subject to the same incidents, of like infirmities, subject to the same frailties and evils, Acts 14:15; Jas. 5:17*
ὅμοιος: like, similar, resembling, Mt. 11:16; 13:31, 33, 44, 45, 47, 52; Jn. 8:55, et al. freq.; like, of similar drift and force, Mt. 22:39
ὁμοιόω: to make like, cause to be like or resemble, assimilate; pass. to be made like, become like, resemble, Mt. 6:8; 13:24; 18:23; to liken, compare, Mt. 7:24, 26; 11:16
ὁμοίωμα: pr. that which is conformed or assimilated; form, shape, figure, Rev. 9:7; likeness, resemblance, similitude, Rom. 1:23; 5:14; 6:5; 8:3; Phil. 2:7*
ὁμοίως: likewise, in a similar manner, Mt. 22:26; 27:41
ὁμολογέω: to speak in accordance, adopt the same terms of language; to engage, promise, Mt. 14:7; to admit, avow frankly, Jn. 1:20; Acts 24:14; to confess, 1 Jn. 1:9; to profess, confess, Jn. 9:22; 12:42; Acts 23:8; to avouch, declare openly and solemnly, Mt. 7:23; in NT ὁμολογεῖν ἐν, to accord belief, Mt. 10:32; Lk. 12:8; to accord approbation, Lk. 12:8; from the Hebrew, to accord praise, Heb. 13:15
ὁμολογία: assent, consent; profession, 2 Cor. 9:13; 1 Tim. 6:12, 13; Heb. 3:1; 4:14; 10:23*
ὁμότεχνος: to the same trade or occupation, Acts 18:3*
ὁμοῦ: together; in the same place, Jn. 21:2; together at the same time, Jn. 4:36; 20:4; Acts 2:1*
ὁμόφρων: of like mind, of the same mind, like-minded, 1 Pet. 3:8*
ὅμως: yet, nevertheless; with μέντοι, but nevertheless, but for all that, Jn. 12:42; even, though it be but, 1 Cor. 14:7; Gal. 3:15*
ὀνάριον: a young donkey, a donkey’s colt, Jn. 12:14*
ὀνειδίζω: to censure, inveigh against, Mt. 11:20; Mk. 16:14; to reproach or revile, Jas. 1:5; to revile, insult with insulting language, Mt. 5:11
ὄνειδος: pr. fame, report, character; usually, reproach, disgrace, Lk. 1:25*
ὀνικός: pertaining to a donkey; μύλος ὀνικός, a millstone turned by a donkey, a large or an upper millstone, Mt. 18:6; Mk. 9:42*
ὀνίνημι: optative, ὀναίμην, to receive profit, pleasure, etc.; with a gen., to have joy of, Phlm. 20*
ὄνομα: a name; the proper name of a person, etc., Mt. 1:23, 25; 10:2; 27:32; a mere name or reputation, Rev. 3:1; in NT a name as the representative of a person, Mt. 6:9; Lk. 6:22; 11:2; the name of the author of a commission, delegated authority, or religious profession, Mt. 7:22; 10:22; 12:21; 18:5, 20; 19:29; 21:9; 28:19; Acts 3:16; 4:7, 12; εἰς ὄνομα, ἐν ὀνόματι, on the score of being possessor of a certain character, Mt. 10:41, 42; Mk. 9:41
ὀνομάζω: to name, Lk. 6:14; to style, entitle, Lk. 6:13; 1 Cor. 5:11; to make mention of, Eph. 5:3; to make known, Rom. 15:20; to pronounce in exorcism, Acts 19:13; in NT to profess, 2 Tim. 2:19
ὄνος: donkey, ass, male or female, Mt. 21:2, 5, 7
ὄντως: really, in truth, truly, Mk. 11:32; Lk. 23:47.
ὄξος: vinegar; a wine of sharp flavor, posca, which was an ordinary beverage, and was often mixed with bitter herbs, etc., and this given to the condemned criminals in order to stupefy them, and lessen their sufferings, Mt. 27:48; Mk. 15:36; Lk. 23:36; Jn. 19:29, 30
ὀξύς: sharp, keen, Rev. 1:16; 2:12; 14:14, 17, 18; 19:15; swift, nimble, Rom. 3:15*
ὀπή: a hole; a hole, vent, opening, Jas. 3:11; a hole, cavern, Heb. 11:38*
ὄπισθεν: can function as an improper prep., from behind, behind, after, at the back of, Mt. 9:20; 15:23
ὀπίσω: can function as an improper prep., behind, after, at one’s back, Mt. 4:10; Lk. 7:38; Rev. 1:10; τὰ ὀπίσω, the things which are behind, Phil. 3:13; ὀπίσω and εἰς τὰ ὀπίσω, back, backwards, Mt. 24:18; Mk. 13:16; Lk. 9:62, when an improper prep., takes the gen.
ὁπλίζω: to arm, equip; mid. to arm one’s self, equip one’s self, 1 Pet. 4:1*
ὅπλον: an implement, Rom. 6:13; pl. τὰ ὅπλα, arms, armor, weapons, whether offensive or defensive, Jn. 18:3; Rom. 13:12; 2 Cor. 6:7; 10:4*
ὁποῖος: what, of what sort or manner, 1 Cor. 3:13; Gal. 2:6; 1 Thess. 1:9; Jas. 1:24; after τοιοῦτος, as, Acts 26:29*
ὅπου: where, in which place, in what place, Mt. 6:19, 20, 21; Rev. 2:13; whither, to what place, Jn. 8:21; 14:4; ὅπου ἄν, or ἐάν, wherever, in whatever place, Mt. 24:28; whithersoever, Mt. 8:19; Jas. 3:4; met. where, in which thing, state, etc., Col. 3:11; whereas, 1 Cor. 3:3; 2 Pet. 2:11
ὀπτασία: a vision, apparition, Lk. 1:22; 24:23; Acts 26:19; 2 Cor. 12:1*
ὀπτός: dressed by fire, roasted, broiled, etc., Lk. 24:42*
ὀπώρα: autumn; the fruit season; meton. fruits, Rev. 18:14*
ὅπως: can function as a conj., how, in what way or manner, by what means, Mt. 22:5; Lk. 24:20; conj. that, in order that, and ὅπως μή, that not, lest, Mt. 6:2, 4, 5, 16, 18; Acts 9:2, et al. freq.
ὅραμα: a thing seen, sight, appearance, Acts 7:31; a vision, Mt. 17:9; Acts 9:10, 12
ὅρασις: seeing, sight; appearance, aspect, a vision, Acts 2:17; Rev. 9:17; 4:3*
ὁράω: pluperfect, ἑωράκειν, some list εἶδον as the second aorist of ὁράω, to see, behold, Mt. 2:2, et al. freq.; to look, Jn. 19:37; to visit, Jn. 16:22; Heb. 13:23; to mark, observe, Acts 8:23; Jas. 2:24; to be admitted to witness, Lk. 17:22; Jn. 3:36; Col. 2:18; with θεόν, to be admitted into the more immediate presence of God, Mt. 5:8; Heb. 12:14; to attain to a true knowledge of God, 3 Jn. 11; to see to a thing, Mt. 27:4; Acts 18:15; ὅρα, see, take care, Mt. 8:4; Heb. 8:5; pass. to appear, Lk. 1:11; Acts 2:3; to reveal one’s self, Acts 26:16; to present one’s self, Acts 7:26
ὀργή: pr. mental bent, impulse; anger, indignation, wrath, Eph. 4:31; Col. 3:8; μετ’ ὀργῆς, indignantly, Mk. 3:5; vengeance, punishment, Mt. 3:7; Lk. 3:7; 21:23; Rom. 13:4, 5
ὀργίζω: some list as deponent, ὀργίζομαι, to provoke to anger, irritate; pass. to be angry, indignant, enraged, Mt. 5:22; 18:34
ὀργίλος: prone to anger, irascible, passionate, Tit. 1:7*
ὀργυιά: the space measured by the arms outstretched; a fathom, Acts 27:28 (2x)*
ὀρέγω: to extend, stretch out; mid. to stretch one’s self out, to reach forward to, met. to desire earnestly, long after, 1 Tim. 3:1; Heb. 11:16; by impl. to indulge in, be devoted to, 1 Tim. 6:10*
ὀρθοποδέω: to walk in a straight course; to be straightforward in moral conduct, Gal. 2:14*
ὀρθός: erect, upright, Acts 14:10; plain, level, straight, Heb. 12:13*
ὀρθοτομέω: to cut straight; to set forth truthfully, without perversion or distortion, 2 Tim. 2:15*
ὀρθρίζω: to rise early in the morning; to come with the dawn, Lk. 21:38*
ὀρθρινός: a later form of ὄρθριος, of or belonging to the morning, morning, Lk. 24:22*
ὄρθρος: the dawn; the morning, Jn. 8:2; Acts 5:21; ὄρθος βαθύς, the first streak of dawn, the early dawn, Lk. 24:1*
ὁρίζω: to set bounds to, to bound; to restrict, Heb. 4:7; to settle, appoint definitively, Acts 17:26; to fix determinately, Acts 2:23; to decree, destine, Lk. 22:22; to constitute, appoint, Acts 10:42; 17:31; to characterize with precision, to set forth distinctively, Rom. 1:4; absol. to resolve, Acts 11:29*
ὅριον: a limit, bound, border of a territory or country; pl. τὰ ὅρια, region, territory, district, Mt. 2:16; 4:13; 8:34
ὁρκίζω: to put to an oath; to obtest, adjure, conjure, Mk. 5:7; Acts 19:13*
ὅρκος: an oath, Mt. 14:7, 9; 26:72; meton. that which is solemnly promised, a vow, Mt. 5:33
ὁρκωμοσία: the act of taking an oath; an oath, Heb. 7:20, 21, 28*
ὁρμάω: pr. trans. to put in motion, incite; intrans. to rush, Mt. 8:32; Mk. 5:13; Lk. 8:33
ὁρμή: impetus, impulse; assault, violent attempt, Acts 14:5; met. impulse of mind, purpose, will, Jas. 3:4
ὅρμημα: violent or impetuous motion; violence, Rev. 18:21*
ὄρνις: bird, fowl; domestic hen, Mt. 23:37; Lk. 13:34*
ὁροθεσία: pr. the act of fixing boundaries; a bound set, certain bound, fixed limit, Acts 17:26*
ὀρφανός: bereaved of parents, orphan, Jas. 1:27; bereaved, desolate, Jn. 14:18
ὅς: who, which, what, that, Mt. 1:16, 23, 25; in NT interrog. ἐφ’ ὅ, wherefore, why, Mt. 26:50; in NT ὅς μὲν ... ὅς δέ, for ὁ μὲν ... ὁ δέ, Mt. 21:35; 2 Cor. 2:16
ὅσιος: pr. sanctioned by the supreme law of God, and nature; pious, devout, Tit. 1:8; pure, 1 Tim. 2:8; supremely holy, Acts 2:27; 13:35; Heb. 7:26; Rev. 15:4; 16:5; τὰ ὅσια, pledged bounties, mercies, Acts 13:34*
ὁσιότης: piety, sacred observance of all duties towards God, holiness, Lk. 1:75; Eph. 4:24*
ὀσμή: smell, odor; fragrant odor, Jn. 12:3; Eph. 5:2; Phil. 4:18; met. 2 Cor. 2:14, 16*
ὅσος: as great, as much, Mk. 7:36; Jn. 6:11; Heb. 1:4; 8:6; 10:25; ἐφ’ ὅσον χρόνον, for how long a time, while, as long as, Rom. 7:1; so, ἐφ’ ὅσον, i.e. χρόνον, Mt. 9:15; ὅσον χρόνον, how long, Mk. 2:19; neut. ὅσον repeated, ὅσον ὅσον, used to give intensity to other qualifying words, e.g., μικρόν, the very least, a very little while, Heb. 10:37; ἐφ’ ὅσον, in as much as, Mt. 25:40, 45; καθ’ ὅσον, by how much, so far as, Heb. 3:3; or, in as much as, as, so, Heb. 7:20; 9:27; pl. ὅσα, so far as, as much as, Rev. 1:2; 18:7; how great, how much, how many, what, Mk. 3:8; 5:19, 20; how many, as many as, all who, 2 Cor. 1:20; Phil. 3:15; 1 Tim. 6:1; ὅσος ἄν, or ἐάν, whoever, whatsoever, Mt. 7:12; 18:18
ὀστέον: contracted form, ὀστοῦν, οῦ, τό, a bone, Mt. 23:27; Lk. 24:39; Jn. 19:36; Heb. 11:22*
ὅστις: whoever, whatever; whosoever, whatsoever, Mt. 5:39, 41; 13:12; 18:4; its use in place of the simple relative is also required in various cases, which may be learned from the grammars; ἕως ὅτου, i.e. χρόνου, until, Lk. 13:8; while, Mt. 5:25
ὄσφρησις: smell, the sense of smelling, 1 Cor. 12:17*
ὀσφῦς: the loins, Mt. 3:4; Mk. 1:6. On the accent see BDF, 13.
ὅταν: when, whenever, Mt. 5:11; 6:2; Mk. 3:11; Rev. 4:9, et al. freq.; in NT in case of, on occasion of, Jn. 9:5; 1 Cor. 15:27; Heb. 1:6
ὅτε: when, at the time that, at what time, Mt. 7:28; 9:25; Lk. 13:35, et al. freq.
ὅτι: originally was the neuter of ὅστις, that, Mt. 2:16, 22, 23; 6:5, 16; often used pleonastically in reciting another’s words, Mt. 9:18; Lk. 19:42; Acts 5:23; as a causal particle, for that, for, because, Mt. 2:18; 5:3, 4, 5; 13:13; because, seeing that, since, Lk. 23:40; Acts 1:17
οὐ: negative adverb, originally the gen. of ὅς, spelled οὐκ if followed by a word beginning with a vowel and a smooth breathing, οὐχ if followed by a vowel and rough breathing, not, no, Mt. 5:37; 12:43; 23:37; for the peculiarities of its usage (especially as distinct from μή) consult a grammar
οὐά: expressive of insult and derision, Ah! Ah!, Mk. 15:29*
οὐαί: Wo! Alas! Mt. 11:21; 18:7; 23:13, 14, 15, 16; ἡ οὐαί, subst., a woe, calamity, Rev. 9:12; 11:14
οὐδέ: negative conj., neither, nor, and not, also not, Mt. 5:15; 6:15, 20, 26, 28; when single, not even Mt. 6:29; 8:10
οὐδείς: latter form, οὐθείς (G4032), not one, no one, none, nothing, Mt. 5:13; 6:24; 19:17; met. οὐδέν, nothing, of no account, naught, Jn. 8:54; Acts 21:24
οὐδέπω: not yet, never yet, never, Jn. 7:39; 19:41; 20:9; Acts 8:16*
οὖν: then, now then, Mt. 13:18; Jn. 19:29; then, thereupon, Lk. 15:28; Jn. 6:14; therefore, consequently, Mt. 5:48: Mk. 10:9; it also serves to mark the resumption of discourse after an interruption by a parenthesis, 1 Cor. 8:4. Sometimes it is not translated.
οὐρανός: heaven, the heavens, the visible heavens and all their phenomena, Mt. 5:18; 16:1; 24:29, et al. freq.; the air, atmosphere, in which the clouds and tempests gather, the birds fly, etc., Mt. 6:26; 16:2, 3; heaven as the peculiar seat and abode of God, of angels, of glorified spirits, etc., Mt. 5:34, 45, 48; 6:1, 9, 10; 12:50; Jn. 3:13, 31; 6:32, 38, 41, 42, 50, 51, 58; in NT heaven as a term expressive of the Divine Being, His administration, etc., Mt. 19:14; 21:25; Lk. 20:4, 5; Jn. 3:27
Οὐρίας: Urias, Uriah, pr. name (2 Sam. 11; 12:24), Mt. 1:6*
οὔτε: neither, nor, Lk. 20:36; οὔτε ... οὔτε, or οὐτὲ ... οὔτε, neither ... nor, Lk. 20:35; Gal. 1:12; in NT also used singly in the sense of οὐδέ, not even, Mk. 5:3; Lk. 12:26; 1 Cor. 3:2
οὗτος: this, this person or thing, Mt. 3:3, 9, 17; 8:9; 10:2; 24:34, et al. freq.; used by way of contempt, this fellow, Mt. 13:55; 27:47; αὐτὸ τοῦτο, this very thing, this same thing, 2 Cor. 2:3; 7:11; εἰς αὐτὸ τοῦτο, and elliptically, αὐτὸ τοῦτο, for this same purpose, on this account, Eph. 6:18, 22; 2 Pet. 1:5; καὶ οὗτος, and moreover, Lk. 7:12; 16:1; 20:30; καὶ τοῦτο, and that too, 1 Cor. 6:6, 8; tοῦτο μὲν ... τοῦτο δέ, partly ... partly, Heb. 10:33
οὕτως: thus, in this way, Mt. 1:18; 2:5; 5:16; et al. freq.; ὁς μὲν οὕτως, ὁς δὲ οὕτως, one so, and another so, one in one way, and another in another, 1 Cor. 7:7; so, Mt. 7:12; 12:40; 24:27, 37, et al. freq.; thus, under such circumstances, Acts 20:11; in such a condition, viz., one previously mentioned, Acts 27:17; 1 Cor. 7:26, 40; and, perhaps, Jn. 4:6; in an ordinary way, at ease, like Latin sic, perhaps, Jn. 4:6
οὐχί: a strengthened form of οὐ, not, Jn. 13:10, 11; when followed by ἀλλά, nay, not so, by no means, Lk. 1:60; 12:51; used also in negative interrogations, Mt. 5:46, 47; 6:25
ὀφειλέτης: a debtor, one who owes, Mt. 18:24; met. one who is in any way bound, or under obligation to perform any duty, Rom. 1:14; 8:12; 15:27; Gal. 5:3; in NT one who fails in duty, a delinquent, offender, Mt. 6:12; a sinner, Lk. 13:4, cf. v. 2*
ὀφειλή: a debt, Mt. 18:32; met. a duty, due, Rom. 13:7; 1 Cor. 7:3*
ὀφείλημα: a debt; a due, Rom. 4:4, in NT a delinquency, offence, fault, sin, Mt. 6:12, cf. v. 14*
ὀφείλω: to owe, be indebted, Mt. 18:28, 30, 34; to incur a bond, to be bound to make discharge, Mt. 23:16, 18; to be bound or obliged by what is due or fitting or consequently necessary, Lk. 17:10; Jn. 13:14; to incur desert, to deserve, Jn. 19:7; to be due or fitting, 1 Cor. 7:3, 36; from the Aramaic, to be delinquent, Lk. 11:4
ὄφελον: originally a ptcp (aor act ptcp nom sg neut) from ὀφείλω, used in NT as an interj. to introduce a wish that cannot be attained, O that! Would that! 1 Cor. 4:8; 2 Cor. 11:1; Gal. 5:12; Rev. 3:15*
ὀφθαλμοδουλία: also written ὀφθαλμοδουλεία, eye-service, service rendered only while under inspection, Eph. 6:6; Col. 3:22*
ὀφθαλμός: an eye, Mt. 5:29, 38; 6:23; 7:3, 4, 5; ὀφθαλμὸς πονηρός, an evil eye, an envious eye, envy, Mt. 20:15; Mk. 7:22; met. the intellectual eye, Mt. 13:15; Mk. 8:18; Jn. 12:40; Acts 26:18
ὄφις: a serpent, Mt. 7:10; 10:16; an artificial serpent, Jn. 3:14; used of the devil or Satan, Rev. 12:9, 14, 15; 20:2; met. a man of serpentine character, Mt. 23:33
ὀφρῦς: a brow, eye-brow; the brow of a mountain, edge of a precipice, Lk. 4:29*
ὀχλέω: pr. to mob; to disturb, trouble, Acts 5:16*
ὀχλοποιέω: to collect a mob, create a tumult, Acts 17:5*
ὄχλος: a crowd, a confused multitude of people, Mt. 4:25; 5:1; 7:28; spc. the common people, Jn. 7:49; a multitude, great number, Lk. 5:29; 6:17; Acts 1:15; by impl. tumult, uproar, Lk. 22:6; Acts 24:18
ὀχύρωμα: a stronghold; met. an opposing bulwark of error or vice, 2 Cor. 10:4*
ὀψέ: can function as an improper prep., late; put for the first watch, at evening, Mk. 11:19; 13:35; ὀψὲ σαββάτων, after the close of the Sabbath, Mt. 28:1
ὀψία: evening, either before or after sundown
ὄψιμος: late; latter, Jas. 5:7; poetic and later prose for ὄψιος*
ὄψις: a sight; the face, countenance, Jn. 11:44; Rev. 1:16; external appearance, Jn. 7:24*
ὀψώνιον: provisions; a stipend or pay of soldiers, Lk. 3:14; 1 Cor. 9:7; wages of any kind, 2 Cor. 11:8; due wages, a stated recompense, Rom. 6:23*
παγίς: a snare, trap, Lk. 21:35; met. device, wile, 1 Tim. 3:7; 6:9; 2 Tim. 2:26; met. a trap of ruin, Rom. 11:9*
πάγος: a hill, Ἄρειος πάγος, Areopagus, the hill of Mars, at Athens, Acts 17:19, 22. See PhotoGuide.
πάθημα: what is suffered; suffering, affliction, Rom. 8:18; 2 Cor. 1:5, 6, 7; Phil. 3:10; emotion, passion, Rom. 7:5; Gal. 5:24
παθητός: passible, capable of suffering, liable to suffer; in NT destined to suffer, Acts 26:23*
πάθος: suffering; an affection, passion, especially sexual, Rom. 1:26
παιδαγωγός: a pedagogue, childtender, a person, usually a slave or freedman, to whom the care of the boys of a family was committed, whose duty it was to attend them at their play, lead them to and from the public school, and exercise a constant superintendence over their conduct and safety; in NT an ordinary director or minister contrasted with an Apostle, as a pedagogue occupies an inferior position to a parent, 1 Cor. 4:15; a term applied to the Mosaic law, as dealing with men as in a state of mere childhood and tutelage, Gal. 3:24, 25*
παιδάριον: a little boy, child; a boy, lad, Jn. 6:9*
παιδεία: education, training up, nurture of children, Eph. 6:4; instruction, discipline, 2 Tim. 3:16; in NT correction, chastisement, Heb. 12:5, 7, 8, 11*
παιδευτής: a preceptor, instructor, teacher, pr. of boys; genr. Rom. 2:20; in NT a chastiser, Heb. 12:9*
παιδεύω: to educate, instruct children, Acts 7:22; 22:3; genr. παιδεύομαι, to be taught, learn, 1 Tim. 1:20; to admonish, instruct by admonition, 2 Tim. 2:25; Tit. 2:12; in NT to chastise, chasten, 1 Cor. 11:32; 2 Cor. 6:9; Heb. 12:6, 7, 10; Rev. 3:19; of criminals, to scourge, Lk. 23:16, 22*
παιδιόθεν: from childhood, from a child, Mk. 9:21*
παιδίον: an infant, babe, Mt. 2:8; but usually in NT as equiv. to παῖς, Mt. 14:21; Mk. 7:28, et al. freq.; pl. voc. used by way of endearment, my dear children, 1 Jn. 2:18; also as a term of familiar address, children, my lads, Jn. 21:5
παιδίσκη: a girl, damsel, maiden; a female slave or servant, Mt. 26:69; Mk. 14:66, 69
παίζω: to play in the manner of children; to sport, to practise the festive gestures of idolatrous worship, 1 Cor. 10:7*
παῖς: a child in relation to parents, of either sex, Jn. 4:51; a child in respect of age, either male or female, and of all ages from infancy up to manhood, a boy, youth, girl, maiden, Mt. 2:16; 17:18; Lk. 2:43; 8:54; a servant, slave, Mt. 8:6, 8, 13, cf. v. 9; Lk. 7:7, cf. v. 3, 10; an attendant, minister, Mt. 14:2; Lk. 1:69; Acts 4:25; also, Lk. 1:54; or, perhaps, a child in respect of fatherly regard
παίω: to strike, smite, with the fist, Mt. 26:68; Lk. 22:64; with a sword, Mk. 14:47; Jn. 18:10; to strike as a scorpion, to sting, Rev. 9:5*
πάλαι: of old, long ago, Mt. 11:21; Lk. 10:13; Heb. 1:1; Jude 4; οἱ πάλαι, old, former, 2 Pet. 1:9; some time since, already, Mk. 15:44
παλαιός: old, not new or recent, Mt. 9:16, 17; 13:52; Lk. 5:36
παλαιόω: to make old; pass. to grow old, to become worn, Lk. 12:33; Heb. 1:11; met. to treat as antiquated, to abrogate, supersede, Heb. 8:13*
παλιγγενεσία: a new birth; regeneration, renovation, Mt. 19:28; Tit. 3:5. See unpublished Ph.D. dissertation, William D. Mounce, The Origin of the New Testament Metaphor of Rebirth, University of Aberdeen, Scotland*
πάλιν: pr. back; again, back again, Jn. 10:17; Acts 10:16; 11:10; again by repetition, Mt. 26:43; again in continuation, further, Mt. 5:33; 13:44, 45, 47, 18:19; again, on the other hand, 1 Jn. 2:8
παμπληθεί: the whole multitude together, all at once, Lk. 23:18*
Παμφυλία: Pamphylia, a country of Asia Minor, Acts 2:10; 13:13; 14:24; 15:38; 27:5*
πανδοχεῖον: a public inn, place where travelers may lodge, called in the East by the name of menzil, khan, caravanserai, Lk. 10:34*
πανδοχεύς: the keeper of a public inn or caravanserai, a host, Lk. 10:35*
πανήγυρις: pr. an assembly of an entire people; a solemn gathering at a festival; a festive convocation, Heb. 12:22*
πανοικεί: also spelled πανοικί, with one’s whole household or family, Acts 16:34*
πανοπλία: panoply, complete armor, a complete suit of armor, both offensive and defensive, as the shield, sword, spear, helmet, breastplate, etc., Lk. 11:22; Eph. 6:11, 13*
πανοῦργος: pr. ready to do anything; hence, crafty, cunning, artful, wily, 2 Cor. 12:16*
πανταχοῦ: in all places, everywhere, Mk. 16:20; Lk. 9:6
παντελής: perfect, complete; εἰς τὸ παντελές, adverbially, throughout, through all time, ever, Heb. 7:25; with a negative, at all, Lk. 13:11*
πάντῃ: everywhere; in every way, in every instance, Acts 24:3*
πάντοθεν: from every place, from all parts, on all sides, on every side, round about, Mk. 1:45; Lk. 19:43; Heb. 9:4*
πάντοτε: always, at all times, ever, Mt. 26:11; Mk. 14:7; Lk. 15:31; 18:1
πάντως: wholly, altogether; at any rate, by all means, 1 Cor. 9:22; by impl. surely, assuredly, certainly, Lk. 4:23; Acts 21:22; 28:4; 1 Cor. 9:10; οὐ πάντως, in nowise, not in the least, Rom. 3:9; 1 Cor. 5:10; 16:12*
παρά: (1) gen., from, indicating source or origin, Mt. 2:4, 7; Mk. 8:11; Lk. 2:1; οἱ παρ’ αὐτοῦ, his relatives or kinsmen, Mk. 3:21; τὰ παρ’ αὐτῆς πάντα, all her substance, property, etc., Mk. 5:26. (2) dat., with, in, among, etc., Mt. 6:1; 19:26; 21:25; 22:25; παρ’ ἑαυτῷ, at home, 1 Cor. 16:2; in the sight of, in the judgment or estimation of, 1 Cor. 3:19; 2 Pet. 2:11; 3:8. (3) acc., motion, by, near to, along, Mt. 4:18; motion, towards, to, at, Mt. 15:30; Mk. 2:13; motion terminating in rest, at, by, near, by the side of, Mk. 4:1, 4; Lk. 5:1; 8:5; in deviation from, in violation of, inconsistently with, Acts 18:13; Rom. 1:26; 11:24; above, more than, Lk. 13:2, 4; Rom. 1:25. (4) Misc., after comparatives, Lk. 3:13; 1 Cor. 3:11; except, save, 2 Cor. 11:24; beyond, past, Heb. 11:11; in respect of, on the score of, 1 Cor. 12:15, 16
παραβαίνω: pr. to step by the side of; to deviate; met. to transgress, violate, Mt. 15:2, 3; to incur forfeiture, Acts 1:25*
παραβάλλω: to cast or throw by the side of; absol., a nautical term, to bring to, land, Acts 20:15*
παράβασις: a stepping by the side, deviation; a transgression, violation of law, Rom. 2:23; 4:15
παραβάτης: transgressor, violator of law, Rom. 2:25, 27; Gal. 2:18; Jas. 2:9, 11*
παραβιάζομαι: to force; to constrain press with urgent entreaties, Lk. 24:29; Acts 16:15*
παραβολεύομαι: also spelled παραβουλεύομαι, to stake or risk one’s self, Phil. 2:30*
παραβολή: a placing one thing by the side of another; a comparing; a parallel case cited in illustration; a comparison, simile, similitude, Mk. 4:30; Heb. 11:19; a parable, a short relation under which something else is figured, or in which that which is fictitious is employed to represent that which is real, Mt. 13:3, 10, 13, 18, 24, 31, 33, 34, 36, 53; 21:33, 45; 22:1; 24:32; in NT a type, pattern, emblem, Heb. 9:9; a sentiment, grave and significant precept, maxim, Lk. 14:7; an obscure and enigmatical saying, anything expressed in remote and ambiguous terms, Mt. 13:35; Mk. 7:17; a proverb, adage, Lk. 4:23
παραγγελία: a command, order, charge, Acts 5:28; 16:24; direction, precept, 1 Thess. 4:2; 1 Tim. 1:5, 18*
παραγγέλλω: to announce, notify; to command, direct, charge, Mt. 10:5; Mk. 6:8, 8:6; Lk. 9:21; to charge, entreat solemnly, 1 Tim. 6:13
παραγίνομαι: pluperfect, παραγεγόνει (3 sg), to be by the side of; to come, approach, arrive, Mt. 2:1; 3:13; Mk. 14:43; Lk. 7:4; seq. ἐπί, to come upon in order to seize, Lk. 22:52; to come forth in public, make appearance, Mt. 3:1; Heb. 9:11
παράγω: to lead beside; intrans. to pass along or by, Mt. 20:30; Jn. 9:1; to pass on, Mt. 9:9, 27; intrans. and mid. to pass away, be in a state of transition, 1 Cor. 7:31; 1 Jn. 2:8, 17
παραδειγματίζω: to make an example of; to expose to ignominy and shame, Heb. 6:6*
παράδεισος: a park, a forest where wild beasts were kept for hunting; a pleasure-park, a garden of trees of various kinds; used in the LXX for the Garden of Eden; in NT the celestial paradise, Lk. 23:43; 2 Cor. 12:4; Rev. 2:7*
παραδέχομαι: to accept, receive, met. to receive, admit, yield assent to, Mk. 4:20; Acts 15:4; 16:21; 22:18; 1 Tim. 5:19; in NT to receive or embrace with favor, approve, love, Heb. 12:6*
παραδίδωμι: pluperfect, παραδεδώκεισαν (3 pl), to give over, hand over, deliver up, Mt. 4:12; 5:25; 10:4, 17; to commit, intrust, Mt. 11:27; 25:14; to commit, commend, Acts 14:26; 15:40; to yield up, Jn. 19:30; 1 Cor. 15:24; to abandon, Acts 7:42; Eph. 4:19; to stake, hazard, Acts 15:26; to deliver as a matter of injunction, instruction, etc., Mk. 7:13; Lk. 1:2; Acts 6:14; absol. to render a yield, to be matured, Mk. 4:29
παράδοσις: delivery, handing over, transmission; in NT what is transmitted in the way of teaching, precept, doctrine, 1 Cor. 11:2; 2 Thess. 2:15; 3:6; tradition, traditionary law, handed down from age to age, Mt. 15:2, 3, 6
παραζηλόω: to provoke to jealousy, Rom. 10:19; to excite to emulation, Rom. 11:11, 14; to provoke to indignation, 1 Cor. 10:22*
παραθαλάσσιος: by the sea-side, situated on the sea-coast, maritime, Mt. 4:13*
παραθεωρέω: to look at things placed side by side, as in comparison, to compare in thus looking, to regard less in comparison, overlook, neglect, Acts 6:1*
παραθήκη: a deposit, a thing committed to one’s charge, a trust, 1 Tim. 6:20; 2 Tim. 1:12; 2 Tim. 1:14*
παραιτέομαι: to entreat; to beg off, excuse one’s self, Lk. 14:18, 19; to deprecate, entreat against, Acts 25:11; Heb. 12:19; to decline receiving, refuse, reject, 1 Tim. 4:7; 5:11; Tit. 3:10; Heb. 12:25; to decline, avoid, shun, 2 Tim. 2:23
παρακαλέω: to call for, invite to come, send for, Acts 28:20; to call upon, exhort, admonish, persuade, Lk. 3:18; Acts 2:40; 11:23; to beg, beseech, entreat, implore, Mt. 8:5, 31; 18:29; Mk. 1:40; to animate, encourage, comfort, console, Mt. 2:18; 5:4; 2 Cor. 1:4, 6; pass. to be cheered, comforted, Lk. 16:25; Acts 20:12; 2 Cor. 7:13
παρακαλύπτω: to cover over, veil; met. pass. to be veiled from comprehension, Lk. 9:45*
παράκειμαι: to lie near, be adjacent; met. to be at hand, be present, Rom. 7:18, 21*
παράκλησις: a calling upon, exhortation, incitement, persuasion, Rom. 12:8; 1 Cor. 14:3; hortatory instruction, Acts 13:15; 15:31; entreaty, importunity, earnest supplication, 2 Cor. 8:4; solace, consolation, Lk. 2:25; Rom. 15:4, 5; 2 Cor. 1:3, 4, 5, 6, 7; cheering and supporting influence, Acts 9:31; joy, gladness, rejoicing, 2 Cor. 7:13; cheer, joy, enjoyment, Lk. 6:24
παράκλητος: one called or sent for to assist another; an advocate, one who pleads the cause of another, 1 Jn. 2:1; genr. one present to render various beneficial service, and thus the Paraclete, whose influence and operation were to compensate for the departure of Christ himself, Jn. 14:16, 26; 15:26; 16:7*
παρακοή: an erroneous or imperfect hearing; disobedience, Rom. 5:19; a deviation from obedience, 2 Cor. 10:6; Heb. 2:2*
παρακολουθέω: to follow or accompany closely; to accompany, attend, characterize, Mk. 16:17; to follow with the thoughts, trace, Lk. 1:3; to conform to, 1 Tim. 4:6; 2 Tim. 3:10*
παρακούω: to overhear, Mk. 5:36; to hear amiss, to fail to listen, neglect to obey, disregard, Mt. 18:17 (2x)*
παρακύπτω: to stoop beside; to stoop down in order to take a view, Lk. 24:12; Jn. 20:5, 11; to bestow a close and attentive look, to look intently, to penetrate, Jas. 1:25; 1 Pet. 1:12*
παραλαμβάνω: pr. to take to one’s side; to take, receive to one’s self, Mt. 1:20; Jn. 14:3; to take with one’s self, Mt. 2:13, 14, 20, 21; 4:5, 8; to receive in charge or possession, Col. 4:17; Heb. 12:28; to receive as a matter of instruction, Mk. 7:4; 1 Cor. 11:23; 15:3; to receive, admit, acknowledge, Jn. 1:11; 1 Cor. 15:1; Col. 2:6; pass. to be carried off, Mt. 24:40, 41; Lk. 17:34, 35, 36
παραλέγομαι: to gather a course along; to sail by, coast along, Acts 27:8, 13*
παράλιος: adjacent to the sea, maritime; ἡ παράλιος, i.e. χώρα, the sea coast, Lk. 6:17*
παραλογίζομαι: to misreckon, make a false reckoning; to impose upon, deceive, delude, circumvent, Col. 2:4; Jas. 1:22*
παραλυτικός: lame, palsied, used only as a noun in NT, paralytic, Mt. 4:24; 8:6; 9:2, 6
παραλύω: to unloose from proper fixity or consistency of substance; to enervate or paralyze the body or limbs; pass. to be enervated or enfeebled, Heb. 12:12; pass. perf. part. παραλελυμένος, paralytic, Lk. 5:18, 24
παραμένω: to stay beside; to continue, stay, abide, 1 Cor. 16:6; Heb. 7:23; met. to remain constant in, persevere in, Phil. 1:25; Jas. 1:25*
παραμυθέομαι: to exercise a gentle influence by words; to soothe, comfort, console, Jn. 11:19, 31; 1 Thess. 5:14; to cheer, exhort, 1 Thess. 2:12*
παρανομέω: to violate or transgress the law, Acts 23:3*
παρανομία: violation of the law, transgression, 2 Pet. 2:16*
παραπικραίνω: pr. to incite to bitter feelings; to provoke; absol. to act provokingly, be rebellious, Heb. 3:16*
παραπίπτω: pr. to fall by the side of; met. to fall off or away from, make defection from, Heb. 6:6*
παραπλέω: to sail by or past a place, Acts 20:16*
παραπλήσιος: pr. near alongside; met. like, similar; neut. παραπλήσιον, adverbially, near to, nearly, with a near approach to, Phil. 2:27*
παραπλησίως: like, in the same or like manner, Heb. 2:14*
παραπορεύομαι: to pass by the side of; to pass along, Mt. 27:39; Mk. 2:23; 9:30; 11:20; 15:29*
παράπτωμα: pr. a stumbling aside, a false step; in NT a trespass, fault, offence, transgression, Mt. 6:14, 15; Mk. 11:25, 26; Rom. 4:25; a fall in faith, Rom. 11:11, 12
παραρρέω: to flow beside; to glide aside from; to fall off from profession, decline from steadfastness, make forfeit of faith, Heb. 2:1*
παράσημος: a distinguishing mark; an ensign of a ship, Acts 28:11*
παρασκευάζω: to prepare, make ready, 2 Cor. 9:2, 3; mid. to prepare one’s self, put one’s self in readiness, Acts 10:10; 1 Cor. 14:8*
παρασκευή: a getting ready, preparation, in NT preparation for a feast, day of preparation, Mt. 27:62; Mk. 15:42
παρατείνω: to extend, stretch out; to prolong, continue, Acts 20:7*
παρατηρέω: to watch narrowly, Acts 9:24; to observe or watch insidiously, Mk. 3:2; Lk. 6:7; 14:1; 20:20; to observe scrupulously, Gal. 4:10*
παρατίθημι: to place by the side of, or near; to set before, Mk. 6:41; 8:6, 7; Lk. 9:16; met. to set or lay before, propound, Mt. 13:24, 31; to inculcate, Acts 17:3; to deposit, commit to the charge of, entrust, Lk. 12:48; 23:46; to commend, Acts 14:23
παρατυγχάνω: to happen, to chance upon, chance to meet, Acts 17:17*
παραυτίκα: instantly, immediately; ὁ, ἡ, τό, παραυτίκα, momentary, transient, 2 Cor. 4:17*
παραφέρω: to carry past; to cause to pass away, Mk. 14:36; Lk. 22:42; pass. to be swept along, Jude 12; to be led away, misled, seduced, Heb. 13:9*
παραφρονέω: to be beside one’s wits; παραφρονῶν, in foolish style, 2 Cor. 11:23*
παραχειμάζω: to winter, spend the winter, Acts 27:12; 28:11; 1 Cor. 16:6; Tit. 3:12*
παραχειμασία: a wintering in a place, Acts 27:12*
παρεδρεύω: to sit near; to attend, serve, 1 Cor. 9:13*
πάρειμι: to be beside; to be present, Lk. 13:1; to have come, Mt. 26:50; Jn. 7:6; 11:28; Col. 1:6; to be in possession, Heb. 13:5; 2 Pet. 1:9, 12; part. παρών, οῦσα, όν, present, 1 Cor. 5:3; τὸ παρόν, the present time, the present, Heb. 12:11
παρείσακτος: secretly introduced, brought in stealthily, Gal. 2:4*
παρεισέρχομαι: to supervene, Rom. 5:20; to steal in, Gal. 2:4*
παρεισφέρω: to bring in beside; to bring into play, exhibit in addition, 2 Pet. 1:5*
παρεκτός: can function as an improper prep., without, on the outside; except, Mt. 5:32; Acts 26:29; τὰ παρεκτός, other matters, 2 Cor. 11:28
παρεμβάλλω: to cast up, set up, throw up a palisade, Lk. 19:43*
παρεμβολή: an insertion besides; later, a marshalling of an army; an array of battle, army, Heb. 11:34; a camp, Heb. 13:11, 13; Rev. 20:9; a standing camp, fortress, citadel, castle, Acts 21:34, 37; 22:24; 23:10, 16, 32*
παρεπίδημος: residing in a country not one’s own, a sojourner, stranger, Heb. 11:13; 1 Pet. 1:1; 2:11*
παρέρχομαι: to pass beside, pass along, pass by, Mt. 8:28; Mk. 6:48; to pass, elapse, as time, Mt. 14:15; Acts 27:19; to pass away, be removed, Mt. 26:39, 42; Mk. 14:35; met. to pass away, disappear, vanish, perish, Mt. 5:18; 24:34, 35; to become vain, be rendered void, Mt. 5:18; Mk. 13:31; trans. to pass by, disregard, neglect, Lk. 11:42; 15:29; to come to the side of, come to, Lk. 12:37; 17:7
πάρεσις: a letting pass; a passing over, Rom. 3:25*
παρέχω: to hold beside; to hold out to, offer, present, Lk. 6:29; to confer, render, Lk. 7:4; Acts 22:2; 28:2; Col. 4:1; to afford, furnish, Acts 16:16; 17:31; 19:24; 1 Tim. 6:17; to exhibit, Tit. 2:7; to be the cause of, occasion, Mt. 26:10; Mk. 14:6; Lk. 11:7
παρθένος: a virgin, maid, Mt. 1:23; 25:1, 7, 11; Acts 21:9; in NT also masc., chaste, Rev. 14:4
Πάρθοι: a Parthian, a native of Parthia, in central Asia, Acts 2:9
παρίημι: to let pass beside, let fall beside; to relax, Lk. 11:42; perf. pass. part. παρειμένος, hanging down helplessly, unstrung, feeble, Heb. 12:12*
παρίστημι: pluperfect, παρειστήκειν, also formed as παριστάνω, trans. to place beside; to have in readiness, provide, Acts 23:24; to range beside, to place at the disposal of, Mt. 26:53; Acts 9:41; to present to God, dedicate, consecrate, devote, Lk. 2:22; Rom. 6:13, 19; to prove, demonstrate, show, Acts 1:3; 24:13; to commend, recommend, 1 Cor. 8:8; intrans. perf. παρέστηκα, part. παρεστώς, pluperf. παρειστήκειν, 2 aor. παρέστην, and mid., to stand by or before, Acts 27:24; Rom. 14:10; to stand by, to be present, Mk. 14:47, 69, 70; to stand in attendance, attend, Lk. 1:19; 1:24; of time, to be present, have come, Mk. 4:29; to stand by in aid, assist, support, Rom. 16:2
πάροδος: a way by; a passing by; ἐν παρόδῳ, in passing, by the way, 1 Cor. 16:7*
παροικέω: to dwell beside; later, to reside in a place as a stranger, sojourn, be a stranger or sojourner, Lk. 24:18; Heb. 11:9*
παροικία: a sojourning, temporary residence in a foreign land, Acts 13:17; 1 Pet. 1:17*
πάροικος: a neighbor; later, a sojourner, temporary resident, stranger, Acts 7:6, 29; Eph. 2:19; 1 Pet. 2:11*
παροιμία: a by-word, proverb, adage, 2 Pet. 2:22; in NT an obscure saying, enigma, Jn. 16:25, 29; a parable, similitude, figurative discourse, Jn. 10:6*
πάροινος: pr. pertaining to wine, drunken; hence, quarrelsome, insolent, overbearing, 1 Tim. 3:3; Tit. 1:7*
παροίχομαι: to have gone by; perf. part. παρῳχημένος, by-gone, Acts 14:16*
παρομοιάζω: to be like, to resemble, Mt. 23:27*
παροξύνω: to sharpen; met. to incite, stir up, Acts 17:16; to irritate, provoke, 1 Cor. 13:5*
παροξυσμός: an inciting, incitement, Heb. 10:24; a sharp fit of anger, sharp contention, angry dispute, Acts 15:39*
παροργίζω: to provoke to anger, irritate, exasperate, Rom. 10:19; Eph. 6:4*
παροργισμός: provocation to anger; anger excited, indignation, wrath, Eph. 4:26*
παροτρύνω: to stir up, incite, instigate, Acts 13:50*
παρουσία: presence, 2 Cor. 10:10; Phil. 2:12; a coming, arrival, advent, Phil. 1:26; Mt. 24:3, 27, 37, 39; 1 Cor. 15:23
παροψίς: pr. a dainty side dish; meton. a plate, platter, Mt. 23:25*
παρρησία: freedom in speaking, boldness of speech, Acts 4:13; παρρησίᾳ, as an adv., freely, boldly, Jn. 7:13, 26; so μετὰ παρρησίας, Acts 2:29; 4:29, 31; license, authority, Phlm. 8; confidence, assurance, 2 Cor. 7:4; Eph. 3:12; Heb. 3:6; 10:19; openness, frankness, 2 Cor. 3:12; παρρησίᾳ, and ἐν παρρησίᾳ, adverbially, openly, plainly, perspicuously, unambiguously, Mk. 8:32; Jn. 10:24; publicly, before all, Jn. 7:4
παρρησιάζομαι: to speak plainly, freely, boldly, and confidently, Acts 13:46; 14:3
πᾶς: all; in the sg. the whole, entire, usually when the substantive has the article, Mt. 6:29; 8:32; Acts 19:26; every, only with an anarthrous subst., Mt. 3:10; 4:4; pl. all, Mt. 1:17, et al. freq.; πάντα, in all respects, Acts 20:35; 1 Cor. 9:25; 10:33; 11:2; by a Hebraism, a negative with πᾶς is sometimes equivalent to οὐδείς or μηδείς, Mt. 24:22; Lk. 1:37; Acts 10:14; Rom. 3:20; 1 Cor. 1:29; Eph. 4:29
πάσχα: the passover, the paschal lamb, Mt. 26:17; Mk. 14:12; met. used of Christ, the true paschal lamb, 1 Cor. 5:7; the feast of the passover, the day on which the paschal lamb was slain and eaten, the 14th of Nisan, Mt. 26:18; Mk. 14:1; Heb. 11:28; more genr. the whole paschal festival, including the seven days of the feast of unleavened bread, Mt. 26:2; Lk. 2:41; Jn. 2:13
πάσχω: to be affected by a thing, whether good or bad, to suffer, endure evil, Mt. 16:21; 17:12, 15; 27:19; absol. to suffer death, Lk. 22:15; 24:26
Πάταρα: Patara, a city on the seacoast of Lycia, in Asia Minor, Acts 21:1*
πατάσσω: to strike, beat upon; to smite, wound, Mt. 26:51; Lk. 22:49, 50; by impl. to kill, slay, Mt. 26:31; Mk. 14:27; Acts 7:24; to strike gently, Acts 12:7; from the Hebrew, to smite with disease, plagues, etc., Acts 12:23; Rev. 11:6; 19:15*
πατέω: intrans. to tread, Lk. 10:19; trans. to tread the winepress, Rev. 14:20; 19:15; to trample, Lk. 21:24; Rev. 11:2*
πατήρ: a father, Mt. 2:22; 4:21, 22; spc. used of God, as the Father of man by creation, preservation, etc., Mt. 5:16, 45, 48; and peculiarly as the Father of our Lord Jesus Christ, Mt. 7:21; 2 Cor. 1:3; the founder of a race, remote progenitor, forefather, ancestor, Mt. 3:9; 23:30, 32; an elder, senior, father in age, 1 Jn. 2:13, 14; a spiritual father, 1 Cor. 4:15; father by origination, Jn. 8:44; Heb. 12:9; used as an appellation of honor, Mt. 23:9; Acts 7:2
Πάτμος: Patmos, an island in the Aegean sea, Rev. 1:9*
πατριά: descent, lineage; a family, tribe, race, Lk. 2:4; Acts 3:25; Eph. 3:15*
πατριάρχης: a patriarch, head or founder of a family, Acts 2:29; 7:8, 9; Heb. 7:4*
πατρικός: from fathers or ancestors, ancestral, paternal, Gal. 1:14*
πατρίς: one’s native place, country, or city, Mt. 13:54, 57; Mk. 6:1, 4; Lk. 4:23, 24; Jn. 4:44; a heavenly country, Heb. 11:14*
πατρολῴας: also spelled πατραλῴας, one who kills one’s father, a patricide, 1 Tim. 1:9*
πατροπαράδοτος: handed down or received by tradition from one’s fathers or ancestors, 1 Pet. 1:18*
πατρῷος: received from one’s ancestors, paternal, ancestral, Acts 22:3; 24:14; 28:17*
Παῦλος: Paulus, Paul, pr. name. (1) Paul, the Apostle, Acts 13:9, et al. freq. (2) Sergius Paulus, the deputy or proconsul of Cyprus, Acts 13:7
παύω: to cause to pause or cease, restrain, prohibit, 1 Pet. 3:10; mid. perf. πέπαυται, to cease, stop, leave off, desist, refrain, 1 Pet. 4:1
Πάφος: Paphos, the chief city in the island of Cyprus. See PhotoGuide.
παχύνω: to fatten, make gross; met. pass. to be rendered gross, dull, unfeeling, Mt. 13:15; Acts 28:27*
πεζεύω: pr. to travel on foot; to travel by land, Acts 20:13*
πεζῇ: on foot, or, by land, Mt. 14:13; Mk. 6:33
πειθαρχέω: to obey one in authority, Acts 5:29, 32; Tit. 3:1; genr. to obey, follow, or conform to advice, Acts 27:21*
πειθός: also spelled πιθός, persuasive, skillful, 1 Cor. 2:4*
πείθω: pluperfect, ἐπεποίθειν, to persuade, seek to persuade, endeavor to convince, Acts 18:4; 19:8, 26; 28:23; to persuade, influence by persuasion, Mt. 27:20; Acts 13:43; 26:28; to incite, instigate, Acts 14:19; to appease, render tranquil, to quiet, 1 Jn. 3:19; to strive to conciliate, aspire to the favor of, Gal. 1:10; to pacify, conciliate, win over, Mt. 28:14; Acts 12:20; pass. and mid. to be persuaded of, be confident of, Lk. 20:6; Rom. 8:38; Heb. 6:9; to suffer one’s self to be persuaded, yield to persuasion, to be induced, Acts 21:14; to be convinced, to believe, yield belief, Lk. 16:31; Acts 17:4; to assent, listen to, obey, follow, Acts 5:36, 37, 40; 2 perf. πέποιθα, to be assured, be confident, 2 Cor. 2:3; Phil. 1:6; Heb. 13:18; to confide in, trust, rely on, place hope and confidence in, Mt. 27:43; Mk. 10:24; Rom. 2:19
πεινάω: to hunger, be hungry, Mt. 4:2; Mk. 11:12; to be exposed to hunger, be famished, 1 Cor. 4:11; Phil. 4:12; met. to hunger after, desire earnestly, long for, Mt. 5:6
πεῖρα: a trial, attempt, endeavor; λαμβάνειν πεῖραν, to attempt, Heb. 11:29; also, to experience, Heb. 11:36*
πειράζω: to make proof or trial of, put to the proof, whether with good or mischievous intent, Mt. 16:1; 22:35; absol. to attempt, Acts 16:7; 24:6; in NT to tempt, Mt. 4:1; to try, subject to trial, 1 Cor. 10:13
πειρασμός: a putting to the proof, proof, trial, 1 Pet. 4:12; Heb. 3:8; direct temptation to sin, Lk. 4:13; trial, temptation, Mt. 6:13; 26:41; 1 Cor. 10:13; trial, calamity, affliction, Lk. 22:28
πειράω: to try, attempt, essay, endeavor, Acts 26:21*
πεισμονή: a yielding to persuasion, assent, Gal. 5:8*
πέλαγος: the deep, the open sea, Mt. 18:6; a sea, distinguished from the sea in general, and named from an adjacent country, Acts 27:5*
πελεκίζω: to strike or cut with an axe; to behead, Rev. 20:4*
πέμπω: to send, to despatch on any message, embassy, business, etc., Mt. 2:8; 11:2; 14:10; to transmit, Acts 11:29; Rev. 1:11; to dismiss, permit to go, Mk. 5:12; to send in or among, 2 Thess. 2:11; to thrust in, or put forth, Rev. 14:15, 18
πένης: pr. one who labors for his bread; poor, needy, 2 Cor. 9:9*
πενθέω: trans. to lament over, 2 Cor. 12:21; absol. to lament, be sad, mourn, Mt. 5:4; 9:15; Mk. 16:10; mid. to bewail one’s self, to feel guilt, 1 Cor. 5:2
πεντακισχίλιοι: five times one thousand, five thousand, Mt. 14:21; 16:9
πεντηκοστή: Pentecost, or the Feast of Weeks; one of the three great Jewish festivals, so called because it was celebrated on the fiftieth day, reckoning from the second day of the feast of unleavened bread, i.e., from the 16th day of Nisan, Acts 2:1; 20:16; 1 Cor. 16:8*
πέραν: can function as an improper prep., across, beyond, over, on the other side, Mt. 4:15, 25; 19:1; Jn. 6:1, 17; ὁ, ἡ, τό, πέραν, farther, on the farther side, and τὸ πέραν, the farther side, the other side, Mt. 8:18, 28; 14:22
πέρας: an extremity, end, Mt. 12:42; Lk. 11:31; Rom. 10:18; an end, conclusion, termination, Heb. 6:16*
Πέργαμος: Pergamus, a city of Mysia, in Asia Minor, Rev. 1:11; 2:12*. See PhotoGuide.
Πέργη: Perga, the chief city of Pamphylia, in Asia Minor, Acts 13:13f.; 14:25. See PhotoGuide.
περί: pr. of place, (1) gen., about, around; about, concerning, respecting, Mt. 2:8; 11:10; 22:31; Jn. 8:18; Rom. 8:3, et al. freq.; (2) acc., of place, about, around, round about, Mt. 3:4; Mk. 3:34; Lk. 13:8; οἱ περί τινα, the companions of a person, Lk. 22:49; a person and his companions, Acts 13:13; simply a person, Jn. 11:19; τὰ περί τινα, the condition, circumstances of any one, Phil. 2:23; of time, about, Mt. 20:3, 5, 6, 9; about, concerning, respecting, touching, Lk. 10:40; 1 Tim. 1:19; 6:21; Tit. 2:7
περιάγω: to lead around, carry about Acts 13:11 in one’s company, 1 Cor. 9:5; to traverse, Mt. 4:23; 9:35; 23:15; Mk. 6:6
περιαιρέω: to take off, lift off, remove, 2 Cor. 3:16; to cast off, Acts 27:40; met. to cut off hope, Acts 27:20; met. to take away sin, remove the guilt of sin, make expiation for sin, Heb. 10:11
περιάπτω: to light a fire, kindle, Lk. 22:55*
περιαστράπτω: to lighten around, shine like lightning around, Acts 9:3; 22:6*
περιβάλλω: to cast around; to clothe, Mt. 25:36, 38, 43; mid. to clothe one’s self, to be clothed, Mt. 6:29, 31; Lk. 23:11; Jn. 19:2; Acts 12:8; Rev. 4:4
περιβλέπω: trans. to look around upon, Mk. 3:5, 34; 11:11; Lk. 6:10; absol. to look around, Mk. 5:32; 9:8; 10:23*
περιβόλαιον: that which is thrown around any one, clothing, covering; a cloak, Heb. 1:12; a covering, 1 Cor. 11:15*
περιδέω: pluperfect, περιεδέδετο (pass., 3 sg), to bind round about; pass. to be bound around, be bound up, Jn. 11:44*
περιεργάζομαι: to do a thing with excessive or superfluous care; to be a busybody, 2 Thess. 3:11*
περίεργος: over careful; officious, a busybody, 1 Tim. 5:13; in NT περίεργα, magic arts, sorcery, Acts 19:19*
περιέρχομαι: to go about, wander about, rove, Acts 19:13; Heb. 11:37; to go about, visit from house to house, 1 Tim. 5:13*
περιέχω: to encompass, enclose; met. to encompass, seize on the mind, Lk. 5:9; περιέχει, impers. it is contained, it is among the contents of a writing, 1 Pet. 2:6*
περιζώννυμι: also spelled περιζωννύω, to bind around with a girdle, gird; in NT mid. to gird one’s self in preparation for bodily motion and exertion, Lk. 12:37; 17:8; to wear a girdle, Rev. 1:13; 15:6
περίθεσις: a putting on, wearing of dress, etc., 1 Pet. 3:3*
περιίστημι: to place around; intrans. 2 aor. περιέστην, perf. part. περιεστώς, to stand around, Jn. 11:42; Acts 25:7; mid. to keep aloof from, avoid, shun, 2 Tim. 2:16; Tit. 3:9*
περικάθαρμα: pr. filth; met. refuse, outcast, 1 Cor. 4:13*
περικαλύπτω: to cover round about, cover over; to cover the face, Mk. 14:65; to blindfold, Lk. 22:64; pass. to be overlaid, Heb. 9:4*
περίκειμαι: to lie around, be surround, Heb. 12:1; to be hung around, Mk. 9:42; Lk. 17:2; to have around one’s self, to wear, Acts 28:20; to be in submission to, Heb. 5:2*
περικρατής: overpowering; περικρατὴς γενέσθαι, to become master of, to secure, Acts 27:16*
περικρύβω: also spelled περικρύπτω, to hide or keep from sight, to conceal by envelopment; to conceal, Lk. 1:24*
περιλείπομαι: to leave remaining; pass. to remain, survive, 1 Thess. 4:15, 17*
περίλυπος: greatly grieved, exceedingly sorrowful, Mt. 26:38; Mk. 14:34
περιοικέω: to dwell around, or in the vicinity; to be a neighbor, Lk. 1:65*
περίοικος: one who dwells in the vicinity, a neighbor, Lk. 1:58*
περιοχή: lit., a compass, circumference, contents; fig., a section, a portion of Scripture, Acts 8:32*
περιπατέω: pluperfect, περι[ε]πεπατήκει (3 sg), to walk, walk about, Mt. 9:5; 11:5; 14:25, 26, 29; to rove, roam, 1 Pet. 5:8; with μετά, to accompany, follow, Jn. 6:66; Rev. 3:4; to walk, frequent a locality, Jn. 7:1; 11:54; from the Hebrew, to maintain a certain walk of life and conduct, Gal. 5:16; Eph. 2:10
περιπείρω: to put on a spit, transfix; met. to pierce, wound deeply, 1 Tim. 6:10*
περιπίπτω: to fall around or upon, to fall in with, Lk. 10:30; to fall into, light upon, Acts 27:41; to be involved in, Jas. 1:2*
περιποιέω: to cause to remain over and above, to reserve, save, Lk. 17:33; mid. to acquire, gain, earn, 1 Tim. 3:13; to purchase, Acts 20:28*
περιποίησις: a laying up, keeping; an acquiring or obtaining, acquisition, 1 Thess. 5:9; 2 Thess. 2:14; a saving, preservation, Heb. 10:39; a peculiar possession, specialty, Eph. 1:14; 1 Pet. 2:9*
περιρήγνυμι: also spelled περιρρήγνυμι, to break or tear all around; to strip off, Acts 16:22*
περισπάω: to draw off from around; to wheel about; to distract; pass. to be distracted, over busied, Lk. 10:40*
περίσσευμα: more than enough, residue over and above, Mk. 8:8; abundance, exuberance, Mt. 12:34; Lk. 6:45; superabundance, affluence, 2 Cor. 8:14*
περισσεύω: to be over and above, to be superfluous, Mt. 14:20; Mk. 12:44; Lk. 21:4; to exist in full quantity, to abound, be abundant, Rom. 5:15; 2 Cor. 1:5; to increase, be augmented, Acts 16:5; to be advanced, be rendered more prominent, Rom. 3:7; of persons, to be abundantly gifted, richly furnished, abound, Lk. 15:17; Rom. 15:13; 1 Cor. 14:12; 2 Cor. 8:7; to be possessed of a full sufficiency, Phil. 4:12, 18; to abound in performance, 1 Cor. 15:58; to be a gainer, 1 Cor. 8:8; in NT trans., to cause to be abundant, 2 Cor. 4:15; 9:8; Eph. 1:8; to cause to be abundantly furnished, cause to abound, 1 Thess. 3:12; pass. to be gifted with abundance, Mt. 13:12; 25:29
περισσός: over and above, Mt. 5:37; superfluous, 2 Cor. 9:1; extraordinary, Mt. 5:47; compar. more, greater, Mt. 11:9; 23:14; excessive, 2 Cor. 2:7; adverbially, περισσόν, in full abundance, Jn. 10:10; περισσότερον, and ἐκ περισσοῦ, exceedingly, vehemently, Mk. 6:51; 7:36; 1 Cor. 15:10; Eph. 3:20; τὸ περισσόν, preeminence, advantage, Rom. 3:1
περισσότερος: comparative adj. from περισσός, greater, more, Mk. 12:40; Lk. 20:47; even more, Lk. 12:48; 1 Cor. 15:10; even more, so much more, Mk. 7:36
περισσοτέρως: more, more abundantly, more earnestly, more vehemently, 2 Cor. 7:13; exceedingly, Gal. 1:14
περισσῶς: much, abundantly, vehemently, Acts 26:11; more, more abundantly, Mt. 27:23; Mk. 10:26; 15:14*
περιτέμνω: to cut around; to circumcise, remove the prepuce, Lk. 1:59; 2:21; met. Col. 2:11; mid. to submit to circumcision, Acts 15:1
περιτίθημι: to place around, put about or around, Mt. 21:33; 27:28; met. to attach, bestow, 1 Cor. 12:23
περιτομή: circumcision, the act or custom of circumcision, Jn. 7:22, 23; Acts 7:8; the state of being circumcised, the being circumcised, Rom. 2:25, 26, 27; 4:10; meton. the circumcision, those who are circumcised, Rom. 3:30; 4:9 met. spiritual circumcision of the heart and affection, Rom. 2:29; Col. 2:11; meton. persons spiritually circumcised, Phil. 3:3 See circumcision.
περιτρέπω: to turn about; to bring round into any state, Acts 26:24*
περιτρέχω: to run about, run up and down, Mk. 6:55*
περιφέρω: to bear or carry about, Mk. 6:55; 2 Cor. 4:10; pass. to be borne about hither and thither, driven to and fro, Eph. 4:14*
περιφρονέω: to contemplate, reflect on; to despise, disregard, Tit. 2:15*
περίχωρος: neighboring; ἡ περίχωρος, i.e. γῆ, an adjacent region, country round about, Mt. 14:35; Mk. 1:28; meton. inhabitants of the region round about, Mt. 3:5
περίψημα: filth which is wiped off; met. 1 Cor. 4:13*
πέρυσι: last year, a year ago, 2 Cor. 8:10; 9:2*
πέτομαι: also spelled πετάομαι, to fly, Rev. 4:7; 8:13; 12:14; 14:6; 19:17*
πέτρα: a rock, Mt. 7:24, 25; met. Rom. 9:33; 1 Pet. 2:8; crags, clefts, Rev. 6:15, 16; stony ground, Lk. 8:6, 13
Πέτρος: a stone; in NT the Greek rendering of the surname Cephas, given to the Apostle Simon, and having, therefore, the same sense as πέτρα, Peter, Mt. 4:18; 8:14
πετρώδης: like rock; stony, rocky, Mt. 13:5, 20; Mk. 4:5, 16*
πήγανον: rue, a plant, ruta graveolens of Linnaeus, Lk. 11:42*
πηγή: a source, spring, fountain, Jas. 3:11, 12; a well, Jn. 4:6; an issue, flux, flow, Mk. 5:29; met. Jn. 4:14
