στηρίζω: to set fast; to set in a certain position or direction, Lk. 9:51; met. to render mentally steadfast, to settle, confirm, Lk. 22:32; Rom. 1:11; to stand immovable, Lk. 16:26; met. to be mentally settled, 2 Pet. 1:12
στιβάς: a stuffing of leaves, boughs, etc., meton. a bough, branch, Mk. 11:8*
στιγμή: pr. a point; met. a point of time, moment, instant, Lk. 4:5*
στίλβω: to shine, glisten, be radiant, Mk. 9:3*
στοά: a colonnade, cloister, covered walk supported by columns, Jn. 5:2; 10:23; Acts 3:11; 5:12*
στοιχεῖον: an element; an element of the natural universe, 2 Pet. 3:10, 12; an element or rudiment of any intellectual or religious system, Gal. 4:3, 9; Col. 2:8, 20; Heb. 5:12*
στοιχέω: pr. to advance in a line; met. to frame one’s conduct by a certain rule, Acts 21:24; Rom. 4:12; Gal. 5:25; 6:16; Phil. 3:16*
στολή: equipment; dress; a long garment, flowing robe, worn by priests, kings, and persons of distinction, Mt. 12:38; 16:5; Lk. 15:22; Rev. 6:11
στόμα: the mouth, Mt. 12:34; 15:11, 17, 18; 21:16; speech, words, Mt. 18:16; 2 Cor. 13:1; command of speech, facility of language, Lk. 21:15; from the Hebrew, ἀνοίγειν τὸ στόμα, to utter, to speak, Mt. 5:2, 13:35; also, used of the earth, to rend, yawn, Rev. 12:16; στόμα πρὸς στόμα λαλεῖν, to speak mouth to mouth, face to face, 2 Jn. 12; 3 Jn. 14; the edge or point of a weapon, Lk. 21:24; Heb. 11:34
στόμαχος: pr. the gullet leading to the stomach; hence, later, the stomach itself, 1 Tim. 5:23*
στρατεία: a military expedition, campaign; and genr. military service, warfare; met. the Christian warfare, 2 Cor. 10:4; fight, 1 Tim. 1:18*
στράτευμα: an army, Mt. 22:7; Rev. 19:14, 19; an armed force, corps, Acts 23:10, 27; troops, guards, Lk. 23:11; Rev. 9:16*
στρατηγός: a leader or commander of an army, general; a Roman praetor, provincial magistrate, Acts 16:20, 22, 35, 36, 38; στρατηγός τοῦ ἱεροῦ, the captain or prefect of the temple, the chief of the Levites who kept guard in and around the temple, Lk. 22:4, 52; Acts 4:1; 5:24, 26*
στρατιά: an army, host; from the Hebrew, στρατιὰ οὐράνιος, or τοῦ οὐρανοῦ, the heavenly host, the host of heaven, the hosts of angels, Lk. 2:13; the stars, Acts 7:42*
στρατιώτης: a soldier, Mt. 8:9; 27:27; met. a soldier of Christ, 2 Tim. 2:3
στρατολογέω: to collect or gather an army, enlist troops, 2 Tim. 2:4*
στρατόπεδον: pr. the site of an encampment; an encampment; meton. an army, Lk. 21:20*
στρεβλόω: pr. to distort the limbs on a rack; met. to wrench, distort, pervert, 2 Pet. 3:16*
στρέφω: to twist; to turn, Mt. 5:39; to make a change of substance, to change, Rev. 11:6; absol. to change or turn one’s course of dealing, Acts 7:42; mid. to turn one’s self about, Mt. 16:23; Lk. 7:9; to turn back, Acts 7:39; to change one’s direction, to turn elsewhere, Acts 13:46; to change one’s course of principle and conduct, to be converted, Mt. 18:3
στρηνιάω: to be wanton, to revel, riot, Rev. 18:7, 9*
στρουθίον: any small bird, spc. a sparrow, Mt. 10:29, 31; Lk. 12:6, 7*
στρωννύω: the thematic form of στρώννυμι, the μι form never being visible in the NT, to spread, to strew, Mt. 21:8; Mk. 11:8; to spread a couch, make your own bed, Acts 9:34; used of a supper-chamber, pass. to have the couches spread, to be prepared, furnished, Mk. 14:15; Lk. 22:12*
στυγνάζω: to put on a gloomy and downcast look, to be shocked, appalled, Mk. 10:22; of the sky, to lower, Mt. 16:3*
στῦλος: a pillar, column, Rev. 10:1; used of persons of authority, influence, etc., a support or pillar of the Church, Gal. 2:9; Rev. 3:12; a support of true doctrine, 1 Tim. 3:15*
σύ: you, gen., σοῦ, dat., σοί, acc., σέ, Mt. 1:20; 2:6
συγγένεια: kindred; kinsfolk, kinsmen, relatives, Lk. 1:61; Acts 7:3, 14*
συγγενής: kindred, akin; as a subst. a kinsman or kinswoman, relative; Mk. 6:4; Lk. 1:58; 2:44; 14:12; 21:16; Jn. 18:26; Acts 10:24; one nationally akin, a fellow countryman, Rom. 9:3; 16:7, 11, 21*
συγκάθημαι: to sit in company with, Mk. 14:54; Acts 26:30*
συγκαθίζω: trans. to cause to sit down with, seat in company with, Eph. 2:6; intrans. to sit in company with; to sit down together, Lk. 22:55*
συγκακοπαθέω: to suffer evils along with someone; to be enduringly adherent, 2 Tim. 1:8; 2:3*
συγκακουχέομαι: to encounter adversity along with any one, Heb. 11:25*
συγκαλέω: to call together, Mk. 15:16; Lk. 15:6, 9; Acts 5:21; mid. to call around one’s self, Lk. 9:1; 23:13; Acts 10:24; 28:17*
συγκαλύπτω: to cover completely, to cover up; met. to conceal, Lk. 12:2*
συγκάμπτω: to bend or bow together; to bow down the back of any one afflictively, Rom. 11:10*
συγκαταβαίνω: to go down with anyone, Acts 25:5*
συγκατάθεσις: assent; in NT accord, alliance, agreement, 2 Cor. 6:16*
συγκατατίθημι: to set down together with; mid. to agree, accord, Lk. 23:51*
συγκαταψηφίζομαι: to count, number with, be chosen together with, Acts 1:26*
συγκεράννυμι: pluperf., συνεκέκρατο (3 sg), to mix with, mingle together; to blend, 1 Cor. 12:24; pass. to be combined, united, Heb. 4:2*
συγκινέω: to agitate, put in turmoil; to excite, Acts 6:12*
συγκλείω: to shut up together, to hem in; to enclose, Lk. 5:6; met. to band under a sweeping sentence, Rom. 11:32; Gal. 3:22; pass. to be banded under a bar of disability, Gal. 3:23*
συγκληρονόμος: pr. a coheir, Rom. 8:17; a fellow participant, Eph. 3:6; Heb. 11:9; 1 Pet. 3:7*
συγκοινωνέω: to be a joint partaker, participate with a person; in NT to mix one’s self up in a thing, to involve one’s self, be an accomplice in, Eph. 5:11; Rev. 18:4; to sympathize actively in, to relieve, Phil. 4:14*
συγκοινωνός: one who partakes jointly; a coparticipant, Rom. 11:17; a copartner in service, fellow, 1 Cor. 9:23; Phil. 1:7; a sharer, 1 Cor. 9:23; Rev. 1:9*
συγκομίζω: to prepare for burial, take charge of the funeral of any one, bury, Acts 8:2*
συγκρίνω: to combine, compound; to compare, to estimate by comparing with something else, or, to match, 2 Cor. 10:12 (2x); to explain, to illustrate, or, to suit, 1 Cor. 2:13*
συγκύπτω: to bend or bow together; to be bowed together, bent over, Lk. 13:11*
συγκυρία: concurrence, coincidence, chance, accident; κατὰ συγκρυίαν, by chance, accidentally, Lk. 10:31*
συγχαίρω: to rejoice with any one, sympathize in joy, Lk. 1:58; 15:6, 9; Phil. 2:17, 18; met. 1 Cor. 12:26; to sympathize in the advancement of, congratulate, 1 Cor. 13:6*
συγχέω: to pour together, mingle by pouring together; hence, to confound, perplex, amaze, Acts 2:6; to confound in dispute, Acts 9:22; to throw into confusion, fill with uproar, Acts 19:32; 21:27, 31*
συγχράομαι: use in common; associate with, have dealings with, Jn. 4:9*
σύγχυσις: pr. a pouring together; hence, confusion, commotion, tumult, uproar, Acts 19:29*
συζάω: to live with; to continue in life with someone, 2 Cor. 7:3; to coexist in life with another, Rom. 6:8; 2 Tim. 2:11*
συζεύγνυμι: to join together; trop. join together, unite, Mt. 19:6; Mk. 10:9*
συζητέω: to seek, ask, or inquire with another; to deliberate, debate, Mk. 1:27; 9:10; Lk. 24:15; to hold discourse with, argue, reason, Mk. 8:11; 12:28; Lk. 22:23; Acts 6:9; 9:29; to question, dispute, quibble, Mk. 9:14, 16*
συζητητής: a disputant, controversial reasoner, sophist, 1 Cor. 1:20*
σύζυγος: an associate, comrade, fellow laborer, or it could be the person’s name, Phil. 4:3*
συζωοποιέω: to make alive together with another; to make a sharer in the quickening of another, Eph. 2:5; Col. 2:13*
συκάμινος: a sycamore tree, mulberry tree, i.q. συκομοραία, q.v., Lk. 17:6*
συκομορέα: the fig mulberry tree, sycamore fig, Lk. 19:4*
σῦκον: a fig, a ripe fig, Mt. 7:16; Mk. 11:13; Lk. 6:44; Jas. 3:12*
συκοφαντέω: to inform against; to accuse falsely; by impl. to wrong by false accusations; to extort money by false informations, Lk. 3:14; 19:8*
συλαγωγέω: to carry off as a prey or booty; met. to make victims of fraud, Col. 2:8*
συλλαλέω: to talk, converse, or discuss with, Mt. 17:3; Mk. 9:4; Lk. 4:36; 9:30; 22:4; Acts 25:12*
συλλαμβάνω: to catch; to seize, apprehend, Mt. 26:55; Acts 1:16; to catch, as prey, Lk. 5:9; to conceive, become pregnant, Lk. 1:24, 31, 36; 2:21; met. Jas. 1:15; mid. to help, aid, assist, Lk. 5:7; Phil. 4:3
συλλογίζομαι: to reason together; to consider, deliberate, reason, Lk. 20:5*
συλλυπέω: to be grieved together with; to be grieved, Mk. 3:5*
συμβαίνω: to step or come together; to happen, meet, fall out, Mk. 10:32; Lk. 24:14 ; Acts 3:10; 20:19; 21:35; 1 Cor. 10:11; 1 Pet. 4:12; 2 Pet. 2:22*
συμβάλλω: pr. to throw together; absol. to meet and join, Acts 20:14; to meet in war, to encounter, engage with, Lk. 14:31; to encounter in discourse or dispute, Acts 17:18; to consult together, Acts 4:15; mid. to contribute, be of service to, to aid, Acts 18:27; συμβάλλειν ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ, to revolve in mind, ponder upon, Lk. 2:19*
συμβασιλεύω: to reign with; met. to enjoy honor with, 1 Cor. 4:8; 2 Tim. 2:12*
συμβιβάζω: pr. to cause to come together; to unite, knit together, Eph. 4:16; Col. 2:2, 19; to infer, conclude, Acts 16:10; by impl. to prove, demonstrate, Acts 9:22; in NT to teach, instruct, Acts 19:33; 1 Cor. 2:16*
συμβουλεύω: to counsel, advise, exhort, Jn. 18:14; Rev. 3:18; mid. to consult together, plot, Mt. 26:4; Acts 9:23*
συμβούλιον: counsel, consultation, mutual consultation, Mt. 12:14; 22:15; 27:1, 7; 28:12; Mk. 3:6; Acts 27:1, 7; 28:12; a council of counsellors, Acts 25:12*
σύμβουλος: a counsellor; advisor, one who shares one’s counsel, Rom. 11:34*
Συμεών: Symeon, Simeon, pr. name. indecl. (1) Simeon, son of Juda, Lk. 3:30. (2) Simeon, son of Jacob, Rev. 7:7. (3) Simeon, a prophet of Jerusalem, Lk. 2:25, 34. (4) Simeon, or Simon Peter, Acts 15:14; 2 Pet. 1:1. (5) Simeon, called Niger, Acts 13:1*
συμμαρτυρέω: to testify or bear witness together with another, confirm, add testimony, Rom. 2:15; 8:16; 9:1*
συμμερίζω: to divide with another so as to receive a part to one’s self, share with, partake with, 1 Cor. 9:13*
συμμέτοχος: a partaker with any one, a joint partaker, Eph. 3:6; 5:7*
συμμιμητής: an imitator together with any one, a joint imitator, Phil. 3:17*
συμμορφίζω: to conform to, take on the same form as, Phil. 3:10*
σύμμορφος: of like form, assimilated, conformed, similar in form, Rom. 8:29; Phil. 3:21*
συμπαθέω: to sympathize with, Heb. 4:15; to be compassionate, Heb. 10:34*
συμπαραγίνομαι: to be present together with; to come together, convene, Lk. 23:48*
συμπαρακαλέω: to invite, exhort along with others; pass. to share in mutual encouragement, Rom. 1:12*
συμπαραλαμβάνω: to take along with, take as a companion, Acts 12:25; 15:37, 38; Gal. 2:1*
συμπάρειμι: to be present with any one, Acts 25:24*
συμπάσχω: to suffer with, sympathize, 1 Cor. 12:26; to suffer as another, endure corresponding sufferings, Rom. 8:17*
συμπέμπω: to send with any one, 2 Cor. 8:18, 22*
συμπεριλαμβάνω: to embrace together; to embrace, Acts 20:10*
συμπίνω: to drink with any one, Acts 10:41*
συμπληρόω: to fill, fill up, Lk. 8:23; pass., of time, to be completed, have fully come, Lk. 9:51; Acts 2:1*
συμπνίγω: to throttle, choke; trop. to choke the growth or increase of seed or plants, Mt. 13:22; Mk. 4:7, 19; Lk. 8:14; to press upon, crowd, Lk. 8:42*
συμπορεύομαι: to go with, accompany, Lk. 7:11; 14:25; 24:15; to come together, assemble, Mk. 10:1*
συμπόσιον: a drinking together; a feast, banquet; a festive company; in NT, pl. συμπόσια, eating party, Mk. 6:39 (2x)*
συμπρεσβύτερος: a fellow elder, fellow presbyter, 1 Pet. 5:1*
συμφέρω: to bring together, collect, Acts 19:19; absol. be for the benefit of any one, be profitable, advantageous, expedient, 1 Cor. 6:12; to suit best, be appropriate, 2 Cor. 8:10; good, benefit, profit, advantage, Acts 20:20; 1 Cor. 7:35; it is profitable, advantageous, expedient, Mt. 5:29, 30; 19:10
συμφυλέτης: pr. one of the same tribe; a fellow citizen, fellow countryman, 1 Thess. 2:14*
σύμφυτος: pr. planted together, grown together; in NT met. grown together, closely entwined or united with, Rom. 6:5*
συμφύω: to make to grow together; pass. to grow or spring up with, Lk. 8:7*
συμφωνέω: to sound together, to be in unison, be in accord; trop. to agree with, accord with in purport, Acts 15:15; to harmonize with, suit with, Lk. 5:36; to agree with, make an agreement, Mt. 18:19; 20:2, 13; Acts 5:9*
συμφωνία: symphony, harmony of sounds, concert of instruments, music, Lk. 15:25*
σύμφωνος: agreeing in sound; met. harmonious, agreeing, accord, agreement, 1 Cor. 7:5*
συμψηφίζω: to calculate together, compute, reckon up, Acts 19:19*
σύμψυχος: united in mind, at unity, Phil. 2:2
σύν: with, together with, Mt. 25:27; 26:35; 27:38; attendant on, 1 Cor. 15:10; besides, Lk. 24:21; with, with the assistance of, 1 Cor. 5:4; with, in the same manner as, Gal. 3:9; εἶναι σύν τινι, to be with any one, to be in company with, accompany, Lk. 2:13; 8:38; to be on the side of, be a partisan of any one, Acts 4:13; 14:4; οἱ σύν τινι, those with any one, the companions of any one, Mk. 2:26; Acts 22:9; the colleagues, associates of any one, Acts 5:17, 21
συνάγω: to bring together, collect, gather, as grain, fruits, etc., Mt. 3:12 6:26; 13:30, 47; to collect an assembly; pass. to convene, come together, meet, Mt. 2:4; 13:2; 18:20; 22:10; in NT to receive with kindness and hospitality, to entertain, Mt. 25:35, 38, 43
συναγωγή: a collecting, gathering; a Christian assembly or congregation, Jas. 2:2; the congregation of a synagogue, Acts 9:2; hence, the place itself, a synagogue, Lk. 7:5
συναγωνίζομαι: to combat in company with any one; to exert one’s strength with, to be earnest in aiding, help, Rom. 15:30*
συναθλέω: pr. to fight or work on the side of any one; in NT to cooperate vigorously with a person, Phil. 4:3; to make effort in the cause of, in support of a thing, Phil. 1:27*
συναθροίζω: to gather; to bring together, Acts 19:25; pass. to come together, convene, Acts 12:12*
συναίρω: to take up a thing with any one; in NT συναίρειν λόγον, to settle accounts, reckon in order to payment, Mt. 18:23, 24; 25:19*
συναιχμάλωτος: a fellow captive, Rom. 16:7; Col. 4:10; Phlm. 23*
συνακολουθέω: to follow in company with, accompany, Mk. 5:37; 14:51; Lk. 23:49*
συναλίζω: to cause to come together, collect, assemble, congregate; mid. to convene to one’s self, Acts 1:4*
συναλλάσσω: to negotiate or bargain with someone; to reconcile, Acts 7:26*
συναναβαίνω: to go up, ascend with someone, Mk. 15:41; Acts 13:31*
συνανάκειμαι: to recline with someone at table, Mt. 9:10; 14:9; Mk. 2:15; 6:22; Lk. 7:49; 14:10, 15*
συναναπαύομαι: to experience refreshment or rest in company with someone, Rom. 15:32*
συναντάω: to meet with, fall in with, encounter, Lk. 9:37; 22:10; Acts 10:25; Heb. 7:1, 10; to occur, happen to, befall, Acts 20:22*
συναντιλαμβάνομαι: pr. to take hold of with someone; to support, help, aid, Lk. 10:40; Rom. 8:26*
συναπάγω: to lead or carry away with; to seduce; pass. to be led away
συναποθνῄσκω: to die together with any one, Mk. 14:31; 2 Cor. 7:3; met. to die with, in respect of a spiritual likeness, 2 Tim. 2:11*
συναπόλλυμι: to destroy together with others; mid. to perish or be destroyed with others, Heb. 11:31*
συναποστέλλω: to send forth together with someone, 2 Cor. 12:18*
συναρμολογέω: to join together fitly, fit or frame together, compact, Eph. 2:21; 4:16*
συναρπάζω: pluperf., συνηρπάκειν, to snatch up, clutch; to seize and carry off suddenly, Acts 6:12; to seize with force and violence, Lk. 8:29; Acts 19:29; pass. of a ship, to be caught and swept on by the wind, Acts 27:15*
συναυξάνω: pass., to grow together in company, Mt. 13:30*
σύνδεσμος: that which binds together, Col. 2:19; a band of union, Eph. 4:3; Col. 3:14; a bundle, or, bond, Acts 8:23*
συνδέω: to bind together; in NT pass. to be in bonds together, Heb. 13:3*
συνδοξάζω: in NT to glorify together with, to exalt to a state of dignity and happiness in company with, to make to partake in the glorification of another, Rom. 8:17*
σύνδουλος: a fellow-slave, fellow-servant, Mt. 24:49; 18:28f., 31, 33; Col. 4:7; Rev. 6:11; 19:10; 22:9; a fellow-minister of Christ, Col. 1:7*
συνδρομή: a running together, forming a mob, Acts 21:30*
συνεγείρω: to raise up with any one; to raise up with Christ by spiritual resemblance of His resurrection, Eph. 2:6; Col. 2:12; 3:1*
συνέδριον: pr. a sitting together, assembly, etc., in NT the Sanhedrin, the supreme council of the Jewish nation, Mt. 5:22; 26:59; meton. the Sanhedrin, as including the members and place of meeting, Lk. 22:66; Acts 4:15; genr. a judicial council, tribunal, Mt. 10:17; Mk. 13:9
συνείδησις: consciousness, Heb. 10:2; a present idea, persisting notion, impression of reality, 1 Pet. 2:19; conscience, as an inward moral impression of one’s actions and principles, Acts 23:1; 24:16; Rom. 9:1; 2 Cor. 1:12; conscience, as the inward faculty of moral judgment, Rom. 2:15; 13:5; 1 Cor. 8:7b, 10, 12; 10:25, 27, 28, 29; 2 Cor. 4:2; 5:11; 1 Tim. 1:5, 19; 3:9; 4:2; 2 Tim. 1:3; conscience, as the inward moral and spiritual frame, Tit. 1:15; Heb. 9:9, 14; 10:22; 13:18; 1 Pet. 3:16, 21*
σύνειμι: from εἶμι, to come together, Lk. 8:4*
συνεισέρχομαι: to enter with someone, Jn. 18:15; to embark with, Jn. 6:22*
συνέκδημος: one who accompanies another to foreign countries, fellow traveller, Acts 19:29; 2 Cor. 8:19*
συνεκλεκτός: chosen along with others; elected to Gospel privileges along with, 1 Pet. 5:13*
συνεπιμαρτυρέω: to join in according testimony; to support by testimony, to confirm, sanction, Heb. 2:4*
συνεπιτίθημι: can also be spelled συνεπιτίθεμαι, mid., to set upon along with, join with others in an attack; to unite in impeaching, Acts 24:9*
συνέπομαι: to follow with, attend, accompany, Acts 20:4*
συνεργέω: to work together with, to cooperate, etc., 1 Cor. 16:16; 2 Cor. 6:1; to assist, afford aid to, Mk. 16:20; Jas. 2:22; absol. to conspire actively to a result, Rom. 8:28*
συνεργός: a fellow laborer, associate, helper, Rom. 16:3, 9, 21; 2 Cor. 1:24
συνέρχομαι: pluperf., συνεληλύθεισαν (3 pl), to come together; to assemble, Mk. 3:20; 6:33; 14:53; to cohabit matrimonially, Mt. 1:18; 1 Cor. 7:5; to go or come with any one, to accompany, Lk. 23:55; Acts 9:39; to company with, associate with, Acts 1:21
συνεσθίω: to eat with, Acts 10:41; 11:3; 1 Cor. 5:11; by impl. to associate with, live on familiar terms with, Lk. 15:2; Gal. 2:12*
σύνεσις: pr. a sending together, a junction, as of streams; met. understanding, intelligence, discernment, Lk. 2:47; 1 Cor. 1:19; meton. the understanding, intellect, mind, Mk. 12:33; Eph. 3:4; Col. 1:9; 2:2; 2 Tim. 2:7*
συνετός: intelligent, discerning, wise, prudent, Mt. 11:25; Lk. 10:21; Acts 13:7; 1 Cor. 1:19*
συνευδοκέω: to approve with another; to agree with in principle, Rom. 1:32; to stamp approval, Lk. 11:48; Acts 8:1; 22:20; to be willing, agreeable, 1 Cor. 7:12, 13*
συνευωχέομαι: to feast together with, 2 Pet. 2:13; Jude 12*
συνεφίστημι: to set together upon, join in an attack, Acts 16:22*
συνέχω: pr. to hold together; to confine, shut up, close; τὰ ὦτα, to stop the ears, Acts 7:57; to confine, as a besieged city, Lk. 19:43; to hold, hold fast, have the custody of any one, Lk. 22:63; to hem in, urge, press upon, Lk. 8:45; to exercise a constraining influence on, 2 Cor. 5:14; pass. to be seized with, be affected with, as fear, disease, etc., Mt. 4:24; Lk. 4:38; 8:37; Acts 28:8; to be in a state of mental constriction, to be hard pressed by urgency of circumstances, Lk. 12:50; Acts 18:5; Phil. 1:23*
συνήδομαι: to be pleased along with others; to congratulate; to delight in, approve cordially, Rom. 7:22*
συνήθεια: use, custom; an established custom, practice, Jn. 18:39; 1 Cor. 8:7; 11:16*
συνηλικιώτης: one of the same age, an equal in age, Gal. 1:14*
συνθάπτω: to bury with; pass. in NT to be buried with Christ symbolically, Rom. 6:4; Col. 2:12*
συνθλάω: to crush together; to break in pieces, shatter, Mt. 21:44; Lk. 20:18*
συνθλίβω: to press together; to press upon, crowd, Mk. 5:24, 31*
συνθρύπτω: to crush to pieces; met. to break the heart of any one, to make to recoil in fear, Acts 21:13*
συνίημι: also συνίω, see BDAG 972 for a discussion, pr. to send together; met. to understand, comprehend thoroughly, Mt. 13:51; Lk. 2:50; 18:34; 24:45; to perceive clearly, Mt. 16:12; 17:13; Acts 7:25; Rom. 15:21; Eph. 5:17; absol. to be well judging, sensible, 2 Cor. 10:12; to be spiritually intelligent, Mt. 13:13, 14, 15; Acts 28:26, 27; to be religiously wise, Rom. 3:11
συνίστημι: also spelled συνιστάνω and συνιστάω, to place together; to recommend to favorable attention, Rom. 16:1; 2 Cor. 3:1; 10:18; to place in a striking point of view, Rom. 3:5; 5:8; Gal. 2:18; to stand beside, Lk. 9:32; to have been permanently framed, Col. 1:17; to possess consistence, 2 Pet. 3:5
συνοδεύω: to journey or travel with, accompany on a journey, Acts 9:7*
συνοδία: pr. a journeying together; meton. a company of fellow travellers, caravan, Lk. 2:44*
σύνοιδα: a defective verb that is actually perfect in form but present in meaning, to share in the knowledge of a thing; to be privy to, Acts 5:2; to be conscious; οὐδέν σύνοιδα, to have a clear conscience, 1 Cor. 4:4*
συνοικέω: to dwell with; to live or cohabit with, 1 Pet. 3:7*
συνοικοδομέω: to build in company with someone; pass. to be built up, form a constituent part of a structure, Eph. 2:22*
συνομιλέω: pr. to be in company with; to talk or converse with, Acts 10:27*
συνομορέω: to be next to, be next door, Acts 18:7*
συνοράω: perceive, become aware of, realize, Acts 12:12; 14:6*
συνοχή: pr. a being held together; compression; in NT met. distress of mind, anxiety, Lk. 21:25; 2 Cor. 2:4
συντάσσω: pr. to arrange or place in order together; in NT to order, charge, direct, Mt. 21:6, 26:19; 27:10*
συντέλεια: a complete combination, a completion, consummation, end, Mt. 13:39, 40, 49; 24:3; 28:20; Heb. 9:26*
συντελέω: pr. to bring to an end altogether; to finish, end, Lk. 4:13; to consummate, Rom. 9:28; to ratify a covenant, Heb. 8:8; pass. to be terminated, Lk. 4:2; Acts 21:27; to be fully realized, Mk. 13:4*
συντέμνω: pr. to cut short, contract by cutting off; met. to execute speedily, or from the Hebrew, to determine, decide, decree, Rom. 9:28 (2x)*
συντηρέω: to keep safe and sound, Mt. 9:17; to observe strictly, or, to secure from harm, protect, Mk. 6:20; to preserve in memory, keep carefully in mind, Lk. 2:19*
συντίθημι: to agree together, come to a mutual understanding, Jn. 9:22; Acts 23:20; to bargain, to pledge one’s self, Lk. 22:5*
συντρέχω: to run together, flock together, Mk. 6:33; Acts 3:11; to run in company with others, met. 1 Pet. 4:4*
συντρίβω: to rub together; to shiver, Mk. 14:3; Rev. 2:27; to break, break in pieces, Mk. 5:4; Jn. 19:36; to break down, crush, bruise, Mt. 12:20; met. to break the power of any one, deprive of strength, debilitate, Lk. 9:39; Rom. 16:20*
σύντριμμα: a breaking, bruising; in NT destruction, ruin, Rom. 3:16*
σύντροφος: nursed with another; one brought up (NIV) or educated with another, intimate friend, friend of the court (RSV) Acts 13:1*
συντυγχάνω: to meet or fall in with; join, in NT to get to, approach, Lk. 8:19*
συνυποκρίνομαι: to dissemble, feign with, or in the same manner as another, join in the playing of the hypocrite, Gal. 2:13*
συνυπουργέω: to aid along with another, help together, 2 Cor. 1:11*
συνωδίνω: pr. to travail at the same time with; trop. suffer together, Rom. 8:22*
συνωμοσία: a banding by oath; a combination, conspiracy, Acts 23:13*
Συράκουσαι: Syracuse, a celebrated city of Sicily, Acts 28:12*
Συρία: Syria, an extensive country of Asia, Mt. 4:24; Lk. 2:2; Acts 15:23
Συροφοινίκισσα: a Syrophoenician woman, Phoenicia being included in Syria, Mk. 7:26*
Σύρτις: a shoal, sand-bank, a place dangerous on account of shoals, two of which were particularly famous on the northern coast of Africa, one lying near Carthage, and the other, the syrtis major, lying between Cyrene and Leptis, which is probably referred to in Acts 27:17*
σύρω: to draw, drag, Jn. 21:8; Rev. 12:4; to force away, hale before magistrates, etc., Acts 8:3; 14:19; 17:6*
συσπαράσσω: to tear to pieces; to convulse altogether, Mk. 9:20; Lk. 9:42*
σύσσωμος: united in the same body; met. pl. joint members in a spiritual body, Eph. 3:6*
συσταυρόω: to crucify with another, Mt. 27:44; Mk. 15:32; Jn. 19:32; pass. met. to be crucified with another in a spiritual resemblance, Rom. 6:6; Gal. 2:20*
συστέλλω: to draw together, contract, straiten; to enwrap; hence, i.q. περιστέλλω, to lay out, prepare for burial, Acts 5:6; pass. to be shortened, 1 Cor. 7:29*
συστενάζω: to groan or lament together, Rom. 8:22*
συστοιχέω: pr. to be in the same row with; met. to correspond to, Gal. 4:25*
συστρατιώτης: a fellow soldier, co-militant, in the service of Christ, Phil. 2:25; Phlm. 2*
συστρέφω: to turn or roll together; to collect, gather, Acts 28:3; Mt. 17:22*
συστροφή: a gathering, tumultuous assembly, Acts 19:40; a combination, conspiracy, Acts 23:12*
συσχηματίζω: to fashion in accordance with; mid/pass. to conform or assimilate one’s self to, met. Rom. 12:2; 1 Pet. 1:14*
Συχάρ: Sychar, indecl., a city of Samaria, Jn. 4:5*
Συχέμ: Shechem, indecl., fem., a city of Samaria, Acts 7:16*. See PhotoGuide.
σφάγιον: a victim slaughtered in sacrifice, offering, Acts 7:42*
σφάζω: also spelled σφάττω, to slaughter, kill, slay; pr. used of animals killed in sacrifice, etc., Rev. 5:6, 9, 12; 13:8; of persons, etc., 1 Jn. 3:12; Rev. 6:4, 9; 18:24; to wound mortally, Rev. 13:3*
σφόδρα: much, greatly, exceedingly, Mt. 2:10; 17:6; Mk. 16:4; Lk. 18:23; Acts 6:7
σφραγίζω: to seal, stamp with a seal, Mt. 27:66; Rev. 20:3; to seal up, to close up, conceal, Rev. 10:4; 22:10; to set a mark upon, distinguish by a mark, Eph. 1:13; 4:30; Rev. 7:3, 4, 5, 8; to seal, to mark distinctively as invested with a certain character, Jn. 6:27; mid. to set one’s own mark upon, seal as one’s own, to impress with a mark of acceptance, 2 Cor. 1:22; to deliver over safely to someone, Rom. 15:28; absol. to set to one’s seal, to make a solemn declaration, Jn. 3:33*
σφραγίς: a seal, a signet ring, Rev. 7:2; an inscription on a seal, motto, 2 Tim. 2:19; a seal, the impression of a seal, Rev. 5:1, 2, 5, 9, 6:1, 3, 5, 7, 9, 12; 8:1; a seal, a distinctive mark, Rev. 9:4; a seal, a token, proof, 1 Cor. 9:2; a token of guarantee, Rom. 4:11*
σχεδόν: pr. near, of place; hence, nearly, almost, Acts 13:44; 19:26; Heb. 9:22*
σχῆμα: fashion, form; fashion, external show, 1 Cor. 7:31; Phil. 2:7*
σχίζω: to split, Mt. 27:51; Mk. 15:38; to rend, tear asunder, Mt. 27:51; Lk. 5:36; 23:45; Jn. 19:24; 21:11); mid. to open or unfold with a chasm, Mk. 1:10; pass. met. to be divided into parties or factions, Acts 14:4; 23:7*
σχίσμα: a split, Mt. 9:16; Mk. 2:21; met. a division into parties, schism, Jn. 7:43; 9:16; 10:19; 1 Cor. 1:10; 11:18; 12:25*
σχοινίον: pr. a cord made of rushes; genr. a rope, cord, Jn. 2:15; Acts 27:32*
σχολάζω: to be unemployed, to be at leisure; to be at leisure for a thing, to devote one’s self entirely to a thing, 1 Cor. 7:5; to be unoccupied, empty, Mt. 12:44*
σχολή: freedom from occupation; later, ease, leisure; a school, Acts 19:9*
σῴζω: to save, rescue; to preserve safe and unharmed, Mark. 8:25; 10:22; 24:22; 27:40, 42, 49; 1 Tim. 2:15; σῴζειν εἰς, to bring safely to, 2 Tim. 4:18; to cure, heal, restore to health, Mt. 9:21, 22; Mk. 5:23, 28, 34; 6:56; to save, preserve from being lost, Mt. 16:25; Mk. 3:4; 8:35; σῴζειν ἀπό, to deliver from, set free from, Mt. 1:21; Jn. 12:27; Acts 2:40; in NT to rescue from unbelief, convert, Rom. 11:14; 1 Cor. 1:21; 7:16; to bring within the pale of saving privilege, Tit. 3:5; 1 Pet. 3:21; to save from final ruin, 1 Tim. 1:15; pass. to be brought within the pale of saving privilege, Acts 2:47; Eph. 2:5, 8; to be in the way of salvation, 1 Cor. 15:2; 2 Cor. 2:15
σῶμα: the body of an animal; a living body, Mt. 5:29, 30; 6:22, 23, 25; Jas. 3:3; a person, individual, 1 Cor. 6:16; a dead body; corpse, carcass, Mt. 14:12; 27:52, 58; Heb. 13:11; the human body considered as the seat and occasion of moral imperfection, as inducing to sin through its appetites and passions, Rom. 7:24; 8:13; genr. a body, a material substance, 1 Cor. 15:37, 38, 40; the substance, reality, as opposed to ἡ σκιά, Col. 2:17; in NT met., the aggregate body of believers, the body of the Church, Rom. 12:5; Col. 1:18
σωματικός: bodily, of or belonging to the body, 1 Tim. 4:8; corporeal, material, Lk. 3:22*
σωματικῶς: bodily, in a bodily frame, Col. 2:9*
σωρεύω: to heap or pile up, Rom. 12:20; met. pass. to be filled with sins, 2 Tim. 3:6*
σωτήρ: a savior, preserver, deliverer, Lk. 1:47; 2:11; Acts 5:31
σωτηρία: a saving, preservation, Acts 27:34; Heb. 11:7; deliverance, Lk. 1:69, 71; Acts 7:25; salvation, spiritual and eternal, Lk. 1:77; 19:9; Acts 4:12; Rev. 7:10; a being placed in a condition of salvation by an embracing of the Gospel, Rom. 10:1, 10; 2 Tim. 3:15; means or opportunity of salvation, Acts 13:26; Rom. 11:11; Heb. 2:3; ἡ σωτηρία, the promised deliverance by the Messiah, Jn. 4:22
σωτήριος: imparting salvation, saving, Lk. 2:30; 3:6; Acts 28:28; Eph. 6:17; Tit. 2:11*
σωφρονέω: to be of a sound mind, be in one’s right mind, be sane, Mk. 5:15; Lk. 8:35; to be calm, 2 Cor. 5:13; to be sober-minded, sedate, Tit. 2:6; 1 Pet. 4:7; to be of a modest, humble mind, Rom. 12:3*
σωφρονίζω: encourage, to restore to a right mind; to make sober-minded, to steady by exhortation and guidance, Tit. 2:4*
σωφρόνως: in the manner of a person in his right mind; soberly, temperately, Tit. 2:12*
σωφροσύνη: sanity, soundness of mind, a sane mind, Acts 26:25; female modesty, 1 Tim. 2:9, 15*
σώφρων: of a sound mind, sane; temperate, discreet, 1 Tim. 3:2; Tit. 1:8; 2:2; modest, chaste, Tit. 2:5*
ταβέρναι: taverns, used in the NT only in the transliterated Latin name of “Three Taverns” (Τριῶν ταβερνῶν), see G5553, Acts 28:15*
τάγμα: pr. anything placed in order; in NT order of succession, class, group, 1 Cor. 15:23*
τακτός: pr. arranged; fixed, appointed, set, Acts 12:21*
ταλαιπωρέω: to endure severe labor and hardship; to be harassed; complain, Jas. 4:9*
ταλαιπωρία: toil, difficulty, hardship; calamity, misery, distress, Rom. 3:16; Jas. 5:1*
ταλαίπωρος: pr. enduring severe effort and hardship; hence, wretched, miserable, afflicted, Rom. 7:24; Rev. 3:17*
ταλαντιαῖος: of a talent weight, weighing a talent, Rev. 16:21*
τάλαντον: the scale of a balance; a talent, which as a weight was among the Jews equivalent to 3000 shekels, i.e., as usually estimated, 114 lbs. 15 dwts. Troy; while the Attic talent, on the usual estimate, was only equal to 56 lbs. 11 oz. Troy, Mt. 18:24; 25:15, 16, 20, 22, 24, 25, 28*
ταμεῖον: a storehouse, granary, barn, Lk. 12:24; a chamber, closet, place of retirement and privacy, Mt. 6:6; 24:26; Lk. 12:3*
τάξις: order, regular disposition, arrangement; order, series, succession, Lk. 1:8; an order, distinctive class, as of priests, Heb. 5:6, 10; 6:20; 7:11(2x), 17; order, good order, 1 Cor. 14:40; orderliness, well-regulated conduct, Col. 2:5*
ταπεινός: low in situation; of condition, humble, poor, mean, depressed, Lk. 1:52; 2 Cor. 7:6; Jas. 1:9; met. of the mind, humble, lowly, modest, Mt. 11:29; Rom. 12:16; 2 Cor. 10:1; Jas. 4:6; 1 Pet. 5:5*
ταπεινοφροσύνη: lowliness or humility of mind, modesty, Acts 20:19; Eph. 4:2; Phil. 2:3; Col. 2:18, 23; 3:12; 1 Pet. 5:5*
ταπεινόω: to bring low, depress, level, Lk. 3:5; met. to humble, abase, Phil. 2:8; mid. to descend to, or live in, a humble condition, 2 Cor. 11:7; Phil. 4:12; to humble, depress the pride of, any one, Mt. 18:4; mid. to humble one’s self, exhibit humility and contrition, Jas. 4:10; 1 Pet. 5:6; to humble with respect to hopes and expectations, to depress with disappointment, Mt. 23:12; Lk. 14:11; 18:14; 2 Cor. 12:21*
ταπείνωσις: depression; low estate, abject condition, Lk. 1:48; Acts 8:33; Phil. 3:21; Jas. 1:10*
ταράσσω: to agitate, trouble, as water, Jn. 5:7; met. to agitate, trouble the mind; with fear, to terrify, put in consternation, Mt. 2:3; 14:26; with grief, etc., affect with grief, anxiety, etc., Jn. 12:27; 13:21; with doubt, etc., to unsettle, perplex, Acts 15:24; Gal. 1:7
τάραχος: agitation, commotion; consternation, terror, Acts 12:18; excitement, tumult, public contention, Acts 19:23*
Ταρσεύς: of, or a native of Ταρσός, Tarsus, the metropolis of Cilicia, Acts 9:11; 21:39*
Ταρσός: Tarsus, the chief city of Cilicia, and birth-place of the Apostle Paul, Acts 9:30; 11:25; 22:3*. See PhotoGuide.
ταρταρόω: to cast or thrust down to Tartarus or Gehenna, 2 Pet. 2:4*
τάσσω: to arrange; to set, appoint, in a certain station, Lk. 7:8; Rom. 13:1; to set, devote, to a pursuit, 1 Cor. 16:15; to dispose, frame, for an object, Acts 13:48; to arrange, appoint, place or time, Mt. 28:16; Acts 28:23; to allot, assign, Acts 22:10; to settle, decide, Acts 15:2*
ταφή: burial, the act of burying, burial place, Mt. 27:7*
τάφος: a sepulchre, grave, tomb, Mt. 23:27, 29; 27:61, 64, 66; 28:1; met. Rom. 3:13*
τάχα: pr. quickly, soon; perhaps, possibly, Rom. 5:7; Phlm. 15*
ταχέως: adverb of ταχύς, quickly, speedily; soon, shortly, 1 Cor. 4:19; Gal. 1:6; hastily, Lk. 14:21; 16:6; with inconsiderate haste, 1 Tim. 5:22
ταχινός: swift, speedy, 2 Pet. 2:1; near at hand, impending, 2 Pet. 1:14*
τάχος: swiftness, speed, quickness; ἐν τάχει, with speed, quickly, speedily; soon, shortly, Lk. 18:8; Acts 25:4; hastily, immediately, Acts 12:7; 22:18; Rom. 16:20; 1 Tim. 3:14; Rev. 1:1; 22:6*
ταχύς: swift, fleet, quick; met. ready, prompt, Jas. 1:19; Mt. 28:7f.; Mk. 9:39; Lk. 15:22; Jn. 11:29
τε: enclitic, can function as a conj., serving either as a lightly-appending link, Acts 1:15; and, Acts 2:3; or as an inclusive prefix, Lk. 12:45; both, Lk. 24:20; Acts 26:16
τεῖχος: a wall of a city, Acts 9:25; 2 Cor. 11:33; Heb. 11:30; Rev. 21:12, 14f., 17-19*
τεκμήριον: a sign, indubitable token, clear proof, Acts 1:3*
τεκνίον: a little child; τεκνία, an endearing appellation, my dear children, Jn. 13:33; 1 Jn. 2:1, 12, 28; 3:7, 18; 4:4; 5:21*
τεκνογονέω: to bear children, to rear a family, 1 Tim. 5:14*
τεκνογονία: the bearing of children, the rearing of a family, 1 Tim. 2:15*
τέκνον: a child, a son or daughter, Mt. 2:18; Lk. 1:7; pl. descendants, posterity, Mt. 3:9; Acts 2:39; child, son, as a term of endearment, Mt. 9:2; Mk. 2:5; 10:24; pl. children, inhabitants, people, of a city, Mt. 23:37; Lk. 19:44; from the Hebrew, met. a child or son in virtue of discipleship, 1 Cor. 4:17; 1 Tim. 1:2; 2 Tim. 1:2; Tit. 1:4; Phlm. 10; 3 Jn. 4; a child in virtue of gracious acceptance, Jn. 1:12; 11:52; Rom. 8:16, 21; 1 Jn. 3:1; a child in virtue of spiritual conformity, Jn. 8:39; Phil. 2:15; 1 Jn. 3:10; a child of, one characterized by some condition or quality, Mt. 11:19; Eph. 2:3; 5:8; 1 Pet. 1:14; 2 Pet. 2:14
τέκτων: an artisan; and spc. one who works with wood, a carpenter, Mt. 13:55; Mk. 6:3*
τέλειος: brought to completion; fully accomplished, fully developed, Jas. 1:4a; fully realized, thorough, 1 Jn. 4:18; complete, entire, as opposed to what is partial and limited, 1 Cor. 13:10; full grown of ripe age, 1 Cor. 14:20; Eph. 4:13; Heb. 5:14; fully accomplished in Christian enlightenment, 1 Cor. 2:6; Phil. 3:15; Col. 1:28; perfect in some point of character, without shortcoming in respect of a certain standard, Mt. 5:48; 19:21; Col. 4:12; Jas. 1:4b; 3:2; perfect, consummate, Rom. 12:2; Jas. 1:17, 25; compar. of higher excellence and efficiency, Heb. 9:11*
τελειότης: completeness, perfectness, Col. 3:14; ripeness of knowledge or practice, maturity, Heb. 6:1*
τελειόω: to execute fully, discharge, Jn. 4:34; 5:36; 17:4; to reach the end of, run through, finish, Lk. 2:43; Acts 20:24; to consummate, place in a condition of finality, Heb. 7:19; to perfect a person, advance a person to final completeness of character, Heb. 2:10; 5:9; 7:28; to perfect a person, advance a person to a completeness of its kind, which needs no further provision, Heb. 9:9; 10:1, 14; pass. to receive fulfillment, Jn. 19:28; to be brought to the goal, to reach the end of one’s course, Lk. 13:32; Phil. 3:12; Heb. 11:40; 12:23; to be fully developed, 2 Cor. 12:9; Jas. 2:22; 1 Jn. 2:5; 4:12, 17; to be completely organized, to be closely embodied, Jn. 17:23
τελείωσις: a completing; a fulfillment, an accomplishment of predictions, promised, etc., Lk. 1:45; finality of function, completeness of operation and effect, Heb. 7:11*
τελειωτής: a finisher, one who completes and perfects a thing; one who brings through to final attainment, perfecter, Heb. 12:2*
τελεσφορέω: to bring to maturity, as fruits, etc.; met. Lk. 8:14*
τελευτάω: to end, finish, complete; absol. to end
τελευτή: a finishing, end; hence, end of life, death, decease, Mt. 2:15*
τελέω: to finish, complete, conclude, an operation, Mt. 11:1; 13:53; 19:1; to finish a circuit, Mt. 10:23; to fulfil, to carry out into full operation, Rom. 2:27; Gal. 5:16; Jas. 2:8; to pay dues, Mt. 17:24; pass. to be fulfilled, realized, Lk. 12:50; 18:31; of time, to be ended, elapse, Rom. 15:8; 20:3, 5, 7
τέλος: an end attained, consummation; an end, closing act, Mt. 24:6, 14; 1 Cor. 15:24; full performance, perfect discharge, Rom. 10:4; fulfillment, realization, Lk. 22:37; final dealing, developed issue, Jas. 5:11; issue, final stage, 1 Cor. 10:11; issue, result, Mt. 26:58; Rom. 6:21, 22; 1 Pet. 1:9; antitypical issue, 2 Cor. 3:13; practical issue, 1 Tim. 1:5; ultimate destiny, Phil. 3:19; Heb. 6:8; 1 Pet. 4:17; a tax or dues, Mt. 17:25; Rom. 13:7; εἰς τέλος, to the full, 1 Thess. 2:16; εἰς τέλος, continually, Lk. 18:5; εἰς τέλος, μέχρι, ἄχρι τέλους, throughout, Mt. 10:22; Mk. 13:13; Jn. 13:1; Heb. 3:6, 14; 6:11; Rev. 2:26
τελώνης: one who farms the public revenues; in NT a publican, collector of imposts, revenue officer, tax gatherer, Mt. 5:46; 9:10, 11; 10:3; Mk. 2:15f.; Lk. 3:12
τελώνιον: a custom-house, toll house; collector’s office, Mt. 9:9; Mk. 2:14; Lk. 5:27*
τέρας: a prodigy, portent, Acts 2:19; a signal act, wonder, miracle, Mt. 13:22; Jn. 4:48; Acts 2:43
Τέρτιος: Tertius, pr. name, a helper of Paul, Rom. 16:22*
Τέρτυλλος: Tertullus, pr. name, an attorney, Acts 24:1f.*
τέταρτος: fourth, Mt. 14:25; the fourth part, quarter, Rev. 6:8
τετράδιον: a set of four; a detachment of four men, Acts 12:4*
τετράμηνος: of four months, four months in duration, Jn. 4:35*
τετραπλοῦς: contracted form of τετραπλόος, four times (as much), fourfold, quadruple, Lk. 19:8*
τετρααρχέω: also spelled τετραρχέω, be tetrarch, Lk. 3:1 (3x)*
τετραάρχης: also spelled τετράρχης, a tetrarch, title of a prince, whose rank was lower than a king, Mt. 14:1; Lk. 3:19; 9:7; Acts 13:1*
τεφρόω: to reduce to ashes, to consume, destroy, 2 Pet. 2:6*
τέχνη: art, skill, Acts 17:29; an art, trade, craft, Acts 18:3; Rev. 18:22*
τεχνίτης: an artisan; workman, mechanic, Acts 19:24, 38; Rev. 18:22; an architect, builder, Heb. 11:10*
τήκω: to dissolve; pass. to melt, 2 Pet. 3:12*
τηλικοῦτος: so great, large, important, 2 Cor. 1:10; Heb. 2:3; Jas. 3:4; Rev. 16:18*
τηρέω: to keep watch upon, guard, Mt. 27:36, 54; 28:4; Acts 12:6; to watch over protectively, guard, 1 Jn. 5:18; Rev. 16:15; to mark attentively, to heed, Rev. 1:3; to observe practically, keep strictly, Mt. 19:17; 23:3; 28:20; Mk. 7:9; Jn. 8:51; to preserve, shield, Jn. 17:15; to store up, reserve, Jn. 2:10; 12:7; 1 Pet. 1:4; 2 Pet. 2:4, 9, 17; to keep in custody, Acts 12:5; 16:23; to maintain, Eph. 4:3; 2 Tim. 4:7; to keep in a condition, Jn. 17:11, 12; 1 Cor. 7:37; 2 Cor. 11:9; 1 Tim. 5:22; Jas. 1:27
τήρησις: a keeping, custody; meton. a place of custody, prison, ward, Acts 4:3; 5:18; met. practical observance, strict performance, 1 Cor. 7:19*
Τιβεριάς: Tiberias, a city of Galilee, built by Herod Antipas, and named in honor of Tiberius, Jn. 6:1, 23; 21:1*
Τιβέριος: Tiberius, the third Roman emperor, 14–37 A.D., Lk. 3:1*
τίθημι: by-form of τιθέω, to place, set, lay, Mt. 5:15; Mk. 6:56; Lk. 6:48; to produce at table, Jn. 2:10; to deposit, lay, Mt. 27:60; Lk. 23:53; Acts 3:2; to lay down, Lk. 19:21, 22; Jn. 10:11, 15, 17, 18; 1 Jn. 3:16; to lay aside, put off, Jn. 13:4; to allocate, assign, Mt. 24:51; Lk. 12:46; to set, appoint, Jn. 15:16; Acts 13:47; Heb. 1:2; to render, make, Mt. 22:44; Rom. 4:17; 1 Cor. 9:18; mid. to put in custody, Mt. 14:3; Acts 4:3; to reserve, Acts 1:7; to commit as a matter of charge, 2 Cor. 5:19; to set, with design, in a certain arrangement or position, Acts 20:28; 1 Cor. 12:18, 28; 1 Thess. 5:9; 1 Tim. 1:12; pass. 1 Tim. 2:7; 2 Tim. 1:11; 1 Pet. 2:8; τιθέναι τὰ γόνατα, to kneel down, Mk. 15:19; Lk. 22:41; Acts 7:60; 9:40; 20:36; 21:5; τίθεσθαι ἐν τῇ καρδίᾳ, to lay to heart, ponder, Lk. 1:66; also, εἰς τὰς καρδίας, Lk. 21:14; to design, resolve, Acts 5:4; also, ἐν πνεύματι, Acts 19:21; also, βουλήν, Acts 17:12; τίθεσθαι εἰς τὰ ὦτα, to give attentive audience to, to listen to retentively, Lk. 9:44
τίκτω: to bear, bring forth children, Mt. 1:21, 23; trop. to bear, produce, as the earth, yield, Heb. 6:7; met. to give birth to, Jas. 1:15
τίλλω: to pull, pluck off, Mt. 12:1; Mk. 2:23; Lk. 6:1*
τιμάω: to estimate in respect of worth; to hold in estimation, respect, honor, reverence, Mt. 15:4, 5, 8; 19:19; Mk. 7:10; to honor with reverent service, Jn. 5:23 (4x); 8:49; to treat with honor, manifest consideration towards, Acts 28:10; to treat graciously, visit with marks of favor, Jn. 12:26; mid. to price, Mt. 27:9
τιμή: a pricing, estimate of worth; price, value, Mt. 27:9; price paid, Mt. 27:6; meton. a thing of price, and collectively, precious things, Rev. 21:24, 26; preciousness, 1 Pet. 2:7; substantial value, real worth, Col. 2:23; careful regard, honor, state of honor, dignity, Rom. 9:21; Heb. 5:4; honor conferred, observance, veneration, Rom. 2:7, 10; 12:10; mark of favor and consideration, Acts 28:10, honorarium, compensation, 1 Tim. 5:7
τίμιος: precious, costly, of great price, 1 Cor. 3:12; Rev. 18:12; precious, dear, valuable, Acts 20:24; 1 Pet. 1:7, 19; honored, esteemed, respected, Acts 5:34; Heb. 13:4
τιμιότης: preciousness, costliness; meton. precious things, valuable merchandise, Rev. 18:19*
Τιμόθεος: Timotheus, Timothy, pr. name, son of Eunice, traveling companion of Paul, Acts 16:1; Rom. 16:21; 1 Cor. 4:17; 2 Cor. 1:1; Phil. 1:1; Col. 1:1; 1 Thess. 1:1; 1 Tim. 1:2, 18; 6:20; 2 Tim. 1:2
τιμωρέω: to avenge, someone; in NT to punish, Acts 22:5; 26:11*
τίνω: to pay; to pay a penalty, incur punishment, 2 Thess. 1:9*
τις: enclitic, indefinite pronoun, a certain one, someone, Mt. 12:47; pl. some, certain, several, Lk. 8:2; Acts 9:19; 2 Pet. 3:16; one, a person, Mt. 12:29; Lk. 14:8; Jn. 6:50; combined with the name of an individual, one, Mk. 15:21; as it were in a manner, a kind of, Heb. 10:27; Jas. 1:18; any whatever, Mt. 8:28; Lk. 11:36; Rom. 8:39; τις, somebody of consequence, Acts 5:36; τι, something of consequence, Gal. 2:6; 6:3; τι, anything at all, anything worth account, 1 Cor. 3:7; 10:19; τι at all, Phil. 3:15; Phlm. 18
Τίτος: Titus, pr. name, friend and helper of Paul, 2 Cor. 2:13; 7:6; Gal. 2:1; 2 Tim. 4:10; Tit. 1:4
τοιγαροῦν: well then, so then, wherefore, for that reason, 1 Thess. 4:8; Heb. 12:1*
τοιόσδε: such as this; such as follows, 2 Pet. 1:17*
τοιοῦτος: such, such like, of this kind or sort, Mt. 18:5; 19:14; such, so great, Mt. 9:8; Mk. 6:2; ὁ τοιοῦτος, such a fellow, Acts 22:22; also, the one alluded to, 1 Cor. 1:5; 2 Cor. 2:6, 7; 12:2, 3, 5
τοῖχος: a wall of a building, as distinct from a city wall or fortification (τεῖχος) Acts 23:3*
τόκος: a bringing forth; offspring; met. produce of money lent, interest, usury, Mt. 25:27; Lk. 19:23*
τολμάω: to assume resolution to do a thing, Mk. 15:43; Rom. 5:7; Phil. 1:14; to make up the mind, 2 Cor. 10:12; to dare, Acts 5:13; 7:32; to presume, Mt. 22:46; Mk. 12:34; Lk. 20:40; Jn. 21:12; Rom. 15:18; Jude 9; to have the face, 1 Cor. 6:1; absol. to assume a bold bearing, courageous, 2 Cor. 10:2; 11:21*
τολμητής: one who is bold; in a bad sense, a presumptuous, audacious person, 2 Pet. 2:10*
τοπάζιον: a topaz, a gem of a yellowish color, different from the modern topaz, Rev. 21:20*
τόπος: a place, locality, Mt. 12:43; Lk. 6:17; a limited spot or ground, Mt. 24:15; 27:33; Jn. 4:20; Acts 6:13; a precise spot or situation, Mt. 28:6; Mk. 16:6; Lk. 14:9; a dwelling place, abode, mansion, dwelling, seat, Jn. 14:2, 3; Acts 4:31; a place of ordinary deposit, Mt. 26:52; a place, passage in a book, Lk. 4:17; place occupied, room, space, Lk. 2:7; 14:9, 22; place, opportunity, Acts 25:16; Heb. 12:17; place, condition, position, 1 Cor. 14:16
τοσοῦτος: so great, so much, Mt. 8:10; 15:33; so long, of time, Jn. 14:9; pl. so many, Mt. 15:33
τότε: then, at that time, Mt. 2:17; 3:5; 11:20; then, Mt. 12:29; 13:26; 25:31; ἀπὸ τότε, from that time, Mt. 4:17; 16:21; ὁ τότε, which then was, 2 Pet. 3:6
τράπεζα: a table, an eating table, Mt. 15:27; Mk. 7:28; Heb. 9:2; by impl. a meal, feast, Rom. 11:9; 1 Cor. 10:21; a table or counter of a money changer, Mt. 21:12; a bank, Lk. 19:23; by impl. pl. money matters, Acts 6:2
τραπεζίτης: a money changer, broker, banker, who exchanges or loans money for a premium, Mt. 25:27*
τραχηλίζω: pr. to grip the neck; to bend the neck back, so as to make bare or expose the throat, as in slaughtering animals, etc.; met. to lay bare in view, Heb. 4:13*
τράχηλος: the neck, Mt. 18:6; Mk. 9:42; Lk. 15:20; 17:2; ἐπιθεῖναι ζυγὸν ἐπὶ τὸν τράχηλον, to put a yoke upon the neck of someone, met. to bind to a burdensome observance, Acts 15:10; 20:37; ὑποτιθέναι τὸν τράχηλον, to lay down one’s neck under the axe of the executioner, to imperil one’s life, Rom. 16:4*
τραχύς: rough, rugged, uneven, Lk. 3:5; εἰς τραχεῖς τόπους, on a rocky shore, Acts 27:29*
Τραχωνῖτις: Trachonitis, part of the tetrarchy of Herod Antipas, the north-easternmost habitable district east of the Jordan, Lk. 3:1*
τρεῖς: three, Mt. 12:40. The frequency count does not include its occurrence in the name Τριῶν ταβερνῶν in Acts 28:15 (G5553)
Τρεῖς ταβέρναι: Three Taverns, the name of a station on the Appian Way in Acts 28:15 (Τριῶν ταβερνῶν). The Latin taberna is an inn or shop
τρέμω: to tremble, be agitated from fear, Mk. 5:33; Lk. 8:47; by impl. to fear, be afraid, 2 Pet. 2:10*
τρέφω: to nourish; to feed, support, cherish, provide for,
τρέχω: to run, Mt. 27:48; 28:8; to run a race, 1 Cor. 9:24; met. 1 Cor. 9:24, 26; Heb. 12:1; in NT to run a certain course of conduct, Gal. 5:7; to run a course of exertion, Rom. 9:16; Gal. 2:2; Phil. 2:16; to run, to progress freely, to advance rapidly, 2 Thess. 3:1
τρῆμα: an aperture, hole, eye of a needle, Lk. 18:25*
τρίβολος: pr. three-pronged; a thistle, thorn, Mt. 7:16; Heb. 6:8*
τρίβος: a beaten track; a road, highway, Mt. 3:3; Mk. 1:3; Lk. 3:4*
τριετία: the space of three years, Acts 20:31*
τρίζω: to creak, grating sound; to gnash, grind the teeth, Mk. 9:18*
τρίμηνος: the space of three months, Heb. 11:23*
τρίς: three times, thrice, Mt. 26:34, 75; ἐπὶ τρίς, to the extent of thrice, as many as three times, Acts 10:16; 11:10
τρίστεγον: the third floor, third story, Acts 20:9*
τρίτον: the accusative singular neuter form of tritos (G5569) used adverbially the third time, for the third time, Mk. 14:41; Lk. 23:22
τρίτος: third, Mt. 20:3; 27:64; ἐκ τρίτου, the third time, for the third time, Mt. 26:44; τὸ τρίτον, i.e. μέρος, the third part, Rev. 8:7, 12;
τρίχινος: of hair, made of hair, Rev. 6:12*
τρόμος: pr. a trembling, quaking; trembling from fear, fear, terror, agitation of mind, Mk. 16:8; anxious, under solemn responsibility, 1 Cor. 2:3; reverence, veneration, awe, 2 Cor. 7:15; Eph. 6:5; Phil. 2:12*
τροπή: a turning round; a turning back, change, mutation, Jas. 1:17*
τρόπος: a turn; mode, manner, way, Jude 7; ὁν τρόπον, + καθ’ ὁν τρόπον, in which manner, as, even as, Mt. 23:37; Acts 15:11; κατὰ μηδένα τρόπον, in no way, by no means, 2 Thess. 2:3; ἐν παντὶ τρόπῳ, and παντὶ τρόπῳ in every way, by every means, Phil. 1:18; 2 Thess. 3:16; turn of mind or action, habit, disposition, Heb. 13:5
τροποφορέω: to bear with the disposition, manners, and conduct of any one, to put up with, Acts 13:18*
τροφή: nourishment, food, Mt. 3:4; Lk. 12:23; Jn. 4:8; Acts 9:19; Jas. 2:15; provision, Mt. 24:45; sustenance, maintenance, Mt. 10:10; met. nourishment of the mind, of spiritual nourishment, Heb. 5:12, 14
Τρόφιμος: Trophimus, pr. name, of Ephesus, a friend of Paul, Acts 20:4; 21:29; 2 Tim. 4:20*
τροχιά: a track, way, path, met. Heb. 12:13*
τροχός: pr. a runner; anything spherical, a wheel; drift, course, with which signification the word is usually written τρόχος, Jas. 3:6*
τρυγάω: to harvest, gather, fruits, and spc. grapes, Lk. 6:44; Rev. 14:18, 19*
τρυμαλιά: a hole, perforation; eye of a needle, Mk. 10:25*
τρύπημα: a hole; eye of a needle, Mt. 19:24*
Τρῳάς: Troas, a city on the coast of Phrygia, near the site of ancient Troy, Acts 16:8, 11; 20:5f.; 2 Cor. 2:12; 2 Tim. 4:13*. See PhotoGuide.
τρώγω: pr. to crunch; to eat, Mt. 24:38; from the Hebrew, ἄρτον τρώγειν, to take food, partake of a meal, Jn. 6:54, 56-58; 13:18*
τυγχάνω: to hit an object; to attain to, to obtain, acquire, enjoy, Lk. 20:35; Acts 24:2; 26:22; 27:3; 2 Tim. 2:10; Heb. 8:6; 11:35; intrans. to happen, fall out, chance; common, ordinary, Acts 19:11; 28:2; as an adv., it may be, perchance, perhaps, 1 Cor. 16:6; εἰ τύχοι, as it so happens, as the case may be, 1 Cor. 14:10; 15:37*
τυμπανίζω: pr. to beat a drum; to drum upon; in NT to torture, beat to death with rods and clubs, Heb. 11:35*
τύπος: pr. an impress; a print, mark, of a wound inflicted, Jn. 20:25; a delineation; an image, statue, Acts 7:43; a formula, scheme, Rom. 6:17; form, Acts 23:25; a figure, counterpart, 1 Cor. 10:6; an anticipative figure, type, Rom. 5:14; a model pattern, Acts 7:44; Heb. 8:5; a moral pattern, Phil. 3:17; 1 Thess. 1:7; 2 Thess. 3:9; 1 Tim. 4:12; Tit. 2:7; 1 Pet. 5:3*
τύπτω: to beat, strike, smite, Mt. 24:49; 27:30; to beat the breast, as expressive of grief or strong emotion, Lk. 18:13; 23:48; in NT met. to wound or shock the conscience of any one, 1 Cor. 8:12; from the Hebrew, to smite with evil, punish, Acts 23:3
Τύριος: a Tyrian, an inhabitant of Tyre, Acts 12:20*
Τύρος: Tyre, a celebrated and wealthy commercial city of Phoenicia, Mt. 11:21; 15:21; Mk. 7:24; Acts 21:3, 7. See PhotoGuide.
τυφλός: blind, Mt. 9:27, 28; 11:5; 12:22; met. mentally blind, Mt. 15:14; 23:16
τυφλόω: to blind, render blind; met. Jn. 12:40; 2 Cor. 4:4; 1 Jn. 2:11*
τυφόω: to besmoke; met. to possess with the fumes of conceit; pass. to be demented with conceit, puffed up, 1 Tim. 3:6; 6:4; 2 Tim. 3:4; 1 Tim. 6:4*
τύφω: to raise a smoke; pass. to emit smoke, smoke, smoulder, Mt. 12:20*
τυφωνικός: stormy, tempestuous; with ἄνεμος it means hurricane, typhoon, whirlwind, Acts 27:14*
Τυχικός: Tychicus, pr. name, a friend or companion of Paul, Acts 20:4; Eph. 6:21; Col. 4:7; 2 Tim. 4:12; Tit. 3:12; Eph. subscr.; Col. subscr.*
ὑακίνθινος: hyacinthine, resembling the hyacinth in color, dark blue, Rev. 9:17*
ὑάκινθος: a hyacinth, a gem resembling the color of the hyacinth flower, dark blue, Rev. 21:20*
ὑάλινος: made of glass; glassy, translucent, Rev. 4:6; 15:2*
ὕαλος: a transparent stone, crystal; also, glass, Rev. 21:18, 21*
ὑβρίζω: to run riot; trans. to outrage, to treat in an arrogant or spiteful manner, Mt. 22:6; Lk. 11:45; 18:32; Acts 14:5; 1 Thess. 2:2*
ὕβρις: insolence; shame, insult, outrage, 2 Cor. 12:10; damage by sea, Acts 27:10, 21*
ὑβριστής: an overbearing, violent person, Rom. 1:30; 1 Tim. 1:13*
ὑγιαίνω: to be sound, in health, Lk. 5:31; 7:10; to be safe and sound, Lk. 15:27; 3 Jn. 2; met. to be healthful or sound in faith, doctrine, etc., Tit. 1:9, 13; 2:1, 2; sound, pure, uncorrupted, 1 Tim. 1:10; 6:3; 2 Tim. 1:13; 4:3*
ὑγιής: sound, in health, Mt. 12:13; 15:31; met. of doctrine, sound, pure, wholesome, Tit. 2:8
ὑγρός: pr. wet, moist, humid; used of a tree, full of sap, fresh, green, Lk. 23:31*
ὑδρία: a water pot pitcher, Jn. 2:6, 7; a bucket, pail, Jn. 4:28*
ὑδροποτέω: to be only a water drinker, 1 Tim. 5:23*
ὕδωρ: water, Mt. 3:11, 16; 14:28, 29; 17:15; Jn. 5:3, 4, 7; watery fluid, Jn. 19:34; ὕδωρ ζῶν, living water, fresh flowing water, Jn. 4:11; met. of spiritual refreshment, Jn. 4:10; 7:38
υἱοθεσία: adoption, a placing in the condition of a son, Rom. 8:15, 23; 9:4; Gal. 4:5; Eph. 1:5*
υἱός: a son, Mt. 1:21, 25; 7:9; 13:55 freq.; a legitimate son, Heb. 12:8; a son artificially constituted, Acts 7:21; Heb. 11:24; a descendant, Mt. 1:1, 20; Mk. 12:35; in NT the young of an animal, Mt. 21:5; a spiritual son in respect of conversion or discipleship, 1 Pet. 5:13; from the Hebrew, a disciple, perhaps, Mt. 12:27; a son as implying connection in respect of membership, service, resemblance, manifestation, destiny, etc., Mt. 8:12; 9:15; 13:38; 23:15; Mk. 2:29; 3:17; Lk. 5:34; 10:6; 16:8; 20:34, 36; Jn. 17:12; Acts 2:25; 4:36; 13:10; Eph. 2:2; 5:6; Col. 3:6; 1 Thess. 5:5; 2 Thess. 2:3; υἱὸς θεοῦ, κ.τ.λ., son of God in respect of divinity, Mt. 4:3, 6; 14:33; Rom. 1:4; also, in respect of privilege and character, Mt. 5:9, 45; Lk. 6:35; Rom. 8:14, 19; 9:26; Gal. 3:26; ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ θεοῦ, κ.τ.λ., a title of the Messiah, Mt. 26:63; Mk. 3:11; 14:61; Jn. 1:34, 50; 20:31; υἱὸς ἀνθρώπου, a son of man, a man, Mk. 3:28; Eph. 3:5; Heb. 2:6; ὁ υἱὸς τοῦ ἀνθρώπου, a title of the Messiah, Mt. 8:20 freq.; as also, ὁ υἱὸς Δαβίδ, (Δαύιδ) Mt. 12:23
ὕλη: wood, a forest; in NT firewood, a mass of fuel, Jas. 3:5*
ὑμνέω: to hymn, praise, celebrate or worship with hymns, Acts 16:25; Heb. 2:12; absol. to sing a hymn, Mt. 26:30; Mk. 14:26*
ὕμνος: a song; a hymn, song of praise to God, Eph. 5:19; Col. 3:16*
ὑπάγω: to lead or bring under; to lead or bring from under; draw on or away; in NT intrans. to go away, depart, Mt. 8:4, 13; 9:6; ὕπαγε ὀπίσω μου, Get behind me! Away! Begone! Mt. 4:10; 16:23; to go, Mt. 5:41; Lk. 12:58; to depart life, Mt. 26:24
ὑπακοή: a hearkening to; obedience, Rom. 5:19; 6:16; 1 Pet. 1:14; submissiveness, Rom. 16:19; 2 Cor. 7:15; submission, Rom. 1:5; 15:18; 16:26; 2 Cor. 10:5; Heb. 5:8; 1 Pet. 1:2, 22; compliance, Phlm. 21
ὑπακούω: to give ear; to listen, Acts 12:13; to obey, Mt. 8:27; Mk. 1:27; in NT to render submissive acceptance, Acts 6:7; Rom. 6:17; 2 Thess. 1:8; Heb. 5:9; absol. to be submissive, Phil. 2:12
ὕπανδρος: bound to a man, married, Rom. 7:2*
ὑπάντησις: a meeting, act of meeting, Mt. 8:34; 25:1; Jn. 12:13*
ὕπαρξις: goods possessed, substance, property, Acts 2:45; Heb. 10:34*
ὑπάρχω: to begin; to come into existence; to exist; to be, subsist, Acts 19:40; 28:18; to be in possession, to belong, Acts 3:6; 4:37; goods, possessions, property, Mt. 19:21; Lk. 8:3; to be, Lk. 7:25; 8:41
ὑπείκω: to yield, give way; absol. to be submissive, Heb. 13:17*
ὑπεναντίος: over against; contrast, adverse, Col. 2:14; ὁ ὑπεναντίος, an opponent, adversary, Heb. 10:27*
ὑπέρ: (1) gen., above, over; met. in behalf of, Mt. 5:44; Mk. 9:40; Jn. 17:19; instead of beneficially, Phlm. 13; in maintenance of, Rom. 15:8; for the furtherance of, Jn. 11:4; 2 Cor. 1:6, 8; for the realization of, Phil. 2:13; equivalent to περί, about, concerning, with the further signification of interest or concern in the subject, Acts 5:41; Rom. 9:27; 2 Cor. 5:12; 8:23; 2 Thess. 2:1. (2) acc., over, beyond; met. beyond, more than, Mt. 10:37; 2 Cor. 1:8; used after comparative terms, Lk. 16:8; 2 Cor. 12:13; Heb. 4:12. (3) in NT as an adv., in a higher degree, in fuller measure, 2 Cor. 11:23
ὑπεραίρω: to raise or lift up above or over; mid. to lift up one’s self; met. to be over-elated, 2 Cor. 12:7 (2x); to bear one’s self arrogantly, to rear a haughty front, 2 Thess. 2:4*
ὑπέρακμος: past the bloom of life, past one’s prime, 1 Cor. 7:36*
ὑπεράνω: can function as an improper prep., above, over, far above; of place, Eph. 4:10; Heb. 9:5; of rank, dignity, Eph. 1:21*
ὑπερβαίνω: to overstep; to wrong, transgress, 1 Thess. 4:6*
ὑπερβάλλω: pr. to cast or throw over or beyond, to overshoot; met. to surpass, excel; surpassing, 2 Cor. 3:10; 9:14; Eph. 1:19; 2:7; 3:19*
ὑπερβολή: pr. a throwing beyond, an overshooting; extraordinary amount or character, transcendency, 2 Cor. 12:7; 4:7; καθ’ ὑπερβολήν, adverbially, exceedingly, extremely, Rom. 7:13; 2 Cor. 1:8; Gal. 1:13; a far better way, 1 Cor. 12:31; beyond all measure, 2 Cor. 4:17*
ὑπερέκεινα: BDAG 1032, list as an adverb used with the gen., others list as an improper prep., beyond, 2 Cor. 10:16*
ὑπερεκπερισσοῦ: in over abundance; beyond all measure, superabundantly, Eph. 3:20; 1 Thess. 3:10; 5:13*
ὑπερεκχύννω: to pour out above measure or in excess; pass. to run over, overflow, Lk. 6:38*
ὑπερέχω: to hold above; intrans. to stand out above, to overtop; met. to surpass, excel, Phil. 2:3; 4:7; τὸ ὑπερέχον, excellence, preeminence, Phil. 3:8; to be higher, superior, Rom. 13:1; 1 Pet. 2:13*
ὑπερήφανος: assuming, haughty, arrogant, Lk. 1:51; Rom. 1:30; 2 Tim. 3:2; Jas. 4:6; 1 Pet. 5:5*
ὑπερλίαν: in the highest degree, preeminently, especially, superlatively, 2 Cor. 11:5; 12:11*
ὑπερνικάω: to overpower in victory; to be abundantly victorious, prevail mightily, Rom. 8:37*
ὑπέρογκος: pr. swollen, overgrown; of language, swelling, pompous, boastful, 2 Pet. 2:18; Jude 16*
ὑπεροχή: prominence; met., excellence, rare quality, 1 Cor. 2:1; eminent station, authority, 1 Tim. 2:2*
ὑπερπερισσεύω: to superabound; to abound still more, Rom. 5:20; mid. to be abundantly filled, overflow, 2 Cor. 7:4*
ὑπερπερισσῶς: superabundantly, most vehemently, above all measure, Mk. 7:37*
ὑπερπλεονάζω: to superabound, be in exceeding abundance, over exceed, 1 Tim. 1:14*
ὑπερφρονέω: to have lofty thoughts, be elated, haughty, Rom. 12:3*
ὑπερῷον: the upper part of a house, upper room, or chamber, Acts 1:13; 9:37, 39; 20:8*
ὑπέχω: pr. to hold under; to render, undergo, suffer, Jude 7*
ὑπήκοος: giving ear; obedient, submissive, Acts 7:39; 2 Cor. 2:9; Phil. 2:8*
ὑπηρετέω: to subserve, Acts 13:36; to relieve, supply, Acts 20:34; to render kind offices, Acts 24:23*
ὑπηρέτης: pr. an under-rower, a rower, one of a ship’s crew; a minister, attendant, servant; an attendant on a magistrate, officer, Mt. 5:25; an attendant or officer of the Sanhedrin, Mt. 26:58; an attendant, or servant of a synagogue, Lk. 4:20; a minister, attendant, assistant in any work, Lk. 1:2; Jn. 18:36
ὕπνος: sleep, Mt. 1:24; Lk. 9:32; Jn. 11:13; Acts 20:9; met. spiritual sleep, religious slumber, Rom. 13:11*
ὑπό: (1) gen., under; hence, used to express influence, causation, agency; by, Mt. 1:22 freq.; by the agency of, at the hands of, 2 Cor. 11:24; Heb. 12:3. (2) acc., under, with the idea of motion associated, Mt. 5:15; under, Jn. 1:49; 1 Cor. 10:1; under subjection to, Rom. 6:14; 1 Tim. 6:1; of time, at, about, Acts 5:21
ὑποβάλλω: to cast under; met. to suggest, instigate, Acts 6:11*
ὑπογραμμός: pr. a copy to write after; met. an example for imitation, pattern, 1 Pet. 2:21*
ὑπόδειγμα: a token, intimation; an example, model, proposed for imitation or admonition, Jn. 13:15; Heb. 4:11; Jas. 5:10; 2 Pet. 2:6; a copy, Heb. 8:5; 9:23*
ὑποδείκνυμι: also spelled ὑποδεικνύω, to indicate, Acts 20:35; to intimate, suggest, show, prove, Mt. 3:7; Lk. 3:7; 6:47; 12:5; Acts 9:16*
ὑποδέχομαι: to give reception to; to receive as a guest, welcome, entertain, Lk. 10:38; 19:6; Acts 17:7; Jas. 2:25*
ὑποδέω: to bind under, mid. to bind under one’s self, put on one’s own feet, Acts 12:8; to shoe, Eph. 6:15; pass. to be shod, Mk. 6:9*
ὑπόδημα: anything bound under; a sandal, Mt. 3:11; 10:10
ὑπόδικος: under a legal process; also, under a judicial sentence; under verdict to an opposed party in a suit, liable to penalty, Rom. 3:19*
ὑποζύγιον: an animal subject to the yoke, a beast of burden; in NT spc. an ass, donkey, Mt. 21:5; 2 Pet. 2:16*
ὑποζώννυμι: to gird under, of persons; to undergird a ship with cables, chains, etc., Acts 27:17*
ὑποκάτω: can function as an improper prep., under, beneath, underneath, Mk. 6:11; 7:28; met. Heb. 2:8
ὑποκρίνομαι: to answer, respond; to act a part upon the stage; hence, to assume a counterfeit character; to pretend, feign, Lk. 20:20*
ὑπόκρισις: a response, answer; an over-acting personification, acting; hypocrisy, simulation, Mt. 23:28; Mk. 12:15; Lk. 12:1; Gal. 2:13; 1 Tim. 4:2; 1 Pet. 2:1*
ὑποκριτής: the giver of an answer or response; a stageplayer, actor; in NT a moral or religious counterfeit, a hypocrite, Mt. 6:2, 5, 16; 7:5
ὑπολαμβάνω: to take up, by placing one’s self underneath what is taken up; to catch away, withdraw, Acts 1:9; to take up discourse by continuation; hence, to answer, Lk. 10:30; to take up a notion, to think, suppose, Lk. 7:43; Acts 2:15; receive as a guest, 3 Jn. 8*
ὑπολείπω: to leave remaining, leave behind; pass. to be left surviving, Rom. 11:3*
ὑπολήνιον: a vat, placed under the press, ληνός, to receive the juice, Mk. 12:1*
ὑπομένω: intrans. to remain or stay behind, when others have departed, Lk. 2:43; trans. to bear up under, endure, suffer patiently, 1 Cor. 13:7; Heb. 10:32; absol. to continue firmly, hold out, remain constant, persevere, Mt. 10:22; 24:13
ὑπομιμνῄσκω: remember, remind, Jn. 14:26; Tit. 3:1; 2 Pet. 1:12; Jude 5; to suggest recollection of, remind others of, 2 Tim. 2:14; 3 Jn. 10; to call to mind, recollect, remember, Lk. 22:61*
ὑπόμνησις: a putting in mind, act of reminding, 2 Pet. 1:13; 3:1; remembrance, recollection, 2 Tim. 1:5*
ὑπομονή: patient endurance, 2 Cor. 12:12; Col. 1:11; patient awaiting, Lk. 21:19; a patient frame of mind, patience, Rom. 5:3, 4; 15:4, 5; Jas. 1:3; perseverance, Rom. 2:7; endurance in adherence to an object, 1 Thess. 1:3; 2 Thess. 3:5; Rev. 1:9; ἐν ὑπομονῇ and δι’ ὑπομονῆς, constantly, perseveringly, Lk. 8:15; Rom. 8:25; Heb. 12:1; an enduring of affliction, etc., the act of suffering, undergoing, etc., 2 Cor. 1:6; 6:4
ὑπονοέω: to suspect; to suppose, deem, Acts 13:25; 25:18; 27:27*
ὑποπλέω: to sail under; to sail under the lee, or, to the south of, an island, etc., Acts 27:4, 7*
ὑποπνέω: to blow gently, as the wind, Acts 27:13*
ὑπόστασις: pr. a standing under; a taking of a thing upon one’s self; an assumed position, an assumption of a specific character, 2 Cor. 11:17; an engagement undertaken with regard to the conduct of others, a vouching, 2 Cor. 9:4; or of one’s self, a pledged profession, Heb. 3:14; an assured impression, a mental realizing, Heb. 11:1; a substructure, basis; subsistence, essence, Heb. 1:3*
ὑποστέλλω: pr. to let down, to stow away; to draw back, withdraw, Gal. 2:12; mid. to shrink back, recoil, Heb. 10:38; to keep back, suppress, conceal, Acts 20:20, 27*
ὑποστρέφω: to turn back, return, Mk. 14:40; Lk. 1:56; 2:39, 43, 45
ὑποστρωννύω: to stow under, spread underneath, Lk. 19:36*
ὑποταγή: subordination, 1 Tim. 3:4; submissiveness, obedience, 2 Cor. 9:13; Gal. 2:5; 1 Tim. 2:11*
ὑποτάσσω: to place or arrange under; to subordinate, 1 Cor. 15:27; to bring under influence, Rom. 8:20; pass. to be subordinated, 1 Cor. 14:32; to be brought under a state or influence, Rom. 8:20; mid. to submit one’s self, render obedience, be submissive, Lk. 2:51; 10:17
ὑποτίθημι: to place under; to lay down the neck beneath the sword of the executioner, to set on imminent risk, Rom. 16:4; mid. to suggest, recommend to attention, 1 Tim. 4:6*
ὑποτρέχω: to run under; as a nautical term, to sail under the lee of, Acts 27:16*
ὑποτύπωσις: a sketch, delineation; a form, formula, presentment, sample, 2 Tim. 1:13; a pattern, a model representation, 1 Tim. 1:16*
ὑποφέρω: to bear under; to bear up under, support, sustain, 1 Cor. 10:13; to endure patiently, 1 Pet. 2:19; to undergo, 2 Tim. 3:11*
ὑπωπιάζω: pr. to strike one upon the parts beneath the eye; to beat black and blue; hence, to discipline by hardship, coerce, 1 Cor. 9:27; met. to weary by continual importunities, pester, Lk. 18:5*
ὗς: a hog, swine, boar, sow, 2 Pet. 2:22*
ὕσσωπος: hyssop, in NT, however, not the plant usually so named, but probably the caper plant; a bunch of hyssop, Heb. 9:19; a hyssop stalk, Jn. 19:29*
ὑστερέω: to be behind in place or time, to be in the rear; to fall short of, be inferior to, 2 Cor. 11:5; 12:11; to fail of, fail to attain, Heb. 4:1; to be in want of, lack, Lk. 22:35; to be wanting, Mk. 10:21; absol. to be defective, in default, Mt. 19:20; 1 Cor. 12:24; to run short, Jn. 2:3; mid. to come short of a privilege or standard, to miss, Rom. 3:23; absol. to come short, be below standard, 1 Cor. 1:7; to come short of sufficiency, to be in need, want, Lk. 15:14; 2 Cor. 11:9; Phil. 4:12; Heb. 11:37; to be a loser, suffer detriment, 1 Cor. 8:8; in NT ὑστερεῖν ἀπό, to be backwards with respect to, to slight, Heb. 12:15*
ὑστέρημα: a shortcoming, defect; personal shortcoming, 1 Cor. 16:17; Phil. 2:30; Col. 1:24; 1 Thess. 3:10; want, need, poverty, penury, Lk. 21:4; 2 Cor. 8:14; 9:12; 11:9*
ὕστερος: posterior in place or time; subsequent, later, last, finally, Mt. 21:31; 1 Tim. 4:1
ὑψηλός: high, lofty, elevated, Mt. 4:8; 17:1; τὰ ὑψηλά, the highest heaven, Heb. 1:3; upraised, Acts 13:17; met. highly esteemed, Lk. 16:15; φρονεῖν τὰ ὑψηλά, to have lofty thoughts, be proud, arrogant, Rom. 12:16
ὑψηλοφρονέω: to have lofty thoughts, be proud, haughty, 1 Tim. 6:17*
ὕψιστος: highest, loftiest, most elevated; τὰ ὕψιστα, from the Hebrew, the highest heaven, Mt. 21:9; Mk. 11:10; met. ὁ ὕψιστος, the Most High, Mk. 5:7
ὕψος: height, Eph. 3:18; Rev. 21:16; met. exaltation, dignity, eminence, Jas. 1:9; from the Hebrew, the height of heaven, Lk. 1:78; 24:49; Eph. 4:8*
ὑψόω: to raise aloft, lift up, Jn. 3:14; 8:28; met. to elevate in condition, uplift, exalt, Mt. 11:23; 23:12; Lk. 1:52
ὕψωμα: height, Rom. 8:39; a towering of self-conceit, presumption, 2 Cor. 10:5*
φαιλόνης: a thick cloak for travelling, with a hood, 2 Tim. 4:13*
φαίνω: to cause to appear, bring to light; absol. to shine, Jn. 1:5; 5:35; 2 Pet. 1:19; 1 Jn. 2:8; Rev. 1:16; 8:12; 21:23; mid./pass. to be seen, appear, be visible, Mt. 1:20; 2:7, 13, 19; τὰ φαινόμενα, things visible, things obvious to the senses, Heb. 11:3; φαίνομαι, to appear, seen, be in appearance, Mt. 23:27; Lk. 24:11; to appear in thought, seen in idea, be a notion, Mk. 14:64
Φάλεκ: Peleg, also spelled Φάλεγ, pr. name, indecl., Lk. 3:35*
φανερός: apparent, manifest, clear, known, well-known, Mk. 4:22; 6:14; Gal. 5:19; in outward guise, externally, Rom. 2:28
φανερόω: to bring to light, to set in a clear light; to manifest, display, Jn. 2:11; 7:4; 9:3; to show, Rom. 1:19; 2 Cor. 7:12; to declare, make known, Jn. 17:6; to disclose, Mk. 4:22; 1 Cor. 4:5; Col. 4:4; to reveal, Rom. 3:21; 16:26; Col. 1:26; to present to view, Jn. 21:1, 14; pass. to make an appearance, Mk. 16:12, 14; spc. of Christ, to be personally manifested, Jn. 1:31; Col. 3:4; 1 Pet. 1:20; 5:4; 1 Jn. 3:5; to be laid bare, appear in true character, 2 Cor. 5:10, 11
φανερῶς: manifestly; clearly, plainly, distinctly, Acts 10:3; openly, publicly, Mk. 1:45; Jn. 7:10*
φανέρωσις: a disclosure, clear display, 2 Cor. 4:2; an outward evidencing of a latent principle, active exhibition, 1 Cor. 12:7*
φαντάζω: to render visible, cause to appear; pass. to appear, be seen; τὸ φανταζόμενον, the sight, spectacle, Heb. 12:21*
φαντασία: pr. a rendering visible; a display; pomp, parade, Acts 25:23*
Φαραώ: Pharaoh, pr. name, indecl., Acts 7:10, 13, 21; Rom. 9:17; Heb. 11:24*
Φαρές: Perezs, pr. name, indecl., Mt. 1:3; Lk. 3:33*
Φαρισαῖος: a Pharisee, a follower of the sect of the Pharisees, a numerous and powerful sect of the Jews, distinguished for their ceremonial observances, and apparent sanctity of life, and for being rigid interpreters of the Mosaic law; but who frequently violated its spirit by their traditional interpretations and precepts, to which they ascribed nearly an equal authority with the OT Scriptures, Mt. 5:20; 12:2; 23:14
φαρμακεία: employment of drugs for any purpose; sorcery, magic, enchantment, Rev. 18:23; Gal. 5:20*
φάρμακον: a drug; an enchantment; magic potion, charm, Rev. 9:21*
φαῦλος: vile, refuse; evil, wicked; Jn. 3:20; 5:29; Rom. 9:11; 2 Cor. 5:10; Tit. 2:8; Jas. 3:16*
φείδομαι: to spare; to be tender of, Rom. 8:32; to spare, in respect of hard dealing, Acts 20:29; Rom. 11:21; 1 Cor. 7:28; 2 Cor. 1:23; 13:2; 2 Pet. 2:4, 5; absol. to forbear, abstain, 2 Cor. 12:6*
φέρω: to bear, carry, Mk. 2:3; to bring, Mt. 14:11, 18; to conduct, Mt. 17:17; Jn. 21:18; to bear, endure, Rom. 9:22; Heb. 12:20; 13:13; to uphold, maintain, conserve, Heb. 1:3; to bear, bring forth, produce, Mk. 4:8; Jn. 12:24; 15:2; to bring forward, advance, allege, Jn. 18:29; Acts 25:7; 2 Pet. 2:11; to offer, ascribe, Rev. 21:24, 26; absol. used of a gate, to lead, Acts 12:10; pass. to be brought within reach, offered, 1 Pet. 1:13; to be brought in, to enter, Heb. 9:16; to be under a moving influence, to be moved, 2 Pet. 1:21; mid. to rush, sweep, Acts 2:2; to proceed, come forth, have utterance, 2 Pet. 1:17, 18, 21; to proceed, make progress, Heb. 6:1; used of a ship, to drive before the wind, Acts 27:15, 17
φεύγω: absol. to flee, take to flight, Mt. 2:13; 8:33; to shrink, stand fearfully aloof, 1 Cor. 10:14; to make escape, Mt. 23:33; trans. to shun, 1 Cor. 6:18; 1 Tim. 6:11; 2 Tim. 2:22; to escape, Heb. 11:34
φήμη: pr. a celestial or oracular utterance; an utterance; fame, rumor, report, Mt. 9:26; Lk. 4:14*
φημί: to utter; to say, speak, Mt. 8:8; 14:8; 26:34, 61; to say, allege, affirm, Rom. 3:8
φθάνω: come before, precede, 1 Thess. 4:15; absol. to advance, make progress, 2 Cor. 10:14; Phil. 3:16; to come up with, come upon, be close at hand, Mt. 12:28; Lk. 11:20; 1 Thess. 2:16; to attain an object of pursuit, Rom. 9:31*
φθέγγομαι: to emit a sound; to speak, Acts 4:18; 2 Pet. 2:16, 18*
φθείρω: to spoil, ruin, 1 Cor. 3:17; 2 Cor. 7:2; to corrupt, morally deprave, 1 Cor. 15:33; 2 Cor. 11:3
φθόνος: envy, jealously, spite, Mt. 27:18; Mk. 15:10; Rom. 1:29; Gal. 5:21; Phil. 1:15; 1 Tim. 6:4; Tit. 3:3; Jas. 4:5; 1 Pet. 2:1*
φθορά: corruption, decay, ruin, corruptibility, mortality, Rom. 8:21; 1 Cor. 15:42; meton. corruptible, perishable substance, 1 Cor. 15:50; killing, slaughter, 2 Pet. 2:12; spiritual ruin, Gal. 6:8; Col. 2:22; met. moral corruption, depravity, 2 Pet. 1:4; 2:19*
φιλάγαθος: a lover of goodness, or, of the good, a fosterer of virtue, Tit. 1:8*
Φιλαδέλφεια: Philadelphia, a city of Lydia, near Mount Tmolus, Rev. 1:11; 3:7*. See PhotoGuide.
φιλαδελφία: brotherly love; in NT love of the Christian brotherhood, Rom. 12:10; 1 Thess. 4:9; Heb. 13:1; 1 Pet. 1:22; 2 Pet. 1:7*
φιλάδελφος: brother-loving; in NT loving the members of the Christian brotherhood, 1 Pet. 3:8*
φιλανθρωπία: philanthropy, love of mankind, Tit. 3:4; benevolence, humanity, Acts 28:2*
φιλέω: pr. to manifest some act or token of kindness or affection; to kiss, Mt. 26:48; Mk. 14:44; Lk. 22:47; to love, regard with affection, have affection for, Mt. 10:37; Jn. 5:20; to like, be fond of, delight in a thing, Mt. 23:6; Rev. 22:15; to cherish inordinately, set store by, Jn. 12:25
φιλήδονος: pleasure-loving; a lover of pleasure, 2 Tim. 3:4*
Φιλήμων: Philemon, pr. name, Phlm. 1; subscr. and title*
Φιλιππήσιος: a Philippian, a citizen of Φίλιπποι, Philippi, Phil. 4:15; title*
Φίλιπποι: Philippi, a considerable city of Macedonia, east of Amphipolis, Acts 16:12; 20:6; Phil. 1:1; 1 Thess. 2:2; 1 & 2 Cor. subscr.*. See PhotoGuide.
Φίλιππος: Philip, pr. name . (1) Philip, the Apostle, Mt. 10:3. (2) Philip, the Evangelist, Acts 6:5. (3) Philip, son of Herod the Great and Mariamne, Mt. 14:3 . (4) Philip, son of Herod the Great and Cleopatra, Mt. 16:13; Lk. 3:1
φιλόθεος: God-loving, pious; a lover of God, 2 Tim. 3:4*
φιλονεικία: a love of contention; rivalry, contention, Lk. 22:24*
φιλόνεικος: fond of contention; contentious, disputatious, 1 Cor. 11:16*
φιλοξενία: kindness to strangers, hospitality, Rom. 12:13; Heb. 13:2*
φιλόξενος: kind to strangers, hospitable, 1 Tim. 3:2; Tit. 1:8; 1 Pet. 4:9*
φιλοπρωτεύω: to love or desire to be first or chief, affect pre-eminence, 3 Jn. 9*
φίλος: loved, dear; devoted; Acts 19:31; as a subst., a friend, Lk. 7:6; 11:5, 6, 8; a congenial associate, Mt. 11:19; Lk. 7:34; Jas. 4:4; used as a word of courteous appellation, Lk. 14:10
φιλοσοφία: a love of science; systematic philosophy; in NT the philosophy of the Jewish gnosis, Col. 2:8*
φιλόσοφος: pr. a lover of science, a systematic philosopher, Acts 17:18*
φιλότεκνος: loving one’s children, duly parental, Tit. 2:4*
φιλοτιμέομαι: pr. to be ambitious of honor; by impl. to exert one’s self to accomplish a thing, use one’s utmost efforts, endeavor earnestly, Rom. 15:20; 2 Cor. 5:9; 1 Thess. 4:11*
φιλοφρόνως: with kindly feeling or manner, courteously, Acts 28:7*
φιμόω: to muzzle, 1 Tim. 5:18; met. and by impl. to silence, put to silence; pass. to be silent, speechless, Mt. 22:12, 34; 1 Pet. 2:15; Mk. 1:25; trop. pass. to be hushed, as winds and waves, Mk. 4:39; Lk. 4:35*
φλογίζω: to set in a flame, kindle, inflame, Jas. 3:6 (2x)*
φλυαρέω: to talk folly or nonsense; in NT trans., bring unjustified charges against, 3 Jn. 10*
φοβέομαι: has an active form, φοβέω (G5828), but only occurs as a passive (deponent) in our literature, to fear, dread, Mt. 10:26; 14:5; to fear reverentially, to reverence, Mk. 6:20; Lk. 1:50; Acts 10:2; Eph. 5:33; Rev. 11:18; to be afraid to do a thing, Mt. 2:22; Mk. 9:32; to be reluctant, to scruple, Mt. 1:20; to fear, be apprehensive, Acts 27:17; 2 Cor. 11:3; 12:20; to be fearfully anxious, Heb. 4:1; absol. to be fearful, afraid, alarmed, Mt. 14:27; 17:6, 7; Mk. 16:8; to be fearfully impressed, Rom. 11:20
φόβητρον: something which inspires terror; terrible sight or event, Lk. 21:11*
φόβος: fear, terror, affright, Mt. 14:26; Lk. 1:12; astonishment, amazement, Mt. 28:8; Mk. 4:41; trembling concern, 1 Cor. 2:3; 2 Cor. 7:15; meton. a terror, an object or cause of terror, Rom. 13:5; reverential fear, awe, Acts 9:31; Rom. 3:18; respect, deference, Rom. 13:7; 1 Pet. 2:18
Φοινίκη: Phoenice, Phoenicia, a country on the east of the Mediterranean, between Palestine and Syria, anciently celebrated for commerce, Acts 11:19; 15:3; 21:2*
Φοῖνιξ: Phoenix, Phoenice, a city, with a harbor, on the southeast coast of Crete, Acts 27:12*
φονεύς: a homicide, murderer, Mt. 22:7; Acts 3:14; 7:52; 28:4; 1 Pet. 4:15; Rev. 21: 8; 22:15*
φονεύω: to put to death, kill, stay, Mt. 23:31, 35; absol. to commit murder, Mt. 5:21
φόνος: a killing, slaughter, murder, Mt. 15:19; Mk. 7:21; 15:7
φορέω: to bear; to wear, Mt. 11:8; Jn. 19:5; Rom. 13:4; 1 Cor. 15:49; Jas. 2:3
φόρον: a forum, marketplace; Φόρον Ἀππίου, Forum Appii, the name of a small town on the Appian way, according to Antoninus, forty-three Roman miles from Rome, or about forty English miles, Acts 28:15*
φόρος: tribute, tax, strictly such as is laid on dependent and subject people, Lk. 20:22; 23:2; Rom. 13:6, 7*
φορτίζω: to load, burden; met. Mt. 11:28; Lk. 11:46*
φορτίον: a load, burden; of a ship, freight, cargo, Acts 27:10; met. a burden of imposed precepts, etc., Mt. 11:30; 23:4; Lk. 11:46 (2x); of faults, sins, etc., Gal. 6:5*
φραγμός: a fence, hedge; a hedgeside path, Mt. 21:33; Mk. 12:1; Lk. 14:23; met. a parting fence, Eph. 2:14*
φράζω: pr. to propound in distinct terms, to tell; in NT to explain, interpret, expound, Mt. 15:15*
φράσσω: to fence in; by impl. to obstruct, stop, close up, Heb. 11:33; met. to silence, put to silence, Rom. 3:19; 2 Cor. 11:10*
φρέαρ: a well, cistern, Lk. 14:5; Jn. 4:11, 12; a pit, Rev. 9:1, 2*
φρεναπατάω: to deceive the mind; to deceive, impose on, Gal. 6:3*
φρήν: pr. the diaphragm, midriff; the mind, intellect, understanding, 1 Cor. 14:20 (2x)*
φρίσσω: to be ruffled, to bristle; to shiver, shudder from fear, Jas. 2:19*
φρονέω: to think, to mind; to be of opinion, Acts 28:22; Phil. 1:7; to take thought, be considerate, Phil. 4:10; to entertain sentiments or inclinations of a specific kind, to be minded, Rom. 12:16; 15:5; 1 Cor. 13:11; 2 Cor. 13:11; Gal. 5:10; Phil. 2:2; 3:16; 4:2; to be in a certain frame of mind, Rom. 12:3; Phil. 2:5; to imagine, entertain conceit, 1 Cor. 4:6; to heed, pay regard to, Rom. 14:6; to incline to, be set upon, mind, Mt. 16:23; Mk. 8:33; Rom. 8:5; Phil. 3:15, 19; Col. 3:2
φρόνημα: frame of thought, will, aspirations, Rom. 8:6, 7, 27*
φρόνησις: a thoughtful frame, sense, rightmindedness, Lk. 1:17; intelligence, Eph. 1:8*
φρόνιμος: considerate, thoughtful, prudent, discreet, Mt. 7:24; 10:16; 24:45; 25:2, 4, 8, 9; Lk. 12:42; sensible, wise, Rom. 11:25; 12:16; 1 Cor. 4:10; 10:15; 2 Cor. 11:19*
φροντίζω: to be considerate, be careful, Tit. 3:8*
φρουρέω: to keep watch; trans. to guard, watch, with a military guard, 2 Cor. 11:32; to keep in a condition of restraint, Gal. 3:23; to keep in a state of settlement or security, Phil. 4:7; 1 Pet. 1:5*
φρυάσσω: pr. to snort, neigh, stamp, etc.; as a high-spirited horse; hence, to be noisy, fierce, insolent, and tumultuous, to rage, tumultuate, Acts 4:25*
φρύγανον: a dry twig, branch, etc., Acts 28:3*
Φρυγία: Phrygia, an inland province of Asia Minor, Acts 2:10; 16:6; 18:23; 1 Tim. subscr.*
φυλακή: a keeping watch, ward, guard, Lk. 2:8; a place of watch, Rev. 18:2; a watch, guard, body of guards, Acts 12:10; ward, custody, imprisonment, 2 Cor. 6:5; 11:23; Heb. 11:36; prison, 1 Pet. 3:19; a place of custody, prison, Mt. 14:10; 25:39, 44; a watch or division, of the night, which in the time of our Savior was divided into watches of three hours each, called ὀψέ, μεσονύκτιον, ἀλεκτοροψωνία and πρωία, or πρωί, Mt. 14:25; 24:43; Mk. 6:48; Lk. 12:38 (2x)
φυλακίζω: to deliver into custody, put in prison, imprison, Acts 22:19*
φυλακτήριον: the station of a guard or watch; a preservative, safeguard; hence, a phylactery or amulet, worn about the person; from which circumstance the word is used in the NT as a term for the Jewish Tephillin or prayer-case, which took their rise from the injunction in Deut. 6:8; 11:18; Mt. 23:5*
φυλάσσω: to be on watch, keep watch, Lk. 2:8; to have in keeping, Acts 20:20; to have in custody, Acts 28:16; to keep under restraint, confine, Lk. 8:29; Acts 12:4; 23:35; to guard, defend, Lk. 11:21; to keep safe, preserve, Jn. 12:25; 17:12; 2 Thess. 3:3; 2 Pet. 2:5; Jude 24; to keep in abstinence, Acts 21:25; 1 Jn. 5:21; to observe a matter of injunction or duty, Mk. 10:20; Lk. 11:28; Acts 7:53; 16:4; 21:24; mid. to be on one’s guard, beware, Lk. 12:15; 2 Tim. 4:15; 2 Pet. 3:17
φυλή: a tribe, Mt. 19:28; 24:30; Lk. 2:36; a people, nation, Rev. 1:7; 5:9
φύραμα: that which is mingled and reduced to a uniform consistence, by kneading, beating, treading, etc.; a mass of potter’s clay, Rom. 9:21; of dough, 1 Cor. 5:6, 7; Gal. 5:9; met. Rom. 11:16*
φυσικός: natural, agreeable to nature, Rom. 1:26, 27; following the instinct of nature, as animals, 2 Pet. 2:12*
φυσιόω: to inflate puff up; met. to inflate with pride and vanity, 1 Cor. 8:1; pass. to be inflated with pride, to be proud, vain, arrogant, 1 Cor. 4:6, 18, 19; 5:2; 13:4; Col. 2:18*
φύσις: essence, Gal. 4:8; native condition, birth, Rom. 2:27; 11:21, 24; Gal. 2:15; Eph. 2:3; native species, kind, Jas. 3:7; nature, natural frame, 2 Pet. 1:4; nature, native instinct, Rom. 2:14; 1 Cor. 11:14; nature, prescribed course of nature, Rom. 1:26*
φυσίωσις: pr. inflation; met. inflation of mind, pride, 2 Cor. 12:20*
φυτεία: plantation, the act of planting; a plant, met. Mt. 15:13*
φυτεύω: to plant, set, Mt. 21:33; Lk. 13:6; 17:6, 28; 20:9; met. Mt. 15:13; Mk. 12:1; to plant the Gospel, 1 Cor. 3:6, 7, 8; 9:7*
φύω: to generate, produce; pass. to be generated, produced; of plants, to germinate, sprout, Lk. 8:6, 8; intrans. to germinate, spring or grow up, Heb. 12:15*
φωλεός: a den, lair, burrow, Mt. 8:20; Lk. 9:58*
φωνέω: to sound, utter a sound; of the cock, to crow, Mt. 26:34, 74, 75; to call, or cry out, exclaim, Lk. 8:8, 54; 16:24; 23:46; to call to, Mt. 27:47; Mk. 3:31; to call, Jn. 13:13; to call, summon, Mt. 20:32; to invite to a feast, Lk. 14:12
φωνή: a sound, Mt. 24:31; Jn. 3:8; Rev. 4:5; 8:5; a cry, Mt. 2:18; an articulate sound, voice, Mt. 3:3, 17; 17:5; 27:46, 50; voice, speech, discourse, Jn. 10:16, 27; Acts 7:31; 12:22; 13:27; Heb. 3:7, 15; tone of address, Gal. 4:20; language, tongue, dialect, 1 Cor. 14:10
