φῶς: light, Mt. 17:2; 2 Cor. 4:6; daylight, broad day, Mt. 10:27; Lk. 12:3; radiance, blaze of light, Mt. 4:16; Acts 9:3; 12:7; an instrument or means of light, a light, Mt. 6:23; Acts 16:29; a fire, Mk. 14:54; Lk. 22:56; from the Hebrew, the light of God’s presence, 2 Cor. 11:14; 1 Tim. 6:16; met. the light of Divine truth, spiritual illumination, Lk. 16:8; Jn. 3:19; Rom. 13:12; Eph. 5:8; 1 Pet. 2:9; 1 Jn. 1:7; 2:8, 9, 10; a source or dispenser of spiritual light, Mt. 5:14; Jn. 1:4, 5, 7, 8, 9; 8:12; 9:5; pure radiance, perfect brightness, 1 Jn. 1:5
φωστήρ: a cause of light, illuminator; a light, luminary, star, Phil. 2:15; radiance, or, luminary, Rev. 21:11*
φωσφόρος: light-bringing; i.e. ἀστήρ, Lucifer, the morning star, met. 2 Pet. 1:19*
φωτεινός: radiant, lustrous, Mt. 17:5; enlightened, illuminated, Mt. 6:22; Lk. 11:34, 36 (2x)*
φωτίζω: to light, give light to, illuminate, shine upon, Lk. 11:36; Rev. 18:1; 21:23; met. to enlighten spiritually, Jn. 1:9; Eph. 1:18; 3:9; Heb. 6:4; 10:32; to reveal, to bring to light, make known, 1 Cor. 4:5; 2 Tim. 1:10; intrans. shine, Rev. 22:5*
φωτισμός: illumination; a shining forth, bringing to light, enlightenment, 2 Cor. 4:4, 6*
χαίρω: to rejoice, be glad, be joyful, be full of joy, Mt. 2:10; 5:12; 18:13; Mk. 14:11; Rom. 12:12; 2 Cor. 2:3; a term of salutation, Hail! Mt. 26:49; λέγω χαίρειν, to greet, 2 Jn. 10:11; an epistolary forth, Health! Acts 15:23
χαλάω: to slacken; to let down, lower, Mk. 2:4; Lk. 5:4, 5; Acts 9:25; 27:17, 30; 1 Cor. 11:33*
Χαλδαῖος: a Chaldean, a native of Chaldea, a country of central Asia, which seems to have included Mesopotamia, Acts 7:4*
χαλεπός: hard, rugged; furious, ferocious, Mt. 8:28; difficult, trying, 2 Tim. 3:1*
χαλιναγωγέω: pr. to guide with a bridle; met. to bridle, control, sway, Jas. 1:26; 3:2*
χαλκεύς: pr. a coppersmith; hence, genr. a worker in metals, smith, 2 Tim. 4:14*
χαλκηδών: chalcedony, the name of a gem, generally of a whitish, bluish, or gray color, susceptible of a high and beautiful polish, and of which there are several varieties, as the onyx, modern carnelian, etc., Rev. 21:19*
χαλκίον: a vessel, copper, brazen utensil, Mk. 7:4*
χαλκολίβανον: orichalcum, fine bronze, a factitious metal of which there were several varieties, the white being of the highest repute, or, deep-tinted frankincense, Rev. 1:15; 2:18*
χαλκός: copper, also, bronze, Rev. 18:12; a brazen musical instrument, 1 Cor. 13:1; copper money, Mt. 10:9; money in general, Mk. 6:8; 12:41*
χαλκοῦς: contracted form of χάλκεος, made of copper, brass, or bronze, Rev. 9:20*
χαμαί: on the ground, to the earth, Jn. 9:6; 18:6*
Χανάαν: Canaan, the ancient name of Palestine, Acts 7:11; 13:19
χαρά: joy, gladness, rejoicing, Mt. 2:10; 13:20, 44; 28:8; meton, joy, cause of joy, occasion of rejoicing, Lk. 2:10; Phil. 4:1; 1 Thess. 2:19, 20; bliss, Mt. 25:21, 23
χάραγμα: an imprinted mark, Rev. 13:16, 17; 14:9, 11; 16:2; 19:20; 20:4; sculpture, Acts 17:29*
χάραξ: a stake; a military palisade, rampart, formed from the earth thrown out of the ditch, and stuck with sharp stakes or palisades, Lk. 19:43*
χαρίζομαι: to gratify; to bestow in kindness, grant as a free favor, Lk. 7:21; Rom. 8:32; to grant the deliverance of a person in favor to the desire of others, Acts 3:14; 27:24; Phlm. 22; to sacrifice a person to the demand of enemies, Acts 25:11; to remit, forgive, Lk. 7:42; 2 Cor. 2:7, 10
χάριν: the acc. sg form of the noun χάριν which can be used as an improper prep., on account of, Lk. 7:47; Eph. 3:1, 14; 1 Jn. 3:12; for the sake of, in order to, Gal. 3:19; Tit. 1:5, 11; Jude 16; on the score of, 1 Tim. 5:14*
χάρις: pleasing show, charm; beauty, gracefulness; a pleasing circumstance, matter of approval, 1 Pet. 2:19, 20; kindly bearing, graciousness, Lk. 4:22; a beneficial opportunity, benefit, 2 Cor. 1:15; Eph. 4:29; a charitable act, generous gift, 1 Cor. 16:3; 2 Cor. 8:4, 6; an act of favor, Acts 25:3; favor, acceptance, Lk. 1:30, 52; Acts 2:47; 7:10, 46; free favor, free gift, grace, Jn. 1:14, 16, 17; Rom. 4:4, 16; 11:5, 6; Eph. 2:5, 8; 1 Pet. 3:7; free favor specially manifested by God towards man in the Gospel scheme, grace, Acts 15:11; Rom. 3:24; 5:15, 17, 20, 21; 6:1; 2 Cor. 4:15; a gracious provision, gracious scheme, grace, Rom. 6:14, 15; Heb. 2:9; 12:28; 13:9; gracious dealing from God, grace, Acts 14:26; 15:40; Rom. 1:7; 1 Cor. 1:4; 15:10; Gal. 1:15; a commission graciously devolved by God upon a human agent, Rom. 1:5; 12:3; 15:15; 1 Cor. 3:10; 2 Cor. 1:12; Gal. 2:9; Eph. 3:8; grace, graciously bestowed divine endowment or influence, Lk. 2:40; Acts 4:33; 11:23; Rom. 12:6; 2 Cor. 12:9; grace, Acts 11:43; Rom. 5:2; Gal. 5:4; 2 Pet. 3:18; an emotion correspondent to what is pleasing or kindly; sense of obligation, Lk. 17:9; a grateful frame of mind, 1 Cor. 10:30; thanks, Lk. 6:32, 33, 34; Rom. 6:17; 1 Cor. 15:57; χάριν or χάριτας καταθέσθαι, to oblige, gratify, Acts 24:27; 25:9
χάρισμα: a free favor, free gift, Rom. 5:15, 16; 6:23; 2 Cor. 1:11; benefit, Rom. 1:11; a divinely conferred endowment, 1 Cor. 12:4, 9, 28, 30, 31
χαριτόω: to favor, visit with favor, to make an object of favor, to gift, Eph. 1:6; pass. to be visited with free favor, be an object of gracious visitation, Lk. 1:28*
Χαρράν: Charran, a city in the northern part of Mesopotamia, Acts 7:2, 4*. See PhotoGuide.
χεῖλος: a lip, and pl. τὰ χείλη, the lips, Mt. 15:8; Mk. 7:6; Rom. 3:13; Heb. 13:15; 1 Pet. 3:10; trop. χεῖλος τῆς θαλάσσης, the seashore, Heb. 11:12; meton. language, dialect, 1 Cor. 14:21*
χειμάζω: to excite a tempest, toss with a tempest; pass. to be storm-tossed, Acts 27:18*
χειμών: stormy weather, Mt. 16:3; a storm, tempest, Acts 27:20; winter, Mt. 24:20; Mk. 13:18; Jn. 10:22; 2 Tim. 4:21*
χείρ: a hand, Mt. 3:12; 4:6; 8:15 freq.; from the Hebrew, χεὶρ Κυρίου, a special operation of God, Acts 11:21; 13:3; ἐν χειρί, by agency, Acts 7:35; Gal. 3:19
χειραγωγέω: to lead by the hand, Acts 9:8; 22:11*
χειραγωγός: one who leads another by the hand, Acts 13:11*
χειρόγραφον: handwriting; a written form, literal instrument, as distinguished from a spiritual dispensation, Col. 2:14*
χειροποίητος: made by hand, artificial, material, Mk. 14:58; Acts 7:48; 17:24; Eph. 2:11; Heb. 9:11, 24*
χειροτονέω: to stretch out the hand; to constitute by voting; to appoint, constitute, Acts 14:23; 2 Cor. 8:19*
χείρων: worse, Mt. 9:16; more severe, Jn. 5:14; Heb. 10:29
Χερούβ: also spelled Χερουβείν and Χερουβίμ, indecl. cherub, a two-winged figure over the ark of the covenant, Heb. 9:5*
χιλίαρχος: commander of a thousand men; hence, genr. a commander, military chief, Mk. 6:21; Rev. 6:15; 19:18; spc. a legionary tribune, Acts 21:31, 32, 33, 37; the prefect of the temple, Jn. 18:12
χιλιάς: the number one thousand, a thousand, Lk. 14:31; Acts 4:4
χιτών: a tunic, vest, the inner garment which fitted close to the body, having armholes, and sometimes sleeves, and reaching below the knees, worn by both sexes, Mt. 5:40; 10:10; pl. χιτῶνες, clothes, garments in general, Mk. 14:63
χλαμύς: chlamys, a type of cloak; a Roman military commander’s cloak, Mt. 27:28, 31*
χλωρός: pale green; green, verdent, Mk. 6:39; Rev. 8:7; 9:4; pale, sallow, Rev. 6:8*
χοῖνιξ: a choenix, an Attic measure for things dry, being the 48th part of a medimnus, consequently equal to the 8th part of the Roman modius, and nearly equivalent to about one quart, being considered a sufficient daily allowance for the sustenance of one man, Rev. 6:6 (2x)*
χοῖρος: pr. a young swine; a swine, hog, or sow, Mt. 8:30, 31, 32
χολάω: pr. to be melancholy; used later as an equivalent to χολοῦμαι, to be angry, incensed, Jn. 7:23*
χολή: the bile, gall; in NT a bitter ingredient, as wormwood, Mt. 27:34; χολὴ πικρίας, intense bitterness, met. thorough disaffection to divine truth, utter estrangement, Acts 8:23*
Χοραζίν: also spelled Χωραζίν and Χοραζείν, Chorazin, a town of Galilee, probably near Bethsaida and Capernaum, indecl., Mt. 11:21; Lk. 10:13*. See PhotoGuide.
χορηγέω: to lead a chorus; at Athens, to defray the cost of a chorus; hence, to supply funds; to supply, furnish, 2 Cor. 9:10; 1 Pet. 4:11*
χορτάζω: pr. to feed or fill with grass, herbage, etc., to fatten; used of animals of prey, to satiate, gorge, Rev. 19:21; of persons, to satisfy with food, Mt. 14:20; 15:33, 37; met. to satisfy the desire of any one, Mt. 5:6
χόρτασμα: pasture, provender for cattle; food, provision, sustenance, for men, Acts 7:11*
χόρτος: an enclosure; pasture ground; fodder for beasts; in NT herbage, grass, Mt. 6:30; 14:19; a plant of corn, Mt. 13:26; Mk. 4:28
χοῦς: uncontracted form χόος, dust, acc., χοῦν, Mk. 6:11; Rev. 18:19*
χράομαι: to use, make use of, employ, Acts 27:17; 1 Cor. 7:31; to take advantage of, 1 Cor. 7:21; 9:12, 15; to use, to treat, behave towards, Acts 27:3; 2 Cor. 13:10
χρεία: use; need, necessity, requisiteness, Eph. 4:29; Heb. 7:11; personal need, an individual want, Acts 20:34; Rom. 12:13; Phil. 2:25; 4:16, 19; χρείαν ἔχω, to need, require, want, Mt. 6:8; 14:16; Mk. 2:25; Jn. 2:25; ἐστὶ χρεία, there is need, Lk. 10:42; τὰ πρὸς τὴν χρείαν, necessary things, Acts 28:10; a necessary business, affair, Acts 6:3
χρή: impersonal verb, there is need or occasion, it is necessary, it is requisite; it becomes, it is proper, Jas. 3:10*
χρῄζω: to need, want, desire, Mt. 6:32; Lk. 11:8; 12:30; Rom. 16:2; 2 Cor. 3:1*
χρῆμα: anything useful, or needful; pl. wealth, riches, Mk. 10:23; Lk. 18:24; money, Acts 8:18, 20; 24:26; sg. price, Acts 4:37*
χρηματίζω: to have dealings, transact business; to negotiate; to give answer on deliberation; in NT to utter a divine communication, Heb. 12:25; pass. to be divinely instructed, receive a revelation or warning from God, Mt. 2:12, 22; Lk. 2:26; Acts 10:22; Heb. 8:5; 11:7; intrans. to receive an appellation, Acts 11:26; Rom. 7:3*
χρηματισμός: in NT a response from God, a divine communication, oracle, Rom. 11:4*
χρῆσις: use, employment; manner of using, Rom. 1:26, 27*
χρηστεύομαι: to be gentle, benign, kind, 1 Cor. 13:4*
χρηστός: useful, profitable; good, agreeable, Lk. 5:39; easy, as a yoke, Mt. 11:30; gentle, benign, kind, obliging, gracious, Lk. 6:35; Eph. 4:32; Rom. 2:4; 1 Pet. 2:3; good in character, disposition, etc., virtuous, 1 Cor. 15:33*
χρηστότης: pr. goodness, kindness, gentleness, Rom. 2:4; 11:22(3x); 2 Cor. 6:6; Gal. 5:22; Col. 3:12; Tit. 3:4; kindness shown, beneficence, Eph. 2:7; goodness, virtue, Rom. 3:12*
χρῖσμα: pr. anything which is applied by smearing; ointment; in NT an anointing, in the reception of spiritual privileges, 1 Jn. 2:20, 27*
Χριστιανός: a Christian, follower of Christ, Acts 11:26; 26:28; 1 Pet. 4:16*
Χριστός: pr. anointed; ὁ Χριστός, the Christ, the Anointed One, i.e. Μεσσίας, the Messiah, Mt. 1:16, 17; Jn. 1:20, 25, 42; meton. Christ, the word or doctrine of Christ, 2 Cor. 1:19; 21; Eph. 4:20; Christ, a truly Christian frame of doctrine and affection, Rom. 8:10; Gal. 4:19; Christ, the Church of Christ, 1 Cor. 12:12; Christ the distinctive privileges of the Gospel of Christ, Gal. 3:27; Phil. 3:8; Heb. 3:14
χρίω: to anoint; in NT to anoint, by way of instituting to a dignity, function, or privilege, Lk. 4:18; Acts 4:27; 10:38; 2 Cor. 1:21; Heb. 1:9*
χρονίζω: to spend time; to linger, delay, be long, Mt. 24:48; 25:5; Lk. 1:21; 12:45; Heb. 10:37*
χρόνος: time, whether in respect of duration or a definite point of its lapse, Mt. 2:7; 25:19 freq.; an epoch, era, marked duration, Acts 1:7; 1 Thess. 5:1
χρονοτριβέω: to spend time, waste time, linger, delay, Acts 20:16*
χρυσίον: gold, Heb. 9:4; 1 Pet. 1:7; Rev. 3:18; 21:18, 21; spc. gold when coined or manufactured; golden ornaments, 1 Tim. 2:9; 1 Pet. 3:3; Rev. 17:4; 18:16; gold coin, money, Acts 3:6; 20:33; 1 Pet. 1:18*
χρυσοδακτύλιος: having rings of gold on the fingers, Jas. 2:2*
χρυσόλιθος: chrysolite, a name applied by the ancients to all gems of a gold color; spc. the modern topaz, Rev. 21:10*
χρυσόπρασος: a chrysoprase, a species of gem of a golden green color like that of a leek, Rev. 21:20*
χρυσός: gold, Mt. 2:11; 23:16, 17; meton. gold ornaments, 1 Tim. 2:9; gold coin, money, Mt. 10:9
χρυσοῦς: golden, made of or adorned with gold, 2 Tim. 2:20; Heb. 9:4; Rev. 1:12, 13, 20; 9:13, 20, 21:15
χρυσόω: to gild, overlay with gold, adorn or deck with gold, Rev. 17:4; 18:16*
χρώς: the skin; the body surface; Acts 19:12*
χωλός: crippled in the feet, limping, halting, lame, Mt. 11:5; 15:30, 31; met. limping, weak, spiritually, Heb. 12:13; maimed, deprived of a foot, for ἀναπηρός, Mk. 9:45
χώρα: space, room; a country, region, tract, province, Mk. 5:10; Lk. 2:8; a district, territory, suburbs, Mt. 8:28; meton. the inhabitants of a country, region, etc., Mk. 1:5; Acts 12:20; the country, as opposed to the city or town, Lk. 21:21; a field, farm, Lk. 12:16; Jn. 4:35
χωρέω: to make room, either by motion or capacity; to move, pass, Mt. 15:17; to proceed, go on, 2 Pet. 3:9; to progress, make way, Jn. 8:37; trans. to hold as contents, contain, afford room for, Mk. 2:2; Jn. 2:6; 21:25; met. to give mental admittance to, to yield accordance, Mt. 19:11, 12; to admit to approbation and esteem, to regard cordially, 2 Cor. 7:2*
χωρίζω: to divide, separate, Mt. 19:6; Mk. 10:9; Rom. 8:35, 39; to dissociate one’s self, to part, 1 Cor. 7:10, 11, 15; to withdraw, depart, Acts 1:4; 18:1, 2; Phlm. 15; to be aloof, Heb. 7:26*
χωρίον: a place, spot; Mt. 26:36; Mk. 14:32; a field, farm, estate, domain, Jn. 4:5; Acts 1:18, 19(2x); 4:34; 5:3, 8; 28:7*
χωρίς: can function as an improper prep., apart, Jn. 20:7; apart from, parted from, Jn. 15:5; Jas. 2:18, 20, 26; alien from, Eph. 2:12; apart from, on a distinct footing from, 1 Cor. 11:11; apart from, distinct from, without the intervention of, Rom. 3:21, 28; 4:6; apart from the company of, independently of, 1 Cor. 4:8; Heb. 11:40 without the presence of, Heb. 9:28; without the agency of, Jn. 1:3; Rom. 10:14; without the employment of, Mt. 13:34; Mk. 4:34; Heb. 7:20, 21; 9:7, 18, 22; without, Lk. 6:49; Phil. 2:14; 1 Tim. 2:8; 5:21; Phlm. 14; Heb. 10:28; 11:6; 12:8, 14; clear from, Heb. 7:7; irrespectively of, Rom. 7:8, 9; without reckoning, besides, Mt. 14:21; 15:38; 2 Cor. 11:28; with the exception of, Heb. 4:15
χῶρος: Corus, or Caurus, the northwest wind; meton, the northwest quarter of the heavens, Acts 27:12*
ψάλλω: to move by a touch, to twitch; to touch, strike the strings or chords of an instrument; absol. to play on a stringed instrument; to sing to music; in NT to sing praises, Rom. 15:9; 1 Cor. 14:15; Eph. 5:19; Jas. 5:13*
ψαλμός: impulse, touch of the chords of a stringed instrument; in NT a sacred song, psalm, Lk. 20:42; 24:44; Acts 1:20; 13:33; 1 Cor. 14:26; Eph. 5:19; Col. 3:16*
ψευδάδελφος: a false brother, a pretend Christian, 2 Cor. 11:26; Gal. 2:4*
ψευδαπόστολος: a false apostle, pretend minister of Christ, 2 Cor. 11:13*
ψευδής: false, lying, Acts 6:13; Rev. 2:2; in NT pl. maintainers of religious falsehood, corrupters of the truth of God, Rev. 21:8*
ψευδοδιδάσκαλος: a false teacher, one who teaches false doctrines, 2 Pet. 2:1*
ψευδομαρτυρέω: to bear false witness, give false testimony, Mt. 19:18; Mk. 10:19; 14:56, 57; Lk. 18:20*
ψευδοπροφήτης: a false prophet, one who falsely claims to speak by divine inspiration, whether as a foreteller of future events, or as a teacher of doctrines, Mt. 7:15; 24:24; Mk. 13:22; Acts 13:6; 1 Jn. 4:1; Rev. 16:13
ψεῦδος: falsehood, Jn. 8:44; Eph. 4:25; 2 Thess. 2:9, 11; 1 Jn. 2:21, 27; in NT religious falsehood, perversion of religious truth, false religion, Rom. 1:25; the practices of false religion, Rev. 14:15; 21:27; 22:15*
ψευδόχριστος: a false Christ, pretend Messiah, Mt. 24:24; Mk. 13:22*
ψεῦσμα: a falsehood, lie; in NT untruthfulness, Rom. 3:7*
ψεύστης: one who utters a falsehood, a liar, Jn. 8:44, 55; Rom. 3:4; 1 Tim. 1:10; Tit. 1:12; 1 Jn. 1:10; 2:4, 22; 4:20; 5:10*
ψηλαφάω: to feel, handle, Lk. 24:39; to feel or grope for or after, as persons in the dark, Acts 17:27; Heb. 12:18; 1 Jn. 1:1*
ψηφίζω: to reckon by means of pebbles, compute by counters; hence genr. to compute, reckon, calculate, Lk. 14:28; Rev. 13:18*
ψῆφος: a small stone, pebble; a pebble variously employed, especially in a ballot; hence, a vote, suffrage, Acts 26:10; a pebble or stone; probably given as a token, Rev. 2:17 (2x)*
ψιθυρισμός: a whispering; a calumnious whispering, gossip, 2 Cor. 12:20*
ψιθυριστής: a whisperer; a whisperer, gossip, Rom. 1:29*
ψιχίον: a morsel, crumb, bit, Mt. 15:27; Mk. 7:28*
ψυχή: breath; the principle of animal life; the life, Mt. 2:20; 6:25; Mk. 3:4; Lk. 21:19; Jn. 10:11; an inanimate being, 1 Cor. 15:45; a human individual, soul, Acts 2:41; 3:23; 7:14; 27:37; Rom. 13:1; 1 Pet. 3:20; the immaterial soul, Mt. 10:28; 1 Pet. 1:9; 2:11, 25; 4:19; the soul as the seat of religious and moral sentiment, Mt. 11:29; Acts 14:2, 22; 15:24; Eph. 6:6; the soul, as a seat of feeling, Mt. 12:18; 26:38; the soul, the inner self, Lk. 12:19
ψυχικός: pertaining to the life or soul; in NT animal, as distinguished from spiritual subsistence, 1 Cor. 15:44, 46; occupied with mere animal things, animal, sensual, 1 Cor. 2:14; Jas. 3:15; Jude 19*
ψύχω: to breathe; to cool; pass. to be cooled; met. of affection, Mt. 24:12*
ψωμίζω: pr. to feed by morsels; hence, genr. to feed, supply with food, Rom. 12:20; to bestow in supplying food, 1 Cor. 13:3*
ψώχω: to rub in pieces, as the ears of grain, Lk. 6:1*
ὧδε: here, in this place, Mt. 12:6, 41; ὡδε ἠ ὡδε, here or there, Mt. 24:23; τὰ ὡδε, the state of things here, Col. 4:9; met. herein, in this thing, Rev. 13:10, 18; to this place, Mt. 8:29; 14:18
ὧδή: an ode, song, hymn, Eph. 5:19; Col. 3:16; Rev. 5:9; 14:3; 15:3*
ὠδίν: the spasms or pains, of a woman in travail, a birth pang, 1 Thess. 5:3; pl. met. birth throes, preliminary troubles to the development of a catastrophe, Mt. 24:8; Mk. 13:8; from the Hebrew, a stringent band, a snare, noose, Acts 2:24*
ὠδίνω: to be in travail, Gal. 4:27; Rev. 12:2; met. to travail with, suffer birth pangs, to make effort to bring to spiritual birth, Gal. 4:19*
ὥρα: a limited portion of time, marked out by part of a settled routine or train of circumstances; a season of the year; time of day, Mt. 14:15; Mk. 6:35; 11:11; an hour, Mt. 20:3; Jn. 11:9; in NT an eventful season, 1 Jn. 2:18 (2x); Rev. 3:10; 14:7; due time, Jn. 16:21; Rom. 13:11; a destined period, hour, Mt. 26:45; Mk. 14:35; Jn. 2:4; 7:30; a short period, Mt. 26:40; Jn. 5:35; 2 Cor. 7:8; Gal. 2:5; 1 Thess. 2:17; Phlm. 15; a point of time, time, Mt. 8:13; 24:42; Lk. 2:38
ὡρᾶιος: timely, seasonable; in prime, blooming; in NT beautiful, Mt. 23:27; Acts 3:2, 10; Rom. 10:15*
ὠρύομαι: to howl; to roar, as a lion, 1 Pet. 5:8*
ὡς: conjunction formed from the relative pronoun ὅς, used as a comparative part. and conj., as, correlatively, Mk. 4:26; Jn. 7:46; Rom. 5:15; as, like as, Mt. 10:16; Eph. 5:8; according as, Gal. 6:10; as, as it were, Rev. 8:8; as, Lk. 16:1; Acts 3:12; before numerals, about, Mk. 5:13; conj. that, Acts 10:28; how, Rom. 11:2; when, Mt. 28:9; Phil. 2:23; as an exclamatory particle, how, Rom. 10:15; equivalent to ὥστε, accordingly, Heb. 3:11; also, on condition that, provided that, Acts 20:24; ὡς εἰπεῖν, so to speak, Heb. 7:9
ὡσαννά: Hosanna! save now, help now, Mt. 21:9, 15; Mk. 11:9, 10; Jn. 12:13*
ὡσαύτως: just so, in just the same way or manner, likewise, Mt. 20:5; 21:30
ὡσεί: as if; as it were, as, like, Mt. 3:16; 9:36; with terms of number or quantity, about, Mt. 14:21; Lk. 1:56; 22:41, 59
ὡσπερεί: just as if; as it were, 1 Cor. 15:8*
ὥστε: so that, so as that, so as to, Mt. 8:24; Mk. 2:12; Acts 14:1; Gal. 2:13; as an illative particle, therefore, consequently, Mt. 12:12; 23:31
ὠτίον: in NT simply equivalent to οὖς, an ear, Mt. 26:51; Lk. 22:51; Jn. 18:26*
ὠφέλεια: help; profit, gain, advantage, benefit, Rom. 3:1; Jude 16*
ὠφελέω: to help, profit, benefit, accomplish, Mt. 27:24; Mk. 7:11; Rom. 2:25; be of value, Jn. 6:63
ὠφέλιμος: profitable, useful, beneficial; serviceable, 1 Tim. 4:8 (2x); 2 Tim. 3:16; Tit. 3:8*
